HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: THE FOREIGN POLICY TEAMS;
Gore's National Security Advisers Assemble as Part of a Government-in-Waiting

BYLINE: By JOHN M. BRODER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 16

 BODY:
Vice President Al Gore has assembled a large team of foreign policy advisers whose members could form the national security nucleus of a Gore administration.
The current role of the advisory group is somewhat nebulous, however, since Mr. Gore has never relied on outsiders for advice on foreign policy, and the new panel has not yet contributed much of substance to his campaign. 
 The vice president has great faith in his own national security experience and instincts. He has a close, 20-year relationship with his national security alter ego, Leon Fuerth, through whom all foreign policy information flows. The vice president has participated in every major national security debate over the past decade and has access to intelligence and foreign policy expertise throughout the government.
But Mr. Gore believes he needs to hear fresh voices on foreign policy, several Gore aides say, and he has begun to assemble a group of advisers who can address foreign policy questions during the campaign and assist in the transition should Mr. Gore win in November.
The vice president's advisory group now includes 25 people, many of whom are veterans of the early years of the Clinton administration, and the list of experts is expected to swell to include as many as 100 names over the next several weeks.
The advisory board will someday provide material for speeches and position papers, but for now the group appears to exist chiefly as the foreign policy arm of a government-in-waiting.
The panel includes a number of respected academics, former ambassadors and former subcabinet officers, but its members are less well known than Gov. George W. Bush's team of foreign policy advisers, who call themselves the Vulcans after the Greek god of fire and the forge.
The Bush group includes Paul D. Wolfowitz, Richard L. Armitage, Richard Perle, Robert B. Zoellick and Stephen J. Hadley, all of whom served in senior national security posts in the Reagan and Bush administrations. Mr. Bush also consults with Richard B. Cheney, the former secretary of defense, and George P. Shultz, the former secretary of state. Condoleezza Rice, a former top Russia specialist at the National Security Council, coordinates the Bush foreign policy advisory team.
"Bush needs them," said Marc C. Ginsberg, a longtime friend of President Clinton who served as envoy to Morocco from 1994 to 1998 and who is now one of two coordinators of the Gore foreign policy group. "He needs the best possible A-list of foreign policy advisers to compensate for his lack of experience and knowledge. Al Gore doesn't suffer from the same deficiencies."
Mr. Gore's group includes former Senator James Sasser, who was ambassador to China from 1996 to 1999; Laura D'Andrea Tyson, the former head of the National Economic Council; Joan E. Spero, former under secretary of state for economic affairs, and Ashton B. Carter and Graham T. Allison, Harvard professors who served at the Pentagon in President Clinton's first term. Mel Levine, a former Democratic congressman from Los Angeles, Robert E. Hunter, a former ambassador to NATO, and Richard N. Gardner, whose government experience dates to the Kennedy administration, are also on the list.
Their role remains indistinct and there is little evidence that Mr. Gore will turn to them for foreign policy guidance any time soon. Unlike the Bush group, they are not holding regular briefings for the vice president, who is as broadly knowledgeable about foreign policy as anyone in the Democratic Party. They have not been canvassed for policy advice or speech drafts. Nor are they authorized to speak to the press on behalf of the Gore campaign. The list of their names was produced only after repeated requests from a reporter.
Nonetheless, competition for spots on the list is fierce because the group is seen as the farm team for senior jobs in a Gore administration, should the vice president win in November. Serving on the ad hoc Gore committee is also a prestigious resume addition for the part-time advisers, many of whom also advise private clients at the same time they give foreign policy counsel to the Gore campaign.
Part of the work of Mr. Ginsberg and his co-director, Bruce W. Jentleson, director of the Terry Sanford Institute of Public Policy at Duke University, is to screen potential members of the advisory group for conflicts of interest. They said that nobody who had pending business before the government or who was a registered lobbyist for a foreign country would be invited to join the group.
Since returning from Morocco in 1998, Mr. Ginsberg, a lawyer, has gone into business raising capital for small firms and advising companies on doing business in North Africa and the Middle East. He said he did not represent any foreign governments, nor does his name show up on the Justice Department's list of registered foreign agents.
Mr. Ginsberg said he had tried to help Gerber Products build a baby formula factory in Gaza with Israeli and Palestinian participation, but the project never got off the ground. This week Mr. Ginsberg was in Morocco to speak at a conference on electronic commerce sponsored by Havas MediMedia, the health care information division of a French advertising company.
The policy of keeping lobbyists off the advisory panel may be hard to enforce, since some of those on the list, including Mr. Levine, work at large law firms that do some lobbying.
Mr. Jentleson, who served in the State Department's office of policy planning early in the Clinton administration, said Mr. Gore was reaching beyond the Beltway for fresh ideas. He said Mr. Gore depended on Mr. Fuerth and Samuel R. Berger, the White House national security adviser, for day-to-day foreign policy guidance. Mr. Gore also consults regularly with Richard C. Holbrooke, the United Nations ambassador, whom many consider the leading candidate for secretary of state in a Gore administration.
Mr. Gore wants to hear a range of voices as he begins to formulate an approach to global affairs that may at times differ from that of Mr. Clinton, Mr. Jentleson said. But the members of the group are well within the mainstream of the Democratic Party, generally supporting global engagement, protection of the environment and free trade, he added.
The panel is being assembled with an eye toward quickly staffing a Gore administration, Mr. Jentleson said. "By asking them to join this group we're not making any promises, he said. "But if Gore wins the election, it's a lot better to start on Wednesday with a group of people you know than to start looking at a pile of resumes."
Foreign policy veterans and even some advisers to Mr. Gore suggest that the group is largely window-dressing at this point, assembled in part to make it look as though Mr. Gore is not dependent wholly on his own foreign policy ideas and those of Mr. Fuerth. Membership on the panel also gives foreign policy thinkers in the Democratic Party a stake in a victory by the vice president in November.
"Every campaign I've ever heard of does this," said a foreign policy expert who has advised several campaigns and who insisted that his name not be printed. "But I can say that I've never heard of a single instance of a paper from that system making its way to the candidate."
He said that Mr. Fuerth tightly controlled what reached Mr. Gore and that the two of them made all important decisions with little outside advice. Mr. Gore did not draw on the advisory group in preparing his most recent address on foreign policy, delivered on May 1 in Boston, aides said. The vice president wrote much of the speech himself, with assistance from Mr. Fuerth and other members of the White House national security staff, they said. In the speech, Mr. Gore called for an activist foreign policy of "forward engagement" and criticized Mr. Bush for hewing to what he called an obsolete cold-war mentality.
The advisory group structure serves one useful purpose: bypassing the limitations placed on political activity by government employees. Most full-time government workers cannot engage in political activity, although certain senior advisers like Mr. Fuerth are exempt from the rule.
"I cannot use members of the vice president's national security staff or others on the federal payroll to provide political advice for the campaign," Mr. Fuerth said. "I need an external skeleton of people to provide advice for me so I can provide advice for the vice president."
Mr. Fuerth said the outside advisers would become more active as the campaign progressed, serving as surrogate speakers, drafting speeches and responding to press questions on national security matters. But they will never serve as the foreign policy "brain" of the Gore operation. That job is already taken, Mr. Fuerth said.
"Everyone needs bright minds," Mr. Fuerth said, "but I could drop dead tomorrow and the vice president could keep going for quite some time based simply on what he personally knows and understands."

HEADLINE: FED LIFTS KEY RATE BY 1/2 POINT, TO 6.5%; MORE RISES HINTED

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 16

 BODY:
The Federal Reserve adopted a more aggressive stance today in its fight against inflation, voting to push short-term interest rates up by half a percentage point to try to slow the headlong pace of economic growth.
Concerned that the economy continues to exceed what the Fed considers to be its speed limit, the central bank put aside its recent preference for small adjustments to monetary policy in favor of an attention-grabbing increase of half a percentage point. The move was intended to make clear that it will do what it takes to bring growth under control. 
 Dashing the hopes of investors that this move -- which follows a series of five quarter-point rate increases over the last 11 months -- might be the last for a while, the Fed also signaled that there may well be more to come.
"Today's move is clearly an escalation of the Fed's anti-inflation campaign," said David Orr, chief economist at First Union.
The Fed's action immediately led some banks to raise their prime lending rates for loans to small business customers to 9.5 percent from 9 percent. It is also likely to lead to higher rates on auto and home equity loans and credit cards. The effect on mortgages is more difficult to predict. Page C1.
It was the first time the central bank raised rates by at least half a percentage point in more than five years, and it lifted the Fed's benchmark federal funds target rate on overnight loans among banks to 6.5 percent, its highest level since January 1991.
The central bank also raised its seldom-used discount rate on loans to banks from the Federal Reserve system by half a point, to 6 percent.
By raising the official rates it controls, the Fed tries to put upward pressure on the rates paid by companies and by consumers, and in that way to put a damper on economic activity.
For all the Fed's concern about inflation over the last year, there is little evidence of any sustained surge in prices or wages, and the move drew criticism from some business groups and political leaders as unnecessary.
Just hours before the Fed's vote today, the Labor Department reported that consumer prices in April were stable. The consumer price index was unchanged for the month after sharp increases in February and March. And the "core" index -- excluding volatile food and energy prices -- rose just 0.2 percent.
Senator Byron L. Dorgan, a Democrat from North Dakota, said the Fed's interest rate increases amounted to an unjustified tax increase on American families. Jerry Jasinowski, president of the National Association of Manufacturers, said gains in worker productivity, or output per hour, were more than offsetting inflation pressures, and he called the Fed's action "unnecessary shock treatment."
But the Fed, which has always said it is easier to prevent inflation than to eradicate it after it has infected the economy, justified its action as a necessary vaccination.
In a statement, the Fed's policy- setting Open Market Committee stressed that demand for goods and services from the vibrant business expansion outstripped the available supply, an equation that every basic economic textbook says will eventually lead to rising prices. Not even the gains from productivity can be counted on to keep inflation in check if the economy continues to run red hot, the statement said.
"The committee is concerned that this disparity in the growth of demand and potential supply will continue," the statement said, "which could foster inflationary imbalances that would undermine the economy's outstanding performance."
In a signal to investors not to assume that this cycle of rate increases is over, the committee added that "the risks are weighted mainly toward conditions that may generate heightened inflation pressures in the foreseeable future."
The Fed's decision to raise rates by half a point had been widely anticipated by investors. Stock prices, which had been up before the Fed's announcement at 2:15 p.m., fell back after right afterward but then rebounded. The Dow Jones industrial average closed at 10,934.57, up 126.79. The Nasdaq composite index rose 109.92 to close at 3,717.57. Bond prices also rose, driving the yield on the 10-year Treasury note down to 6.42 percent from 6.45 percent.
There is considerable debate among economists about how fast the economy can grow without igniting inflation. But even though Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, has been willing to give the economy far more running room than he probably would have just a few years ago, he has consistently said that the "new economy" -- in which technology and Internet stocks have made their impact felt -- is still subject to the basic laws of supply and demand.
Mr. Greenspan has focused in particular on the shrinking pool of workers available to employers, noting that eventually wage increases will accelerate to inflationary levels. The unemployment rate -- 3.9 percent in April -- is the lowest in more than 30 years.
Mr. Greenspan has also said that the economy has been able to meet the robust demand from consumers in part by importing more goods from abroad, a trend that the United States cannot afford to sustain forever. To the degree that additional demand cannot be met from abroad, it could lead to a surge in prices.
After months in which he singled out the stock market as the source of much of the excess demand in the economy, Mr. Greenspan has publicly shifted his emphasis in recent months to slowing the economy and halting the decline in unemployment.
But despite the five previous rate increases starting last June, the economy grew 7.3 percent in the fourth quarter of last year and 5.4 percent in the first quarter of this year. That was well above the roughly 4 percent that many economists now think is sustainable without generating higher inflation.
There are some signs that the earlier rate increases are having an effect. Consumer spending, the primary engine of demand in this business cycle, cooled off somewhat in April, with retail sales falling 0.2 percent. But other indicators, like the pace of housing starts and auto sales, suggest that the economy remains in overdrive.
Whether the Fed raises rates again at its next meeting in late June -- and by how much -- largely depends on what the economic data reveals over the next five weeks. Many economists now assume that the Fed will raise rates by at least another quarter point in June.
"They certainly leave the way open to further tightening, and almost certainly further tightening will occur," said Bruce Steinberg, chief economist at Merrill Lynch. "The question is how much."
The Fed's goal is not to stop the economy in its tracks, but to achieve a "soft landing," in which inflation pressures recede but the expansion continues at a more moderate pace, avoiding a recession.
The last time the Fed tried to engineer a soft landing, in 1994 and early 1995, it succeeded, but only after doubling its target rate to 6 percent from 3 percent in seven steps. In that cycle it raised rates by half a point three times and by three-quarters of a point once.
Based on his record in keeping the expansion going, Mr. Greenspan has enjoyed widespread bipartisan support even as he has raised interest rates. Both Vice President Al Gore and Gov. George W. Bush of Texas have expressed confidence in him, and so far the Fed has not been an issue in the presidential campaign.
The Fed has rarely been shy about tinkering with interest rates during presidential campaigns, but it has always avoided doing so in the month or so before the election. Some analysts suggested that today's action was intended to get as much monetary tightening as possible out of the way before the campaign gets into full gear.
"If the Fed's job is done by June 28, and we believe that it will be, there won't be a need to act closer to the election," said Richard Yamarone, director of economic research at Argus Research. "In that case, the Fed will have stayed ahead of the curve and taken the Federal Reserve and the tightening cycle out of the political process."

HEADLINE: Snapping Up Chinese Goods Despite Qualms on Trade Bill

BYLINE: By JOSEPH KAHN 

DATELINE: BROOKLYN PARK, Minn., May 14

 BODY:
The American flag flies over Wal-Mart in this Minneapolis suburb. The parking lot is packed with Ford S.U.V.'s and Chevy pickups. Even the stucco facade is a patriotic melange of red, white and blue.
Yet the appeal of America's most successful retail chain, with its "We Sell for Less" slogan emblazoned over the front door, stems in part from the enormous low-cost production capacity of a faraway nation that many people in this country view as a moral outcast and potential military rival: China. 
 From $16.95 Looney Tunes Tweeties to $5.94 Rawlings N.C.A.A. Final Four basketballs, Wal-Marts are two-square-acre valentines to the idea that America should trade with China -- or, as President Clinton put it when visiting a nearby farm last week, "reaching out a hand, not shaking a clenched fist."
But even as they fill their carts, shoppers have their doubts.
Dawn Hentges, a housewife, was browsing specials in the shoe section, where "China" is inscribed on seemingly every tongue or sole.
Ms. Hentges ruminated about a friend who had recently adopted a Chinese baby girl. The girl, she said, had to be treated for eczema and lice she acquired in a government-run orphanage. "They just throw their little girls out like the trash," she said. "That place really scares me."
She said she would prefer not to buy Chinese goods, but suggested that it was not easy to keep the faith when "every other thing" she looked at was made there.
Mike Hanaho helped his daughter lace up new made-in-China Nike sneakers as he discussed China's growing military might. A Navy veteran who was stationed in the Pacific in the late 1980's, Mr. Hanaho said China's Asian neighbors worried about its regional ambitions. "Taiwan sure sees them as the evil empire," he said.
Congress is to vote next week on whether to upgrade economic ties with Beijing, a step that would allow American companies to take full advantage of concessions China made to enter the World Trade Organization. The cliffhanger in the House, where supporters and opponents are locked in a battle to control the future of United States-China relations, echoes in the Midwest as dissonance. People play with Chinese-made toys, fish with Chinese-made rods and ride Chinese-made bicycles, all decent products at low prices, the staples of Wal-Mart. But they also worry about China's human rights abuses and its military buildup.
Most of the shoppers said they were aware that many consumer products come from China. Some say America's appetite for goods from China encourages capitalism and promotes change there.
Others say they worry that the tens of billions of dollars Americans spend on Chinese goods each year only entrenches the Beijing leadership, though they rarely use their wallets to support their convictions.
Shopping for spray paint, Fred Holloway said he did not see what the fuss was about. Mr. Holloway, a software engineer for Medtronic, a Minneapolis-based maker of medical products, argues that trade and politics don't mix. "We sell them some of our pacemakers," he said, referring to a Medtronic product. "So why shouldn't I buy their stuff? I mean, that's normal."
Mr. Holloway compared the China trade debate to the ongoing feud about whether Elian Gonzalez should go back to Cuba to live with his father. "That should be about family, and China should be about trade," he said. "I don't agree with those people who want to mix it up with whether they're Communists."
Still, when asked how he would vote on the issue before lawmakers -- whether to continue to review China's trade status each year or, as President Clinton has asked, grant so-called permanent normal trade relations -- he stepped back, scratched his beard and hedged. "We probably still need the power to review it every so often," he said. "Say if they attack Taiwan, then it can't just be business as usual."
If there is a big group of Americans who refuse to buy Chinese-made goods for political reasons, they probably are not Wal-Mart shoppers. Though the store drapes itself in Americana and uses bright shelf tags to advertise "Made in the U.S.A." products, the chain is an importing goliath.
From car stereos to steel-toed work boots, Wal-Mart is the single largest United States importer. About half of its imports come from China, according to a study of Customs Department documents conducted by the Citizens Trade Campaign, which is critical of the company. Wal-Mart declined to comment on what percentage of its merchandise was made in China.
Overall, the United States bought $82 billion worth of China-made goods last year, $69 billion more than the value of what it sold to China. The trade deficit, America's second largest, was slightly smaller than the one with Japan.
Japan in the 1980's inspired fears that its high-quality, high-tech products would put Americans out of business. The anti-China lobby complains more about an affront to American values. Some crusaders have targeted Wal-Mart itself, accusing the company of exploiting Chinese workers in sweatshops.
For unions and some lawmakers, Chinese labor and human rights practices are a central issue in the trade debate.
Wal-Mart says it neither operates nor does business with sweatshops. The company says it frequently inspects conditions at all of its own factories and those of many of its suppliers to ensure that they maintain Western standards.
Americans implicitly vote on the issue every day.
Joyce Smith, a worker in a Minneapolis factory that makes Harley Davidson motorcycle parts, said she wondered how Chinese laborers bear the strain of working 14-hour days for 3 cents an hour, if a recent television expose she saw is true.
"It's just really sad about those women," she said of the Chinese workers. She dangled a pair of girls' slippers and searched for the price tag. "These cost $7.95, but you can bet that those workers don't see more than a penny or two."
Asked if that meant she would shun such products, she raised her eyebrows and pushed her cart ahead.
China is an enigma. It is Communist and occasionally bellicose, but less powerful or menacing than the former Soviet Union. Its economy has grown quickly and it has become one of the world's largest exporters, but its industries have yet to challenge the United States directly the way Japan and Germany did in the 80's.
All that leaves some people preferring the middle course -- neither confrontation nor acquiescence.
"We should be in there picking their brains," said Don Gavic, a World War II veteran with a wizened face, well tanned from his days teaching golf in Minneapolis. He is not one to dismiss what he calls the "Asia threat." But he argues that China's opponents have it all wrong. He said he believes in engagement.
"If you want to know what they are thinking, you can't cut them off," he said, pausing to put a $10.88 Ozark Trail packable armchair, made in China, into his cart.
Like many others in Minnesota, Mr. Gavic has more than a passing interest in the question. His son-in-law has a 600-acre family soybean farm near here. Farmers have been among the strongest supporters of granting China permanent normal trade relations, because they see doing so as giving them more access to that country's huge but tightly regulated grain market.
"We sold wheat to the Soviets, didn't we?" Mr. Gavic said. "My son-in-law has bank loans riding on this."
Though Mr. Clinton said on Friday during his visit to this area that the China vote in Congress was vital to protecting America's economic and national security interests, "permanent normal trade relations" do not rattle people the way Sputnik and "mutually assured destruction" once did, at least not Minnesota residents on the first day of walleye fishing season.
Deborah Hackett, a white-haired sock shopper of 60, brushed off a question about United States relations with China with a one-sentence answer. The more money Americans spend on Chinese imports, the better to promote capitalism, she said.
Asked how she would choose among Wal-Mart's socks -- some made in the United States, others in Costa Rica and many others, of course, in China -- she said, "I want the ones that match my pants."

SECTION: Section C; Page 1; Column 1; Business/Financial Desk

LENGTH: 628 words

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Lycos Agrees to Be Bought By Spanish Telephone Giant
Lycos, the big Internet portal, agreed to be bought by Terra Networks, the Internet unit of the Spanish telephone giant Telefonica, for $12.5 billion in stock.
The companies said the combination, which also includes a partnership with the German media conglomerate Bertelsmann, would create the first truly global Internet company with operations in 37 countries. Page C4. 

Robert J. Davis, the self-described driven chief executive of Lycos, lives by a couple of mottos. "You let up, you lose," is one. "Speed is life" is another. The Boss. C8.
 
Profit Up 6.5% at Hewlett-Packard
Hewlett-Packard posted a 6.5 percent increase in operating profit, exceeding Wall Street estimates. The company cited strong sales of personal computers and Unix servers used on corporate networks and the Internet. Revenue from continuing operations grew 15 percent. Before the company announced its results, its shares closed at $140, up $6. C10.
 
Cybersleuths Pursue Net Criminals
A growing number of Internet habitues have turned into cybersleuths, and their work has become vital to the pursuit of online criminals. In the spirit of members of a neighborhood watch program, they point law enforcement officials to leads. And some have escalated their role from tipster to sleuth, accumulating evidence to identify actual suspects including malicious hackers, virus writers and online child pornographers. A1.
 
Stocks Hold Gains After Fed Action
Stocks held onto early gains after the Federal Reserve announced its sixth interest-rate increase since last June. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 126.79 points, or 1.2 percent, to 10,934.57. Broader stock indicators also closed higher. The Nasdaq composite index climbed 109.92 points, or 3.1 percent, to 3,717.57, and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 13.68 points, to 1,466.04. C10.
 
Investors Assail BMW's Rover Deal
A week after BMW agreed to pay a British group more than $750 million to take over the German automaker's money-losing Rover subsidiary, angry investors accused BMW's top management of amateurism, arrogance, bad judgment and deceptive statements. And in a blunt rebuttal to aspiring buyers, the controlling Quandt family announced that it had "not the slightest interest in selling" and is "100 percent committed to BMW." C3.
 
Mining Company Chief to Step Down
Anglo American, the world's largest mining company, announced that Julian Ogilvie Thompson, the last of a generation of managers who dominated the South African-led company during and beyond the apartheid era, would step down as chief executive. C3.
 
U.P.I. Reporter Resigns Abruptly
Helen Thomas, a White House reporter since John F. Kennedy was president, abruptly resigned from United Press International, one day after the news service was acquired by News World Communications, which was founded by the Rev. Sun Myung Moon, leader of the Unification Church. Ms. Thomas, who is 79, broke into journalism in 1943 as a radio writer for the news service, took over the White House beat in 1961 and became the unofficial dean of White House reporters. A18.
 
Consumer Prices Unchanged in April
Consumer prices were unchanged in April and the construction of new homes rose, government figures showed, signaling that the economy was expanding with little to no inflation. The flat Consumer Price Index came after a 0.7 percent jump in March and was the first report since last June's to show no change. C25.
 
House Backs Bill to Ban Web Fees
The House unanimously endorsed a bill that would prohibit federal fees on Internet access in a move to put to rest longstanding rumors of pending Internet e-mail taxes. C25.

HEADLINE: Dominicans Stay Tuned To Voting At Home

BYLINE: By JUAN FORERO 

 BODY:
In cafes, on street corners and in front of newsstands, many people in Washington Heights have been heatedly talking for weeks about the tactics of the presidential campaign and the merits of the candidates. But in their rapid-fire Spanish, they aren't speaking of Al Gore or George W. Bush. Instead, they intone the names Balaguer, Mejia and Medina, the three men seeking the presidency of the Dominican Republic.
And yesterday in the Heights, heart of the nation's largest enclave of immigrants from the Caribbean, the fervor for presidential politics reached a fever pitch as their relatives on the island went to the polls to choose a president. 
 That those who stayed in New York could not vote did not seem to matter: they passionately argued politics on street corners, tuned in to Spanish-language broadcasts and phoned relatives on the island.
"The Dominican, every Dominican immigrant, keeps feeling for his country," said Bienvenido Ovalles, 60, turning for a moment away from a heated political discussion on St. Nicholas Avenue. "The Dominican is very much involved in the election, even though he is absent. He may not be there, but his heart is always in his homeland."
Political parties on the island have long known that to get an edge in the fractious world of Dominican politics, it is smart to seek votes and money in New York's Dominican population, which, at around 600,000, is second in size only to the Dominican capital, Santo Domingo.
That has meant raffles and $500-a-plate fund-raisers in Manhattan hotels and Jimmy's Bronx Cafe. It has meant stump speeches, caravans of cars and rallies where Dominican immigrants have been urged to return home to vote, or even tell their relatives back home whom to vote for. It has meant that Tati Ayala, who works at EZ Vision Tours and Travel, has sold at least 150 airline tickets to Dominicans who, she said, flew home simply to vote.
"This is like a small slice of the Dominican Republic, like a city in the Republic," said Mario Caraballo, a local organizer for the Social Christian Reformist Party, whose leader is the former president, Joaquin Balaguer, 93. "The parties have organized here because the people here are an economic power."
Dr. Silvio Torres-Saillant, director of the Dominican Studies Institute at City College, said Dominican political parties have become highly adept at stirring nationalist sentiment among the rapidly growing Dominican population.
"The political parties have done an excellent job of keeping Dominicans from breaking their political umbilical cord, by turning New York City and all Dominican neighborhoods throughout the United States into arenas for island politics," said Dr. Torres-Saillant. "So they come, they establish chapters, they do fund-raising here. They promise positions to Dominicans here."
Indeed, Mr. Caraballo said, his party pushed hard for months to garner support in New York. The party's local branch conducted polls in New York to gauge support, raised $56,000 in two big-ticket fund-raisers and even helped pay for airfare so some Dominican supporters could go home to vote, he said. "Every party does this kind of thing," Mr. Caraballo explained. "No one sees anything wrong with it. They all do it."
Dominicans said yesterday that they felt compelled to have some say in politics in their country, whether through campaign contributions or by trying to sway their relatives back home. After all, they noted, Dominicans here maintain an important economic lifeline to the island, sending hundreds of millions of dollars to relatives.
In casual conversations, many said they supported Hipolito Mejia of the center-left Dominican Revolutionary Party, who was leading in the polls but was not expected to receive enough votes to avoid a June 30 runoff against Mr. Balaguer or Danilo Medina of the governing Dominican Liberation Party.
Not everyone sees the two-country political campaigns as a good thing. Fermin Luna, 63, producer of "Nueva York de Noche," a cable-access program about Dominican issues, said he has long worried that Dominican politicians have exploited immigrants in New York, promising patronage jobs or vast improvements in the standard of living on an island long mired in poverty.
"The Dominican lets himself be fooled by promises from politicians from there," said Mr. Luna, who came to the United States more than 30 years ago. "I think to myself, 'Why are we so involved in the Dominican politics when this is where our children are growing up?' "

LENGTH: 928 words

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: THE STOCK MARKET PROPOSAL;
Social Security Debate Framed in Generalities

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
Gov. George W. Bush of Texas has reignited the debate over the future of Social Security and whether it is a good idea to allow individuals to invest some of their payroll taxes in the stock market.
At the same time, Mr. Bush provided few specifics, saying they would be worked out in bipartisan negotiations. 
 So supporters and critics were left talking yesterday in the same generalities that have dominated the debate for years. And voters were still a long way from being able to figure out how they might be affected and whether a change would be beneficial.
Still, the announcement has signaled a change in the debate. Although Vice President Al Gore has attacked the idea as inherently risky, the concept of investing some money from payroll taxes in the stock market seemed to be more acceptable today than it was several years ago.
William Shipman, a principal at State Street Global Advisers who is co-chairman of the Cato Institute program on Social Security and a proponent of individual Social Security accounts, said, "I think that we are coming closer together; the idea that there should be some stock market investment was not in the cards six years ago."
Henry Aaron, a senior fellow at the Brookings Institution who opposes the idea of individuals investing their payroll taxes in the stock market, agreed. "The idea of investing in the stock market is right," Mr. Aaron said. "It's a good idea to increase the return as much as possible."
But he wants the government to do the investing, not individuals, a position President Clinton once proposed. "The problem with the individual accounts is that they waste money on needless administrative costs," he said.
As Mr. Aaron's comment indicated, debate over who does the investing, and how, will continue. And that is where the lack of specifics undermines any analysis.
Mr. Shipman, for example, would not comment on how Mr. Bush's proposal dealt with the cost of administering the Social Security accounts of private investors because it did not provide enough detail.
But the issue is important: will the costs of running the private accounts by Wall Street firms or mutual fund companies be so high that they will significantly reduce the returns that the individual would get from those accounts?
"It is not a necessary condition that administrative costs eat up returns," Mr. Shipman said. "It depends on how you design the system."
He said he has designed a system with very low costs, ranging from two-tenths of 1 percent to three-tenths of 1 percent of the assets in the account.
John Mueller, a principal at Lehrman Bell Mueller Cannon Inc., a financial market forecasting company in Chevy Chase, Md., argued that the cost would be much higher.
Mr. Mueller, a onetime supporter of privatizing the entire Social Security System, noted that the administrative costs for stock mutual funds in 1998, according to the Investment Company Institute, were 1.35 percent of the assets in the funds.
He and others argued that both the administrative costs and the transition costs for shifting to a system with private accounts would consume much of the additional return for many investors. Mr. Mueller's studies contend that investors would be better off under the existing system than the numerous versions that have been proposed.
He also faulted Mr. Gore and Mr. Bush for not developing proposals that he said would actually deal with the solvency of Social Security. The system will start paying out more in benefits than it is collecting in payroll taxes in 2015.
"Neither Gore nor Bush have a plan for balancing the system," Mr. Mueller said.
Mr. Shipman dismissed the issue of the transition costs. He argued that if nothing is done to finance Social Security properly, "there is a transition cost and that is, reasonably, the unfunded liability of the system -- $3 trillion to $8 trillion."
So, he said, the cost of a transition to a new system -- which some suggest would top $1 trillion -- must be compared to the cost of doing nothing about the current system.
Among other issues that have not been addressed was how investors who build private Social Security accounts would be treated when they retire. Will they get both the return from their individual account and the benefits that accrued from the rest of their payroll deductions?
Mr. Aaron said that a proposal for individual Social Security accounts that had been studied by the House Ways and Means Committee would allow retirees to keep what gave them the largest return -- the benefits based on payroll deductions or the benefits based on individual accounts.
He said that an analysis of this proposal showed that only 5 percent of the money from the individual accounts actually went to beneficiaries. The rest went back into the Social Security system and would be used, he said, to help pay off the transition costs.
And what benefits would a retiree get -- and how would the Social Security system cover them -- if the retiree was allowed, as Mr. Bush proposed, to pass on the assets in the individual accounts to his or her heirs?
Mr. Bush will also face another nagging question: why does he put so much faith in the stock market if his chief economic adviser, Lawrence B. Lindsey, is so bearish?
Almost two years ago, Mr. Lindsey said that he had sold all of his equity holdings because stock prices were overvalued. At the time, the Dow Jones industrial average was around 8,500. Despite this year's almost 5 percent sell-off, the Dow closed yesterday at 10934.57.

HEADLINE: E.P.A. to Issue Tougher Rules On Diesel Fuel

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 16

 BODY:
The Environmental Protection Agency plans on Wednesday to announce new pollution-control rules that would cut truck and bus emissions drastically, in part through a 97 percent reduction in the sulfur content of diesel fuel over the next 10 years.
The rules, the biggest change in regulation of trucks and buses in the agency's 30-year history, are intended to cut smog and remove from the air chemicals that have been linked to a variety of health problems, like cancer and asthma, E.P.A. officials said. 
 The oil industry strongly opposes the new rules, which it insists will sharply raise the price of diesel fuel and could result in shortages, in part because refiners would be hard-pressed to install the new equipment needed to meet the requirements.
The industry has said it is willing to accept sharp, but less severe, cuts in sulfur content.
The draft rules, which may be modified during the course of public hearings this year, have been in preparation for several years.
They are being announced now to give the Clinton administration time to hold the hearings and follow other procedures for public comment required by law before the rules can be made final. Under the Clean Air Act, the administration has the power to impose new rules without Congressional approval.
The changes would be phased in over 10 years. The new limits on emissions from diesel trucks would apply only to new models, but the cuts in sulfur content in diesel fuel would reduce emissions from existing trucks and buses.
The proposed rules call for a 95 percent reduction in nitrogen oxide emissions, which should cut smog appreciably, and a 90 percent reduction in particulate emissions, or soot.
Sulfur particles are part of soot, so cutting the fuel's sulfur content would help reduce soot levels in the air.
Getting rid of the sulfur allows engineers to install pollution reduction equipment on the trucks and buses, just as a generation ago, removing the lead from gasoline allowed the introduction of catalytic converters on cars that have been so successful in controlling their pollution. Very few trucks and buses now carry such devices.
Environmentalists were ecstatic about the E.P.A.'s plans.
"It will be the end of the big smoking dirty obnoxious truck as we know it today," said Frank O'Donnell, executive director of the Clean Air Trust, an environmental group.
S. William Becker, executive director of the State and Territorial Air Pollution Program Administrators -- a national association of state regulators -- called trucks and buses "one of the last remaining unregulated sources of air pollution."
"It will result in huge air quality benefits to the states," Mr. Becker said of the set of proposed rules. "It will prevent tens of thousands of cancers. It will provide benefits to every locality in the country."
The oil industry warned that the planned 97 percent cut in allowable levels of sulfur in diesel -- to 15 parts per million, from the current level of 500 parts per million -- would raise fuel prices by 10 cents a gallon or more, and cause supply shortages. The petroleum industry is calling for a 90 percent cut, or 50 parts per million, as more economically practical.
The cut proposed by the E.P.A., the American Petroleum Institute said, would make it difficult if not impossible for the industry to produce enough diesel. "We don't think we can consistently produce and supply it," said Edward H. Murphy of the institute, the industry's biggest trade association.
Mr. Murphy said that some refineries have equipment on hand that could meet a ceiling of 50 parts per million, but that tougher rules would require the installation of expensive new production equipment.
Mr. Murphy added that refiners say they are now struggling to meet new stringent limits on sulfur in gasoline and cannot handle new requirements of diesel as well.
Administration officials said that the E.P.A. planned to hold five public hearings around the country in the next few weeks and then open a 45-day public comment period, allowing the agency to put the rule into final form this year, before President Clinton leaves office.
The fuel rules would take effect in June 2006. The emissions cuts on the amount of nitrogen oxide produced by new trucks and buses would be phased in; a quarter of new vehicles would have to meet them in 2007, half by 2008, three-quarters by 2009 and all by 2010. The new rules on particulate emissions would take effect in 2007.
When they introduce the proposal, administration officials plan to argue that diesel exhaust may cause lung cancer, and clearly brings on asthma attacks and other respiratory problems.
The E.P.A. plans hearings in New York, Chicago, Atlanta, Denver and Los Angeles, followed by the comment period for the public -- and affected industries -- to submit statements.
The agency plans to seek comments on "ways to incorporate additional flexibility for small oil refiners," an E.P.A. official said.
In the past, the government has tried to write its regulations to allow smaller refiners to survive.
Experts say that the public should not notice any change in the low-sulfur fuel other than its cost; it should smell the same and behave the same way in engines.
The fuel industry has been far more vociferous than engine manufacturers in opposing the rules.
The engine companies are apparently not eager for another battle with the E.P.A. Seven of the companies were caught by the agency installing "defeat devices" on their engines, devices that allowed the engines to pass certification tests but made them run much dirtier on the highways.
The companies agreed in 1998 to pay $83.4 million in penalties, and to spend $850 million to produce cleaner engines.

HEADLINE: New Jersey Democratic Candidates for Senate Clash on Gun Control and Taxes

BYLINE: By DAVID KOCIENIEWSKI 

DATELINE: LIVINGSTON, N.J., May 16

 BODY:
New Jersey's two Democratic candidates for the United States Senate clashed over gun control, national security and taxes tonight during their third debate, as each candidate tried to portray himself as the stronger champion of working families and the elderly.
Jon S. Corzine, who appeared defensive and tongue-tied during much of the first debate last Thursday, has been more confident and lucid in his subsequent outings, and tonight he continued his criticism of the $2.8 billion tax increase that his opponent, Jim Florio, enacted as governor. 
 Opening a new line of attack before a standing-room-only audience of 500 at the Temple Beth Shalom Synagogue here, Mr. Corzine also accused Mr. Florio of supporting cuts in defense spending and ending economic sanctions against Iraq.
Mr. Florio, who has tried to use the debates to compensate for his disadvantage in campaign financing, struck back by accusing Mr. Corzine of investing in several gun manufacturers when he was chairman of Goldman, Sachs & Company.
"During the 90's, when Jon, at Goldman Sachs, was financing the gun industry, I was standing up to the gun lobby," Mr. Florio said.
Mr. Florio also rebutted Mr. Corzine's criticism of his tax increase by pointing out that Mr. Corzine was one of the most generous contributors to his re-election campaign, giving the maximum legal donation to both his primary and general election efforts.
"I'm startled to see this opportunistic political expediency come forward," Mr. Florio said, to cheers and laughs from the audience.
Although this was the third encounter between the candidates in a week -- with the final debate scheduled for Thursday -- Mr. Corzine has come under criticism in recent days because he has agreed to debates on small radio stations and cable television outlets but has refused to attend a May 26 debate sponsored by the League of Women voters, to be broadcast on network television.
Tonight's encounter was scheduled to be televised in excerpted form Wednesday night by the Regional News Network, a cable station that reaches a limited number of homes in northern New Jersey.
But Mr. Corzine, whose unfettered campaign spending has filled the airwaves with a barrage of television and radio ads, has little to gain strategically by participating in uncontrolled forums like debates. He points out that some of Mr. Florio's previous campaigns included fewer than four debates.
It is not clear, however, if the debates have changed the dynamic of this race. Mr. Corzine, a political unknown when he declared his interest in the Senate seat last February, has spent more than $15 million of his own money on a flood of television advertisements during the last eight weeks. There is little reliable polling available, because poll respondents are notoriously untrustworthy when asked if they will vote in a primary, but both campaigns believe that Mr. Corzine has narrowed Mr. Florio's once-formidable lead, and some suggest that Mr. Corzine is slightly ahead.
So with three weeks remaining before the June 6 primary, the contest has become increasingly heated. Mr. Florio, who has money for television advertisements only during the final two weeks of the campaign, has tried to halt Mr. Corzine's momentum by portraying him as out of tune with the concerns of working families and as politically naive.
When Mr. Corzine expressed his support tonight for President Clinton's nuclear missile shield "within the context of negotiations with Russia," Mr. Florio said he was being duped by Congressional Republicans.
Mr. Corzine has accompanied the week of debates with an acceleration in spending, which is likely to shatter all records for primary candidates. After the candidates' radio debate on Monday, Mr. Corzine unveiled three new television ads. And in recent weeks, his voice has been heard on a growing number of radio stations and his face has become a familiar sight on buses and billboards.
Mr. Corzine has said that his intense television campaign is the only way that a political newcomer can compete with "professional politicians" like Mr. Florio, whose name recognition in New Jersey is nearly universal.
Although Mr. Florio has branded Mr. Corzine's proposal to invest part of the Social Security trust fund in the stock market as a risky scheme that might send elderly Americans to "the poor house," Mr. Corzine did not back away from the plan.
Mr. Corzine asserted that he supported President Clinton's Social Security plan, which would use the nation's present prosperity to help ensure the economic well-being of elderly Americans in the decades to come.

HEADLINE: Battle on Federalism

BYLINE: By LINDA GREENHOUSE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 16

 BODY:
At first glance, the Violence Against Women Act appeared an unlikely battleground for the Supreme Court's continuing federalism wars.
This 1994 federal law neither told the states to do anything nor prohibited them from taking any action. By permitting private damage suits by victims of "gender-motivated violence" against their attackers, the law did not expose the states themselves to any new legal liability. 
 This was no titanic struggle among co-equal sovereigns: when the legislation was pending in Congress, the attorneys general from 38 states urged its passage, and 36 states joined a brief supporting the law before the Supreme Court. Only one, Alabama, filed a brief asking the justices to strike the law down.
Despite all that, the court invalidated a central provision of the law on Monday by a 5-to-4 vote. Developments at the court over the last five years made the law a nearly perfect target for the narrow but determined majority of justices who, through half a dozen earlier rulings, brought the court to the point at which the invalidation of the Violence Against Women Act, as an unconstitutional exercise in Congressional overreaching, was close to inevitable.
There are distinct strands to the court's new federalism jurisprudence, and in a formal sense, the decision in United States v. Morrison, Monday's ruling, represents only one of them: holding Congress to its limited and enumerated powers. In this sense, the ruling flowed directly from a 1995 decision that struck down, as beyond Congress's power to regulate interstate commerce, a law that made it a federal crime to carry a gun near a school. That decision, United States v. Lopez, was the first time since the New Deal that the court found Congress to have exceeded its authority under the commerce clause. States' rights, as such, were not directly at issue either in the Lopez case or in the decision on Monday.
But in a broader sense, the latest decision represents something more: a convergence between the court's focus on a Congress of limited powers and its newly found solicitude for state sovereignty, the focus of other recent federalism decisions that have carved out new immunities for the states from federal court lawsuits or federal policy "commandeering." The convergence lay not so much in anything Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist's majority opinion said explicitly, but in the background music of a decision that rejected a large volume of evidence that the law's sponsors had compiled to show why a national approach to violence against women was needed.
"The court applied its own meta-test" to the legislative record, said Prof. Laurence H. Tribe of Harvard Law School: "We don't care what the findings are, if accepting them endangers our vision of state sovereignty, our view of the architecture of our system." That test applies, Professor Tribe said in an interview, "even when the states are basically willing bystanders."
Further, the decision moved the federalism counterrevolution closer than any of the other recent cases toward the core issues of civil rights for which the court for so long had given Congress wide scope. By ruling that the Violence Against Women Act was not an appropriate exercise of Congress's power to enforce the equal protection guarantee of the 14th Amendment, the court emphasized that in the area of civil rights, no less than interstate commerce, Congressional assertions of power were now to be scrutinized under a judicial microscope.
"It's the intersection of the New Deal and civil rights, coming together in a case concerning women," Prof. Judith Resnik of Yale Law School said in an interview. She said the court's rejection of the argument that violence against women was an appropriate subject for national legislation was a reminder of earlier eras, when the Supreme Court viewed labor-management issues and, even earlier, slavery, as a matter of interpersonal relations, not properly subject to federal intervention.
In the years leading up to its final passage, the Violence Against Women Act was a frequent target of criticism from federal judges, including Chief Justice Rehnquist, who singled it out in a 1998 speech as one of "the more notable examples" of laws that unduly expanded the jurisdiction of the federal courts. "Our system will look more and more like the French government, where even the most minor details are ordained by the national government in Paris," the chief justice warned in a speech to the American Law Institute.
The familiar federal civil rights laws that bar discrimination in employment and in public accommodations are not in any danger from the decision, which cast no doubt on the court's assumption in prior cases that jobs, hotels, restaurants and the like are part of the national economy that Congress can properly regulate under its commerce power.
But when states themselves are defendants, there are strong signals that the court is looking through a different lens. Already, the court has declared states immune from suit by their employees for federal labor law violations and for age discrimination. In its next term, the justices will decide whether states can be sued under the Americans With Disabilities Act.
Beyond those particular implications, the broader fallout from the decision this week could lie outside the courtroom. Beginning with the Lopez decision, which invalidated a law few people had ever heard of, most of the court's federalism rulings have involved obscure statutes or obscure constitutional provisions like the 10th and 11th Amendments. As a result, a constitutional development of potentially enormous significance has been unfolding -- albeit in plain sight -- largely outside the realm of public discussion.
That could change, given the higher public profile of the Violence Against Women Act, the considerable attention the decision has received, and the closeness of the vote. Not too many years ago, it would hardly have seemed likely that questions about federalism might dominate a Supreme Court confirmation hearing. Now that prospect seems likely when the next vacancy occurs.
In another respect, the fallout from the decision could be surprising. Prof. Glenn H. Reynolds of the University of Tennessee Law School noted in an interview today that to regard the decision as a victory for conservatives could well be short-sighted. As recent Congressional debates on flag burning, school prayer, abortion methods and other such issues indicate, he said, much of what Congress does these days is symbolic, and much of the symbolism is conservative. But under the logic of this week's decision, Professor Reynolds added, any action in these areas would almost certainly exceed Congress's authority. "The beauty of our system is that everything bites back eventually," he said.

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: THE VICE PRESIDENT;
Gore Denounces Bush Social Security Plan as Too Risky

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO and ALISON MITCHELL 

 BODY:
Taking the offensive against Gov. George W. Bush's proposal to let workers invest some of their Social Security taxes, Vice President Al Gore asserted yesterday that the plan would hurt the very baby boomers it is intended to help by placing their retirement savings at the mercy of ruthless and whimsical markets.
In an event intended to sway younger voters who have grown accustomed to gravity-defying markets and are more likely to be receptive to the Bush plan, the vice president painted a bleak picture of unsophisticated taxpayers losing their savings in fraudulent, risky or just plain bad investments. 
 The result, he warned graduate students at Fordham Business School in Manhattan, would be a costly taxpayer-financed bailout of failed investors that would dwarf the multibillion-dollar rescue of bankrupt savings and loans in the 1980's. And yesterday, Mr. Bush suggested he might support allowing workers to invest a large portion of their payroll taxes, which Mr. Gore said would increase the chances of financial disaster.
"Tens of millions of investors who have not gone through the Fordham Business School, who have not had an opportunity to gain some basic knowledge to protect themselves against fraud," Mr. Gore said, "would be placed in a situation where a lot of financial shenanigans could take place, where they are losing their investments because they are not equipped in the way that sophisticated investors are. It happens all the time."
But Mr. Bush accused the vice president of flip-flopping on the issue, releasing a videotape from January 1999 showing Mr. Gore arguing that it might make sense for the federal government to invest some revenue in the stock market to take advantage of its historically strong returns.
Asked on the tape whether long-term stock investments would be safe, Mr. Gore replies: "Over any 10-year period in American history returns on equities are just significantly higher than these other returns. And in order to capture some part of that economic advantage, surely there is a way to solve these problems."
When asked about his remarks yesterday, the vice president said that he was talking about investing general tax revenues and not money from the Social Security trust fund -- an idea the Clinton administration was considering at the time. He also suggested that his views had changed after hearing debate over the proposal.
But Mr. Bush asserted that Mr. Gore had switched positions for political purposes. "I believe it's important to be consistent," he said in a news conference in Portland, Ore. "I believe it's important to have somebody willing to take a stand."
The day's swirling debate underscored Mr. Gore's desire to block Mr. Bush from seizing the advantage -- particularly among young voters -- on an issue that historically has played to the strengths of Democratic candidates.
For decades, Social Security has been a powerful Democratic weapon because it is so important to the most active group of voters in the electorate: the elderly. Older people have also tended to vote Democratic, so for years Democrats have successfully turned out their core voters by accusing Republicans of wanting to end or undermine the Social Security system.
But Mr. Bush's proposal could change that dynamic by making Social Security more relevant to younger voters who have grown skeptical about the system's viability but are also comfortable with the idea of investing in Wall Street. Polls show those younger voters supported President Clinton in 1996.
"I think Bush is slicing into part of the Democratic coalition with this," said Andrew Smith, director of polling for the University of New Hampshire. "But if older voters can be convinced that this plan is a threat to their Social Security, Bush will have problems."
Mr. Gore plans to make that argument to retirees in Florida on Wednesday.
In making Social Security a major campaign issue, Mr. Gore and Mr. Bush have offered sharply different proposals for extending the life of the system, which is projected to become insolvent by the year 2037.
Mr. Bush argues that allowing workers to invest a small portion of their payroll taxes would enable them to take advantage of the wealth created by Wall Street and reduce the cost to taxpayers of financing the system. But his plan would also leave those investors vulnerable to losses from market fluctuations.
Mr. Gore would not change the current system that guarantees a minimum benefit. To prolong the system's life, Mr. Gore proposes using the Social Security surplus to pay down the national debt and then devoting the interest saved to the retirement system. The proposal would keep the system solvent until 2054, he contends.
Mr. Bush's event yesterday, like Mr. Gore's, was designed to take the issue beyond the elderly, as he tailored his message to the blue-collar work force at a Portland company that makes railroad freight cars and marine barges.
Mr. Gore's advisers contend that such working-class voters are more fiscally conservative, less comfortable with the idea of investing in Wall Street and likely to be opposed to Mr. Bush's plan.
Mr. Bush tried to show that was not the case yesterday. Leading a discussion with workers who spoke highly of their 401(k) plan, the governor suggested that opponents of his plan do not trust working Americans to manage their own money.
"You know I wonder out loud whether there may be some in Washington saying these workers are not smart enough to figure it out," Mr. Bush said. "I wonder whether or not that's what people may be really saying deep down. You can't trust individuals in America who maybe don't have Ph.D.'s in economics."
But even as he sought to sell his proposal, Mr. Bush -- who has not provided details for many aspects of the plan -- made several remarks that are likely to provide fodder for additional attacks from Mr. Gore.
First, Mr. Bush left open the possibility that his call for limited accounts was just the first step in a broader transformation of the federal retirement system. Answering a question about his plan, Mr. Bush said that the government could not go "from one regime to another overnight." He said: "It's going to take a while to transition to a system where personal savings accounts are the predominant part of the investment vehicle. And so, this is a step toward a completely different world and an important step."
Mr. Bush has refused to say what proportion of the 12.4 percent payroll tax people could put into private accounts under his plan.
Mr. Bush also refused to say how much benefits might be reduced for workers who created private investment accounts.
"That's all up for discussion," Mr. Bush said.
With many finance majors present at his Fordham event, Mr. Gore noted that he supported individuals investing in the stock market for retirement, provided no Social Security funds are involved. But to bolster his point that the markets can be risky, he brought along several experts, including Robert E. Rubin, a Wall Street executive who was Treasury secretary until last year.
"I've been involved with markets virtually my entire working life," Mr. Rubin told the group. "There is no question, stocks have risks."
In many ways, Mr. Gore's arguments might have seemed a tough sell to a youthful audience that was both knowledgeable about financial markets and accustomed to hearing that the best retirement savings are in the stock market.
Indeed, many students' questions indicated a general support for the idea of private investment accounts. But several students said after the event that Mr. Gore had raised deep questions in their minds about the Bush plan.
"When he says there are certain to be losers, that's a compelling argument," said Scott Horton, a 27-year-old finance major.

HEADLINE: Excerpts From Hillary Clinton's Remarks at Nominating Convention

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from Hillary Rodham Clinton's remarks to the New York State Democratic Convention last night in Albany:
Tonight I'm deeply honored and humbled to accept the nomination of the New York Democratic Party for the United States Senate. . . . 
 And I pledge to you that I will work my heart out every day in this campaign to become your next senator. And I will work every day in the Senate to keep faith with you, with the values and the ideals of the Democratic Party of New York.
Because make no mistake about it: This election is not about me or about any Republican opponent. It's about the people of New York, and the mission that we are pledged to. What is that mission? I think it is to strengthen our families and to protect our children, to improve our schools and to extend health care to every New Yorker. To free our families and our communities from the terror of gun violence. Strengthen Social Security and modernize Medicare. Ensure America's continued leadership in the world.
It was, after all, New York Democrats who led the way in building the great American middle class. In giving rise to the labor union, to civil rights, to women's rights, to gay rights.
We can continue leading this by building on the progress of the last seven years. Twenty-one million new jobs, balanced budgets, lowered crime, stronger schools, better child care, a cleaner environment, a safer and more inclusive American community. And our thanks must go to Vice President Al Gore and President Bill Clinton.
New York has made tremendous strides in the last seven years. But there are still too many forgotten New Yorkers. Millions of children without the families, health care or education they need to prepare them for the future. Millions of mothers and fathers working full time but still stressed with too little money or too little time. An upstate economy that isn't generating enough jobs to keep our young people here.
We have some of the greatest institutions of higher learning in the nation. Yet too many of our students still can't afford a college education.
We have some of the best public schools around. Yet far too many of our students are crammed into overcrowded, dilapidated school buildings more suited to the 19th century than the 21st.
We have the finest hospitals in the world. Yet more than half a million children in New York do not have health insurance, and two million older New Yorkers cannot afford their prescription drugs.
We have the most beautiful scenery -- from the Finger Lakes to the Adirondacks to Long Island's beaches. Yet we face environmental challenges to our air, our water and our health.
I know we can do better and New York should not settle for less.
We owe it to ourselves and to our children.

HEADLINE: TRENDS;
For Job Hunters, Networking Beats the Net

BYLINE: By DYLAN LOEB McCLAIN 

 BODY:
Millions of people search the Internet every month looking for jobs, but for actually landing one, nothing beats the old-fashioned personal touch, the latest studies show.
 While the top 10 Internet job search sites had almost twice as many users in March as they did one year earlier -- 17.4 million versus 8.9 million -- networking and referrals remained the main way people found work. A survey by Drake Beam Morin, a workplace consulting firm, of 7,400 executives who switched jobs last year, showed that just 4 percent found their positions on the Internet, while 64 percent got them by networking. 
 Another survey, by Forrester Research, indicated that the majority of people who used job-search sites were generally dissatisfied with the quality of the jobs advertised. Nevertheless, companies and recruiters said they planned to spend more on advertising jobs online than they do now because it is such an efficient way to reach job hunters.
 Todd Hoffman, national director of recruiting for tax and legal services at PricewaterhouseCoopers, said that about 3 percent of the 900 people he has hired this fiscal year made initial contact via the Internet. In the next 12 to 15 months, he said he would like that percentage to be 10 to 12 percent. This is a high priority for us, he said. It is more cost effective. DYLAN LOEB McCLAIN

HEADLINE: Metro Business;
New Jersey Jobless Rate Up

BYLINE: AP 

 BODY:
New Jersey's jobless rate edged up slightly in April, rising to 3.8 percent from 3.7 percent, according to labor statistics released yesterday. 
The rate has remained below 4.5 percent for the past six months.
"It's still a tenth of a point below the national rate," said the state's labor commissioner, Mel Gelade.
About 11,600 jobs were added in April, but with more people looking for jobs, the unemployment rate rose, Mr. Gelade said.
The service sector had the biggest gains, with 4,800 new jobs. The retail sector added 4,000 jobs, with food stores posting 1,500 new jobs.
Construction added 400 jobs, pushing employment in that sector to its highest level since August 1990.
Manufacturing lost 700 jobs, and finance/insurance/real estate lost 200 jobs.
