SECTION: Section F; Page 1; Column 2; Dining In, Dining Out/Style Desk 

LENGTH: 1780 words

HEADLINE: Remember When $29 Shocked . . .

BYLINE: By RICK MARIN 

 BODY:
IN bringing his chain of meateries from Dallas to Midtown Manhattan, Terry White, the executive chef at Del Frisco's, introduced a special menu item just for New Yorkers.
The Double Eagle strip steak (bone-in, 26 ounces). 
 $49.95.
For one. With nothing else on the plate but a smooth coat of butter -- and a little parsley.
Is this the most expensive per-person steak in town? In recorded history?
"We are offering the best that money can buy, and we're not shy about charging for it," said Mr. White, whose restaurant opened on West 49th Street a couple of months ago. "We're in an age when people are trading cars in every two years, people are getting pedicures and manicures. They're taking care of themselves. They're living large. And we provide them with an atmosphere to live large."
He, and plenty more big-ticket restaurateurs in these big-ticket times. Has anyone looked at the column to the right of the entrees lately? Crazy numbers! A $32 cod at Picholine. Duck for $35 at Gotham Bar & Grill. A $38.25 rack of lamb at Limoncello. Limoncello!
Entrees used to hover politely under $30, with maybe a lobster or prime sirloin thrusting boldly beyond that old psychic and budget barrier, $29.95. Now you see menus with hardly anything under $30, and it's not necessarily buying four-star food, service or ambience. More modest neighborhood places are up there, too. Soft-shell crabs are $32 at Little Dove. Della Femina charges $44 for its veal rib chop. Decade, on First Avenue and 61st Street, wants $33 for a veal chop and is not even in Zagat.
The $30 barrier has been broken in New York restaurants, quietly, with enough money around to muffle any noise about it. These places are packed. On the horizon is what may be the most expensive of them all. Alain Ducasse, the French chef with six Michelin stars, comes to the Essex House this summer with the possibility that his per-person rate might climb north of $200.
A spokesman for Mr. Ducasse said his New York prices had not been determined yet. But a Ducasse dinner in Paris can run as high as $215 a person, not including wine.
Clark Wolf, a restaurant consultant based in Manhattan, said prices began spiking over the last year or two. "Some people are just trying to see, 'Let's see how far I can go,' " he said. "Sometimes it's justified, and sometimes it's a rip-off." Mr. Wolf offered a few of the typical justifications for a $32 piece of fish. Food costs are up, as is rent. Competition for preternaturally picky New York diners has driven chefs to seek out the most rarefied ingredients, six-figure sommeliers, exotic architects.
To hear the owner of Bayard's tell it, $33 for his halibut dish is barely enough to break even.
"Garnishes aren't cheap," said Peter Poulakakos, who operates the restaurant, at 1 Hanover Square.
"You've got potato on there. A lot of people are touching that plate. There are a lot of hands on that plate, and all those hands cost money. Even the plate it's on costs me $30 to $40."
Terrance Brennan, the chef and owner of Picholine on West 64th Street, decided almost two years ago that he wanted to upgrade. "Then I had a couple of dishes breaking the $30 barrier," he said. "I was very sensitive to it." But he increased his staff to 88 employees and took on an assistant sommelier and two "cheese guys."
"To try and achieve this next level, you have to hire more experienced managers, which costs a lot more," he continued. "And there's no other way except to raise prices." The butter clams served with his $32 cod cost $20 a pound from his supplier in Maine, he added, explaining, "there's a lot behind the cod dish itself."
In the fall, Mr. Brennan will be serving a plate of white-truffle risotto for $100, a reasonable price, he argued, considering the high truffle content. "I shave heavy," he said.
Picholine solicits feedback on customer comment cards. Complaints about cost come in rarely, Mr. Brennan said. "I can't remember the last time I got a comment card that said prices are too high or anything like that," he said.
In 1975, when a pleasure dome called the Palace opened with the unheard-of prix fixe of $50 a person, a reviewer for The New York Times suggested that a mob might string up the perpetrators on the nearest lamppost. No stars were given "because of the impossibility of averaging quality and price in this instance," John Canaday wrote.
In today's economy, admitting to being unable to afford a $36 entree might be considered rube behavior, or at least embarrassing. A certain caste of New Yorkers is experiencing "bracket creep," said David Brooks, the author of the new "Bobos in Paradise: The New Upper Class and How They Got There" (Simon & Schuster, $25).
"As you rise to each new income and price bracket, you have total amnesia of what life was like at the previous bracket," Mr. Brooks said. The advent of fabulous cyberwealth has also had a trickle-down effect. "People are adapting to the behavior of people who are beyond rich," he said.
It is no secret that New York is an expensive place to eat. Del Frisco's pumped up its prices $1 or $2 when it opened here to cover what Mr. White, the executive chef, called "the ambience, the rent, the total experience" of his 16,400-square-foot cow palace. Rather than offer a huge steak for two, he went with the $49.95 steak for one, because his market research had revealed the startling fact that New Yorkers do not like to share.
Gotham Bar & Grill has never been cheap, but of 13 second courses listed on its current menu, only two of them weigh in at under $ 30: the Maine brook trout for $28.50 and organic free-range chicken for $28. In this context, a $28 chicken starts to look like a bargain.
Alfred Portale, chef at Gotham for 16 years, recalled when his entrees "started stacking up under $30" -- maybe five years ago. "I didn't want to go over $30, but I had to," he said. "Now I feel the same way about $35."
Four of Mr. Portale's entrees have reached or broken that barrier: the Maine lobster tails ($37), roast rack of veal ($36), Chinese spiced duck breast ($35) and rack of lamb ($36).
"I hate raising prices," he said. "You're forced to." He said that his rent on East 12th Street doubled last year but that "we don't try to capture that in the food costs." The reason, he said was "super-expensive ingredients." Earlier this year, he switched from 21-day aged top choice beef (at $4.10 a pound wholesale) to prime (more than $6 a pound). He always used sushi-grade tuna ($5.50 to $6 a pound), but now it has to be belly ($10 a pound). His old Monini extra virgin olive oil ($70 for six one-liter bottles) isn't good enough anymore. He imports single-vineyard, organic olive oils from his wine purveyors ($140 for six half-liter bottles).
Mr. Portale and Mr. Brennan run ambitious kitchens and dining rooms that can justify crossing the $30 border. But for a halibut dish at the brand-new Bayard's to be only $2 less than the $35 halibut at Restaurant Daniel, with no cheese cart or exclusive ingredients in the package, does not seem to be in the natural order of things.
There is a formula for menu pricing. At most restaurants, between 30 and 35 percent of an entree's price is the food cost. This is usually an average. Forty percent on a steak is mitigated by 20 percent on chicken. Many chefs and owners said they make less money on their highest-priced entrees. Mr. Portale says he pays $14 for the duck in his $35 Chinese spiced duck breast. Kevin Penner, the executive chef and a partner at Della Femina, on East 54th Street, is "not coming close to making money" on his $42 cowboy steak, he said, adding, "It should be $52 based on what it costs me."
Still, do customers ever blanch at breaking not only the $30 barrier, but $40?
"We do get people in who perhaps suffer from a bit of sticker shock at times, and we're willing to work with them and split things," Mr. Penner said. "Typically, they'll say something like, 'I'm not so hungry.' But they want to have the experience of saying they ate here and tell their friends."
At other restaurants, the price of admission almost seems like a membership fee, observed Mr. Wolf, the consultant.
At Harry Cipriani, where chicken marsala sets back its Brioni-blazered diners $34.95, the staggering bills are "as much about who's not welcome as who is," Mr. Wolf said.
The Four Seasons restaurant also cultivates a clubby atmosphere of powerful money -- money that does not have to worry about a $46 Dover sole.
Alex von Bidder, one of the restaurant's owners, said of eating there: "You're renting a piece of real estate. The fish is unfortunately only a small part of the cost. There is the exquisite setting and the location."
Asked if the arrival of Mr. Ducasse and his expected hefty prix fixe would drag other restaurants up with him, Mr. von Bidder said, "I really don't pay attention to what other people charge."
Jean-Georges Vongerichten, who owns five New York restaurants, estimated that Mr. Ducasse's prix fixe would probably be in the $150 to $200 range. "He's going to be in a class of his own," he said.
Mr. Vongerichten charges a $125 prix fixe for dinner at Jean Georges. But at Nougatine, his casual cafe attached to Jean Georges, lobster lemon risotto is $34. At a table with hardly enough room under it to cross your legs.
Mr. Vongerichten bemoaned the high cost of running a high-end establishment. "If you don't spend $3 million on the design and construction, you have nothing serious anymore," he said. A 10-year loan of $8 million to $10 million means at least $1 million a year in payments. Running the numbers in his mental calculator, he added, "Some places are paying $500,000 in rent, a chef costs $100,000 -- and they'll probably close after six months."
One New York restaurateur whose wings have been singed is Frank Valenza, the owner of Two Two Two on West 79th Street -- and 25 years ago, the Palace. Last week Mr. Valenza announced that he was lowering his prices. His $59 prix fixe is $39 a person. A la carte entrees that were $32 to $49 are now $24 to $42. Gone from the new menu is the 16-ounce Kobe sirloin for $180.
"We used to get stockbrokers pulling up in their limos, and that's kind of died down," Mr. Valenza said. "So what do you do?"
At the Palace, Mr. Valenza, who came to food from a theatrical background, gave customers ice sculptures of a fisherman with nets full of caviar. To attract clientele back to Two Two Two, he has once again mustered his flair for showmanship. On display in the entrance area of the restaurant is his wife's Barbie collection.
He's throwing that in free.

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN;
Campaign Briefing

BYLINE: Compiled By B. Drummond Ayres Jr.

 BODY:

THE ISSUES
 
BATTLE OVER BATTLE FLAG -- If South Carolina lawmakers hoped that the N.A.A.C.P. would drop its economic boycott of the state now that they have agreed to move the Confederate battle flag from the Statehouse dome, they had not counted on the group's tenacity. Kweisi Mfume, the national president of the group, said yesterday that the N.A.A.C.P. might even consider expanding the boycott beyond tourism, because the state plans to move the banner to a flagpole in front of the State Capitol, near a monument to Confederate soldiers. Although the group's original boycott resolution demanded that the flag be moved out of a position of sovereignty, Mr. Mfume argued that the flag was no less prominent in front of the building than it was on top. The State Senate and House are expected to iron out minor differences on a bill to move the flag in the next few weeks, and it is scheduled to be lowered on July 1. David Firestone (NYT) 

THE DEMOCRATS
 
DECISION IN KENNEDY CASE -- The Los Angeles city attorney declined yesterday to file misdemeanor battery charges against Representative Patrick J. Kennedy of Rhode Island over a confrontation with a security guard at Los Angeles International Airport in March. The prosecutor's office summoned Mr. Kennedy, 32, and the guard, Della Patton, 58, to a hearing last week to review a videotape of the incident. Mr. Kennedy had earlier acknowledged acting rudely and apologized, but he denied hurting Ms. Patton. "I am obviously happy that city officials agree that I did not do what I was accused of," Mr. Kennedy said in a statement. George L. Mallory Jr., a lawyer for Ms. Patton, who has complained of shoulder pain and has not worked since the incident, said he expected to approach Mr. Kennedy about a settlement and would sue if those talks failed.
 Todd S. Purdum (NYT)
 
THE STATES
 
GUBERNATORIAL EARLY BIRD -- It's a year early, but the 2001 governor's race in Virginia is already taking shape, with one self-made millionaire announcing this week that he is stepping aside for another in the Democratic competition. Former congressman L. F. Payne Jr., a Charlottesville developer who lost as the Democratic Party's candidate for lieutenant governor in 1997, took himself out of the running and endorsed Mark R. Warner, who heads a venture capital firm in Alexandria. Mr. Payne said Mr. Warner had "the right experience, the right ideas and the right values" to win the governorship. Mr. Payne's base is among rural conservative Democrats and he showed his popularity by finishing ahead of the rest of his ticket in the Democrats' bid to take the Statehouse in 1997. But he conceded that Mr. Warner, whose base is in the northern suburbs, already had a dominant edge in organization and fund-raising among high-tech corporate donors. As he stepped aside, Mr. Payne was accompanied by supporters insisting that he would still be a good candidate for governor in 2005. In the meantime, he may take on a role in Mr. Warner's campaign. The Republican nomination for governor next year is expected to be contested by Lt. Gov. John H. Hager, who defeated Mr. Payne in 1997, and Attorney General Mark L. Earley.
 Francis X. Clines (NYT)
 
'LIVE TAX FREE OR DIE' -- Gov. Jeanne Shaheen of New Hampshire announced yesterday that she would seek a third two-year term. But she did not say whether she would renew her pledge to veto an income tax, which is seen by some state leaders, albeit reluctantly, as the best way for the state to respond to a court order to reform its school financing system. Year in and year out, taxes are the hottest political issue in New Hampshire, a state that, along with Alaska, has no personal income tax or general sales tax (its official motto is "Live Free Or Die") and whose residents take great pride in roughing up politicians who do not pledge to oppose new levies. Governor Shaheen, a Democrat, took "the pledge" in her 1996 and 1998 campaigns but she has thus far avoided discussing what she might do in the 2000 campaign -- though she did agree to a temporary tax, at one point, as the state initially tried to respond to the court school-financing order. In this year's Democratic primary, she will face State Senator Mark Fernald, who supports a state income tax to solve the school problem. On the Republican side, four candidates are competing for the nomination, with mixed views on the tax question. There is also an independent candidate. John Kifner (NYT)

HEADLINE: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;
The Showgirl and Her (Many) Princes

BYLINE: By WILLIAM WRIGHT; William Wright is the author of "Born That Way: Genes, Behavior, Personality" and "Lillian Hellman: The Image, the Woman."

 BODY:

GOLD DIGGER
The Outrageous Life and Times of Peggy Hopkins Joyce
By Constance Rosenblum
Illustrated. 293 pages. Metropolitan Books. $26.
Those who brood that hollow, distinction-free celebrities are an idiosyncrasy of our talk show-driven times might be relieved to learn that other periods had them as well. Peggy Hopkins Joyce was a Broadway showgirl who won fame during the rollicking 1920's for parlaying her knockout looks into a string of rich lovers and husbands. Her forays into stage acting and films were embarrassments, but her tally of generous males -- among them Charlie Chaplin and Walter Chrysler -- was thought to be record-breaking, at least by the day's tabloids. 
 She was a barber's daughter from Virginia who not long after arriving in New York in 1915 won deification by Florenz Ziegfeld. In the grand "Follies"-girl tradition, she was besieged by wealthy suitors and found that she liked men almost as much as they liked her. At a time when virility was measured by the cost of a suitor's gifts, Joyce soon learned that her favorite pastime could be highly remunerative.
The basic economic equation on which she operated was simplicity itself and was examined fully in the Jule Styne-Leo Robin song, "Diamonds Are a Girl's Best Friend." (Anita Loos's Lorelei Lee, the character for whom this song was written, was inspired by Joyce.) After a few lines on the subject, however, we get the idea, but Constance Rosenblum, editor of the City section of The New York Times, has written a full-length biography, inspired, we learn, by the discovery of a carton of Joyce's papers and memorabilia.
Ms. Rosenblum deftly sets up Joyce's erotic magnetism and her flaunting of the rigid morals of the day, when even a twice-married woman was looked upon with disapproval if not scorn. Interestingly, she places Joyce in the context of the great courtesans of the French court (she got less respect, but then Walter Chrysler was no Louis XIV) and compares her to our own day's repeater brides. The reader is ready to become acquainted with a mores-defying free spirit, to tag along on romantic adventures, to encounter some of the day's more diverting luminaries -- in short, to enjoy a romp through the Jazz Age in the company of one of its liveliest figures. Unfortunately, very little of this happens.
In spite of acknowledgments that run four pages, the book has few interviews with people who knew Joyce, and most of those who are interviewed did not know her well. Even Joyce's last husband, whom Ms. Rosenblum thanks for being "helpful," has little to say: no hint of her personality or how they spent the six years before she died in 1957. Even the book-prompting carton of memorabilia is a disappointing mishmash of notes from friends, bills from florists, postcards from love-sick suitors and gossip-column clippings. While those odds and ends suggest the outlines of a life, they also establish that as a conserver of biographical documents, Peggy Joyce was no Boswell.
For its picture of Joyce, the book relies most heavily on mentions in tabloid columns or on other dubious sources like Photoplay magazine and the scandal primer "Hollywood Babylon." Ms. Rosenblum culls anecdotes from Joyce's own memoirs, more often than not adding that the stories are probably untrue.
For the most part, the public persona is all we get, but even here the book falls short. There are numerous references to Joyce's "outrageous" behavior and statements to the press, but when we are presented with illustrations, they land with a thud. An example of her outre behavior tells us that when answering her phone Joyce often disguised her voice as a French maid's. Another divulges that new boyfriends were told by Joyce that a half-knitted wool scarf that she kept around for years was undertaken for them. Readers primed for the gin-soaked debaucheries of the Roaring Twenties might have hoped for a bit more. Banal as these stories are, such glimpses of Joyce in action are scarce.
Her shockers to the press are equally low-voltage. A typical example was when she was asked by reporters about the assets of the family of a Swedish count she was about to marry. Joyce told them: "I do not think they have much besides the castle. However, a castle is something after all." And later, discussing her husband's nobility (a term Ms. Rosenblum worryingly uses interchangeably with "royalty") , Joyce says: "I could have done better than countess. I could have been a princess or something." While endearingly crass, these statements are less than outrageous.
In an effort to evoke the glamour of Joyce's world, Ms. Rosenblum makes frequent mention of well-known figures of the day like Eddie Cantor, W. C. Fields and Al Jolson, but in linking these names with her heroine falls back on phrases like "rubbed elbows with." If Joyce interacted with any of these notables, we are not to know. An egregious example of such teasing is an account of Joyce's friction with her "Follies"-girl colleagues that grew so acrimonious that Ziegfeld removed her to the dressing room of Fanny Brice. Hopes that we have at last hit pay dirt are dashed when the animosity is improbably explained as jealousy over Joyce's being given a line. Although Joyce became friends with Brice, we are offered only two quick glimpses of that legend.
It was well known that Joyce did more than brush up against Charlie Chaplin, but even the few pages devoted to this romantic interlude prove disappointing. Ms. Rosenblum tells of "a private frolic" that Joyce and Chaplin enjoyed on an isolated beach during which the couple was spied from a distance through the binoculars of some locals. The stillborn anecdote seems to encapsulate some of the problems with this book: the scene is viewed from a distance by anonymous peeping Toms unknown to Joyce, it is given only a few cursory lines and we are denied the revealing details, both biographical and prurient, that would seem essential to a book about a woman who possessed, finally, just one talent.
We are frequently reminded of how famous Joyce was, how the public's interest in her was insatiable and how she was a fixture, in furs and jewels, at the most exciting nightclubs and openings, even turning up in the lyrics of Irving Berlin and Cole Porter as the day's symbol of the naughty madcap. But the reiteration of her notoriety lends a defensive, flap-copy tone to the biography, suggesting that the author shares readers' misgivings about her subject's book-worthiness. A more up-close and revealing book about Peggy Hopkins Joyce might have been fun to read, but there is little in this one to make us think so.

HEADLINE: Life in the Slow Lane;
Rural Residents Are Frustrated by Sluggish Web Access and a Scarcity of Local Information Online

BYLINE: By CATHERINE GREENMAN 

 BODY:
ALTHOUGH Debbie Wintz often surfs the Internet in the evenings, much of that time is actually spent folding clothes, feeding the cat or tidying up the kitchen.
Ms. Wintz, a real estate agent who lives in Pryor, Okla., about 40 miles northeast of Tulsa, uses a standard dial-up modem to connect through her local Internet service provider. The connection is never very fast -- 33 kilobits per second at most, although she has a 56K modem -- and at night it often slows to a crawl. So Ms. Wintz occupies herself with other tasks until a Web page with a few links and pop-up messages finally appears on her screen. 
 Like millions of other Americans, Ms. Wintz craves a faster Internet connection. But unlike millions of urban and suburban Americans, Ms. Wintz is stuck with dial-up service because there are no other choices in Pryor, population 8,300.
While high-speed options like cable modems and D.S.L. (digital subscriber line) service are becoming increasingly available in populous areas, Ms. Wintz and other residents of more isolated communities are stuck in low gear, limited by the capabilities of local providers, which in turn rely on local phone networks to transmit data. For her and other rural Americans, the much-touted promise of a high-speed Internet seems as far off as the East or West Coast.
"I understand that it's about profits," Ms. Wintz said, "but I feel like we're being discriminated against. How come we always have to be last?"
Broadband technologies like D.S.L. and cable modem service have been slow to reach rural America. According to a report issued last month by the Department of Commerce, the percentage of towns with fewer than 10,000 people that have access to D.S.L. service from their regional phone companies is closer to zero than 1. But that number is 86 percent for cities with more than 100,000 residents. About 1 percent of towns with fewer than 10,000 people had cable modem service, compared with 72 percent of cities with more than 250,000 residents.
Even though some people who have tried to get high-speed access, particularly D.S.L., have been frustrated by poor service and other problems, people in rural areas would at least like to have the choice.
The scarcity of high-speed connections is not the only complaint among rural Internet users. News and information about rural areas is often difficult to find online. It can be far easier to find the address of every coffee bar in Seattle, say, than the hours of the local library in a small town in rural eastern Washington. And rural residents who use national I.S.P.'s like America Online or EarthLink often find themselves paying toll charges to call access numbers.
"If you're looking for free local access, you're better off going with a small local I.S.P.," said Laura Kelso, co-founder of Ubundle.com, a company that lets consumers customize their Internet and telecommunications services. "Even America Online has a lot of areas where it's going to be a long distance call to dial up." Most big providers, she said, lack the necessary Internet connection points, known as points of presence, to cover rural areas.
But above all, slow Internet transmissions and crowded phone networks are the biggest frustrations for many people in rural areas.
David Haskin, a journalist in Barneveld, Wis., noticed how slow his dial-up connection became when he moved 35 miles out of Madison, Wisc., to Barneveld. The move also coincided with his getting a job as a Web content producer.
"You don't want to be a Webmaster with a slow modem connection," he said. "When I lived in Madison, I could get a 56K connection, but in the country, the calls have to go through central office switches so everything slows down."
Bob Holton, who lives in Fort Gibson, Okla., and works in nearby Muskogee, said he could not call his office between 8 p.m. and 10 p.m. because the phone lines in his area were tied up by young people on the Internet. "The bottom line is that the infrastructure is old and noisy," he said, "and the issues to fix it are cost and amortization of the equipment. It leaves me and everyone else in the area just dying."
Mr. Holton, who uses Azalea.net, a local I.S.P., also has an AOL account for e-mail, but he has to dial a number in Tulsa -- a long-distance call -- to gain access.
The problems of Internet access in rural areas are attracting the attention of the Federal Communications Commission. Linda Kinney, assistant chief of the common carrier bureau, said the agency planned a survey this summer to determine whether rural areas were being properly served.
Many of the larger telephone companies say they are working to increase local dial-up access. "It's been a part of our strategy to continue reaching into smaller calling areas," said Rich Jeffers, a spokesman for Bell South, which covers nine southeastern states. Mr. Jeffers said Bell South's Internet service, BellSouth.net, was available to more than 80 percent of its customers through a local call. "Our goal is to get it to 100 percent," he said.
Trish Primrose, a spokeswoman for AOL, said the company offered consumers who could not dial in to the service with a local number an alternative plan in which they could sign up with local I.S.P.'s and connect to AOL through their I.S.P.'s at a reduced rate of $9.95 per month.
In the last few years, many rural communities have connected to the Internet through small local I.S.P.'s that sprang up to fill a need. The local I.S.P. is the only access available for a toll-free call in many areas because the larger I.S.P.'s have opted not to invest in the installation of network equipment in those areas.
John Nunn, for example, started Twin County Internet Access, an I.S.P., in 1996 because he and his neighbors in Galax, Va., in the southwest corner of the state, were paying long-distance charges for access to I.S.P.'s like AOL and Netcom.
Mr. Nunn was also frustrated because there was little local information online. Mr. Nunn's I.S.P. provided local users with links to Virginia newspapers and even had its own advice column, "Ask the Blonde," written by a local schoolteacher. (He has since sold the I.S.P. to NetAccess, a regional I.S.P.)
But as broadband D.S.L. and cable Internet access spreads to metropolitan areas and suburbs, rural I.S.P.'s that were started to provide basic dial-up service find that they cannot meet the demand for faster access. Instead, they are usually forced to wait until their local phone networks or cable companies decide that their markets are worth the investment.
The Mendocino Community Network, an I.S.P. in Mendocino, Calif., with about 5,000 customers, was built in part to foster economic growth in the community, which is about 125 miles north of San Francisco.
The Mendocino Community Network provides community residents with 150 hours of local dial-up access for $19.95 per month, and it donates I.S.P. services to local nonprofit organizations. The I.S.P. also functions as an active community service, featuring local news and events on its Web page and sending out electronic newsletters from movie theater and store owners. But without broadband Internet access, the community is at a disadvantage, said the network's manager, Rennie Innis.
"One of the biggest complaints is the slow speed of the phone lines," Mr. Innis said. "D.S.L. or cable access would be a real gift because how you operate your business depends on what the technology will allow. It's not just about faster speeds -- it's about people living where they want to live and still maintaining an urban quality job."
D.S.L. service is limited to customers who live within about three miles of a telephone company central office, which is more of a problem in rural areas than in cities or suburbs. But D.S.L. providers say new technology will help ease the distance limitations before the end of the year.
"We'll break through those limitations, which will justify a further reach into rural areas from an economic standpoint," said Hank Carabelli, president and chief operating officer of @Link Networks, based in Louisville, Colo., which sells broadband services to regional I.S.P.'s and businesses.
Some broadband providers, like New Edge Networks and DSL.net, specialize in providing D.S.L. service to smaller markets through line-sharing agreements with local telephone companies and reseller agreements with local, regional and national I.S.P.'s. Although they are still in the testing stages, wireless technologies like multichannel multipoint distribution services and satellites are seen by some in the industry as effective ways to offer high-speed Internet access to rural areas without incurring the high costs of installing networks.
Sprint Broadband Wireless Group is test-marketing Sprint Broadband Direct in Phoenix, a multichannel multipoint service the company says is 36 times as fast as a regular dial-up connection. It relies on radio transmission rather than phone or cable lines, and it works with a two-way digital transceiver installed on a rooftop that is pointed toward a radio tower to send and receive signals. Although the service is designed to reach people who do not have D.S.L. or cable access, it has a 35-mile limit, which does not help many rural residents.
Some people in rural areas are hopeful about satellite technology, which does not pose the same distance limitations as other broadband solutions. Hughes Network Systems, which has about 8.5 million subscribers on its DirectTV satellite service, said it expected to add two-way high-speed Internet access later this year. "We discovered we could hit a low cost for this two-way terminal and offer it to consumers for about the same cost as a dial-up account," said Paul Gaske, executive vice president of the Consumer Division at Hughes. Prices have not been announced.
The two-way transmission will work with an antenna that transmits and receives satellite data. Downloading will run at 400K; uploading, 128K to 256K.
Regardless of what speeds are involved, larger I.S.P.'s have generally been slower than local and regional I.S.P.'s in building their networks to provide rural residents with local Internet access. There are a few larger I.S.P.'s, however, that are focusing specifically on rural markets.
For the past two years, for example, OneMain.com, based in Reston, Va., has been acquiring small, local I.S.P.'s, in addition to building Internet connection points in rural areas, in an effort to become the leading national I.S.P. for rural communities. "In 65 percent of the rural markets, you can't access America Online with a local phone call," said Stephen E. Smith, chairman and chief executive of One Main. "We think there's a lot of growth potential because they've been largely ignored."
OneMain.com also designs its I.S.P. affiliates as local portals and tailors contentgeographically, through agreements with local newspapers and merchants. "People don't want to dial up from Bakersfield, Calif., and read information about Roanoke, Va.," Mr. Smith said. "We built our networks around geographical content, which is what the larger I.S.P.'s can't do because they've outsourced nationwide networks."
Mr. Smith said One Main had 800,000 customers and planned to provide Internet access to more than 65 markets by the end of this year. Many of OneMain affiliates will also offer D.S.L. access, Mr. Smith said.
Another I.S.P., OneWorldOnline.com, based in Provo, Utah, offers potential users cash incentives to persuade other people in the area to fill out forms saying they will sign up once a local connection is established. When a local I.S.P. affiliate is established, the original customer gets $25 for each subscriber the customer signed up for the service. "Our rural approach has been to go and identify the customers first, then go and put a point of presence in," said David Nemelka, chief executive of OneWorldOnline.com.
ISP Channel, a subsidiary of SoftNet Systems, a broadband Internet access company based in San Francisco, is entering into partnerships with smaller cable television operators to provide rural areas with broadband Internet service via cable networks. Customers who sign up with ISP Channel buy or lease cable modems, which are connected to their home cable service. Each customer's modem sends data to the cable operator, where ISP Channel provides a connection via high-speed telephone lines to the Internet. Downloading speeds average 500K, and uploading speeds average about 100K, according to ISP Channel's president, Jonathan Marx.
ISP Channel also provides Web-building services to cable operators who want to build local Web sites. "A lot of other I.S.P.'s have national content, but we provide local," said Larry Brilliant, chief executive of SoftNet Systems, ISP Channel's parent company. "We've found that people really like to do business locally and to know who they're working with."
Mr. Marx said ISP Channel had agreements to reach 2.4 million homes in 22 states. It is available in parts of California, Arizona, Mississippi and Florida. But the service will not benefit rural residents who do not already have cable service.
Even if problems of low-speed access are solved, however, people in smaller communities could still local information hard to find online. But several companies, including Streetmail.com and Koz.com, are working with smaller I.S.P.'s to fix that.
Streetmail.com, based in Waltham, Mass., for example, hires correspondents in small communities around the country and has a central editing group at its headquarters to produce local newsletters, which it then puts out with local I.S.P.'s. A recent newsletter for Cape Lookout, N.C., for example, included an opinion poll about what the local drawbridge's hours of operation should be.
"Many small I.S.P.'s have wanted this kind of thing but aren't organized enough to create editorial content," said Barbara Johnson, chief executive of StreetMail. "We've used the Internet to connect in all kinds of ways around the globe. We're only now turning to connect ourselves to where we live."

HEADLINE: ESSAY;
New Front in the Copyright Wars: Out-of-Print Computer Games

BYLINE: By GREG COSTIKYAN; Greg Costikyan designs games, consults on game industry business issues and writes science fiction and articles about games.

 BODY:
THE phrase "software pirate" conjures up images of foreign sweatshops mass-copying software or hackers swapping files. But the Interactive Digital Software Association is trying to shut down a different type of pirate: people who just want to play out-of-print games.
Publishers don't want to make old games available. The market wants games that push the limits of the processing and graphics capabilities of modern computers; a game designed for the Atari 800 or Apple II just won't sell at CompUSA. 
 But at more than 100 sites on the Internet, you can download old out-of-print games, along with emulators to let you run them -- the games include the original versions of Atari 2600 games like Missile Command and Space Invaders as well as landmark computer games like M.U.L.E. and Balance of Power. These sites call the games abandonware: software for which publishers no longer offer technical support.
Of course, the publishers don't view the games as abandoned. "Copyrights and trademarks of games are corporate assets," Nintendo says on its Web site. "If these vintage titles are available far and wide, it undermines the value of the intellectual property and adversely affects the right owners. Emulator and ROM piracy is competing head-on with Nintendo's current systems and software."(ROM piracy is the copying of game code from the old read-only memory chips into files that can be stored on a computer.) So Nintendo and other companies want abandonware sites to shut down -- they leave enforcement to the software association.
Their position is highly debatable. Gamers don't go out and download games for the original Nintendo Entertainment System instead of buying new games for Nintendo 64. Someone who wants to play an older game is looking for an experience that is different from what is available from a modern game. And by keeping older games alive, abandonware sites sometimes serve the ultimate interests of publishers: a new version of Frogger (first released in 1981) was one of the Top 10 best-selling computer games in 1999. Publishers became interested in re-releasing titles like Frogger precisely because they noticed that people were still playing it. Abandonware helped them identify a new market niche.
Moreover, publishers provide no legal way for gamers to get older games; the market is too small to justify the effort. So gamers feel justified in making vintage games available, despite the legal risks.
Older gamers' enthusiasm for games of their youth is only part of the story. In a speech at the Game Developers Conference in May in San Jose, Calif., Henry Jenkins, director of the comparative media studies program at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, called electronic gaming one of the "lively arts for the 21st century." He said that just as once-despised arts like jazz and film were now accepted as legitimate, so, too, would games be someday.
If Dr. Jenkins is right, if gaming is ever to be understood as an art form that is worthy of study and has valuable things to offer, critics and academics and gamers must come to appreciate the history and development of the form. That appreciation can be created and sustained only if they have access to the games of the past.
Access to vintage games is important for game designers, too. Just as novelists learn from novels and artists from art, game designers learn technique from the games they play.
Their design repertory is expanded through exposure to games, but far too many game designers are ignorant of games published more than five years ago. That is especially a problem now because the hit-driven, me-too nature of the current market means that there is far less variety in the industry than there was even a few years ago. There is no way a company would pay to produce a game like Balance of Power, a serious simulation of international political dynamics by Chris Crawford; M.U.L.E., a nonviolent economic game by Dani Bunten; or the original SimCity, by Will Wright (all best sellers in their day), because those games don't fit into accepted marketing categories.
"Preserving old computer games isn't about sentimentality or retro trendiness or collectibility," said Richard Carlson, a game developer at Rogue Entertainment, in an e-mail message. "It's about the history of art, storytelling, music, animation, programming, level design and all of the other disciplines involved in making classic game entertainment."
A book printed on acid-free paper will last for centuries. Film stock will last for decades, but even so, many early movies have been lost forever. Game preservation is in worse shape. Hardware and operating systems come and go. If you have a game designed for an Apple II, you will have a hard time figuring out how to run it.
Software is about as ephemeral as you can get, yet preserving it is essential. Illegal abandonware sites are providing a critical service to game designers and scholars and gaming enthusiasts. They do not, however, provide a lasting and satisfactory solution to the problem because they are illegal.
There may be another way. A group called the Electronic Conservancy has periodically mounted a museum exhibition called "Videotopia," which last appeared in 1999 at the Maryland Science Museum.
"Videotopia" consists of 75 old and new arcade game machines, along with historical and background material. The Electronic Conservancy is devoted to preserving and maintaining these machines, and its advisory board consists of some of the most prominent figures in the development of the arcade game industry.
Arcade gaming, however, is now about one-eighth the size of the combined console and computer gaming industries. It has stagnated for more than a decade.
No one is doing anything similar to preserve console and computer games. And doing so through a museum exhibition or physical collection would be pointless; the way to offer these games to the largest possible audience is the way the abandonware movement does it: via the Web, providing emulators to allow people with new computers and consoles to play the original code. Ideally, you would do it one better, however: you would do it legally, with a Web site and with information to help people install and play the games.
Call it Gamemuseum.org. Create it as a nonprofit organization offering software that enables people to play out-of-print games -- with the permission of the owners. Publishers could offer older products at no cost to themselves, and scholars, designers and fans of retro games could gain access.
Even if a publisher developed a new version of an older game, the older version could serve, in a sense, as a demo for the new one. Players of the old version would be very likely to search out and buy the updated, superior version.
Such a project would require financing, of course, but probably not much. The enthusiasm that leads to abandonware sites could be harnessed, providing volunteer labor to build and maintain the online museum.
It would take an energetic person from the nonprofit sector to raise the money and build the organization, of course. But surely the effort would be worthwhile.
Any takers?
 
http://www.nytimes.com

LENGTH: 1757 words

HEADLINE: Helping Paterson Get Better Grades in Urban Renewal

BYLINE: By WILLIAM L. HAMILTON 

 BODY:
"TREES. I would like to add trees," reads the legend on a simple map of a street in Paterson, N.J., drawn in colored pencil by a freshman high school student, Leon White, who lives on it. Green trees have been swirled onto the black and white street like the rotations of a wand.
Urban solutions can be this simple -- so simple, in fact, that a child can create them. 
 Through an ambitious plan called the City of Learning, Paterson, a city of 170,000, is giving public high school students not only the tools to understand its urban problems, but also the chance to solve them.
Leon White is enrolled at the Metro Paterson Academy for Communications and Technology, or Mpact, a new public school established in September in an empty downtown mall, where open-classroom walls are papered with student projects: urban renewal studies and school construction proposals.
Mpact is a pilot in a program of innovative academies that offer specialized curricula and smaller classes. Started by Manhattan's Center for Innovative Education, they are being tested in other cities. In Paterson, the academies are also being proposed as tools for urban renewal in an economically distressed city with a school performance so poor that the district was taken over by the state in 1991.
Anticipating $500 million to $800 million in state money to build new school facilities, Dr. Edwin Duroy, the state-appointed superintendent of schools, realized that improving schools was meaningless if the struggling city was ignored. His budget represented Paterson's largest potential capital investment. Why not use it to rescue the schools and try rehabilitating the city at the same time? And put students at the center of the equation by teaching them city planning -- at school.
The opportunity demanded vision. Dr. Duroy invited urban designers from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, with experience in school districts from Berkeley, Calif., to Washington, D.C., to develop a master plan for Paterson's schools and its 25,000 students.
The New American School Design Project, a workshop of graduate students at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology led by Roy Strickland, an architect, developed a concept called the City of Learning -- an expanding system of academies throughout Paterson that would spark investment in neighborhoods, especially a sorely vacant, turn-of-the-century downtown.
By September, seven academies will be in operation.
In an election year, when the nature of education and the fate of cities are being debated at a national level, Paterson is putting the American high school on Main Street. Mpact is at number 175. At the school, which opened last September with a freshman class of 25, students study college preparatory subjects like mathematics and history in the morning and technology, entrepreneurship and urban planning in the afternoon. It is an extended day, ending at 4 p.m. Visited recently, students were still working at 6.
Posted in the classroom where urban planning is taught is a list of "Existing Conditions" in Paterson, identified by students. They include "railroad tracks," "crackheads," "parking lots," "lost treasures" and "discarded clothing": a stream of consciousness from its younger citizens that runs like the Passaic River and its treacherous falls, through the heart of the city.
"We live here; nobody knows it better than us," Kemesha Pringle, 14, said.
Her classmate, Maurice Moore, 14, said, "Now, we've got a responsibility to give people what they want."
On June 14, the class will present its first proposal to the Board of Education: a plan to replace a faculty parking lot between two schools with an educational park for the community. Their proposals include a food court (the children complained about the cafeteria lunch), a swimming pool (the community asked for it), an arcade for games after school and a tent for reading during the summer -- improvements to school property that a school budget theoretically would pay for.
Javier Mendez, 15, said that his work improving Paterson with planning was important because "it's my home."
In "stepping outside the box," as Dr. Duroy called beyond-the-classroom steps like Mpact and the City of Learning, Paterson hopes to move toward smaller, more personal learning environments, which are now widely acknowledged as improving performance. Paterson hopes smaller classes will combat the dropout rate, which exceeded 15 percent in the 1998-99 school year. The state average was 2.9 percent.
"Many eighth graders choose not to go to the high schools, but to vocational schools," Dr. Duroy said. "Recognizing this, I felt we needed to become competitive. We needed to bring alternative choices to parents."
The academies are being created to compete. Applications to Mpact, which is choosing its second freshman class of 25 now, have doubled because of word-of-mouth between parents.
The anticipated budget is Paterson's share of a 1998 New Jersey Supreme Court decision requiring the state to dedicate billions of dollars to school construction in 28 low-income districts.
The New Jersey Senate will vote today on a proposal to put the Economic Development Agency in charge of school construction, a plan that Gov. Christine Todd Whitman supports, said Gregg Edwards, executive director of the Senate.
"The sponsors of the bill want towns to think creatively about what school money can be used to do, and that's just what Paterson is talking about," he said. "Paterson is looking at the money as part of an economic development strategy. The Economic Development Agency will be more sympathetic to the sort of things Paterson wants to do."
But James W. Hughes, dean of the Edward J. Bloustein School of Planning and Public Policy at Rutgers University, questioned the ability of schools to act as economic engines in a city.
"I'm trying to think of what they'll achieve beyond bailing out property owners," he said, explaining that putting schools in vacant, downtown buildings was not the invitation to commercial development that placing businesses would be. And, he added, "there's not that much buying power to support retail facilities."
Tom Lonreghan, executive director of the Special Improvement District in Paterson, a coalition of local businesses and property owners, said of the academies' new downtown: "We do feel the schools have had a positive impact -- the added presence of hundreds of students and teachers. But as for bringing in higher-end business like Starbucks, I haven't seen that impact."
Will Paterson take its student planners seriously?
Partnerships with institutions like M.I.T. and Lucent Technologies, which is working with Stephen Cohen, the school district's technology planner, to wire the City of Learning with Internet-access cable for every school in Paterson, has gotten the city's attention.
"That these are ideas being generated by kids doesn't undermine the fact that they are bright ideas that have merit," said William McKoy, president of the Board of Education, who was elected to the Paterson City Council last week on a platform promoting Paterson as the City of Learning.
"They're training and thinking with good institutions," he said. "The collaboration is meaningful to the city -- it's not Monopoly."
At Mpact, the students have already developed their own mass-transit system: rolling desk chairs that speed them from desk to desk, across the plaza of the classroom, to confer on projects. The plan for the laboratory is a Socratic circle; there are no rows or lecterns.
Jean Riesman, an instructor with an M.I.T. master's degree in city planning, is developing Mpact's first year of programs, which include working with the class on converting a municipal parking lot into a civic center and park, with schools, malls and a transportation hub for a proposed light-rail link to New York.
Like any planning session, the discussion, chaired by Ms. Riesman, a woman in black jeans and wide-heeled boots with a salt-and-pepper ponytail, came down to what Paterson had, what it didn't have and what it could have as a place to live.
"Everybody wanted stores," LaToya Matthews, 14, said. "Old Navy, Gap. But then we had to stop and think: That's going to take away business from the stores that are here. We don't want to put them out of business. So there had to be some sort of collaboration."
Marilyn Medina, 15, said that she thought people living downtown would encourage businesses to open.
"You see the building across the street?" she asked, turning to the classroom window behind her. Above an open store, the building was empty. "There's just a bunch of junk in there. We would like to turn the old buildings into apartments, because there are a lot of apartments needed in Paterson, with more living space."
Ruth Melecio, 15, qualified the idea. "Not change the outside, just the inside," she said. "We have some really nice buildings. We want to keep those in Paterson, so it's not like everywhere else."
As a group, the students agreed that there should be recreational facilities and entertainment at the city-center site, which are lacking now.
"Not only for us, but for younger kids growing up, too," Kemesha Pringle said. "We're trying to change things so that they could have a better life or experience different things that aren't here."
Ruth Melecio interviewed her family. "I asked my mom what she thinks would go nicely downtown," Ms. Melecio said. "She said, 'Oh, a movie theater, a bowling alley.' I brought that in, and everyone said, 'Oh yeah, I didn't think about that.' "
With no theater of its own, Paterson moviegoers travel to Passaic and Clifton.
More citizen than city official, Leon White, 14, proposed the obvious.
"All the movie theaters that aren't being used, that are just collecting dust," he said, speaking of several shuttered theaters downtown, "maybe they should try reopening them."
LaToya Matthews added: "When a movie comes out, everybody talks about going that Saturday night. Why can't they go in their own town?" She also advocated a skating rink. "When a D.J. from Paterson wants to throw a party, we have to go all the way to Wayne," she said.
Maurice Moore, 14, made an observation that could help him in an election, if he pursues his participation in the city. "If we had all this stuff that we want," he said, "it would be stuff that would attract tourism. People would come in, spend money and leave."
The adults led the class in appreciative laughter.

HEADLINE: Paul Bartel, Director and Star Of 'Eating Raoul,' Dies at 61

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE VAN GELDER 

 BODY:
Paul BartelPaul Bartel, a director, screenwriter and actor whose taste for farce, black humor and social satire was reflected in films like "Eating Raoul," "Death Race 2000" and "Scenes From the Class Struggle in Beverly Hills," died on Saturday at his home in Manhattan. He was 61 and also had a home in Los Angeles.
The cause was not immediately determined, said his father, William, who added that Mr. Bartel had undergone eight hours of surgery two weeks ago for cancer of the liver ducts. 
 Mr. Bartel, whose love affair with movies began in his childhood, last appeared as Osric in the filmmaker Michael Almereyda's new corporate setting of "Hamlet," and at the time of his death was engaged in discussions with a British producing group about a new film and had also been asked to write episodes of a new television series.
"He was interested in theatrics from Day 1," his father said as he traced Mr. Bartel's life from childhood marionettes to theater and film studies and to a long career in directing, writing and acting, particularly in independent films.
Mr. Bartel, in later years a heavyset man with a white beard, achieved his greatest acclaim in 1982, when his "Eating Raoul" was chosen for the 20th New York Film Festival.
"One has to be careful not to overstate the case when praising 'Eating Raoul,' " Vincent Canby wrote in his review in The New York Times. "One mustn't blunt its pleasures by calling it a laff riot. It is full of smiles, punctuated here and there by marvelously unseemly guffaws, but most of the time it works its little wonders quietly. The comic style is purposely flat, plain and ordinary, like a piece of Pop art."
Mr. Bartel was not only the director and co-writer of "Eating Raoul." He was also its co-star, joining Mary Woronov in their portrayal of a married couple, Paul and Mary Bland, who like nice things, share a belief that sex is dirty and have the misfortune to live in a Los Angeles apartment house inhabited mostly by swingers. The Blands also share a dream. In time, the prissy Paul, who fancies himself a wine connoisseur, will quit his job in a liquor store, and the sexually charged Mary will leave her job as a hospital dietitian and they will open their own restaurant in the country.
One day when a drunk swinger, looking for an orgy in the building, invades their apartment and attempts to rape Mary, Paul hits him over the head with a cast iron skillet and kills him. The Blands, who have fallen on hard economic times, empty his wallet and dispose of his body.
They quickly realize they have found a path to fortune: advertise in the underground press, lure swingers to their apartment, dispatch them with the skillet, rob them and toss the bodies in the garbage compactor, all with a clear conscience.
As Paul sees it, the victims are "horrible, sex-crazed perverts that nobody will miss anyway." But life grows complicated when Raoul, a young Chicano locksmith with a passion for Mary, attempts to share in their scheme.
As Mr. Bartel recalled afterward, "I was sitting on the terrace of the Carlton Hotel in Cannes, sipping a $7 coffee," when Richard Roud, then the director of the New York Film Festival and chairman of its program committee, "came strolling down the Croisette, casually glanced in my direction and turned thumbs up."
Mr. Roud was signaling that Mr. Bartel's $500,000 black comedy had been chosen for the festival, where it was to charm the critics and win their praise. "I felt enormous elation and relief." Mr. Bartel said.
"Eating Raoul" was not his first film at the festival. "The Secret Cinema," a 30-minute film about a New York secretary for whom everybody's paranoid fantasy becomes a reality, was shown in 1967. Mr. Canby called it "a very funny, completely lunatic experience."
Among the films Mr. Bartel directed -- and sometimes acted in or co-wrote -- were "Cannonball" (1976), "Not for Publication" (1984) and "Lust in the Dust" (1985). As an actor he appeared in everything from "Eat My Dust" (1976) and "Rock 'n' Roll High School" (1979) to "White Dog" (1982), "Heart Like a Wheel" (1983), "National Lampoon's European Vacation" (1985), "Shelf Life" (1993), "The Usual Suspects" (1995) and "Basquiat" (1996).
Mr. Bartel, the eldest of the two sons and two daughters of William and Jesse Bartel, who died five weeks ago, was born in Brooklyn and grew up in Manhattan and Montclair, N.J. William Bartel said Paul was 4 or 5 when "he started out with a marionette show, strung them and built himself a little stage. He really didn't worry too much about learning to articulate the marionettes, but he was great on the dialogue."
By the time he was a student at Montclair High School, he had persuaded his father to buy him a 16-millimeter German-made motion picture camera and, in the words of his father, "proceeded to con" a teacher into allowing him to devote a semester to making an animated cartoon, doing the main drawings himself and using the class to do the "in-betweens," which required 3,000 cels, the transparent sheets on which the original drawings are traced or transferred.
Mr. Bartel, who was fluent in French and Italian, studied theater and film at U.C.L.A. and won a Fulbright scholarship that took him to Rome and the Cinecitta studio. He fulfilled his military service by talking his way into the Army Signal Corps Pictorial Center in Long Island City and later made films for the United States Information Agency. By the early 1970's, he was making films in Hollywood.
Besides his father, of Delray Beach, Fla., and Bay Head, N.J., he is survived by two sisters, Lucy Kizirian of Tallahassee, Fla., and Wendy Bartel of Bay Head, N.J., and a brother, Peter of Floyd, Va.,

HEADLINE: Harry J. Volk, 94, a Bank Executive Known for Innovations

BYLINE: By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH 

 BODY:
Harry J. Volk, a finance executive whose impact was felt as much in the world of philanthropy as in business, died at his Los Angeles home on Friday, according to his son Robert. He was 94.
During a financial career that spanned more than three decades, he showed little patience for the idea that the status quo was right just because it was the status quo. 
 As a vice president of the Prudential Insurance Company of America in the mid-1940's, for example, he helped mastermind the company's huge decentralization program. The revamping took him to Los Angeles in 1947, where he opened Prudential's first regional home office. While he was there, he also introduced the concept of family life insurance plans.
Later, as chairman of the Union Bank of California -- a job he was recruited from Prudential to fill in 1957 -- he helped bring about new offerings like daily compounding of interest and banking by mail, which were radical for the time. It was Mr. Volk who spotted the loophole in federal laws that made it possible for banks to form holding companies, and in 1967 he established the country's first one-bank holding company, Union Bancorp Inc.
While other banks were trying to broaden their customer base, Mr. Volk successfully steered Union through the recession of the 1970's by keeping it focused on lending to small and medium-size businesses. And, at a time when bankers generally considered marketing beneath them, Mr. Volk marketed Union aggressively to those target customers.
It was a lesson that many of his employees spread to other banks. "Most bankers had the idea, you sit there and customers come in and you sort of judge them," Carl E. Reichardt, a former Union Bank executive who was chairman of Wells Fargo from 1983 through 1994, said in 1989. "Harry said that was all wrong -- that you had to go out and drag them in."
Not all of Mr. Volk's innovations served Union well. He took Union into insurance and mortgage banking, only to have California regulators insist that it pull out of those enterprises in 1975. The bank never quite regained its vibrant growth. Many of its higher-level executives departed, and many of the bank's business customers followed them to their new employers. Union Bank was taken over by Standard Chartered Bank Ltd. of London in 1979. Mr. Volk retired a year later.
Mr. Volk never confined his taste for innovation and activism to the financial world. If it had anything to do with California, it interested him. He was an active board member of several California companies, including Western Air Lines, Southern California Gas and Times Mirror. He was also a trustee of the California Institute of Technology, a board member of the Los Angeles branch of the Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco and president of the Los Angeles Clearing House Association.
He also plunged into the Los Angeles philanthropic world. He headed a committee that looked into disputes between the United Way and some of its recipient charities. Soon after, he created a system that allowed employers to funnel payroll deductions to charities designated by individual employees. The system is now widely used, and, by giving donors more of a say in where their contributions went, was a linchpin of the United Way's revamped methods for collecting and distributing money.
Mr. Volk was a prime mover in rebuilding Los Angeles's historic Bunker Hill. And he helped found many cultural institutions, including the Music Center (now the Performing Arts Center of Los Angeles County) and the Los Angeles County Museum of Art. While still at Union Bank, he was a board member of the Southern California Symphony Association and the Boys Club Foundation.
After he retired from the bank in 1980 he became head of the Weingart Foundation, a California charitable organization with $155 million in assets. By the time Mr. Volk retired from the foundation in 1993, its assets had plumped up to more than $500 million.
In 1987, when Union Bank became one of the first banks in the country to offer child care as an employee benefit, it named its day care center the Volk Center.
Mr. Volk's love of all things Californian notwithstanding, he hailed from the opposite coast. He was born in Trenton, and earned degrees in business and law from Rutgers University.
Mr. Volk's first wife, Marion, whom he married in 1931, died in 1972. He is survived by his second wife, the actress Marjorie Lord; two sons from his first marriage, Robert, of Los Angeles, and Richard, of San Francisco; 2 stepchildren; 9 grandchildren; and 12 great-grandchildren.

HEADLINE: WORLD BRIEFING

BYLINE: Compiled by Terence Neilan

 BODY:

MIDDLE EAST
 
PALESTINIANS: CLASHES CONTINUE -- Sporadic clashes between young Palestinians and Israeli troops continued in the West Bank and near Jewish settlements in the Gaza Strip. Israeli soldiers fired tear gas and rubber bullets at protesters who threw stones and firebombs; they also reported that Israeli posts had been fired upon and that they responded with live fire. Deborah Sontag (NYT)
 
ISRAEL: TYING UP BARAK -- Two opposition bills that could tie Prime Minister Ehud Barak's hands in negotiations with the Palestinians passed preliminary votes, although both require three more readings to become law. They would require absolute majority approval of the Parliament to change the municipal boundaries of Jerualem and to allow the right of return of Palestinian refugees to Israel. Deborah Sontag (NYT) 

ISRAEL: UNCERTAIN WELCOME -- A Palestinian legislator said eggs were thrown at President Costas Stephanopoulos of Greece as he toured the walled Old City, to protest his position on Jerusalem. Greek and Israeli officials, however, adamantly denied the claim. "Not a single egg was thrown at the Greek president," said an indignant spokesman for the Israeli police. Deborah Sontag (NYT)
 
IRAN: JAILED FOR ATTACK -- A revolutionary court handed down a 15-year jail sentence to Said Asghar, a chemistry student accused of shooting a leading Iranian reformer, Said Hajarian, the official news agency reported. Four other defendants were sentenced to between 3 and 10 years for their role in the attack on Mr. Hajarian, who was in a coma for several days after the shooting. Three others were acquitted. (Agence France-Presse)
 
EUROPE
 
AUSTRIA: FORCED-LABOR ACCORD -- After a two-day conference attended by delegates from the United States, Austria and six eastern European countries, Austria agreed in principle to a $390 million compensation fund for Nazi-era forced laborers. The fund is to be distributed among 150,000 survivors, most in eastern Europe. A meeting on the "legal closure" of the accord will be held in Washington on May 30. Victor Homola (NYT)
 
YUGOSLAVIA: CLEARING THE DANUBE -- A plan to clear bomb wreckage that has blocked the Danube for more than a year has finally been agreed upon. The president of the Danube Commission in Budapest told Reuters that work on a $21 million plan is scheduled to begin in about five months. Three bridges in Novi Sad, Serbia, were bombed by NATO as part of the campaign to end the expulsion of Albanians from Kosovo. The wreckage of one bridge, the Varazdin, has blocked barge traffic ever since. Donald G. McNeil Jr. (NYT)
 
RUSSIA: NUCLEAR PACT APPROVED -- The upper house of Parliament voted after a secret debate to ratify the Comprehensive Nuclear Test Ban treaty, which the lower house ratified last month. While Russia has not conducted a nuclear test since 1990, it will officially forswear the tests only after the United States and a handful of other nuclear powers, including China, Pakistan and India, also approve it. The United States Senate rejected the treaty last year. Michael Wines (NYT)
 
THE AMERICAS
 
CANADA: ALBERTA WARNED -- Health Minister Alan Rock has threatened to withhold health funding from Alberta after it approved a law to allow overnight stays in private clinics, which Canadians fear might undercut the national health service monopoly. Mr. Rock also said he would double the budget for inspectors to check for violations of the Canada Health Act, which created the state monopoly for much health care. James Brooke (NYT)
 
COLOMBIA: DOUBTS ON BOMB -- The Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia may be innocent of the "necklace bomb" killing that prompted the government to cancel a key meeting with them, and overall peace talks have not been interrupted, a top government official said. Attorney General Alfonso Gomez said another group may have been responsible for strapping a bomb to the neck of a woman after raiding her country estate, contradicting President Andres Pastrana's certainty in blaming the rebels. (Agence France-Presse)
 
ASIA
 
SRI LANKA: BLAST KILLS 23 -- At least 23 people were killed by a bomb blast near a Buddhist temple in the eastern town of Batticola. The government blamed the Tamil Tigers for the attack, which occurred as the birth of the Buddha was being celebrated. Barry Bearak (NYT)
 
JAPAN: PREMIER'S APOLOGY -- Prime Minister Yoshiro Mori made a "heartfelt apology" for calling Japan a "divine country with an emperor at its core." Mr. Mori's comments, to a Shinto religious group, drew widespread criticism for violating the spirit of the postwar Constitution guaranteeing a secular state. Shinto was the official religion of wartime Japan, and the emperor was regarded as a deity. Howard W. French (NYT)
 
INDONESIA: NEW CLASHES -- At least 23 people were killed in new violence between Muslims and Christians in Ambon, in the Maluku islands, residents said. Twenty-one died when security forces opened fire to try to separate the warring mobs, they said. (Agence France-Presse)
 
AFRICA
 
ZAMBIA: KAUNDA BOWS OUT -- Kenneth D. Kaunda, left, the country's founding president, has handed over the leadership of the United National Independence Party, the main opposition party, to the former governor of the central bank, Francis Nkhoma, ending a political career that spanned more than four decades. Mr. Nkhoma, a 63-year old economist, beat eight other candidates. (Reuters)

HEADLINE: THE CHINA TRADE WRANGLE: THE SILICON LOBBY;
High-Tech Companies Making Their First Big Push in Congress on a Trade Bill

BYLINE: By LIZETTE ALVAREZ 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 17

 BODY:
Next week's Congressional vote on whether to expand trade and economic ties with China has high stakes for Beijing and the Clinton administration, but it is also a test of the political clout of the technology industry.
For the first time, technology companies are playing a leading role in Washington lobbying over a geopolitical issue. For several months, executives from Silicon Valley and other technology centers have been roaming the halls of Congress, lobbying for what they say will be billions of dollars of expanded exports to China as well as new jobs for Americans. 
 Whether to grant China permanent normal trade relations is going to be "the most important vote of this decade," said David McCurdy, a former Democratic member of Congress who is the president of Electronic Industries Alliance, a trade association. "The industry will support people who support high tech."
Nearly a dozen chief executives made the rounds again today. And a few companies have gone a step further, running radio and television advertisements and conducting grass-roots campaigns to nudge thousands of their employees to write letters and send electronic messages to lawmakers.
Although they are relative novices in the political arena, technology concerns are using big business and organized labor as models for how to press undecided members of Congress on the China bill. Their involvement is in contrast to the detachment they showed three years ago, when Congress decided not to give President Clinton authority to negotiate trade deals that Congress can accept or reject, but not amend.
Previously, high-tech companies lobbied most visibly on narrower issues, including Internet privacy, data scrambling and immigration. Microsoft has become a player in Washington's arena of money and politics, in part to protect its interests in the antitrust battle.
In the past, few high-tech companies had large lobbying presences in Washington. This time around, the industry has unleashed scores of lobbyists and has banded together in powerful coalitions.
At the same time, their trade associations are using the kind of hardball tactics, including advertising, that have served other industries well in other lobbying wars, working with the United States Chamber of Commerce, the agriculture sector and companies like Boeing, all experienced in past fights involving trade with China.
Frank Coleman, a spokesman for the Chamber of Commerce, welcomed the help from high-tech companies. "They've thrown themselves into this battle in a strong and aggressive way, and I think they are picking up the game very quickly," he said.
Robert A. Kapp, president of the U.S.-China Business Council, an umbrella group of 300 diverse companies, said the China issue had led to "a massive energizing of the technology field." Their effort, he said, has been especially helpful in the campaign to sway Democrats, whose party has close ties to organized labor.
These new lobbyists have been effective, lawmakers and others say. By emphasizing the power of the Internet, lobbyists have been selling a message that goes beyond their bottom line, stressing that the products they would export would spread democracy in China.
And unlike organized labor and big corporations, technology companies have no firm loyalties and are considered up for grabs by both parties. Their popularity has translated into easy access in Congress.
Still, the lobbying of high-tech executives pales next to organized labor's whirlwind approach and its grass-roots army. And the companies lag behind their more experienced big business allies.
"They are catching up," said Representative David Dreier, a California Republican and a technology booster. "But anyone juxtaposed to the organization that labor has put together, it's tough."
Intel Corporation has sent its chairman, Andy Grove, and Craig R. Barrett, chief executive, to the lobbying in Congress. The company has also run radio and newspaper ads and set up a grass-roots campaign through the company Web site. Within 48 hours, 5,000 of its employees sent letters to their lawmakers.
Motorola has also plunged money into the battle, running television advertisements.
Representative Rush D.Holt, a Democrat, has a host of high-tech companies in his district in central New Jersey, and has been courted by the industry, in part because he is a scientist. He spent one evening taking a technology tour of a New Jersey plant, where he met with executives from Sony, Intel and Hewlett-Packard.
Mr. Holt, who is facing a tough re-election battle, remains unconvinced that more trade with China is the cure-all that proponents make it out to be. "It's as if trade is the most important thing," he said. "And I don't think Americans necessarily think so."

HEADLINE: Essay;
The Biggest Vote

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
The most far-reaching vote any representative will cast this year will take place next week. It will be on the bill to permanently guarantee that Congress will have no economic leverage to restrain China's internal repression of dissidents or external aggression against Taiwan.
Bill Clinton, architect of the discredited "strategic partnership" with Beijing, is lobbying for H.R. 4444 as part of his legacy thing. His strange bedfellow is the G.O.P. leadership, fairly slavering at the prospect of heavy contributions from U.S. companies that want to profit from building up China's industrial and electronic strength. 
 Clinton has been purchasing Democratic votes one by one. The latest convert to pulling the U.S. teeth is Charles Rangel of New York, who was seduced by last week's legislation to benefit African workers at the expense of Chinese laborers in sweatshops at slave wages. He is the ranking Democrat on Ways and Means, which yesterday voted to send the any-behavior-goes bill to the House floor.
The president's tactics include frightening Americans with "dangerous confrontation and constant insecurity" from angry China if his appeasement is not passed.
He also divides American farmers from workers with his mantra, "exports mean jobs." Of course they do; in the past decade, our trade deficit with China has ballooned from $7 billion to $70 billion. That means China's exports to the U.S. have created hundreds of thousands of jobs -- in China. Clinton's trade deficit is certainly not creating net jobs for Americans.
His trade negotiator, Charlene Barshefsky, has become increasingly shrill, turning truth on its head this week by telling Lally Weymouth of The Washington Post that "organized labor, human rights advocates and some environmentalists have aligned themselves with the Chinese army and hard-liners in Beijing who do not want accession for China."
Not to be outdone in twisting the truth and kowtowing to Communists, Republican investors and the Asia establishment assure us that only by abandoning yearly review of China's rights abuses and diplomatic conduct can we encourage democracy there.
I confess to writing speeches for Richard Nixon assuring conservatives that trade with China would lead to the evolution of democratic principles in Beijing. But we've been trading for 30 years now, financing its military-industrial base, enabling it to buy M-11 missiles from the Russians and advanced computer technology from us.
Has our strengthening of their regime brought political freedom? Ask the Falun Gong, jailed by the thousands for daring to organize; ask the Tibetans, their ancient culture destroyed and nation colonized; ask the Taiwanese, who face an escalation of the military threat against them after the U.S. Congress spikes its cannon of economic retaliation.
Before Nixon died, I asked him -- on the record -- if perhaps we had gone a bit overboard on selling the American public on the political benefits of increased trade. That old realist, who had played the China card to exploit the split in the Communist world, replied with some sadness that he was not as hopeful as he had once been: "We may have created a Frankenstein."
(I was on the verge of correcting him that Dr. Frankenstein was the creator, and that he meant "Frankenstein's monster," but I bit my tongue.)
To provide a face-saver for Democrats uncomfortable with forever removing Scoop Jackson's economic pressure, Clinton's bipartisan allies have cooked up a toothless substitute: a committee to cluck-cluck loudly when China cracks down and acts up. We already have a State Department annual report that does that, to no effect on a China whose transgressions have always been waived.
Human rights advocates know the smart money in Washington is betting on the appeasers. Our only hope is that the undecideds in Congress consider that unemployment in their districts will not always be under 4 percent, and that when recession or aggression bites, voters will not forget who threw away economic restraints on China.
