SECTION: Section E; Part 2; Page 29; Column 1; Leisure/Weekend Desk 

LENGTH: 3115 words

HEADLINE: A Faux Pas? Get Over It!

BYLINE: By CHARLES STRUM 

 BODY:
Five years ago, at a stationery store on the Left Bank, I picked up a copy of Paris Match, fished in my pants pocket for some francs and walked toward the counter, a smile of fear frozen on my face. As my brain locked, I croaked out this sentence to the old woman at the counter:
"Je voudrais acheter ce magasin, s'il vous plait." 
 The common word for magazine is magazine (mah-gah-ZEEN), not magasin (mah-gah-ZAA). I had asked to buy the shop.
And so it went. For 10 days in Paris I was a helpless prisoner of my past: four years of undistinguished high school French and one semester at college. I could make my way through a French newspaper, but conversation was out of the question.
Until now. No longer the 98-pound-weakling of bilingualism, I have persuaded myself that it is possible to function confidently, perhaps even thrive, in another culture. I am a graduate of language immersion.
Alas, I have no immediate plans to do much more than order en francais at a midtown restaurant. But others are looking forward to a fresh round of business travel, or a summer visit to France or Italy or Japan, and yearn to be more self-sufficient, even fluent. For them, language courses like the one in which I enrolled, offered by the Language Immersion Institute, function as an introduction, a brush-up or a steppingstone to broader learning. A friendly caution, however: in the elementary levels, a weekend in another language can saute your brain, leaving you momentarily mute and at least a half-sentence behind the person you're straining to understand. At times it's like trying to do long division in your head.
My only previous encounter with immersion was a week at a tennis camp in Massachusetts years ago. Possessed of an average hacker's game at the time, I left the campus paralyzed by instruction. So focused had I become on where to step, how to swing and what my next shot should be that I couldn't hit the ball at all. Eventually the reflexes returned, including some bad habits. But it was demoralizing. Not so with French.
In 15 hours of weekend conversation, the equivalent of one-third of a semester, my classmates and I were continually coaxed to struggle aloud. Mercifully, this was not like high school, where teenagers wince from embarrassment. I felt no trace of the angst of my sophomore year, when my teacher -- a humorless woman who looked like Howdy Doody with a gray wig and spoke French with an Indiana twang -- aimed her intolerance up and down the rows like a machine gunner.
Instead, we were tutored by Denise Springer, a native speaker from the northeast seaside town of Berck-Plage in Flanders. A master teacher who retired in December as a language professor at the State University of New York at New Paltz, she happily transformed our gaucheries into new lines of instruction. We were applauded because we tried. It was O.K. to be ignorant. It was acceptable to be clumsy. We probably set a record for the number of sentences fractured per quarter-hour, but our persistence was always rewarded, with more instruction and more encouragement.
 
'Hate to Make Mistakes'
"It's a form of benign brainwashing," said Dr. Henry Urbanski, the director of the institute, which he founded on campus in 1981. The immersion technique isn't new, of course. In the 1960's, the Peace Corps placed its volunteers in similar programs. Among its most successful practitioners is the Defense Language Institute in Monterey, Calif., which trains the military.
Dr. Urbanski, a walking advertisement for immersion, was born in Poland and speaks seven languages: English, French, German, Italian, Russian, Hebrew and Polish. He learned some of them, he says, by living in the country where the language is spoken.
"I am a believer in learning the language when you have an urgency to use it, when you need to, when you're totally immersed in it," he said. But the program he established initially served another purpose as well.
"I was chairman of the foreign language department at New Paltz in the late 70's, which coincided with the time that language requirements at colleges were being abolished," he said. "We were experiencing a drop in students and a consequent drop in faculty members. I felt that we had some talented language teachers, and they had no students to teach. That's when I decided there's people out in the world who are no longer in school who need language instruction."
So what is immersion?
"You exclude English for 15 hours in one weekend, and after a while students develop more confidence," he said. "They are not afraid to speak and make mistakes and to try to communicate in the language."
That's the key: making mistakes.
"Americans," he said, "hate to make mistakes."
He's right. So on a recent Friday evening, my classmates and I left our pride at the door of the Dumont Plaza Hotel on East 34th Street.
 
La Plume de Ma Tante? Non!
We students, about 70 of us, and 10 or 12 instructors -- a fairly typical gathering for Manhattan -- arrived at a hotel conference room at 7 p.m.
As individual classes go -- they range from 6 to 15 students -- mine was on the cozy side and fairly typical in its goals. Of the six of us, four wanted to learn more French for touring the country, one needed French for a doctoral program, and I was curious to see whether I was facile enough to move beyond irrelevant textbook phrases about le cahier, le stylo and mon oncle.
In Manhattan, classes are held at the Dumont Plaza. The institute also conducts weekend instruction at the State University campus at New Paltz, at the nearby Mohonk Lake Mountain House and at Mercy College in Dobbs Ferry. Instruction begins with Elementary I and Elementary II (my level) and two intermediate levels. There are also advanced immersion courses of two weeks and four weeks, at New Paltz. Most students in the Manhattan program are commuters, but some stay overnight at their own expense. Tuition was $295 for the weekend, which included a welcome break for bagels and coffee on Sunday morning.
We began drifting into our meeting room in twos and threes, randomly filling seats and waiting to meet our teachers before following them to one-bedroom suites that would serve as classrooms.
Dr. Urbanski's welcome was low-key. He urged us to shed our inhibitions and expectations, recalling Heywood Hale Broun's observation of his own language studies. Broun felt he had been a good student, Dr. Urbanski said, but complained that "when he got to Paris he found that no one spoke intermediate French."
One by one, the instructors came forward to call the roll for their classes. They rattled off greetings and room numbers and a few phrases to lubricate us for what was to come.
Mild panic swept the room, and someone who was dead serious yelled out, "I think I'd better switch to Level I."
By 7:30 we were in our "classrooms." My group was interrupted several times in the first hour by late arrivals, until finally 10 of us crowded into the suite's sitting room. We received paperback texts, introduced ourselves and talked in French about our jobs, worked on vocabulary and conversation, and adjourned at 10 p.m. With the exception of a few necessary instructions for the next day, Mme. Springer spoke only in French.
 
One in Every Class
When we reconvened at 9 a.m. on Saturday, there were just the six of us, the others having bailed out. (Most Friday night dropouts tend to sign up for lower-level instruction either the same weekend or at a future date, Dr. Urbanski said.) Our group was set: Vicky Jeffers, a psychologist from Morristown, N.J.; her friend Ann Elkas, a registered nurse from Chatham, N.J.; Mitzi Pratt, a bookbinder from Martha's Vineyard, Mass.; Debra Schmidt Bach, from Brooklyn, a curator at the South Street Seaport Museum; and Cellen (pronounced SELL-in) Wolk, a landscape gardener from Rockland County. They all knew I would be writing about our experience.
We were pretty well matched, but the consensus was that Mitzi was the class genius. Her accent and pronunciation were quite good, and her command of sentence structure was superior to ours. She had spent some months working with a set of language tapes, and it had paid off.
"I hadn't been to Europe for a while," she said, "and then I went to France last fall for the grape harvest, the vendange. It was a great trip, and it inspired me to improve on the French that I had."
Her childhood French instruction, she said, had begun in a private, co-ed elementary school on the North Shore of Boston.
Of her weekend at the Dumont Plaza, Mitzi said later: "I was very nervous beforehand, but I had underestimated my ability. I had this vision of us sitting in this room being forced to speak French to each other."
 
Not Just a Bag
That did, indeed, happen. But most of the time we interacted with Madame Springer, or created conversations at her direction.
On Saturday morning, we paired off and interviewed our partners in French. Then we reported to the group. I learned that Ann was a nurse who also volunteered at a domestic-abuse phone line. She has three grown children, one of whom is married. She drives a Lexus and lives in a two-story house with four bedrooms.
Now try saying that in French. In full sentences.
More grist for Mme. Springer, who stood by a large easel and jotted down new words or phrases or verb forms with a marking pen. Nothing escaped her interest.
At one point, she gestured to an oversize handbag on the floor near Vicky's chair. She referred to it as le sac, but then went on to explain that its size qualified it for what Parisians call by a slyly suggestive name that will not be repeated here. It is a prostitute's bag, big enough for a change of clothes, makeup, etc. Suddenly we were immersed not only in language but also in culture.
Ann and Vicky were both relative newcomers to French. In school, Ann had studied Latin and taken a year of Spanish. Vicky said she had been a pretty fair student of German. "I could think in German," she said. "I could read poetry."
Both had been to France recently ("I fractured French there," Ann said) and wanted to become more comfortable with the language. So they enrolled together in a weekly hourlong course in New Jersey.
"I wasn't getting enough conversation," Ann said. "I'm great at visual learning, but my conversation is terrible. Just don't ask me to go, impromptu, into a big conversation with you."
We all survived the day. But when we left the hotel at 6 p.m. on Saturday, some of us displayed the telltale squint of fatigue.
"When I drove home, my husband said I sat there like a lump, I was so tired." Ann said. "I said, 'We're going out to eat, aren't we?' "
 
Say It Right, Mon Ami
Food had been our salvation on Saturday afternoon, too. Mme. Springer, it seems, relishes lunchtime on an immersion weekend, and her favorite restaurant is a Theater District fixture, Pierre au Tunnel, on West 47th Street.
Pierre Pujol opened the restaurant, on 48th Street, about 50 years ago, and it has remained in the family. Pujol's son-in-law, Jean-Claude Lincy, greeted us, and a member of the staff cheerfully put up with our attempts to order a tartine of this or a plat of that. We kept up some snappy table patter about de Gaulle, French socialism and Madame's wartime experiences in occupied France. But mercifully the food arrived, and it struck us all that it was the first time in hours that we had opened our mouths without having to think. (We split the bill, in English.)
The biggest event of the weekend, though, was the dreaded oral report on Sunday. Mme. Springer had directed each of us to prepare a five-minute presentation. We were permitted to write it out the night before, but not to read from it in class.
Vicky went first. Her report was on an American doughboy in Paris in 1918 and the penniless French countess he married. They eventually became her in-laws.
"I was amazed that I could make the presentation and elaborate spontaneously," she said later. "I felt comfortable."
Ann talked about her work as a volunteer with the domestic-abuse line. Cellen, the jardiniere, spoke lovingly about landscaping. It turned out that Cellen had been a competent Spanish speaker after having lived in Mexico years ago. But she had all but given up on French.
"I had four years of first-year French in high school," she said, adding that her mother, a French teacher, seemed to think her daughter had no aptitude for language. After doing poorly in her first French class, she repeated French I the next year. Then she moved to a new school, and another French I class, and so on.
But that was years ago, and with the prospect of a trip to Europe this summer, she chose to try immersion.
"I began dreaming in French," she said, after a day of class.
Mitzi told us about a trip to ancient ruins in Peru. I tried to describe a French cartoon character a friend had introduced me to. Named Becassine, she is a chauvinistic Bretonne in regional apron and cap whose exploits, chronicled in two dozen books, became popular between the world wars. (I had hoped for extra credit.)
Debra is working toward her Ph.D. at Columbia University in the history of decorative arts, for which she must pass a French comprehension exam in the fall. She described a visit to Paris about 13 years ago, when she was in her 20's. "On my way home one night," she said, "I gave my address to a taxi driver, but apparently I didn't pronounce it properly. When I showed the correct address, he started yelling at me."
That night, she said, she dreamed that people were shouting at her in French. She awoke to find that, in fact, they were: her hotel was next to a noisy restaurant kitchen.
 
The Secret, Revealed
Which provoked a stern caution from Madame and may explain at long last why the French become frustrated with Americans. It's not because we take pratfalls in pursuit of fluency; it's because we make the sounds wrong.
"Remember," she said, "if you don't pronounce it correctly, the French simply won't understand you." It must have been important: she said this in English!
By 1:30 on Sunday, exhausted but triumphant and with just 30 minutes remaining, we realized that making mistakes had not been so bad after all. We had stuttered and stumbled and persevered. And our teacher was still smiling.
Our valedictory was brief but pleasant. We read poems and sang songs in unison -- a younger person's classroom activity, perhaps, but a curiously comfortable one -- and recited tongue twisters: "Comment sont ces six saucissons-ci? Ces six saucissons-ci sont six sous."
There were hugs for the teacher, promises to enroll with her again and invitations to visit her in the Hudson Valley. And a valedictory of her own.
"I am moved by the fact that people come and spend a weekend, people who have other interesting things to do," Mme. Springer would tell me later. "If you are intelligent, you are self-criticizing, and it can work.
"We never know exactly the level of the people when they enroll. Some people think they are better than they are. But most people are better than they think they are."
 
Immerse Yourself in a Foreign Language
 
 Here is a sampling of places in the New York metropolitan region that offer intensive language classes.
 
 BERLITZ. Various centers in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut; (800) 457-7958 or www.berlitz.com. The centers offer "virtually any language" in four programs: "Total Immersion" (seven and a half hours a day for one to six weeks); individual instruction; semiprivate lessons (two students with one instructor) and a group program. All are based on a conversational approach. The most economical programs are two-month courses in Spanish, German, French and Italian for groups of fewer than eight students, meeting once a week for sessions of 2 hours and 15 minutes. Cost: $299.
 
 DEUTSCHES HAUS AT NEW YORK UNIVERSITY, 42 Washington Mews, near University Place, Greenwich Village; (212) 998-8660 or www.nyu.edu/deutscheshaus. Monthlong classes in German at all levels, meeting for just under three hours twice a week. Fee: $430.
 
 LANGUAGE IMMERSION INSTITUTE, JFT 916, State University of New York at New Paltz, 75 South Manheim Boulevard, New Paltz, N.Y.; (914) 257-3500 or www.
newpaltz.edu/lii. Offers 20 languages, from American Sign to Yiddish, at elementary, intermediate and advanced levels. Courses are offered in Manhattan at the Dumont Plaza Hotel, 150 East 34th Street; Mercy College in Dobbs Ferry, N.Y.; the Mohonk Mountain House in New Paltz, N.Y., and at the State University of New York in New Paltz. Tuition for the weekend course at all locations is $295; overnight lodging is extra. Course hours: 7 to 10 p.m. Fridays; 9 a.m. to 6 p.m. Saturdays and 9 a.m. to 2 p.m. Sundays. There is a program at the Manhattan location today through Sunday and again from June 23 to 25. The next weekend at the State University at New Paltz is June 9 to 11; two-week courses at the college are planned July 3 to 14 and July 17 to 28. At Mohonk, the next weekend language immersion weekend, called "The Tower of Babble," is scheduled for Nov. 10 to 12. Room rates range from $307 to $572 for double occupancy and $177 to $472 for single occupancy; tuition, to be determined, is additional. The tuition for the next five-day getaway at Mohonk in January 2001 has not yet been determined; last January it was $475.

HEADLINE: A Weekend's Lark For Studebaker Club

BYLINE: By CHARLES MCEWEN 

 BODY:
STUDEBAKER owners are a stubborn, iconoclastic group. John Cohoe, a founder of the Manhattan Studebaker Club, said: "One of the early mottoes was, 'We'd rather fix than switch.' And some cigarette smokers in the club would only smoke Lark. I guess they've grown up to Avanti cigars now."
Studebaker was one of the great independents in American automaking. The company started out as a wagon maker in 1852 and built its first car, an electric, in 1902. The last Studebaker rolled off the line in 1966. Notable Studebakers over the years include the big eight-cylinder Presidents of the 1920's and 1930's, the economical 1939 Champion, the 1950 "bullet nose" (named for its unusual round grille), the 1953 Starlight coupe and Starliner hardtop, the compact 1959 Lark and the wedge-shaped Avanti of 1963. 
 On Sunday, from about 11 a.m. to 4 p.m., the 35-member Manhattan Studebaker club will show off cars like these on the north side of Pier 17 at the South Street Seaport. The emphasis of the show, which is free, will be on Studebakers and other "orphan" makes whose manufacturers are no longer in business, but any car built in 1974 or earlier can enter for a fee of $15, Mr. Cohoe said. Thirty to 50 cars are expected, he added.
Old-car shows are a rarity in Manhattan, not the friendliest of places for any car, especially one that's 40 or 50 years old. "Owning an old car is the dream of childhood come true, and Manhattanites don't tend to be that type of person," said Gary Hallgren, another founder of the Manhattan Studebaker Club. "They dream of old cars, but the price of realizing that dream is too high. If they are native New Yorkers, it's not in their blood as much as us hick country people."
Mr. Hallgren's tongue was firmly in cheek. Although he now lives in Mastic Beach on Long Island, and grew up in Ferndale, Wash., he lived in Manhattan for nine years and kept a Studebaker in the city the whole time. In fact, he parked his 1949 pickup on the street and never even locked it. And nothing ever happened to it.
"A bum slept in it once," he said, "but I didn't care."
 CHARLES McEWEN

HEADLINE: DESIGN REVIEW;
When Americans Awoke to Modern Styles

BYLINE: By GRACE GLUECK 

 BODY:
The United States had to take a pass when offered a choice exhibition space at the great Paris show of modern design in 1925, the "Exposition des Arts Decoratifs et Industriels Modernes." Why? Herbert Hoover, at the time secretary of commerce, had consulted V.I.P.'s in the art, educational and business worlds, who advised that there was no modern design in America.
Sadly, with a few exceptions, it was true. European designers and manufacturers, particularly the French, were alive to the merchandising potential of design trends, like Art Deco. (Although it took its name from the Paris exposition, by 1925 Art Deco had already peaked in Europe.) 
 But Americans were still stuck in the worn groove of period furniture and decor. There was no serious contemporary movement in the decorative arts and, except for the tradition-busting skyscrapers going up in big cities, the public was hardly aware that such a thing as modern design could exist.
The Paris exhibition changed all that, awakening -- as did the Armory show of 1913 for modern art -- a new American interest in matters of design. The Metropolitan Museum bought seven important pieces from the Art Deco-oriented show, including a cabinet by Emile-Jacques Ruhlmann, then the high priest of French decoration. What's more, the next year the Met played host to a traveling exhibition of works by craftsman-designer stars of the Paris extravaganza. The display caught on, articles appeared and trend-spotters in this country took notice. By the 1930's, manufacturers and designers were working together to stimulate the economy.
The Met, which happily seems to have stepped up its interest in design shows, has chosen that exposition year of 1925 as the kickoff for two new ones. "American Modern, 1925-1940: Design for a New Age" is bracketed between the Paris exposition and the New York World's Fair of 1939-40. A smaller show, "A Century of Design, Part II, 1925-1950," the second in a four-part series surveying the 20th century, concentrates on European work. (Part I, covering the first quarter of the century, ran from last December through March.)
"American Modern," a collaboration between the Met and the American Federation of Arts organized by J. Stewart Johnson, consultant for design and architecture in the Met's department of modern art, is the larger and more interesting, not just by virtue of its size.
Drawn from the Met's collection and from a collection promised to the museum by John C. Waddell, "American Modern" displays more than 150 objects: furniture, appliances, clocks, radios, cameras, textiles, tableware, book covers, posters, a vacuum cleaner, parts of a snappy blue-and-chrome dining room and even a shiny, skyscraperish step-on scale that told your weight and fortune for a penny. If much of it is familiar stuff, it wears well. The designers include such stellar names as Norman Bel Geddes, Donald Deskey, Henry Dreyfuss, Paul Frankl, Ilonka Karasz, Raymond Loewy, Isamu Noguchi, Eliel Saarinen, Charles Sheeler, Walter Dorwin Teague and Russel Wright.
At first, Art Deco -- a conservative but catchy fusion of earlier neo-classical styles like Louis XVI and Empire laced with Cubism, Futurism and late Art Nouveau -- was all the rage. Sumptuous materials were its hallmark, like the inlaid armoire of 1926 done for the New York furniture store W & J Sloane by an unknown designer. Made of mahogany, satinwood and ebony, with a kitschy little inlaid design on its veneer front, it epitomized the luxury appeal of Art Deco, not meant for a mass market.
But the French-fostered movement, with its curvilinear forms and cushy materials, was soon supplemented by the austere geometrics of the Bauhaus, the German design school initially led by Walter Gropius. Of real intellectual substance as against the derivative, backward-looking Art Deco, Bauhaus design was dedicated to producing functional, well-made, affordable items for a broad public through cooperation with manufacturers and the use of practical materials. When the school was closed by the Nazis in 1933, many of its teachers, including Gropius, came to America, where their ideas found a receptive audience.
In this country, Art Deco became the term for design influenced by the age of skyscrapers and machines. It was America's first popular modern style, although the terms Art Moderne or Streamlined Moderne are preferred by many in the decorative arts. And a new tastemaker, the industrial designer, emerged.
Among the more prolific of them were Teague, Bel Geddes and Dreyfuss. Teague (1883-1960), one of the first industrial designers, did the Ford Motor Company and the National Cash Register pavilions for the '39 World's Fair. He is represented in the show by no fewer than 18 items, among them the "Bluebird" radio (1934) for the Sparton Company. Of blue mirror glass, the radio face is horizontally trisected by chrome-plated bars that cross two central circles surrounding the dial.
Bel Geddes (1893-1958), originally a designer of productions for the theater, the opera and films, later did streamlined cars for Chrysler and Plymouth and the Futurama Pavilion for the '39 World's Fair. In 1940 he designed what has become the show's icon: the cheerful little "Patriot" radio for Emerson, a plastic portable whose grille is striped in red and white like the bars of an American flag. No less celebrated a design brain was Dreyfuss (1904-1972), a pioneer in the field of ergonomics, who redid the 20th-Century Limited train for the New York Central Railroad and produced such iconic mass-manufactured items as the thermos bottle (1937), which appears in the show.
The skyscraper, a native American product whose soaring height and bold architecture seemed to speak optimistically of the future, was a design inspiration, affecting everything from furniture to lamps to cocktail shakers. Among the show's most engaging objects are the "skyscraper" desk and bookcase, designed around 1927 by the Viennese-born Paul Frankl (1887-1958) in wood, Formica and Bakelite, an early plastic. Their geometric modules were staggered and set back, like the real thing.
Streamlining, with its rounded, rocket-shaped forms that symbolized speed, was yet another American contribution to the design field, although its roots could probably be traced to Italian Futurism of an earlier date. From trains, cars and planes, streamlining spread to ordinary household objects, like desk lamps, clocks, radios and tableware. Its effect can be seen on such disparate items in the show as the "Radio Nurse" (1937), done by the sculptor Isamu Noguchi for the Zenith Radio Corporation, a sleek, helmetlike contraption of black Bakelite meant for monitoring sounds in another room, and the "Airline" armchair (circa 1934) by the German-born Karl Emanuel Martin Weber (1889-1963), whose loungey seat and back of Naugahyde are counterpoint to an aerodynamic-looking wood frame.
It would be nice to see a Hupmobile designed by Loewy (1893-1986) instead of just the dinky little chrome-plated hood ornament he designed for the car, or Dreyfuss's 20th-Century Limited in the flesh, so to speak. But even at the Met, space limitations prevail, and besides neither object is in its collection.
Because it is a collection show, "American Modern" does not have the sharp point of view of "Packaging the New: Design and the American Consumer," mounted in 1994 by the Cooper-Hewitt National Design Museum, Smithsonian Institution. Covering 50 years of the 20th century, that show presented stylistic change as the driving force behind design, manufacturing and consumerism.
But why carp? The attractive, thematically arranged displays and lucid juxtapositions of the Met's show are a visual feast and enticingly evoke the spirit of the age.
"A Century of Design, Part II, 1925-1950," also organized by Mr. Johnson, by contrast with the first installment of this four-part series, seems a very mixed bag, stocked with the expected, unexciting and just plain ugly.
Focusing on Europe while covering virtually the same time frame as "American Modern," it presents 50 objects from the Met's collection by such talents as Alvar Aalto, Marcel Breuer, Jean Dunand, Charles Eames, Eileen Gray, Rene Jules Lalique, Ludwig Mies van der Rohe, Joan Miro, Emile-Jacques Ruhlmann, Gerrit Rietveld and Eva Zeisel, along with lesser lights.
Among the Art Deco exhibits looms Ruhlmann's overfussy sideboard (circa 1922) of macassar ebony tricked out with ivory and silver bronze. Two quieter but also unappealing Art Deco objects are cutesy etched glass vessels by the Swedish designer Edward Hald (1883-1980), dated 1926 and 1927.
The show improves with the geometric Bauhaus influence, seen in a pair of square hanging lamps (circa 1935) whose sides are surfaced like graters by the British designer Eileen Gray (1879-1976). Not to be scanted either is the wonderfully architectural inkwell (1929-30) in bright orange earthenware by Eva Zeisel (born in Hungary in 1906) that looks like a skyscraper lying on its side. Other good things include a wonderful scale drawing for the Daimler-Benz sport convertible No. 3384 (circa 1933) by Wilhelm Reuter, a German.
Chairs are rife, most of them fairly familiar. They include Breuer's "Wassily" armchair (1925), of tubular steel and canvas upholstery; Mies van der Rohe's "MR" model (1927), with a cantilevered seat and back of black caning set in a chrome-plated steel frame; and Aalto's "39" chaise longue (1936-37), a long, body-loving chair whose webbed seat is also cantilvered, on a simple bentwood frame.
As mentioned, the show has its quota of nontreasures. The biggest such surprise is an earthenware vase (1942) by Joan Miro, whose conventional urn shape is inflected by a painted abstract motif or two. What it's doing here is hard to figure out.
 
 "American Modern, 1925-1940: Design for a New Age" remains at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue and 82nd Street, (212) 535-7710, through Jan. 7. "A Century of Design, Part II: 1925-1950" is at the museum through Oct. 29.

HEADLINE: Trade Deal Will Hurt China's Hard-Liners

BYLINE: By Samuel R. Berger and Gene Sperling; Samuel R. Berger is the national security adviser. Gene Sperling is President Clinton's national economic adviser.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
As Congress takes up the bill that would establish permanent normal trade relations with China, the question before it is not whether China's human rights record is good or whether the deal by itself will cure it. The question is, in addition to the overwhelming economic benefits, will its passage increase the chance of positive change in China?
We believe it will, not out of faith that increased trade always brings freedom, but because the specific concessions China is making in order to enter the World Trade Organization will move China in the right direction. 
 The divisions within China are clear. Those advocating W.T.O. membership and closer ties with the United States are the same leaders pushing a more daring transition from a command-and-control to a market economy. They realize that if they open China to global competition, they risk unleashing forces beyond their control -- temporary unemployment, social unrest and demands for freedom. But they have concluded that without competition, China will not be able to build a modern, successful economy.
The opposition is the entrenched state-owned manufacturing sector and those Communist officials clinging desperately to one-party control over how people work and live. They know that if China slashes protective tariffs to get into the W.T.O., more of its state enterprises will go. The government's ability to control workers and their loyalty will diminish. There will be more internal pressure for political change.
Last year alone there were more than 120,000 labor disputes across China over demands for openness and accountability. In some places, the government has cracked down. In others, it has responded by giving people a greater say, holding local elections and letting workers take grievances to court. That is how real change can begin. How would we be encouraging it by handing a humiliating defeat to reformers seeking normalized trade and a huge victory to the stalwarts of a state-dominated economy?
If China enters the W.T.O. and we approve permanent normal trade relations, the resulting greater participation of American telecommunications companies will also make telephones and the Internet more accessible for Chinese citizens. Right now only 12 percent of Chinese have phones; fewer than 1 percent have Internet access. No matter how hard Chinese officials try to stuff the information genie back into the bottle, an explosion in information technology will lead to an explosion of idea sharing in China. But if we reject permanent trade ties, our information industries will be denied access. How would that help Chinese citizens seeking new ideas and tools for political activism?
Finally, as Martin Lee, the leader of Hong Kong's Democratic Party has said, participation in the W.T.O. would bolster those in China who understand that the country must embrace the rule of law. Economic activity in China is mostly based on vague and unpublished rules that maximize the arbitrary power of party officials. To join the W.T.O., China must publish key rules, making it easier for citizens to advance on the strength of their ideas, not their connections.
Of course, W.T.O. membership does not guarantee China's leaders will choose political reform. But by accelerating economic change, it will force them to confront that choice sooner, and will make the imperative for the right choice stronger. If we reject the trade deal and undercut the reform-minded leaders who have risked their reputations for greater openness, we will increase the likelihood of the wrong choice.
Certainly, establishing permanent normal trade relations is not by itself a human rights policy toward China. Change will come through a combination of internal pressure and external validation of China's human rights struggle. We have to maintain our leadership in the latter, even as the W.T.O. contributes to the former. That's why we sanctioned China under the International Religious Freedom Act last year, and why last month we sponsored a U.N. Human Rights Commission resolution condemning China's human rights violations.
Those who oppose the trade deal have little vision of how a no vote would further reform in China other than maintaining our annual vote to threaten to close our market to Chinese goods (at considerable cost to millions of American families). Yet, after 20 years, this ritual has become just that, a ritual. Even when our relationship was at its lowest point, after the Tiananmen massacre in 1989, this process has affirmed our trading relationship with China. A human rights commission like that proposed by Representatives Sander Levin and Douglas Bereuter could be much more effective.
We do not know what path China will take. All we can do is make the decisions most likely to push China in the direction of economic and political reform. It is hard to see how freezing the status quo, empowering hard-liners, slowing the economic transition, and keeping American companies out of China will increase respect for human rights or lead to a more open society.

HEADLINE: Fed's Notes Give Reasons for Show of Restraint in March

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 18

 BODY:
Federal Reserve policy makers unanimously approved raising interest rates by a quarter percentage point at their March 21 meeting, preferring to stick with what they called a gradual approach to monetary policy absent evidence of surging prices, according to minutes released today.
Because a "significant acceleration in inflation did not appear to be imminent and because uncertainties continued to surround the economic outlook, a gradual approach to policy adjustments was warranted," according to the minutes. 
 The policy makers, the Federal Open Market Committee, voted unanimously at that meeting to raise the federal funds target rate on overnight loans between banks by a quarter-point, to 6 percent. At its next meeting, on Tuesday, it raised the rate by a half-point, to 6.5 percent, the highest level in nine years. In an accompanying statement, the committee also suggested that more increases were likely.
At the committee's March meeting, a similar move was contemplated but rejected.
"Although a more forceful policy move of 50 basis points might be needed at some point, measured and predictable policy tightening moves, such as the one contemplated today, still were desirable in current circumstances, which included somewhat unsettled financial markets," the minutes said.
Moreover, "there were few signs of any acceleration in labor costs," the minutes said. "Price inflation was still moderate, except for the upturn in energy prices in recent months."
The minutes suggest that in March, the Fed did not see the kind of inflationary forces that have since become evident in economic data, like robust growth and consumer spending and an unemployment rate that is at a 30-year low.
At the committee's February meeting, a few members had "expressed a preference" for a half-point increase but settled for the quarter-point favored by the majority, who saw "little risk in a gradual approach to policy tightening and considerable advantage to preserving the possibility of calibrating those actions to the emerging situation," the minutes of the Feb. 1-2 meeting said.
In March, the majority's support for a gradual series of rate increases prevailed again, though central bankers said further rate increases were likely.
The half-point increase in rates on Tuesday was the sixth rate increase since June. Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, and other F.O.M.C. members justified the rate rise by saying in a statement that "increases in demand have remained in excess of even the rapid pace of productivity-driven gains in potential supply."

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Europe Regulators Raid Coke Offices in Brussels and London

BYLINE: By CONSTANCE L. HAYS 

 BODY:
Investigators from the European Commission raided Coca-Cola's office in Brussels early yesterday as well as the office of the company's largest bottler, in London, expanding an inquiry into Coke's marketing practices that began last summer.
At issue are many of the methods Coke uses to bolster sales of its soft drinks: contracts that prohibit competitors' products, sales incentive programs and discounts for certain customers. Last July, investigators seized documents from the offices of Coca-Cola Beverages in London; the offices of Coke's principal German bottler, Coca-Cola Erfrischungsgetranke, and Coca-Cola Nordic Beverages in Denmark. 
 By bringing Coca-Cola Enterprises into the investigation, regulators seem intent on examining the entire European operation. Coca-Cola Enterprises, based in Atlanta, bottles Coke products in France, Britain, Belgium, the Netherlands and Luxembourg, and controls about 70 percent of Coke's bottling in the United States.
In a statement, the European Commission said its inquiry "aims to assess whether C.C.E.'s distribution practices may constitute an abuse of a dominant position in violation of E.U. competition rules." It added that the investigation focused on the Belgian and British markets, and began after complaints were received by the commission. Pepsico and Virgin Cola have acknowledged that they complained to regulators about Coke, setting off the investigation in July.
Coca-Cola said it was cooperating with the authorities. "We are confident that our actions are in compliance with all national and European regulations," said the company's spokesman, Rob Baskin.
A spokesman for the bottler, Coca-Cola Enterprises, confirmed that regulators had entered its offices in London and Brussels. "We are disappointed that the European Commission felt the need to execute a dawn raid," said the spokesman, John H. Downs Jr. "However, we are not surprised that the commission included our European operations since it has a continuing investigation into the Coca-Cola system."
The investigators remained at the Coke offices throughout the day, examining files and removing documents that pertained to the inquiry, which has no deadline. "The length of investigations depends largely on complexity of cases, and on whether the commission's suspicions turn out to be justified," the commission said in its statement.
On Tuesday, Coca-Cola Enterprises disclosed that its profits were falling, citing a flood of cheaper products into Britain, the bottler's second-biggest market. European Union law permits companies based in one country to import products from other member nations, so the bottler cannot prevent the flow of soft drinks from countries like Spain or Ireland.
Mr. Downs said there was "no connection" between the cheaper imports and the European Union's inquiry into Coca-Cola Enterprises.
Coca-Cola's new chairman and chief executive, Douglas N. Daft, has pledged to improve the company's battered image in Europe as well as its conduct there. Coke's efforts in recent years to buy Orangina and the Cadbury Schweppes brands ran into trouble from regulators on competitive grounds, with the plans ultimately scuttled or trimmed back. Last June, Coke recorded its biggest product recall in company history after people in Belgium said they felt ill after drinking Coke products; the recall cost Coke $200 million and cost Coca-Cola Enterprises $103 million.
In December, Italian authorities fined Coke $16 million over the practices of Coca-Cola Beverages, a bottler in which Coke holds a majority stake. The authorities objected to several of the bottler's practices, including discounts to retailers carrying Coca-Cola products exclusively and year-end bonuses to wholesalers carrying only Coca-Cola. The investigation began in 1997 after complaints from Pepsi and an Italian supermarket chain, Esselunga.
"Nineteen ninety-nine was a pretty tough year for Coca-Cola, particularly in Europe," Mr. Daft told the British and American Chamber of Commerce earlier this month. "We've said the series of setbacks we suffered last year served as a clear wake-up call for us."

HEADLINE: Tax Payments Lead to Big April Surplus

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 18

 BODY:
Thanks to a flood of tax receipts, the Treasury posted a record budget surplus of $159.5 billion in April, a month that typically generates a lot of cash because of the April 15 income tax deadline, the Treasury Department announced today.
The government's surplus for last month was 40.5 percent higher than the surplus of $113.5 billion recorded in April 1999. 
 Last month's surplus was in line with the $158 billion surplus many analysts expected, but was slightly smaller than the $163 billion projected by the Congressional Budget Office.
Revenue for April reached a record monthly high of $295.1 billion, while spending came to $135.7 billion.
With help from the booming economy, the government collected $184.2 billion in individual income tax payments last month, compared with $164.8 billion for April 1999. It received $27.7 billion in corporate tax payments, up from $21.7 billion.
For the first seven months of fiscal 2000, which began Oct. 1, the government is running a surplus of $123.9 billion -- just about matching the record $124.4 billion surplus recorded for all the 1999 fiscal year. Revenue during the first seven months of fiscal 2000 totaled $1.72 trillion, while spending came to $1.04 trillion.
If a surplus materializes as expected for the current fiscal year, it will be the first time for three consecutive years of surplus since 1947, 1948 and 1949.
The Clinton administration is predicting a $166.69 billion surplus for the current fiscal year, while the Congressional Budget Office has projected that the surplus will exceed $200 billion.

HEADLINE: Average Cost Of Apartments Hits $700,000

BYLINE: By DENNIS HEVESI 

 BODY:
Continuing a seemingly inexorable climb, the average price for apartments in much of Manhattan jumped by nearly a third over the last year, breaking the $700,000 mark for the first time, according to one of the real estate industry's most comprehensive surveys.
The average price for an apartment south of West 116th Street and East 96th Street rose to $733,860 during the first quarter of 2000, a 31 percent rise from the $559,204 average recorded in the first quarter of 1999, according to the study, the Douglas Elliman Manhattan Market Report. 
 "This is the first time ever that the average has exceeded $700,000," said Jonathan Miller, president of Miller Samuel, the appraisal company that prepares the quarterly report. Mr. Miller said a major contributor to the jump in the overall average price was an increased proportion of larger apartments in the quarter's sales.
The $733,860 figure represents a 77 percent increase over the average price of $414,187 recorded in 1995 -- during the bottoming-out of the last real estate recession -- and 62 percent over the $453,909 average in 1990.
"Things are crazy, but it's still not the 80's in terms of percentage," Mr. Miller said, pointing out that between the fourth quarters of 1985 and 1986, the overall average price rose 49.1 percent, to $580,282 from $389,170. Adjusted for inflation, that 1986 average of $580,282 would be $906,458 today.
Dr. James W. Hughes, dean of the Edward J. Bloustein School of Planning and Public Policy at Rutgers University, put the current increases in perspective. "We're in an era of setting economic records," Dr. Hughes said. "Each month, we break the record for the longest economic expansion in history. Manhattan has become one of the major locomotives of this record-setting, and it would be shocking if this were not reflected in surging housing prices in Manhattan.
"This now rivals the boom of the 1980's in terms of a single year," Dr. Hughes said. "The difference in the 80's was that the price surge was sustained over a seven-year period. This current boom has really only taken off the last two years. As long as the national economy keeps expanding, the price momentum in Manhattan will continue. And the national economy is still red hot, which is why we had the Federal Reserve interest rate hike on Tuesday."
Manhattan, to be sure, is not the only place in the country where price rises have been breathtaking. In Santa Clara County, Calif., which includes most of Silicon Valley, the local association of Realtors reported in April that the average price for a single-family home hit $702,165, a 37 percent increase from $513,085 in April 1999, and that the average price of condominiums and town houses had jumped 30 percent over the same period, to $341,167 from $262,139.
The Elliman first-quarter report was based on 2,313 closed deals for both co-op and condominium apartments, representing about 75 percent of the market's volume. It does not include sales of less than $75,000, Mr. Miller said, because there are so few transactions below that mark "that they are insignificant to the overall results."
Deborah Beck, executive vice president of the Real Estate Board of New York, expressing concern that the Elliman numbers might scare off potential buyers, pointed out that the report did not cover northern Manhattan and that prices for smaller apartments throughout the borough, while increasing significantly, were more reasonable.
And placing the Manhattan numbers in geographical context, Kevin Thorpe, an economist with the National Association of Realtors, cited the median price for an existing single-family home in the Greater New York Region, which the association defines as the city and certain suburban areas. The median was $221,500 in the first quarter of 2000 -- a rise of 14.3 percent from the $193,800 median in the first quarter of 1999, and 6.5 percent above the median of $207,900 at the end of last year. The median price is the point at which half the sales were above that figure and half were below it.
The Elliman Manhattan survey found that the average price for condominiums had increased 40 percent in a year, from $682,094 in the first quarter of 1999 to $952,761 this quarter. "That's a staggering increase, since we have never seen the quarterly average for condos exceed $700,000," Mr. Miller said.
Breaking down the condominium category by apartment size, the average price for a studio in the first quarter of 2000 was $243,667, up 38 percent from $175,986 in the first quarter of 1999. For one-bedrooms, the average was $387,961, a 7 percent increase from $361,397 a year ago. The two-bedroom average this year was $958,202, up 8 percent from $888,093.
For three-bedrooms, the average price was $1,997,053, a 75 percent jump from $1,140,600 in the first quarter of '99. (Mr. Miller attributed that increase to great demand for the few available properties.) And for condos with four or more bedrooms, the average price in the first quarter of 2000 was $4,118,750, a 7 percent increase from $3,836,414 in the first quarter of '99.
"My theory for the change in the overall average is that there has been a shift to larger units; a significant increase in the number of two-bedroom sales relative to the rest of the market," Mr. Miller said. "The two-bedroom apartment is becoming a first-purchase preference." In the first quarter of '99, two-bedroom condominium sales represented 33 percent of the condominium market; this year, they represented 49 percent of the market.
Lawrence Sicular, director of appraisal and consulting at Brown Harris Stevens, a major Manhattan real estate brokerage firm, concurred: "The change in mix sounds like a very plausible explanation. The demand for one-bedrooms may be in relative decline because people may prefer to rent until they can buy a two-bedroom.
"In the 80's," Mr. Sicular explained, "people felt that every type of property went up, so anything they bought would provide leverage for their next purchase. Now they are viewing real estate less as a speculative investment than they did in the last real estate cycle. They're not going to trade up every one or two years, thinking they are going to make money."
In the co-op category, the Elliman survey reported the average price increased 24 percent over the year, to $576,596 from $464,692. "That's the highest average ever recorded for co-ops in our study," Mr. Miller said. "And like the condos, the co-ops also saw a gain in the two-bedroom market share, from 33 percent last year to 38 percent this year."
For co-ops, by apartment size, the average price for a studio was $142,060 in the first quarter of this year, up 19 percent from $119,444 in the first quarter of 1999. For one-bedrooms, the average was $291,675, a 28 percent increase over $227,229 in 1999. In the two-bedroom category, the average this year was $760,578, up 39 percent from $547,407. For three-bedrooms, it was $1,858,576, up 44 percent from $1,294,840. And for those with four or more bedrooms, the average price in the first quarter of 2000 was $3,565,625, a decrease of 24 percent from $4,690,833 last year. There are relatively few sales of apartments with four or more bedrooms, so prices in that category are particularly volatile.
Asked about further price increases, Mr. Miller said his company's appraisals showed a continued rapid increase in prices in the last six weeks, the first half of the second quarter. "I would expect it to continue at least through mid-June, when the kids are out of school and we usually see a lessening of activity."
Concerned about wary buyers, Ms. Beck of the real estate board noted that the board's report covered all of Manhattan, "so that our figures aren't quite as euphoric, although they are wonderful." The median price for co-ops in all of Manhattan during the first quarter of this year was $397,500, the real estate board reported, up 14 percent from $350,000 in the first quarter of 1999. Condominium prices were not available.
Ms. Beck pointed out that more than 80 percent of all apartments in Manhattan were studios, one-bedrooms or two-bedrooms. And the median price for those apartments, taken together, was $342,500 in the first quarter of this year, up 12 percent from $306,000 a year ago.
"Some consumers would look at the Elliman numbers and say, 'I can't afford that,' " Ms. Beck said. "But if they look at the median price, particularly on studios, one- and two-bedroom units, they will find encouragement."

HEADLINE: South Carolina Votes to Remove Confederate Flag From Dome

BYLINE: By DAVID FIRESTONE 

DATELINE: ATLANTA, May 18

 BODY:
After 38 years of conducting their state's business under the Confederate battle flag, the two houses of the South Carolina General Assembly voted today to remove it from the Capitol dome and their chambers. At noon on July 1, South Carolina will become the last state to remove the old symbol of secession from its seat of government.
The Senate vote was 37 to 8; the House vote was closer, 66 to 43. 
 "Thank you, Jesus, thank you," Senator J. Verne Smith, a white Democrat from Greenville, said on the floor of the Senate, reflecting that body's relief after so many years of fatigue and bitterness over the issue.
But the bill, which Gov. Jim Hodges, a Democrat, said he would sign as early as next week, will not put an end to the racial division that the flag has caused. To capture the support of the flag's backers, the bill calls for a smaller version of it to be flown atop a 30-foot pole in front of the Capitol, next to a slightly taller monument to slain Confederate soldiers.
That setting as well is too prominent for most of the 26 black members of the House, only 4 of whom voted for the measure. The N.A.A.C.P. has said it will not lift its tourism boycott of the state, and may even expand it to discourage filmmaking and organized-labor events in South Carolina.
Black officials are by no means unanimous in opposition, however. Six of the seven black senators voted for the bill, and several joined their white colleagues in calling the vote a historic moment for race relations.
"Now all of South Carolina can be a part of a great day, of a great coming together of our citizens," said Senator Robert Ford, a black Democrat from Charleston. "All of us should be proud, and I think the coming together of the members of the General Assembly should be the coming together of every citizen in South Carolina."
The flag has flown on the dome, beneath the American and South Carolina flags, since 1962, when it was raised by the legislature, then all-white, for a Civil War centennial and to send a clear message of defiance to the growing civil rights movement. Over the years, leading blacks, many elected officials and one former governor, David Beasley, have repeatedly called for its removal as an offensive reminder of the slavery era, while white lawmakers have kept it flying as an emblem of Southern heritage.
The issue reached a fever pitch in the last year, after the N.A.A.C.P. announced its boycott and the presidential candidates weighed in, with the Democratic contenders calling for the flag's removal and Republicans declining to take a position. The struggle, which has recently overshadowed almost every other policy issue in South Carolina, became so intense because it perfectly embodied a large political gulf between the races there that has persisted since Reconstruction. Blacks have long felt that they are barely tolerated as political equals, and have seen every reference to "Southern heritage" as scarcely veiled nostalgia for the days of white supremacy.
"That flag represents the Confederacy that enslaved, exploited, murdered, raped and killed our people for over 300 years," said Representative Joseph H. Neal, a black Baptist minister, in explaining today why he and others would not vote to move the flag to the Capitol grounds.
White legislators, on the other hand, maintained that the flag was a legitimate expression of reverence for ancestors who died fighting for the South, and said they resented being lumped together with Klansmen and other racists who have embraced the flag for their own purposes. But many made clear as well that they had chafed over the years at the growth of affirmative action and other policies sought by black residents, and considered the flag a last remnant of a vanishing nobility.
Many formerly hard-line flag supporters voted for the bill, partly because they believed the flag's presence was hurting the state economically, and because they considered the Confederate monument to be an acceptable alternative setting.
"It was equally hard for both sides to take this step," said Senator Glenn F. McConnell, a Charleston lawyer who owns a gallery that sells Confederate memorabilia. "Both sides had to bleed on this."
Last week, a few flag supporters in the House who opposed the plan tried to make the flag's new position even more prominent by raising the height of the flagpole to 30 feet, 10 feet higher than called for in the original compromise, forged in the Senate. This last act of defiance, which the Senate was forced to swallow today for the sake of passage, helped persuade the N.A.A.C.P. to continue its boycott. Kweisi Mfume, the organization's president, said on Tuesday that the move was a "slap in the face" to those who wanted to end racial division in the state.
But Governor Hodges, who had long pushed for any compromise that would move the flag off the dome, predicted today that the boycott would soon fizzle.
"There may be differences about the final resolution," he said in an interview, "but what people will remember at the end of the day is that the flag came down. Like other states, we're moving the flag to a historical monument, and we will no longer be the only state with the flag on our dome. And I think people will see that as a major step forward for South Carolina."
The brunt of national attention on the Confederate issue is now likely to turn to Georgia and Mississippi, both of which incorporate the Southern-cross design of the battle flag in their own state flags. Efforts have begun in both states to change those flags in legislative sessions next year.

HEADLINE: A State Votes to End Its Death Penalty

BYLINE: By JOHN KIFNER 

DATELINE: CONCORD, N.H., May 18

 BODY:
Reflecting a mounting national unease over the death penalty, New Hampshire's generally conservative Legislature today became the first in the country to approve a bill banning capital punishment since the Supreme Court allowed executions to resume nearly 24 years ago.
The Senate, evenly divided between Republicans and Democrats, voted 14 to 10, after an emotional hourlong debate, to approve a bill repealing the state's death penalty. The House passed the same bill in March. 
 But Gov. Jeanne Shaheen, who not only favors the death penalty but wishes to expand it, has vowed to veto the bill.
"There are some murders so heinous that the death penalty is an appropriate punishment and, accordingly, I will veto this legislation," Governor Shaheen, a Democrat, said in a statement issued after the vote.
Nevertheless, the vote here, in a state that has not executed anyone since 1939 and has no prisoners on death row, was greeted by opponents of the death penalty as a striking indication of changing public attitudes.
Over the years, polls have shown that somewhat more than half the population approves of capital punishment. And while even death penalty opponents say no other state is likely to abolish the death penalty, over the past few years more concerns have been raised about its fairness and application, even among death penalty supporters.
"I think this is a historic vote and may signal a trend by states away from the death penalty," said Richard Dieter, executive director of the Death Penalty Information Center, a group in Washington that opposes capital punishment.
"There is clearly a growing concern about the accuracy and fairness of the death penalty in many other states," Mr. Dieter said.
Perhaps the most significant change came in January, when Gov. George Ryan of Illinois, a Republican who was a longtime proponent of the death penalty, ordered a moratorium on executions after discovering that since 1987 the state had freed 13 prisoners from death row because they were found to be innocent.
That was more than the number of convicts executed in that time. Some who were ordered to be freed had been exonerated after investigations by student journalists in a workshop at Northwestern University.
Governor Shaheen's legal counsel, Judy Reardon, had tartly dismissed that example in the debate here.
"If Governor Shaheen were the governor of Illinois, she'd have imposed a moratorium on the use of the death penalty, too," Ms. Reardon said. "We don't have those problems in New Hampshire."
But Mr. Dieter, the death penalty opponent, said the possibility of wrongful convictions and executions, as well as publicized cases of death row convicts exonerated with newly available DNA evidence, was a major factor in the changing attitudes.
"I think that the issue of innocence is what has triggered much of this concern," he said.
Death penalty opponents in the New Hampshire Legislature appear unlikely to be able to muster the two-thirds vote in both houses necessary to override the governor's veto. Nevertheless, the votes this spring indicated a major shift. Two years ago, the House rejected a similar repeal bill by 40 votes.
This year, when the vote on repeal came up in the House in March, the speaker of the overwhelmingly Republican body, Donna Sytek, who is noted for controlling party line votes with an iron hand, decreed a "free vote" in which the representatives should vote their consciences.
The measure passed 191 to 163. While its main sponsor, James Splain, a Democrat from Portsmouth, is regarded as one of the most liberal legislators in the House, the measure was also backed by a number of conservatives.
The possibility of executions carried out in error weighed heavily in the debate. One Republican representative, a lawyer, argued that economics fundamentally skewed the system of justice, leaving high numbers of poor blacks and Hispanics awaiting execution.
"There are no millionaires on death row," the representative, Anthony DiFruscia, said. "Can you honestly say that you're going to get equal justice under the law when, if you've got the money, you're going to get away with it."
As the measure moved to the Senate, early political soundings suggested that the 24-member body was just about evenly split.
But in the weeks leading to the vote today, three senators -- including the Democratic chairwoman of the Judiciary Committee, Debora Pignatelli -- changed their minds and voted to repeal the death penalty, providing the margin of victory.
Senator Rick Trombley, a Democrat from Boscawen, had favored the death penalty. But Mr. Trombley became troubled by testimony before the House Judiciary Committee over the case of a man, Richard Buchanan, who was charged with the murder and rape of a 6-year-old girl but was later exonerated by DNA evidence. Even so, prosecutors still held Mr. Buchanan in jail for months after the new evidence was discovered.
"If scientific evidence today shows that we're making mistake after mistake after mistake, the Legislature ought not to allow for the possibility of that mistake being made," Mr. Trombley told The Concord Monitor in an article that detailed the anguished decisions of the three senators. "The only way to do that is to abolish the death penalty."
Mrs. Pignatelli had also favored the death penalty until the Legislature began holding hearings. In January, one witness, Paris Carriger, told lawmakers that he had spent 21 years on Arizona's death row, and once came within three hours of being executed, before being released.
"There's something unseemly about the state being in the position of executing people," Mrs. Pignatelli finally concluded.
Leo Fraser, a Republican from Pittsfield, the third senator who changed his mind, said that several factors figured in his decision, including doubts that capital punishment was a deterrent to crime, but that he was particularly struck by a letter from a woman in Guilford.
"She wrote to me that she considered me her agent," Mr. Fraser told The Monitor. " 'And as my agent,' she said, 'I'd be devastated if I thought you'd put someone to death.' "
New Hampshire's death penalty is limited to a short list of crimes, including murder of a law enforcement or corrections officer, murder for hire and murder during rape or attempted rape. Governor Shaheen has advocated expanding the list to include categories like killing witnesses or informers.
There are 3,600 people on death rows nationwide, and 87 death row inmates have been freed since 1973, according to the Death Penalty Information Center.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Boo.com, Online Fashion Retailer, Goes Out of Business

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSS SORKIN 

DATELINE: LONDON, May 18

 BODY:
It was supposed to follow the dot-com fairy tale script. Two young entrepreneurs devise an idea for the next big e-commerce Web site, raise enormous sums of cash, spend lavishly on advertising, lose money on every sale, take the company public and make every employee a billionaire.
Today, Boo.com, a European fashion e-tailer backed by the French luxury goods magnate Bernard Arnault, the Benetton family, Goldman, Sachs & Company and J. P. Morgan, among others, is insolvent and has been forced to call the liquidators, six months after its Internet debut. 
 The concept for Boo.com seemed plausible enough. Ernst Malmsten and Kajsa Leander, two 29-year-old Swedes, founded Boo.com here in 1998, planning to create an online fashion retailer that would provide global service in seven languages and multiple currencies. And, of course, the site would use the most advanced technology. Boo.com bragged of its ability to let users view products in three dimensions from 360 degrees, giving them a true sense of how a garment looked.
Investors were so taken with the idea and its two founders -- Ms. Leander had been an Elite model and both had started an online bookstore called Bokus.com -- that Boo.com was able raise $125 million almost immediately from an elite roster of the extremely wealthy. Before even starting Boo.com, the founders promoted the site in trade journals and glossy fashion magazines.
But it was also clear that the founders were excessively ambitious. The company established its headquarters on swanky Carnaby Street in London, with satellite offices in New York, Paris, Stockholm, Amsterdam and Munich. The staff expanded from 40 initially to more than 400. Employees routinely flew first class and stayed in five-star hotels, according to a former staff member. Many were given laptops and Palm Pilots for home use, according to this person, and the company used Federal Express to send regular mail.
"They had very little spending restraint, to put it mildly," said Noah Yasskin, an analyst at the London office of Jupiter Communications, an Internet research firm.
The site itself was also plagued by technical problems and delays, and took twice as long as anticipated to develop.
Once up and running, it became clear that users without fast connections to the Internet could not use the site, a point Boo.com boasted about. That e-snobbery alienated customers with more modest modem speeds, which happened to be most of Europe and the United States, Boo.com's two most important markets.
"Ninety-nine percent of European and 98 percent of U.S. homes lack the bandwidth needed to easily access such animation," Therese Torris, an analyst at Forrester Research in Amsterdam, wrote in a report. And anyone with a Macintosh computer could not use the site.
While Boo.com later adjusted itself to allow users with slower connections and Macs to gain access, the changes came too late.
Sales for the first three months of the site's operation were $680,000, while the company was blowing through more than $1 million a month.
The end came as Boo.com's founders, with only $500,000 left, struggled in vain to find backers to plow more money into the site.
"We are deeply disappointed that it has been necessary to ask KPMG to become liquidators of the company," the co-founders and investors said in a joint statement. "The senior management of Boo.com has made strenuous efforts over the last few weeks to raise the additional funds which would have allowed the company to go forward with a clear plan."
Over the last several weeks, Mr. Malmsten and Ms. Leander, who together own about 40 percent of the company, had been pleading with investors to ante up more.
According to a spokesman for Mr. Arnault: "He didn't want to take the risk. He would have been willing to stay involved if he could have had more control." In fact, in an interview in Paris several weeks ago about his Internet holdings, Mr. Arnault refused to discuss Boo.com.
Whether Boo.com's failure presages further problems for clothing e-tailers is unclear. But some Internet analysts said Boo.com's rise and fall reflect a problem that goes beyond just selling clothes. .
"The market has woken up to the fact that the amount of business e-tailers like Boo.com generate is a lot lower than we anticipated," said Tony Shiret, an analyst at Credit Suisse First Boston in London. "A key turning point was what happened in the U.S. over Christmas," he added, referring to many online retailers that reported missed sales projections. "It's been disappointing."
On Wednesday, PricewaterhouseCoopers released a report predicting that 25 percent of all Internet companies in Britain could exhaust their cash within six months.
Still, the problems at Boo.com problems were somewhat self-inflicted, Mr. Yasskin said. "They tried to do too much," he said. "Opening up in multiple countries simultaneously is impossible."
One major stumbling block for Boo.com may simply have been the type of merchandise it was trying to sell. "If you look at successful sites, they are driven by price," Mr. Shiret said. "It is very hard to sell clothing at a cost base that makes sense without the scale."
Indeed, Boo.com never competed on price like most other retailers; it hoped to woo customers with its interactive services and convenience.
Nonetheless, Boo.com might be worth something, even if it is only a fraction of the $400 million value its founders once ascribed to the company. KPMG, which is managing the liquidation process, said today that it had received more than 30 inquiries. In an interview with The Sunday Telegraph earlier this month, Mr. Malmsten admitted he might have made missteps. "We have made some mistakes and we were late with our launch, yes," he said. "But people are welcome to come 'round here into our offices and see what is going on now."

HEADLINE: Jobless Claims Decline Again

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 18

 BODY:
New claims for unemployment benefits fell last week for the second consecutive week, leaving claims at a level suggesting that businesses are scrambling to find workers.
The Labor Department reported today that 276,000 Americans filed new claims for jobless benefits for the week that ended last Saturday, down by 21,000 from the previous week. That was the lowest level since April 15, when claims were at 258,000. 
 The decline was sharper than many analysts were expecting. They were forecasting that claims would fall to 295,000.
Two weeks ago, new applications for jobless benefits slipped by 7,000, to 297,000.
The more stable four-week moving average of claims, which smooths out week-to-week volatility, edged up slightly last week, however, to 289,750. That was the highest level since Jan. 15, when such claims were at 290,000.
The four-week moving average has been running below 300,000 since late October. Economists consider claims below 300,000 an indication of a tight labor market, meaning employers are having trouble finding qualified workers to fill job openings.

HEADLINE: Conflicting Views Hinder Dissidents on China Trade Vote

BYLINE: By JOSEPH KAHN 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 8

 BODY:
As political jockeying on a China trade bill entered an intensive final stretch, both the Clinton administration and its opponents claimed crucial backing today from persecuted democracy leaders in China and in exile.
The dueling claims are possible because the dissident community is sharply divided over whether China should have permanent trade ties with the United States, a decision many see as the most important test of American policy toward China since 1989, when Beijing ordered a bloody crackdown on democracy protesters. 
 While many of the bill's backers say that it appears headed for passage, both sides are continuing to fight for every vote in the House, where scores of lawmakers remain undecided.
In newspaper opinion pieces and lobbying calls on Capitol Hill, Chinese democracy leaders are expressing opposite views about whether permanent normal trade relations will increase or retard human rights and political freedoms.
The conflicting messages have largely neutralized the dissidents' impact on the vote, lawmakers said today, and appear to have driven a new wedge between opposition leaders who have long tended to fight among themselves instead of unifying against the Beijing government.
"The moment Congress says yes to permanent normal trade relations is the moment that China stops listening to what the United States says about human rights," said Wei Jingsheng, one of China's best-known dissidents, who spent 18 years in Chinese prison before becoming an exile in this country.
Mr. Wei, 50 years old, said he moved temporarily to Washington from New York so that he could lobby full-time to defeat permanent trade ties, one of the Clinton administration's top foreign policy priorities.
Congressional opponents of the trade bill staged a rally on Capitol Hill today in which they introduced several dozen Chinese workers, student leaders and veteran activists who urged Congress to vote down permanent trade ties.
But President Clinton is also pointing to support from well known opposition leaders in China and abroad.
He has cited on opinion piece written by Dai Qing, a Beijing-based human rights and environmental activist. He asked Martin Lee, a leading Hong Kong democrat who supports permanent trade ties, to help him lobby Congress. And the White House has distributed copies of a pro-trade message from what it called an underground democracy activist in the Chinese province of Zhejiang.
Several Tiananmen Square student leaders, including Wang Dang and Chai Ling, have also said that they support granting China permanent trade status.
"I believe that permanent normal trade status, with its implication of openness and fairness, is among the most powerful means of promoting freedom in China," Ms. Dai wrote in an essay published in The Los Angeles Times. Ms. Dai is best known for seeking to stop China's giant Three Gorges Dam construction project and for investigating corruption within the ruling Communist Party.
The Clinton administration today sought to build momentum for the vote after two Congressional committees strongly endorsed the measure Wednesday.
The White House said President Clinton intends to make a short, prime-time television address on China Sunday night. But of the major national networks, only NBC has agreed to grant air time to the president, while CBS, Fox and ABC declined, network officials said.
In a highly unusual move, Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan joined Mr. Clinton in the White House Rose Garden to lend his support. Though Mr. Greenspan has weighed in on legislation before, especially on fiscal and financial matters, the Fed chairman usually maintains impartiality on White House foreign-policy goals.
Mr. Greenspan, who was asked to speak out on China trade by Treasury Secretary Lawrence H. Summers, said he supports the bill on economic grounds. He said the trade bill would have "profound implications for the free world's trading system and the long-term growth potential of the American economy."
On Capitol Hill, some Democratic and Republican lawmakers were still scrambling to secure Republican leadership support for a new Congressional-executive human rights commission to monitor China and advise Congress and the administration.
Legislation to create the commission is seen as essential to rounding up support for the trade bill among the large number of undecided lawmakers in both parties, many of whom say they are wary of sacrificing their annual review of China's trade status unless they create a new forum to monitor human rights.
Republican Congressional leaders have already agreed to support one part of the so-called Levin-Bereuter proposal, a provision that would help guard against sudden surges of imports from China.
But Republican leaders last night were still discussing whether to include language authorizing a human rights commission in the trade bill. Democrats are insisting that the trade and human right measures must be considered together in one package.
"Many of our colleagues are concerned that if the commission moves only in parallel legislation that it could falter and not become law," said Doug Bereuter, Nebraska Republican who co-sponsored the proposal.
Supporters scheduled a press conference for Friday morning to unveil details of the new legislative package, and Congressional aides said they expected several undecided lawmakers to announce their support for the trade bill at the same time.
The Capitol Hill rally was intended to refute White House claims that Chinese opposition leaders support elevated trade ties. Participants argued that by ending the annual trade review, Congress would sacrifice the only real leverage it has over China's behavior toward its own citizens.
"China will never change unless it's under pressure," said Wang Xizhe, a gray-haired veteran of the opposition movement who now lives in the United States. Mr. Wang wrote an influential essay criticizing the excesses of the Cultural Revolution in 1974 and had been in and out of prison for nearly 25 years before he fled China three years ago.
He said that without the annual review of China trade status, Beijing authorities might never have released him from jail.
"The debate in Congress each year was one of the few things to lift my spirits when I was in jail," he said.
But he acknowledged a deep split in the dissident community and he criticized exiled Tiananmen Square student leaders who support the trade bill as naive. "Some of us understand the Chinese people and some of us do not," he said.
