HEADLINE: U.N. Expands Troop Limit For Mission In Sierra Leone

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, May 19

 BODY:
The Security Council today increased the number of troops allowed in the United Nations peacekeeping force in Sierra Leone by 2,000 and is likely to expand the force by several thousand more in the next week or two.
The Sierra Leone mission, originally limited to 11,000 troops by the council, is already the largest United Nations peacekeeping operation anywhere. 
 But today's increase was required after reinforcements from Bangladesh, Jordan and India arrived this week. Those troops were expected to push the force above the limit set in February, just before the United Nations took over peacekeeping in Sierra Leone from a regional contingent led by Nigeria.
But another increase to as many as 16,500 troops, which Secretary General Kofi Annan is expected to recommend to the council in the next few days, will represent a substantial commitment to bringing peace to Sierra Leone, even while rebels there are still holding more than 300 peacekeepers hostage.
Some hostages have been freed, but with alarming delays, United Nations officials said. Releases have been promised, then have not taken place, causing the United Nations to increase the number of troops listed as missing. More than 500 soldiers and monitors, most of them African, were seized by rebels at the beginning of the month.
Any increases in the size of the peacekeeping force in Sierra Leone pose a problem for American diplomats here because they are expected to give Congress, where there is considerable opposition to these operations, 15 days' notice of any new or augmented mission. The administration can waive this notification, as it apparently did for today's vote, but the procedure could seriously delay the next move in Sierra Leone.
Meanwhile, officials are concerned about how a weak elected government in the capital, Freetown, will deal with Foday Sankoh, the leader of the Revolutionary United Front, whose forces took the hostages. Mr. Sankoh is now in custody after nine days in hiding. But the fact that the government has not decided what to do with Mr. Sankoh appears to be emboldening some of his followers to demand that he be freed if the war is to be settled.
The government said today that it was investigating Mr. Sankoh's case. His troops have been responsible for savage brutality in a civil war that has lasted nearly nine years. In 1997, Mr. Sankoh was sentenced to death for treason. In an agreement signed in Lome, Togo, last July, Mr. Sankoh was nevertheless given amnesty -- not recognized by the United Nations -- in return for a promise to disarm. But when his soldiers began turning in weapons to peacekeepers, rebels in the group responded by taking the hostages.
Today, Sir Jeremy Greenstock, Britain's representative at the United Nations, who introduced the resolution to enlarge the peacekeeping force, said that Mr. Sankoh had violated the Lome agreement, implying that all promises made to him in the peace accord were off. Mr. Sankoh had also been promised a role in a power-sharing government.
Ambassador Greenstock also warned that there could be no negotiating for the release of hostages or attempts to link the fate of the United Nations soldiers to any other issue.
Britain has about 800 troops in Sierra Leone who were sent to evacuate foreigners. But now those troops are playing a major role in keeping Freetown reasonably calm, United Nations officials say.
With an increase in United Nations troop strength for Sierra Leone, Nigerian troops are likely to return to the country, along with other West African peacekeepers representing a regional organization, the Economic Community of West African States and its cease-fire monitoring group, known as Ecomog. It is still not clear whether they will be under direct United Nations command or deployed in some other way.
In Monrovia, Liberia, today, the Rev. Jesse Jackson, a special envoy sent to the region by President Clinton to work for the release of the hostages, said that there was no room for negotiation. "Peacekeepers cannot be target practice for the R.U.F.," he said. Liberia's president, Charles Taylor, another former rebel leader with ties to Mr. Sankoh's Revolutionary United Front, has been credited with a role in the freeing of about 150 hostages before the releases stopped.
Mr. Jackson told reporters in Monrovia that during an earlier stop in Lagos, he had urged Nigeria to send more troops to Sierra Leone to help settle the political crisis. "They have the power to remove the R.U.F. as a military consideration in negotiations," he said at a news conference at Monrovia's airport.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
European Cities Of Two Minds On One Bourse

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS 

DATELINE: FRANKFURT, May 19

 BODY:
The pioneering merger of the London and Frankfurt stock exchanges is running into heavy resistance in both cities.
In Germany, regulators and the nation's state-owned banks fear that Frankfurt will lose control over the market for small growth companies, which has been a huge success here in the last three years. 
 In Britain, the fear is that Frankfurt will grab all the good business and that London traders will be left with little except the costs of switching over to Frankfurt's system for electronic trading.
Some British executives also complain that the merger has been engineered by big American investment banks that want lower trading costs even if London is diminished as a financial center.
But even some of Europe's biggest trading institutions, which badly want a more efficient pan-European stock market, are complaining that the deal announced two weeks ago has serious problems.
"Everyone is in favor of getting a single trading system, but this isn't the way to do it," said an executive at a London trading institution. "This is two exchanges that are trying to carve up everything for themselves and monopolize the market."
Under the deal, the market for smaller growth stocks is to be based in Frankfurt while London assumes responsibility for blue-chip stocks.
But the two exchanges also plan to form a joint venture with Nasdaq, which is focused on the same kinds of small technology stocks in the United States. The joint venture will be incorporated in London.
Executives at both exchanges say their merger plans are still on track. The supervisory board of Deutsche Borse, the parent of the Frankfurt exchange, will vote next Tuesday on the plan, which needs support from three-quarters of the members.
But at least 2 of the 21 board members have publicly criticized the plan. More ominously, the economics minister for the state of Hesse, who regulates the Frankfurt exchange, is raising pointed questions as well.
And Donald Cruickshank, chairman of the London Stock Exchange, acknowledged on Wednesday that members of the London exchange would not approve the merger until they received more detailed information. That will not be coming until July, because many details remain to be negotiated.
In the meantime, Dieter Posch, the economics minister of Hesse, the state that includes Frankfurt, has demanded that the Deutsche Borse answer a list of 14 detailed questions.
Addressing Werner G. Seifert, chairman of Deutsche Borse, Mr. Posch questioned whether it was even realistic to create a system that would operate under two regulatory regimes -- a British one for blue-chip stocks, and the German one for small growth stocks.
Mr. Posch also demanded to know whether the Nasdaq venture would be managed from London; why the parent company of the new exchange, called iX, will be based in London; and whether German investors might end up paying higher transaction fees if they had to buy German blue-chip stocks in London.
Germany's powerful Bundesbank, whose board members heard a presentation by Mr. Seifert on Thursday, seems to cautiously support the merger.
At a news conference today, a Bundesbank board member, Hans Reckers, warned that Frankfurt had to keep control of trading in small growth stocks but said that the merger was fundamentally positive.
The main opposition in Germany appears to be coming from publicly owned savings banks and cooperative banks. Manfred Zass, head of the DGZ Dekabank in Frankfurt and a member of the German stock exchange's supervisory board, said on Wednesday that he would not agree to a merger that amounted to a "takeover" of the Frankfurt market.
Heinz Hilgert, a managing director at SGZ Bank, a cooperative bank in Frankfurt, said today that the overriding fear of smaller banks was of losing control of the market for growth stocks -- the "neue markt."
"This is clearly the domain of cooperative and public-sector savings banks, in both I.P.O.'s and in trading," Mr. Hilgert said. "The growth of this growth market has been in German, not Spanish, not French and certainly not British," he added, referring to companies.
Mr. Hilgert predicted that Nasdaq's American executives would inevitably view London rather than Frankfurt as their European center.
But some British executives are worried that London will lose its primacy, noting that Mr. Seifert is to become chief executive of the combined entity.
"The proposed takeover of the London Stock Exchange -- for that is effectively what it is -- by the Deutsche Borse has serious implications for London's continued role," wrote George Cox, director general of a British business association called the Institute of Directors.
In a letter to The Financial Times, Mr. Cox said that Mr. Seifert "is hardly likely to have London's interests as his main concern" and that the merger was being promoted by a small group of "powerful stock exchange members, all of whom appear to be American."
Goldman Sachs was the lead investment bank advising Deutsche Borse, while Merrill Lynch was among the banks advising the London Stock Exchange.

HEADLINE: Guatemalan Squatters Torching Park Forests

BYLINE: By DAVID GONZALEZ 

DATELINE: EL CEIBAL, Guatemala

 BODY:
The distant roar of howler monkeys echoed like a ghastly dirge on a recent day in the smoldering remains of a thick forest of palms, cedar and mahogany. Illegal loggers had cut down the best trees and hauled them off at night, while land-starved peasants torched what remained to clear the land for cornfields.
The effect of a population boom here has been disturbingly visible during the peak of the dry season in April and May, with the area's natural beauty shrouded in smoke from countless fires. 
 Although El Ceibal is a national park that is home to Mayan ruins, it is protected only on paper. The fires were set by invasores, or squatters, more than 200 of whom have lived in the park in two settlements of thatched-roof shacks since 1998.
They are part of an unending internal migration to Guatemala's Peten region, which covers a third of the country. It includes the sprawling, environmentally sensitive jungles of the Maya Biosphere Reserve, which is rich with wildlife, thick clusters of trees and majestic temples. The area's population is estimated to have grown from 20,000 in 1960 to almost a half million today -- not all illegal, but nonetheless harmful.
The fires, by and large, are set; some are from slash-and-burn farming gone awry, and others are touched off by poachers who hunt armadillos and large rodents by smoking them out of burrows and hollow logs. Some are even believed to be set by poor peasants who hope that the local authorities will hire them to help the understaffed local fire brigades.
The migration, with its accompanying fires and deforestation, underscores the problems facing Guatemala as it emerges from 36 years of civil war, ending in 1996. Peasants, including thousands who returned after years of exile in Mexico, scramble to find a patch of land they can farm. In their struggle for self-preservation, conservation is forgotten. And the government lacks money and manpower to fight all the fires, much less arrest wrongdoers.
"The Peten has served for the last 20 years as a pressure valve," said Roan McNab, the Guatemala program director for the Wildlife Conservation Society. "How can Guatemala prioritize conservation in the face of overwhelming pressure? When you're hungry for tomorrow, it's impossible to think 20 years down the road."
Since early April, fires have raged not only in El Ceibal, but also in several larger parks inside the reserve, scaring off or killing wildlife. The Guatemalan government mobilized soldiers and authorized $400,000 to fight the fires all over the country, a small amount for damage that is expected to extend to 125,000 acres, if rains do not start soon. But the aid has been slow to get to the hardest-hit areas.
The United States and Mexico have lent helicopters to help spot the fires and to bring water and food to park workers who have been battling the flames, snatching a few hours of fitful sleep on palm fronds spread on the jungle floor.
While the blazes can be battled, if slowly, it has proved more difficult to stem the flood of people who see the Peten as the promised land. It is a deceptive vision of lush land, since the thin layer of humus is unsuitable for agriculture. Settlers burn trees and bushes to enrich the ground with nutrients, which makes the land arable for three years at most. Then new land is cleared.
Peten natives used to earn a living by carefully managing the forests, tapping the sap from chicle trees for export to chewing gum manufacturers or plucking the leaves of xate palms to be used overseas in floral arrangements. The area's remoteness was its best protection.
But in the western part of the reserve, where oil production has been allowed, squatters followed the roads built to carry oil, carving out settlements when they could not find work in the oil fields.
Neria Virginia Guerrero Pinelo, who grew up in the central Peten, remembers how, as a child, she saw planes before she ever saw a car. When a road was built from Guatemala City in the 1960's, the transformation for the worse began. The situation deteriorated further during that era as the government encouraged development through an agency essentially run by the military that cleared land for farms and cattle ranches.
Now, she said, native Peteneros are in the minority, squeezed out by migrants from the south who bundle their belongings into pickup trucks and head to the Peten like latter-day Okies.
"They think the Peten is a paradise, and they hear the land is so rich," she said. "They come looking for work, but there is no work, so they take a little piece of land for a cornfield. There are large groups that go in, and they begin to cut trees and burn."
Some squatters, desperate for money, have been enlisted by illegal loggers who give them chain saws to cut down trees, then use them as security guards, having dozens ride on the trucks with their illegal bounty, ready to confront any authority who would try to stop them. In several recent instances, policemen or park workers were reported killed or tortured by squatters working for the loggers.
In El Ceibal, the squatters do not bother to hide. Their houses line the road into the park. The buzz of chain saws is common, said park workers, who, fearing attack, try to avoid the squatters. A few months ago, the squatters stole the solar panel that powered the park's only phone to prevent the administrator from calling the authorities.
Recently, while workers were trying to clear areas with machetes to contain a fire, the squatters were right behind them putting fresh wood on the fire, park workers said. There have also been scattered incidents of squatters stealing Mayan artifacts.
"When they finish with the wood, they will throw themselves into excavating the ruins, because that will be all that is left for them to destroy," said William Perlas Pineda, El Ceibal's caretaker.
Conservation has been difficult to promote. When Guatemala established the National Council for Protected Areas, peasants were angered that someone would interfere with their ability to use the land as they saw fit. Most regard the idea of protected lands as something foisted on them by groups from the United States and Europe.
"Some say we are protecting land for the gringos, while we Guatemalans have a right to land," said Marie Claire Paiz, the administrator of the Sierra del Lacanadon National Park.
Ms. Paiz said the peace accords' reference to every Guatemalan's right to land has been broadly interpreted. "Public land is seen as nobody's land," she said.
Equally new is the idea of enforcing the country's environmental laws, considered the best in Central America. Park workers and the police grouse that when they talk to squatters about their illegal land use, they are quickly told that to remove them would be a violation of their human rights. There is also fear that forcing the squatters to move would be denounced as mistreatment of indigenous peoples.
The government has been working with some international groups to sort out a quagmire of land titles, and it started a program this year of low-interest loans to acquire land. Officials have also enlisted international conservation groups to negotiate with the squatters to relocate them outside of environmentally sensitive areas. The Peten governor is trying to find land in a nearby town to resettle the El Ceibal squatters.
"There have been some positive examples of such moving, but very few," said Goran Fejic, director of the United Nations' mission monitoring the peace accords in Peten. "You need a long-term strategy of social development."
While some people fault the government for a lack of political will to address the problems, some initiatives are seen as hopeful signs. The government has been granting 25-year land concessions to some communities, letting them live off the area's above-ground resources as long as they come up with management and business plans.
The village of Uaxactun has the largest such concession, more than 200,000 acres. Run by a local assembly assisted by outside advisers, the concession has developed plans to sell allspice, xate palm and handicrafts.
To keep squatters out, Uaxactun has been made accessible only by passing through the guarded gates of Tikal National Park, to the south. Anyone wishing to move into the village must be approved by the entire community, though no one has yet to get the nod. Recently, a family whose carelessness led to a fire's getting out of control was expelled. But residents worry that the government may allow oil exploration nearby, which would mean more roads and settlers.
"Other people look at this with an eye to destruction," said Julio Cesar Corado, the vice president of the assembly. "Our plan is to manage and conserve this. Our area is rich, but we are not trying to get rich. We are only looking for equality among the members of our assembly, human rights, health and schools for our children."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS;
Stock Prices Fall as Fears of More Interest Rate Increases Grow

BYLINE: By ALEX BERENSON 

 BODY:
United States stock markets suffered another down trading session yesterday as investors became increasingly afraid that the Federal Reserve plans to raise short-term interest rates through the summer.
Technology stocks led the way down, with the Nasdaq composite index falling 148.31 points, or 4.2 percent, to 3,390.40. But other indexes were not spared, with the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index down 30.26 points, or 2.1 percent, at 1,406.95. The Dow Jones industrial average finished at 10,626.85, down 150.43 points, or 1.4 percent. 
 As has been the case for most of May, trading volume yesterday was light, with investors in no hurry to buy the new-economy companies they craved so ardently earlier this year.
Investors had shaken off their pessimism earlier, with rallies on Monday and Tuesday in advance of the Federal Reserve's decision to raise short-term interest rates by half a percentage point. Bulls had hoped that Tuesday's increase might be the Fed's last, because rate increases slow the economy and can hurt corporate profits.
But now investors seem to think that the Fed is not done. "After the rate hike, there was temporary euphoria. People said, 'They did 50 basis points. Phew, that's going to be it,' " said Michelle Clayman, chief investment officer at New Amsterdam Partners, which manages more than $1 billion. "Now people are saying that there's going to be more." (A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.)
 Barton Biggs, the global strategist for Morgan Stanley Dean Witter and a longtime bear, said he expected more rate increases. "The cyclical news on inflation is not good. Wage costs are increasing, and wage costs are sticky, so once they get embedded in the system, it's not so easy to get them out," he said. With energy prices also increasing, the Fed has no choice but to raise rates to slow the economy, Mr. Biggs said.
"Interest rates are going up," he said.
In addition, many money managers say they believe that the biggest technology companies will have to drop further before they are reasonably valued compared with both nontechnology companies and smaller Internet-focused technology names like Ariba and Phone.com. Last month's sell-off brutalized the money-losing companies that soared to huge valuations in 1999 and early 2000 as investors threw aside traditional valuation measures. Some of those stocks are down as much as 80 percent from their highs of March.
But their bigger cousins, like Cisco, Oracle and JDS Uniphase, have come through the last two months relatively unscathed. At 53 7/16, Cisco is down roughly one-third from its March 27 high of 82. Oracle has dropped to 70 1/16 from 90, a 22 percent slide.
Still,the technology leaders are hardly cheap. Both Cisco and Oracle trade at more than 100 times trailing earnings, almost four times the valuation of the average S.& P. 500 company and a level rarely seen before the last two years. Now, many professionals think the rout in the technology sector will not end until even the megacaps feel significant pain.
"The bear market is incomplete in technology stocks and the Nasdaq," Mr. Biggs said. "In this next stage, the big-cap tech companies that are wonderful companies but very overpriced stocks are going to get hit." He expects the Nasdaq to fall below 3,000, a drop of more than 10 percent.
Michael Murphy, editor of the California Technology Stock Letter and a longtime technology bull, expects the Nasdaq to remain at its current levels until the fourth quarter of this year, when earnings at leading technology companies finally begin to catch up with their stocks.
"Some of the smaller ones are getting reasonable, but you look at a Microsoft or Cisco, and they've come down by half, and they're still expensive," Mr. Murphy said.
Still, Mr. Murphy said he did not think the Nasdaq would fall below 3,321.29, its April 14 low, and he advised investors to remain patient. Demand for technology stocks is stronger than ever, he said.
"What's supporting the market is earnings. Earnings are just great," Mr. Murphy said. "Internet traffic is still doubling every 100 days. That's a huge driver. Computing is strong; communications is very strong, and consequently, semiconductors look good."
Michael Manns, senior portfolio manager at American Express Asset Management in Minneapolis, said he did not expect to see a commitment of capital to technology stocks until the Fed finishes raising short-term rates. "Investors are nervous," he said.
Nevertheless, Mr. Manns plans to keep buying technology and telecommunications. He recently attended a conference of automotive and industrial companies and found they were spending heavily on Internet equipment as a way to cut their operating expenses.
"Industrial companies are looking at the Internet as a really concrete way to lower their procurement costs and rationalize S.G.& A.," Mr. Manns said, using a common term for selling, general and administrative expenses, or corporate overhead.
"This is the area of growth in the marketplace," he said. "I'm willing to go ahead and buy on the dips."
For now, individual investors seem to concur. AMG Research, which tracks purchases and sales of mutual funds, said $7.9 billion flowed into stock funds for the week ended May 17, including almost $600 million into technology funds.

HEADLINE: Dearborn Journal;
Challenging Islamic Myth on Organ Transplants as Ailments Rise

BYLINE: By NICHOLE M. CHRISTIAN 

DATELINE: DEARBORN, Mich., May 17

 BODY:
Even now, six months after her decision, Najah Bazzy's family is still upset with her. Her 14-year-old daughter pleads with her to reconsider. Older relatives fear that she has offended God.
But Mrs. Bazzy is resolute. When she dies, her heart, liver, kidney and lungs will be donated. While thousands of other people have made the decision to sign organ donor cards or become live donors, Mrs. Bazzy's declaration is controversial. As an Arab-American Muslim, she is part of a community that ardently believes it is forbidden for Muslims to donate organs, even to a relative. To see Heaven, they say, their bodies must return to God in one piece. 
 These days, that notion is being challenged as increasing numbers of Arab-Americans here in what is perhaps their largest and most influential community in the United States, as well as their relatives back home, are found to have liver and kidney disease.
"There is a saying in Islam: He who saves a life saves humanity," said Mrs. Bazzy, a 40-year-old Lebanese transcultural nurse who is spearheading an initiative to include in Islamic wills a section for organ donations. "Why are we so eager to take our organs with us and give up the opportunity to save a life? How do I know I'm not depriving the world of a genius?"
That is why religious leaders are rallying with doctors and community outreach workers to dispel a decades-old myth that the Koran forbids organ donation.
At the same time, the International Association for Organ Donation, a year-old nonprofit organization founded by a former marketing executive whose teenage son was battling kidney disease, has started an education campaign. By introducing reluctant donors to Arab-American patients waiting for transplants and by holding dinners, distributing posters, bumper stickers and T-shirts, the group hopes to sign up thousands of the more than 275,000 Arabs here and in parts of Detroit. Doctors say organ transplants between relatives or people of the same ethnicity have a higher rate of success.
"There is no Islamic taboo banning the donation of organs," said Imam Hassan Qzawani, who heads the Islamic Center of America, which has more than 8,000 members and is one of Detroit's largest mosques. "People have reservations because it was not practiced in the old countries and because of Islam's strict guidelines about disfiguring the body. But as long as you're not giving your eyes or an organ that is needed for one's own survival, we have the right to help save someone's life."
Nadia Hammoud, 29, tried desperately last year to persuade her father to accept a kidney from his son. But he opted for a cadaver donation, which later failed.
"He would have waited another eight years rather than take it from my brother," Ms. Hammoud said.
In Michigan, about 20 people are waiting for either a kidney or liver transplant, said the Gift of Life Transplant Society of Michigan, which only last year started studying Arabs as a separate group. In the last six years, only one Arab-American donated an organ in Michigan, though at least a dozen have received transplants, doctors and organ donation researchers say.
Of the 69,399 patients waiting for organ transplants in the United States, it is unclear how many are Arabs. The United Network for Organ Sharing, in Richmond, Va., which oversees transplants in the United States, traditionally counts Arabs as Caucasian, a spokesman said.
But Joanna El Hajj, a health care coordinator at the Arab Community Center for Economics and Social Service, said she needed only to pick up her phone to know that the numbers were growing. The calls come with frightening frequency, Mrs. El Hajj says. Almost every day she is talking to someone, or the relative of someone, waiting for a kidney, liver or bone marrow transplant. The center routinely sponsors fund-raisers to help patients across the country pay medical bills and bring sick relatives to the United States for help.
"Four years ago, I would get maybe one call, two calls," said Mrs. El Hajj, who recently decided to become a donor. "Now, every day there is a new case. I get calls from Tulsa, from Boston, Maryland, Jordan, Iraq. We can't continue to ignore what is happening."
Mrs. El Hajj, who received a heart tissue transplant 26 years ago in London, has a theory about the increase in need: "We're seeing the aftereffects of war, I believe. A lot of the people who are coming, they lived through the chemical pollution of the civil wars in Iraq and Lebanon. It's like in Vietnam when they sprayed the gases, you only see the effects over a period."
Others believe that the Arab population is merely in the midst of growing pains.
"Anytime you have an immigrant community this large, eventually they will develop the same disease as the larger population," said Marwan Aboujould, director of transplant surgery at the Henry Ford Hospital in Detroit. "The problem is that medical technology and the population have surpassed the community's education.
"That can be as hard to overcome as issues of culture and faith."

HEADLINE: Coup Attempt in Paraguay Is Quickly Quelled

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: ASUNCION, Paraguay, May 19

 BODY:
For the third time in four years, Paraguay's fragile democracy was severely tested today, this time by mutinous soldiers and police officers who fired at the legislative building from armored personnel carriers before surrendering four hours later.
The government was back in full control this morning, and soldiers with automatic weapons set up checkpoints around the capital as passers-by gawked at bullet holes in the legislature's building. 
 President Luis Gonzalez Macchi, who took office in March after another crisis, went on television to assure citizens that the "antidemocratic" forces believed to be loyal to a former coup plotter had been defeated for good.
"Rest easy, countrymen," Mr. Gonzalez Macchi said. "Public order has been restored. The destabilizing and antidemocratic forces have been disbanded, the crisis brought under control, and the mutineers detained."
He said his government's response would be to accelerate economic and social reforms in the face of high unemployment and discontent.
Three members of Congress and 12 police officers were detained. Their roles in the uprising were unclear.
Interior Minister Walter Montalto Bower said the rebellious soldiers were sympathetic to former Gen. Lino Cesar Oviedo of the army, a fugitive wanted in the killing of Vice President Luis Maria Argana last year, an assasination that brought Mr. Gonzalez Macchi to power. General Oviedo was also suspected in a brief mutiny in 1996.
The crisis began when soldiers barreled through the capital late Thursday and headed to the palace. The standoff ended when the soldiers surrendered at 2:45 a.m., Col. Felix Dario Collante said. He would not say how many surrendered.
The permanent council of the Organization of American States "vehemently condemned" the coup attempt and expressed full support for the government.
This wobbly democracy, which emerged from the defeat of the 35-year dictatorship of Gen. Alfredo Stroessner in 1989, has been buffeted by one crisis. The latest was in March 1999, when Raul Cubas Grau was ousted as president and replaced by Mr. Gonzalez Macchi.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

F.T.C. Is Seeking Authority To Protect Privacy Online
Concluding that companies on the Internet have not properly protected the privacy of consumers, the Federal Trade Commission has decided to ask Congress for authority to impose tough consumer privacy safeguards.
The F.T.C. approved a staff recommendation in an unannounced vote to seek legislation giving it such authority. The action comes as the agency has stepped up investigations of several major Internet companies over their use of consumer data. It represents a sharp departure from the agency's previous policy of relying almost entirely on the industry to police itself. Democratic lawmakers in both the House and Senate, however, said this week that the prospects for final passage of any privacy measure were not strong. Page A1. 

Nissan Reports $6.3 Billion Loss
Nissan Motor said its loss widened to 684.4 billion yen on a consolidated basis, or $6.3 billion at current exchange rates, in the fiscal year ended March 31. Carlos Ghosn, the company's president, contended that while lower, the sales in fiscal 1999 were more profitable than in the previous year. C2.
 
China Trade Bill Edges Near Victory
Opponents of a decisive China trade bill refused to admit defeat and vowed to step up their lobbying over the weekend. But growing signs indicated that barring an unforeseen shift in votes or provocation by Beijing against Taiwan, the measure was edging toward victory. House Republican leaders scheduled a vote for Wednesday. A4.
 
Appeals Court Upholds Cable Law
A federal appeals court upheld the constitutionality of a law that sets limits on the size of a cable company. The ruling strengthens the hand of the government as it reviews AT&T's pending merger with MediaOne. C4.
 
Intel Revises Earnings Down 1 cents
Intel said that it had revised its first-quarter per-share earnings downward by a penny and had lowered sales by $28 million, disclosing the initial financial hit it would take for circuit boards found earlier this month to have a defective component. C14.
 
United States Trade Deficit Widens
The United States trade deficit widened to a record in March as surging demand for oil, automobiles and other imports overpowered a second consecutive monthly increase in exports, Commerce Department figures showed. The deficit in goods and services grew to $30.2 billion in March from $28.7 billion in February. Economists had expected a $29.5 billion deficit. Although the United States shortfall with China narrowed, record imports from Japan, Canada and Western Europe caused the trade gaps with those regions to widen. C2.
 
Korean Traders Plan Monday Strike
Thirty-thousand members of South Korea's securities industry union are planning to strike during their lunch hour Monday, when the stock exchange plans to continue trading during what has historically been a midday break. The change, approved by the South Korean government, makes this country the first in Asia to keep its stock exchange open during the lunch hour. C2.
 
Softbank Doubles Profit Forecast
Softbank, Japan's largest Internet investor, more than doubled its forecast for its annual earnings. C2.

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN;
CAMPAIGN BRIEFING

 BODY:

THE DEMOCRATS
 
A GETAWAY FOR THE GORES -- Vice President Al Gore and his wife, Tipper, escaped Washington yesterday to spend their 30th wedding anniversary at Bethany Beach in Delaware. The Gores were staying at the beach home of Tony Coelho, Mr. Gore's presidential campaign chairman, through Sunday. The couple took a Marine helicopter at taxpayer expense -- a requirement of the Secret Service, a spokesman said. Accompanying them were Mr. Gore's Secret Service detail, a military aide and a press aide, although the White House had not notified reporters of the vice president's travel until yesterday afternoon, after the Gores had left Washington. Mr. Gore last month had told reporters covering his presidential campaign that he would notify them when he traveled, including on his anniversary. "I will err on the side of openness and full access as much as possible," he said. But he apparently had not shared this decision with his wife, who has said she hopes to maintain her family's privacy even if her husband becomes president and in a recent interview questioned why reporters would need to accompany the vice president on private trips. Katharine Q. Seelye (NYT) 

THE REPUBLICANS
 
BUSH IN KENTUCKY -- Wending his way across Kentucky on a campaign bus, Gov. George W. Bush took his "compassionate conservatism" on the road yesterday, calling on the elderly to volunteer. At a center for the elderly in Paducah, Mr. Bush praised retired volunteers who share "wisdom, experience and values" as foster grandparents or mentors. He proposed to increase federal financing for such volunteer programs from $183 million a year to $240 million annually across five years. Some of the money would go to a pilot program, under which 10,000 low-income elderly volunteers would earn a $1,000 scholarship for a grandchild or a child of their choice. Alison Mitchell (NYT)
 
THE ISSUES
 
GORE WEB SITE ATTACKS BUSH PLAN -- Certain that Governor Bush has handed them the perfect campaign weapon with his Social Security proposal, the Gore campaign unveiled a new Web site this week devoted to attacking his plan. Its not-so-subtle address: www.bushinsecurity.com. The home page features a photograph of rolling dice (Mr. Gore likes to accuse Mr. Bush of promoting "casino economics") and a picture of a slightly crazed-looking Mr. Bush over the caption, "When he was asked if people could lose money under his plan, Bush replied, 'Maybe, maybe not." Asked to respond to the Web site, Ari Fleischer, Mr. Bush's spokesman, said, "Having invented the Internet, you would have thought Al Gore could have used it for something positive and not just another attack barrage." He added that he would check the site to see whether it included a link to the White House Web site that promotes the Clinton administration's proposal to invest Social Security money in the stock market, an idea Mr. Gore once supported. James Dao (NYT)
 
CONSERVATIVE NAMED TO N.R.A. BOARD -- Grover G. Norquist, president of a nonprofit anti-tax group called Americans for Tax Reform and a leader in conservative circles, has been elected to the board of the National Rifle Association, Mr. Norquist and N.R.A. officials said. Mr. Norquist has close ties to the Republican Party -- he is a friend of former Speaker Newt Gingrich and accepted $4.6 million in 1996 from the Republican National Committee to flood Congressional districts with literature defending Republican candidates. So his election is viewed by Democrats and gun-control advocates as further evidence of tightening bonds between the Republicans and the N.R.A., which he calls "the nation's largest civil rights group." Joining him on the board will be David Keene, chairman of the American Conservative Union. James Dao (NYT)
 
THE STATES
 
END OF POLITICAL WINDSTORM -- Richard A. Gebhardt, whose sound-alike primary challenge to the House minority leader, Representative Richard A. Gephardt, had Democrats in a tizzy in recent months, dropped his candidacy, a state spokesman announced yesterday. Mr. Gebhardt, 65, filed paperwork on Thursday withdrawing from the Third District primary and will not appear alongside the congressman on the Aug. 8 ballot, said Jim Grebing, a spokesman for Secretary of State Bekki Cook. "I stirred up a lot of wind, didn't I?" Mr. Gebhardt said with a laugh. (AP)

HEADLINE: Taiwan's New Leader Ends Decades of Nationalist Rule

BYLINE: By ERIK ECKHOLM 

DATELINE: TAIPEI, Taiwan, Saturday, May 20

 BODY:
Chen Shui-bian was sworn in as president of Taiwan this morning, a landmark for Taiwan's democracy but the start of a risky period in relations between this prospering island of 23 million people and a strengthening Chinese mainland that claims Taiwan as its own.
With his inauguration, Mr. Chen ended 50 years of rule -- much of it under martial law -- by the Nationalist Party that fled from the mainland under Chiang Kai-shek in 1949. 
 As the candidate of the Democratic Progressive Party, which has long advocated Taiwan's independence from China, Mr. Chen won a three-way race in March, in the island's second election of a national leader.
He succeeds Lee Teng-hui, 77, the flamboyant Nationalist who became world famous for ushering democracy to Taiwan but whose recent tenure was increasingly tainted by his party's vote-buying and corruption.
"This is the first peaceful transition of power from one political party to another in Taiwanese history and probably in all of Chinese history," said Wu Yu-shan, a political scientist at National Taiwan University. "But this triumph is being overshadowed by the prospect of deep tension across the Taiwan Straits."
Today, in his first speech as president, Mr. Chen repeated pledges not to declare independence unless Taiwan comes under attack, but he did not give Beijing the commitment to "one China" it demands, and serious new tensions seemed likely.
"Long live freedom and democracy," he shouted as he concluded.
The inauguration took place in a brief ceremony inside the presidential palace a few minutes after 9 a.m. Mr. Chen bowed before a picture of Sun Yat-sen -- who is claimed by both the Taiwanese and the mainland governments as founding father -- then pledged to uphold the Constitution and was handed the national seal.
The ceremony capped the storybook rise of Mr. Chen, 49, whose intelligence and preternatural determination took him from mud-house poverty to success as a corporate attorney before he became involved, in 1979, in the dissident movement against the Nationalists' authoritarian rule. He became a star of the opposition after his election as mayor of Taipei in 1994.
Annette Lu, 55, was sworn in as vice president. She is an outspoken feminist and advocate of Taiwan independence with a law degree from Harvard who spent more than five years in Nationalist prisons in the early 1980's.
Until recently, Mr. Chen called for Taiwan's formal independence from the mainland -- a step that Beijing has repeatedly said would bring a military attack. Seeking to broaden his appeal among the worried electorate and to placate the United States, which is pledged to help defend Taiwan but does not want to be drawn into war, Mr. Chen has moderated his position.
Mr. Chen now says that since Taiwan already functions like a state it does not need to declare independence. He has held out olive branches to Beijing, proposing to talk about strengthened commerce and even about the meaning of "one China."
Beijing officials have expressed growing impatience with Mr. Chen's refusal to accept their absolute precondition for any talks -- that Taiwan is part of a single China.
Earlier this week, the Communist Party's flagship paper, People's Daily, said that Mr. Chen has "adopted an evasive and defiant posture" over the one-China principle and that his friendly gestures "lack sincerity." It reminded him that "matters of sovereignty are not for negotiation."
In recent months, China has warned that indefinite delay in progress toward unity may be grounds for military action.
Mr. Chen's long-anticipated inaugural speech today was almost an anticlimax, devoted mainly to calls for domestic reconciliation, cleaner politics and economic issues.
In the most scrutinized portion, on cross-straits ties, Mr. Chen offered good will and pledged not to take formal steps toward independence. As long as the mainland does not use military force against Taiwan, he said, "I pledge that during my term in office, I will not declare independence."
He made one cryptic reference to "jointly" dealing "with the question of a future 'one China,' " which fell far short of the kind of commitment Beijing has sought.
The international turnout for today's ceremony provided a stark reminder of China's relative power and its campaign to isolate Taiwan diplomatically. Listed as attending were only four heads of state -- from Swaziland, Nicaragua, Palau and Nauru -- countries drawn from fewer than 30 states that have dared to recognize Taiwan in return for its financial aid.
Representing President Clinton was Laura D'Andrea Tyson, a former White House adviser. Although the United States sells defensive weapons to Taiwan and has strong economic ties, senior American officials do not visit since the United States, by agreement with Beijing, does not grant formal recognition.
Taiwan's political status and relations with Beijing are always central issues here. But Mr. Chen's strongest mandate from the election, analysts say, was in domestic affairs, especially to start cleaning up corruption in politics, including growing ties between local Nationalist politicians and organized crime.
As he takes on these and other issues, Mr. Chen will be operating in what for Taiwan is the novel territory of a divided government.
Mr. Chen received less than a majority of votes in the election and faces a legislature dominated by the Nationalists. Experts give him good marks for cobbling together a multiparty cabinet that may blunt some opposition. But many still wonder whether he can govern with any force in a jumbled system of presidential and parliamentary institutions that in the past was always controlled by one disciplined party.
In what many people here regarded as a master stroke, Mr. Chen persuaded the former Nationalist defense minister and a retired general, Tang Fei, to serve as prime minister. Mr. Tang is one of several holdovers in the national security field, a deliberate effort to assure various parties -- China, the United States and the Taiwanese -- that Mr. Chen will not act rashly to incite China.
Mr. Tang's powers relative to the president's are not clearly defined, and he has lately been suffering complications from surgery.
The cabinet includes a mix of Nationalists, members of Mr. Chen's party and others. But divisive questions have already been raised within the Nationalist and the Democratic Progressive parties about the party loyalty of those in the cabinet, and the extent to which they should follow Mr. Chen's lead on issues.
Since Mr. Lee, the outgoing president, was forced from his job as Nationalist Party leader, the Nationalists have been in chaos.
A new third party, led by James Soong, a former Nationalist, is struggling to lure supporters from the legislative ranks and define its role. And the Democratic Progressives have begun squabbling as well.
"Any new government is going to be somewhat messy and incoherent," said Shelley Rigger, an expert on Taiwan at Davidson College in North Carolina who gives Mr. Chen high marks under difficult circumstances. "Chen is trying to put together a government that can actually govern, and he had to violate the conventional rules of party politics."

HEADLINE: Financier Uses Scholarships To Spur Action

BYLINE: By EDWARD WYATT 

 BODY:
In a drive to fill all of the 7,500 empty seats in parochial and private schools in New York City, a philanthropic organization co-founded by Theodore J. Forstmann, the billionaire financier, has offered $50 million in new, partial scholarships to underprivileged children for this fall.
The program will be managed by the Children's Scholarship Fund, which Mr. Forstmann co-founded with John T. Walton, the son of Wal-Mart founder Sam Walton. The two men started the fund, which sends children from poor families to private schools, by each donating $50 million and then raising an additional $80 million from outside donors. 
 Letters awarding the 7,500 new scholarships were mailed this week.
The new scholarships, which will be paid for mostly by Mr. Forstmann, are part of his campaign against what he calls the "government monopoly" in elementary and secondary education. He wants to establish a system that would allow parents to send their children to any school with taxpayer-provided money, a move that he says would engender competition and draw scores of companies to start new schools.
"By the time this is over, I am going to give parents of this country a voice," Mr. Forstmann said in an interview yesterday. "And we will find out whether they want to be in charge of the education of their children or not."
Mr. Forstmann is one of a growing number of wealthy Americans who have turned their attention to elementary and secondary education. Among such philanthropists are Eli Broad, the chairman of Sun America, the insurance and financial services company; Leonard Riggio, the chairman of Barnes & Noble; William H. Gates 3rd, the co-founder of Microsoft; and George Lucas, the film maker.
Unlike most of those donors, Mr. Forstmann, who made his fortune on leveraged buyouts of companies like Gulfstream Aerospace and Dr Pepper, is intent on doing away with public education as it is structured today.
Describing himself as "a necessary voice for a new model for education," Mr. Forstmann foresees what some experts -- but not he -- would call a voucher program, that would allow parents to put the taxpayer-financed dollars that currently go to public schools toward sending their children to any school, religious or secular, private, for-profit or otherwise. Mr. Forstmann said he disavows the word voucher, however, because of the political implications it carries.
The Children's Scholarship Fund's initial $180 million is being used to help finance four years of private school for 40,000 children from low-income families around the country. Participating families are required to contribute about $1,000 annually toward the tuition. This year, the fund paid about $47 million, or up to $1,700 per child, including $2.5 million that went to 1,955 students in New York City.
The additional New York City scholarships were awarded on the same basis as the original ones: by lottery from among the 166,000 applicants who did not previously receive money.
The foundation received about 1.25 million applications from around the country.
About 92 percent of the New York City children who receive aid from the Children's Scholarship Fund attend church-affiliated or religious schools, about two-thirds of them Catholic. Mr. Forstmann said a survey of the city's parochial and private schools by the scholarship fund found about 7,500 available positions, mostly in church-related schools.
Mr. Forstmann said his program is not intended to promote religious education, but that those are the only alternatives now to public school.
"The demand is there, but the supply is not," Mr. Forstmann said. "Guess why? Because the one thing the government monopoly is very good at is keeping supply out."
By requiring taxpayers to pay for public schools and, if they want an alternative for their children, to pay that tuition as well, the government makes it economically not feasible for companies to open schools, he said.
The expanded scholarship program, Mr. Forstmann said, like the original, will help to awaken parents to the need for competition in the educational system. That, Mr. Forstmann believes, is the only way to increase the supply of education providers and encourage companies like General Electric, Microsoft or National Geographic to start schools to compete for the $370 billion spent annually in the United States on private and public elementary and secondary education.
Mr. Forstmann said yesterday that he intended to spend a considerable amount of time and money on the effort. While he briefly considered seeking the Republican nomination for United States Senate as an alternate to Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, Mr. Forstmann announced that he would not run early this week, before the mayor left the race. Instead, he said, he will campaign between now and November to encourage parents to demand change in the country's educational system.
The purpose of Mr. Forstmann's campaign is "to wake people up," he said.
"Who should be in charge of the education of a child -- the parent or the government?," Mr. Forstmann said. "Certainly most of the parents in America would say, 'Of course, it should be me.' But if they can't pick the school, they can't pick the subjects, and they can't pick who teaches the subjects, then you please tell me what they are in charge of."
While the scholarships are intended to help children from low-income families, he said: "We're also trying to get people to pay attention to what's really going on. If the current system was any good, we would be out of business in the Children's Scholarship Fund."

HEADLINE: U.S. Is Said to Seek New Law to Bolster Privacy on Internet

BYLINE: By STEPHEN LABATON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 19

 BODY:
Concluding that companies on the Internet have not properly protected the privacy of consumers, the Federal Trade Commission has decided to ask Congress for authority to impose tough consumer privacy safeguards, government officials said today.
In an unannounced vote taken today, the commission approved a staff recommendation to seek legislation giving the agency such authority. The action comes after the recent completion of a survey by the commission that found that only about 20 percent of major companies on the Internet had adequate standards for protecting the privacy of Internet users. 
 The commission's decision comes as the agency has stepped up its investigation of major Internet companies over their use of consumer data. It represents a sharp departure from the agency's previous policy of relying almost entirely on the industry to police itself. But lawmakers said that the prospects were not strong for Congress to adopt legislation so late in the session.
The legislation sought by the commission would permit it to regulate the kinds of notice given to consumers about use of information regarding them, as well as whether consumers can block that use. It would allow the commission to establish rules for keeping the information secure from third parties. And it would authorize the commission to penalize companies that violate privacy rules.
Commission officials are preparing to brief members of Congress about the proposal on Monday. The commissioners are also planning to testify before the Senate Commerce Committee on Thursday.
Democratic lawmakers in both the House and Senate who have been the most vocal advocates for privacy legislation said this week that the prospects for final passage of any privacy measure were not strong, since the Republicans have largely sided with industry and there are not enough legislative days remaining to pass a significant new measure.
"I would say the chances are virtually nil," said Representative Edward J. Markey, Democrat of Massachusetts, whose own privacy bill has stalled. "The Republican leadership is committed to not doing privacy this year in any area."
Nonetheless, a group of nine Democratic senators led by Ernest F. Hollings of South Carolina and John D. Rockefeller 4th of West Virginia is preparing to introduce a measure next week that is similar to what the commission has sought. The legislation also contains measures that appeal to Internet companies, most notably a provision that pre-empts all state law on Internet privacy.
"For many, privacy concerns represent the only remaining obstacle impeding consumers' full embrace of the Internet's ample commercial opportunities," Mr. Hollings said today. "Advances in technology have provided information gatherers the tools to seamlessly compile and enhance highly detailed personal histories of Internet users.
"Nonetheless, industry has to this point nearly unanimously opposed even a basic regulatory framework that would ensure the protection of consumer privacy on the Internet -- a basic framework that has been successfully adopted in other areas of our economy. My bill gives customers, not companies, control over their personal information on the Internet."
A report accompanying the commission's proposal for legislation found that the industry had made significant progress in policing itself, but not enough. Robert Pitofsky, the chairman of the trade commission, has said recently that there is a big role for companies to monitor themselves, but that as the market develops, there may also be a need for government to play a role as well.
Mr. Pitofsky has recently told others at the agency that while self-regulation was a crucial element of protecting privacy rights, he had also come to believe that the marketplace had developed sufficiently to seek new authority to give the government tools to prosecute companies that do not police themselves.
But industry groups say any effort to give the commission new rule-making authority would be an unwarranted incursion by the government into regulating cyberspace and could discourage the development of many start-up Internet companies.
"Even though this industry is the basis for a tremendous economic boom, most of these companies in fact aren't making money right now," said a lobbyist for a major Internet and entertainment company.
Christine A. Varney, a former member of the trade commission who is now representing an industry group, said the agency already had significant authority to crack down on companies that violated the privacy interests of consumers by engaging in deceptive practices.
"Clearly they already have authority and they have exercised it," said Ms. Varney, an adviser to the Online Privacy Alliance, a group of about 100 companies and associations interested in Internet issues.
But some privacy advocates call the agency's record disappointing.
"The bottom line is that the privacy gap between the safeguards in place and the intrusions seems to be growing not narrowing, and that has as much as anything to do with the lack of enforcement at the F.T.C.," said Marc Rotenberg, director of the Electronic Privacy Information Center, a research organization that studies privacy issues and technology. "There is little indication that self-regulation is working."

HEADLINE: THE MAYOR'S DECISION: THE GOVERNOR;
Lazio Was the Main Choice For Pataki From Beginning

BYLINE: By RAYMOND HERNANDEZ 

DATELINE: ALBANY, May 19

 BODY:
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's decision to drop out of the Senate race today may or may not turn out to be good for New York Republicans. But for one top Republican, Gov. George E. Pataki, there was no such ambiguity.
Mr. Pataki much preferred Representative Rick A. Lazio of Long Island as the Republican candidate to oppose Hillary Rodham Clinton. He supported Mr. Giuliani a few months ago only because of a growing consensus among State Republican Party leaders that Mr. Giuliani would be Mrs. Clinton's strongest opponent. 
In an interview today, Mr. Pataki said he believed that Mr. Lazio would ultimately be the party's choice to run against Mrs. Clinton. He described Mr. Lazio as a worthy candidate with a politically appealing record in Congress on issues like tax cuts and smaller government.
"I think he will be a very strong candidate," Mr. Pataki said. "He knows the issues. He has a knowledge of policy in Washington. He has a very different philosophy than Mrs. Clinton. He believes in what has worked in this state."
Mr. Pataki also tried to cut off speculation that he might enter the race himself, saying that he is happy to remain in his current job and support whoever becomes the Republican Party's candidate. "I think governor is one of the great jobs, and I love New York," Mr. Pataki said.
But many Republican officials interviewed today expressed some disappointment that Mr. Pataki has refused to jump into the race, saying that he is probably the strongest candidate the party has at this point.
Kemp Hannon, a Republican State Senator from Nassau County, said he had mixed feelings about Mr. Pataki's decision to stay out of the race. On the one hand, he said, the governor would pose a daunting challenge for Mrs. Clinton, given his statewide stature. But Mr. Hannon added that the governor's absence from Albany would be a major loss for the state and the party.
"He would be the strongest candidate," Mr. Hannon said. "But people support his policies in Albany and want to keep him as governor."
Another Republican senator put the matter more bluntly. "We would love the governor to run because he is by far the best candidate," the senator said, speaking on condition of anonymity. "There is no question that he would be the party's first choice, possibly even before Rudy."
Mr. Pataki, the de facto head of the state party, is formidable in many respects. He is the most successful fund-raiser in state history, and has won two statewide races in a largely Democratic state. He has also kept his political operation running at a feverish pace in a nonelection year, raising $3.2 million since 1999 through three political action committees he has established.
The governor has used the money to raise his profile nationally. He has hired nationally known political consultants like Benjamin L. Ginsberg, an elections specialist and Washington lawyer who serves as a campaign adviser to Gov. George W. Bush of Texas, and Stephen Moore, an economist with the Cato Institute in Washington.
But Mr. Pataki has good reason to want to stay put. If Mr. Pataki stepped down as governor, he would forfeit his annual state salary of $177,984 a year and any additional income that he earns from outside activities. He received $48,000 for three speeches he gave last year, and $50,000 for speeches he gave in 1998. He also received $24,000 for his autobiography. His salary would be considerably less in Washington, where rank-and-file members earn about $140,000 a year.
As governor, Mr. Pataki also appoints hundreds of people to important positions in state government -- people who, in turn, could return the favor in a number of ways, including volunteering in the governor's campaign and raising funds for him. As senator, he would be entitled to make only a couple of dozen appointments.
The governor's job also gives Mr. Pataki the status of the unchallenged boss of the state party, not to mention control over a $77 billion-a-year enterprise full of jobs and lucrative contracts that can be awarded to friends. United States senators rarely get that kind of power, either in their own party or in the day-to-day affairs of government.
That said, Mr. Pataki has shown some interest in leaving Albany. Last year, for example, he gave a series of speeches around the country in an effort to bolster his national stature. Mr. Pataki was widely seen as vying for a spot on the Republicans' national ticket, possibly as a vice presidential candidate.
But today, Mr. Pataki tried to dispel any notion that he was seeking a job in Washington, including a cabinet post in a new Republican administration. "Right now, I see myself in New York," he said in an interview. "If I were looking in Washington, I would have taken a harder look at the Senate race."

HEADLINE: Three States After Plum Role: Hollywood East;
De Niro and Miramax Scout Locations for a Studio

BYLINE: By LISA W. FODERARO 

 BODY:
They are the bouquets and bonbons of the economic-development world, and these days they are raining down on Robert De Niro, the Academy Award-winning actor, and Harvey Weinstein of Miramax Films, who are still looking for a place to build a sprawling film studio.
New York State is down on one knee, pledging a road and perhaps even a sewer system. New Jersey is whispering sweet nothings about sales tax exemptions and possibly a direct capital investment. And Connecticut, though hush-hush about its exact courtship strategy, is also dangling tax incentives. 
 In the seven months since a tentative film studio deal between New York City, Mr. De Niro and Miramax Films collapsed, the three states have wasted no time in wooing the taciturn film star and his influential partner, Mr. Weinstein, co-chairman of Miramax. Officials say they are eager to pick up the ball they believe Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani dropped.
It was no secret that the partners felt burned when the Giuliani administration announced in October that it had chosen another set of developers to build studios at the Brooklyn Navy Yard. Mayor Giuliani had, after all, tried out his best Godfather imitation for Mr. De Niro and then held a glittering news conference in Brooklyn about their collective vision for a sound stage complex there.
But the city's sudden shift in favor of other developers (after administration members decided that that group would build the studios faster and require less city money) apparently did not dim the interest of Mr. De Niro in creating a film studio in the New York region. Although a record number of films and television shows have been shot in New York and New Jersey in recent years, members of the movie industry and state officials have long complained about the area's shortage of sound stages, which has forced filmmakers to go to Los Angeles and Toronto for indoor photography.
The leading studio site contenders appear to be properties in the city of Yonkers in southern Westchester County and in the Hudson County town of Harrison, N.J., two municipalities desperate to redevelop their industrial waterfronts with the sort of sexy centerpiece that the movie partners could provide. Mr. De Niro and Mr. Weinstein had briefly considered sites in New York City, but they have zeroed in on those two tracts, according to someone who went on some of the tours.
Neither Miramax, a subsidiary of the Walt Disney Company, nor Mr. De Niro's company, TriBeCa Productions, would comment on their quest for a parcel. But people who have met with the actor and Mr. Weinstein and seen architects' sketches for the two sites say their plan goes beyond a large film studio to include housing and possibly stores and restaurants. Such elements could make the proposal more attractive to investors skittish about the possibility of studios sitting empty between productions.
"There's a dire need for studios in New York," said Charles A. Gargano, chairman of the Empire State Development Corporation, New York State's economic development agency. "The problem is these things do not work by themselves. They do not generate enough money, so they have to have some additional development with them."
Some developers and film executives doubt whether Miramax and TriBeCa Productions will ever get a shovel in the ground. They cite a series of grand plans for film studios in recent years that either evaporated or were drastically scaled back, mostly for lack of financing.
Abandoned late last year, for instance, was an ambitious plan to build a television and movie studio complex on top of a Manhattan office building at Houston and West Streets. The $160 million project, called Hudson River Studios, was to include five sound stages. But the developers lost their financing after two soap operas that had committed to using the space pulled out.
In addition, after years of robust growth, the number of feature films shot in New York City actually fell by 12 last year to 209. The Mayor's Office of Film, Theater and Broadcasting is quick to point out that film production was down slightly nationwide as well. But the office still contends that there is not enough studio space in New York to meet demand.
Others disagree. They cite a glut of studio space in Los Angeles and fear an eventual glut in the New York region, too, especially if the developer selected for the Brooklyn Navy Yard, New York Studios, realizes its plan for 11 sound stages. The development group, led by Douglas C. Steiner, is demolishing buildings at the site.
And Kaufman Astoria Studios in Queens is adding a seventh studio, but its president, Hal G. Rosenbluth, said: "We're pushing the envelope to believe you can build dozens of stages and actually fill them. We're never going to displace Hollywood. All the creative decisions to green-light things are still in Los Angeles, and the majority of the actors, directors and producers live in L.A."
But officials in New York and New Jersey are downright bubbly, promoting the superiority of their respective sites as they assemble incentive packages for Mr. De Niro and Mr. Weinstein.
Connecticut is more coy. Edward Dombroskas, executive director of the state's film office, said the filmmakers "are looking at a couple of different sites, but I can't reveal where they are." Mr. Dombroskas was also circumspect about incentives, but did say breaks on sales and property taxes were available to companies locating in so-called entertainment zones.
In New Jersey, the filmmakers are looking at a former steel plant on the Passaic River in Harrison, according to local and state officials. In 1998, an independent film production company in Manhattan, the Shooting Gallery, settled on the same 41-acre site for a grandiose studio plan with 15 sound stages and a $75 million price tag. That plan was abandoned for a much smaller project in Manhattan, on Leroy Street in the West Village.
Harrison officials think a Miramax-De Niro studio would have a better chance of succeeding given the principals' track records. The mayor of Harrison, Raymond J. McDonough, said he met with representatives of TriBeCa Productions and Miramax in April, and "they asked me how they could obtain all the property in the redevelopment area."
Meanwhile, officials are offering several lures, from financing through the Hudson County Improvement Authority to annual payments to the studio company over 10 years that would represent a portion of the state income tax revenue generated by the new jobs.
Gualberto Medina, New Jersey's secretary of commerce, said the state was also considering a direct investment of money in the project and was working with the filmmakers on a "joint request for proposals" from potential real estate developers.
Local and state officials said the Harrison property would be perfect for a studio complex: it has a cavernous column-free building with 103,000 square feet and a 100-foot-high ceiling, and it is across the street from a PATH train station. Gregory J. Castano, the lawyer for the Harrison Redevelopment Agency, said, "No other site offers a building like that."
The Yonkers site, a former wire factory, also has a building with a 100-foot ceiling, sans columns, although it is smaller, at 30,000 square feet. The 13-acre parcel may be a bit cramped for a mixed-used development, but it is a striking location, sitting alongside the Hudson River, with the wooded cliffs of the Palisades across the way and the Manhattan skyline to the south. It, too, is convenient to public transportation, with a Metro-North Railroad stop only a couple of hundred yards away.
The soaring main building, which is clad in unfortunate powder-blue panels, was recently used to film a scene from "Sleepy Hollow" -- a nighttime shot of a cornfield that entailed hauling in 600 tons of dirt.
"The girth of the walls, the thickness of the floors, the enormity of the space -- it's got such character," said Paul W. Adler, the general manager of commercial services for Prudential Rand Realty, which represents the property's owner, BICC P.L.C. "Some of the offices look like something you could film a Bogart movie in."
BICC, a transportation and development company in London, is talking to Mr. Weinstein and Mr. De Niro about a joint venture, Mr. Adler said. That would also enable the company to oversee a necessary environmental cleanup of the site, estimated to cost $7.5 million.
Mr. Gargano, the economic development chairman in New York State, said the state reached out to the filmmakers after learning that they were looking in New Jersey last fall. While New York would not contribute "seed money" to the studio project, the state could help with infrastructure improvements and savings on sales tax, he said.
"The key thing here is to get them to build studios in New York," Mr. Gargano said. "That's a very important industry, and it's good for New York State. New Jersey is ahead of us because they've been dealing with them longer."
So are Mr. De Niro and Mr. Weinstein stringing along New Jersey and New York, the same way that the Giuliani administration treated them? State and local officials say their eyes are open. "They've been candid that they're looking at other areas," said Mr. Castano, the lawyer for the Harrison Redevelopment Agency, "and we've known that from the beginning."

HEADLINE: HOCKEY;
Sather One Step Closer to the Rangers

BYLINE: By JASON DIAMOS 

 BODY:
After 24 years with the Edmonton Oilers, Glen Sather, the team's president and general manager, announced his resignation yesterday. The only question now is whether he will end up in New York or Phoenix, running either the Rangers or the Coyotes.
Sather, 56, is the Rangers' first choice for their vacant team presidency. Dave Checketts, the president of Madison Square Garden, who has already met twice with Sather, will most likely attempt to arrange a third meeting in the next few days, said a person familiar with the Garden's thinking. 
 Checketts's time frame may be affected by Wayne Gretzky's plans. Gretzky, who played for Sather in Edmonton, Alberta, and is good friends with him, is mulling an offer to become the majority owner in Phoenix and could try to persuade Sather to go with him.
The Oilers' general manager for the last 21 years, Sather gave up his positions yesterday morning, forfeiting the last two years of a contract that would have paid him almost $2 million a year.
"I am a free agent," Sather said at last night's news conference in Edmonton after announcing his resignation. "I don't like the process, but I think it's the right thing to do."
Cal Nichols, chairman of the Edmonton ownership group, said the Oilers would not seek compensation from any team that signed Sather. He also said the Oilers would not pursue tampering charges against other teams, after saying Thursday that they might.
"We just thought it was the ethical thing to do, just drop it and let everyone get on with their lives," Nichols said.
Sather said he did not have a job offer on the table. "This is the first time since I was 16 years old that I've been unemployed."
Speaking about the possibility of a position with the Coyotes, Sather said, "The last I looked, Phoenix had a general manager, they don't have new ownership and I'm not sure Wayne's going there." But he also said his decision would not depend on what Gretzky did.
Sather said he would not have left the Oilers had Jim Hole not been succeeded by Nichols. "I never thought I'd leave the organization," he said. "I thought I'd retire here. But things change."
Nichols said that "this didn't happen in 24 hours," and, noting that the Oilers' owners expected to lose $8 million this season, added, "In part, this all boils down to money."
 Before flying to Edmonton for the news conference, Sather spoke from an airport near his home in La Quinta, Calif. "I would say that my biggest regret is that it eventually had to come to this," he said. "But sometimes in life, you need a new adventure. I'm looking forward to whatever happens. I haven't decided on what I'm doing. I'm just going to take it one step at a time."
As has been the case throughout his search for a new Rangers president, coach and general manager, Checketts had no comment yesterday.
Friends and associates of Sather have expressed skepticism that he was leaving Edmonton for New York. Sather is more comfortable in the West.
But Sather played down that factor. "It's easier and quicker to get from New York to La Quinta than it is from Edmonton to La Quinta," he said Thursday night, adding that his wife is from Philadelphia. "When I played in New York, I loved it."
Sather played left wing for the Rangers for four seasons, from 1970 to 1973. Later, as coach and general manager in Edmonton, he came to be synonymous with the Oilers, who won five Stanley Cups with him at the helm.
Four of those cup triumphs came with Gretzky as the Oilers' captain. Gretzky, who retired from the Rangers a year ago, is weighing an offer from Steve Ellman, an Arizona developer, to become majority owner of the Coyotes. Ellman, however, is having difficulty meeting payments to secure his purchase of both the team and land for a new arena in Scottsdale.
Those in hockey who know both Gretzky and Sather say that the race is on between the Rangers and Gretzky. "If the Rangers do what they can do, they'll make Glen make his decision before Gretz makes his," said one person, who insisted on anonymity. "The Rangers need to move quickly now."
Earlier this month, the Rangers and Ellman were both granted permission to speak with Sather by Hole, who represents Edmonton on the National Hockey League's board of governors. Hole is a close Sather ally. Nichols, who replaced Hole as chairman of the team earlier this season, is not.
Many expressed surprise that Sather decided to leave. But he grew frustrated with the constraints of running a small-market team. Edmonton's $21.2 million payroll this season ranked 22nd in the 28-team league. Yesterday, Sather cited a change in ownership, a change in the leadership of the ownership, and the inability of Canadian teams to receive financial subsidies from their national government as factors in his decision.
"I don't think it's been an instant, spin-of-the-moment, not-thought-out decision," Sather said. "It's been around for a couple of years. I've been there for almost 25 years. I had a lot of great times and a lot of great experiences. I just think it's time to look around and take some time off.
"Unfortunately, this had to come to an end," Sather said. "But I've been thinking pretty hard about it for quite a long time."
