HEADLINE: John Sawhill, Ex-N.Y.U. Chief Who Led Conservation Group, Dies at 63

BYLINE: By DAVID STOUT

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 19

 BODY:
John C. Sawhill, a former president of New York University who advised three presidents on energy policy and for the last decade of his life was president and chief executive of the Nature Conservancy, died on Thursday at a hospital in Richmond, Va. He was 63 and lived in Washington and Virginia.
 The cause of death was diabetes, the Nature Conservancy said. 
 Mr. Sawhill became head of the conservancy, which describes itself as the world's largest private conservation group, in January 1990. The organization's mission is to preserve animals and plants by acquiring land and water to protect the environment from development.
 The conservancy said in a statement today that during Mr. Sawhill's tenure it had protected more than seven million acres of land in the United States; that the conservancy work force had tripled, to about 3,000, and that its membership had more than doubled, to 1.1 million people.
 The conservancy said that in 1995, under Mr. Sawhill's direction, it completed the largest fund-raising campaign in the history of the conservation movement, raising $315 million. Last March, Mr. Sawhill announced the start of a $1 billion campaign.
 Mr. Sawhill was president of New York University from 1975 to 1979. When he took office, the university, like its hometown, was mired in debt and its very future seemed in danger. Mr. Sawhill, who was a professor of economics while serving as president, led a huge fund-raising drive and was widely credited with putting the university's finances back in order.
 Ann Mancuso, dean of the N.Y.U. School of Education, said today that Mr. Sawhill was a risk taker and a strong manager, believing that crises required new approaches. She praised him for helping women achieve positions of responsibility at the university.
 Mr. Sawhill was a lean six-footer, ascetic in behavior and diet. He rose early, often running for a few miles before starting his workday. Lunch might be fresh fruit, cheese, crackers and a soft drink. Ms. Mancuso recalled fondly that some of his first luncheons at N.Y.U. were notable for "extremely tiny portions of unappetizing food." More seriously, she wondered whether his habits were part of his never-ending campaign to stave off the effects of diabetes, a disease she never knew he had.
 Laurence A. Tisch, co-chairman of Loews Corporation and a longtime friend of Mr. Sawhill, also expressed surprise today upon learning of Mr. Sawhill's disease. Mr. Tisch described Mr. Sawhill as "a very private man," especially for a public figure, and one who managed to be blunt and honest without being rude.
 Under Presidents Richard M. Nixon and Gerald R. Ford, he was administrator of the Federal Energy Administration, deputy administrator of the Federal Energy Office, and associate director for energy and environmental matters in the Office of Management and Budget.
 In late 1974, Mr. Sawhill was forced out by President Ford, undone in part by his candor. With the country still reeling from an oil shortage, Mr. Sawhill favored additional gasoline taxes, and said so in public. President Ford opposed new gasoline taxes.
 Mr. Sawhill also conceded in an interview that the Ford administration did not have a plan to stop the rise in oil prices -- an admission that was not exactly a surprise, but one that fanned criticism of the administration as having a less than clear-cut energy policy.
 Though his credentials as an environmentalist became impeccable, Mr. Sawhill's positions were not always predictable. In 1974, for instance, he said that the environmental risks of strip-mining coal might be acceptable to meet national energy demands. That year, he said oil drilling off the New England coast, an idea that horrified fishermen, lobstermen and many environmentalists, should not be beyond consideration.
 And he told a Senate committee in 1974 that higher fuel prices were not necessarily bad, especially if they encouraged oil companies to find new supplies.
 Mr. Sawhill was deputy energy secretary under President Jimmy Carter, then became chairman and chief executive of the United States Synthetic Fuels Corporation. From 1981 until 1990, he was a director of McKinsey & Company, the international management consultants, specializing in energy issues.
 John Crittenden Sawhill was born in Cleveland on June 12, 1936, and grew up in Baltimore. He graduated cum laude from Princeton University's Woodrow Wilson School of Public and International Affairs in 1958 and received a doctorate in economics from New York University in 1963. From 1960 to 1963, he was assistant dean and assistant economics professor at N.Y.U.
 He is survived by his wife, Isabel, a senior fellow at the Brookings Institution; a son, James, of San Francisco; a brother, James, of Newport News, Va.; two sisters, Sally Supplee of Palo Alto, Calif., and Munroe Hodder of London, and a grandson.
 As head of the Nature Conservancy, Mr. Sawhill pressed for more cooperation between business interests and environmental groups. He refused to see an unbridgeable chasm between profits and clean air and water, and he insisted that Americans would never succeed in cleaning up the environment unless there was growth in per capita income.
 In 1998, George magazine announced, not entirely tongue in cheek, that Mr. Sawhill's accomplishments and free-ranging intellect made him ideal to be president of the United States.
 "I saw President Clinton after the George story came out," Mr. Sawhill said. "I told him he didn't have to worry."

CORRECTION-DATE: May 22, 2000

 CORRECTION:
An obituary on Saturday about John Sawhill, president and chief executive of the Nature Conservancy and former president of New York University, misstated the surname of the dean of the N.Y.U. School of Education, who reminisced about his management style. She is Ann Marcus, not Mancuso.

And Bear in Mind
(Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest)
 
DREAMBIRDS: The Strange History of the Ostrich in Fashion, Food, and Fortune, by Rob Nixon. (Picador USA, $23.) Camouflaged as natural history, ode to gawky beauty and social study of precarious empires built on feathers, this book is at bottom a haunting memoir of a South African boyhood.
 
THE FEAST OF LOVE, by Charles Baxter. (Pantheon, $24.) A luminous he-said-she-said of a novel, in which He, a handsome toadlike man, and She, Ex-Wife No. 1, unspool contrary narratives of their life together.
 
THE HUMAN STAIN, by Philip Roth. (Houghton Mifflin, $26.) The novel's doomed protagonist is a modern converso: a black man passing as a Jew so he'll be taken for white; our old friend Nathan Zuckerman tells his story.
 
HUNTS IN DREAMS, by Tom Drury. (Houghton Mifflin, $22.) A sequel to "The End of Vandalism" set in the same bleak farm community, this novel centers on the ex-vandal, now a plumber (gone straight more from detachment than maturity), as he confronts the breakup of his marriage.
 
JOHN RUSKIN: The Later Years, by Tim Hilton. (Yale University, $35.) Opening when its subject is 40 and a rising authority on aesthetics, Volume 2 of this vast biography charts Ruskin's unraveling from passionate cataloger (rocks, plants, buildings, paintings, clouds) to tragic obsessive (irrigation, drainage, running water, little girls).
 
THE MAN WHO WROTE THE BOOK, by Erik Tarloff. (Crown, $23.) Dead-ended at a jerkwater college, the scholar hero of this riotous novel strikes pseudonymous pay dirt as a pornographer: his magnum opus, "Every Inch a Lady," out-Potters Potter and draws a glowing notice -- by Updike yet -- in the very pages you are holding.
 
THE MANY ASPECTS OF MOBILE HOME LIVING, by Martin Clark. (Knopf, $24.) This first novel by a Southern judge features . . . a Southern judge, who logs overtime as cuckold, bribe taker, treasure hunter and devoted tester of controlled substances but by the end has become a guy worth knowing. (Caveat: Contains one scene in which a certain discomfort befalls two small kitties.)
 
MEN IN THE OFF HOURS, by Anne Carson. (Knopf, $24.) There is a startling freshness deep down these poems, the work of a writer for whom the ever-sharp world exerts attractive and repulsive forces in equal measure.
 
NEWJACK: Guarding Sing Sing, by Ted Conover. (Random House, $24.95.) A journalist's account of his year as a correction officer, where his moral well-being was as much at risk as his bodily safety.
 
SIX FIGURES, by Fred G. Leebron. (Knopf, $22.) The yuppie couple in this novel, no strangers to anger, covetousness and envy, now confront great violence -- and the suspicion that it is home-grown.

HEADLINE: BOOKEND;
Navigating the Amazon Circle

BYLINE: By Katie Hafner; Katie Hafner is a reporter for the Circuits section of The Times.

 BODY:
Introduce a computer to a heap of raw data and the temptation to slice the information every which way can prove irresistible. One example is Amazon.com's purchase-circle program, which enables customers to see what books are popular among different groups. Apparently, the idea is that readers can learn the buying preferences of people with whom they might have something in common, or about whom they might be curious, and that one can glean insights into a place or company by seeing, for instance, that a top seller in Kenya is "The Carbohydrate Addict's Lifespan Program" or that in Hoboken, N.J., a number of people want to know how to put on a Jewish wedding.
Amazon has two types of purchase-circle lists. There are rankings strictly by the numbers, and the Harry Potter books invariably top the list. More interesting are the "uniquely best-selling" books -- titles that are more popular with a particular group than among Amazon.com customers generally. 
 A recent look shows that people in affluent Pacific Palisades, Calif., for example, are working hard on their marriages and culinary skills. Winter Park, Fla., is steeped in self-pity; its residents read "Trapped in the Mirror: Adult Children of Narcissists in Their Struggle for Self." And religion is a big deal in Nyack, N.Y.; the books selling there are "More Light on the Path: Daily Scripture Readings in Hebrew and Greek" and "Encountering the Old Testament."
Overseas, meanwhile, all of Luxembourg seems worried about the stock market and the Internet bubble, while Romanians are obsessed with management and public relations. Latvians are more well rounded in their tastes, if a bit slow on the uptake, as they are just now discovering "Emotional Intelligence," Daniel Goleman's 1995 best seller, and "The Seven Habits of Highly Effective People," which was published in 1989. As expected, the French are worried about the United States. Amazon's No. 1 seller in France is "Manifest Destiny: American Expansionism and the Empire of Right," a book that normally ranks around 102,000 on the company's main list. The French are also obsessed with Raymond Carver's "Short Cuts."
In Chappaqua, N.Y., the new home of the Clintons, kids matter a lot; the biggest sellers there include "Nurturing Good Children Now."
What are those in government buying? Representatives are working on their golf games and apparently taking some pleasure in reading about the fall from grace of their former colleague Dan Rostenkowski. Senators, on the other hand, are dipping into slightly more highbrow literature -- that is, until you reach
No. 8 on their list: "Diana in Search of Herself."
Then there are corporate purchases -- or, rather, purchases made by people who supply Amazon with their corporate e-mail addresses. Much has been made of the competitive lessons that can be taken from a company's reading list. At Qualcomm, a highflying high-tech company in San Diego, it would appear that when workers aren't busy exploring their surroundings ("Afoot & Afield in
San Diego") and exercising, they are worrying
about money, with five books on stock options and investment guides among the 10 best sellers.
If you believe the purchase-circle data, employees at Wired Ventures are not only happy-go-lucky youngsters, they are uninterested in business books altogether, as they devour such works as "Mind Hunter: Inside the F.B.I.'s Elite Serial Crime Unit" and "The Simpsons Forever!" No. 9 there is "How to Be a Great Lover: Girlfriend-to-Girlfriend Totally Explicit Techniques That Will Blow His Mind."
Not only are many Texaco employees on the same carbohydrate-rich diet that all of Cairo (Egypt, that is) is trying, but -- personnel managers, take note -- many are also buying "What Color Is Your Parachute? A Practical Manual for Job Hunters and Career Changers." They're shedding pounds over at Toyota, too, but the workers are also interested in new approaches to management and are buying "First, Break All the Rules: What the World's Greatest Managers Do Differently."
Not a frivolous moment is to be had at the Gap, where workers are buying "Nothing's Impossible," a book about leadership, and "The End of Fashion," about the mass-marketing of clothing. Then there's the beleaguered Levi Strauss & Company, whose top books are "Journey to the Emerald City: Achieve a Competitive Edge by Creating a Culture of Accountability" and "Building Strong Brands."
And at Microsoft? Everyone appears to be learning Japanese.
The purchase-circle lists also neatly reinforce stereotypes. In Sedona, Ariz., known for its love of all things New Age, they're reading "Sanctuary: The Path to Consciousness." Managers at the United States Postal Service still have a few morale kinks to iron out, as a big seller there is "Why Employees Don't Do What They're Supposed to Do and What to Do About It." And NASA really is filled with geeks reading "Low-Speed Wind Tunnel Testing."
Manhattanites, of course, are obsessed with parties, housing and finding a private school for their tots. Sure enough, they're reading "The Manhattan Directory of Private Nursery Schools," "The Manhattan Family Guide to Private Schools," "New York's 100 Best Places to Have a Party" and "Tenant Power" (author: Tenant X).
Fun, isn't it? Maybe. Amazon has taken a lot of heat for the threat to privacy that its circles pose. It makes the argument that it does not make individuals' purchases public (even though its database is capable of doing so), and the lists give no actual sales figures. Further, a company or group can opt out and request that its buying habits not be included in the listings. Barnesandnoble.com, Amazon's biggest rival, which happily followed suit when Amazon began posting each book's sales ranking, has reached for the moral high ground. It publishes no equivalent to the purchase-circle lists. But the privacy concern seems to be something of a red herring. The real objections to the lists should center not on the threat to personal privacy they present, but on their silliness.
So why does Amazon have purchase circles? To keep users on the site, clicking away voyeuristically while catching the Amazon aura? Even the company's executives seem a bit unclear on this point. During an interview, J. J. Jacobi, Amazon's director of product development, stumbled a bit at this question. Customers enjoy the lists, she said, and look at them "just for fun." She carried on in this vein until her public relations woman, who was monitoring the interview, broke in to help her out. "It's to help customers make better purchasing decisions," she said.
Just how these lists are supposed to help customers make purchasing decisions is a mystery. But no matter. They will also tell you what's big in music, videos and electronics. Only in its selection of videos does Manhattan's intellectual bent emerge: after "Sesame Street" sing-along videos are "The 400 Blows," "Last Year at Marienbad" and "Jules and Jim." Chappaquidians, it turns out, are mad for the soundtrack from "The Simpsons" and the Backstreet Boys, the Palm V electronic organizer and the "Yellow Submarine" DVD. In fact, folks in Chappaqua buy a lot more DVD's than videotapes, which tells you something about their disposable income level, in case you didn't already know.
IN La Jolla, Calif., another affluent community, the purchase lists show residents reading "Life: The Science of Biology" and "The Pump House Gang." But if you want some real insight into La Jolla's literary preferences, ask Adrian Newell, a buyer and manager at Warwick's bookstore, whose inventory is small but whose customers realize that she always has them in mind. She knows they go for science essays and inspirational books but not celebrity biographies. She keeps "Galileo's Daughter" well stocked, along with "Eleanor of Aquitaine." She also knows a good deal more about the lifestyles and political bent of her neighbors than Amazon does. "The majority of my clientele is 50-something," she said. "They are politically conservative, they like to travel and they have disposable income." She knows, too, that what sells well in La Jolla won't sell in the bookstore in the neighboring town of Del Mar. That store "sells younger, edgier fiction," she said. "Tons of Nick Hornby. Whereas I carry all these cozy mysteries."
When Amazon's computers can create a virtual Adrian Newell for each of its purchase circles, then it might really be on to something, even if that something is less fun to browse.

HEADLINE: Tightening the Noose

BYLINE: By Charles B. Dew; Charles B. Dew teaches Southern history at Williams College and has recently completed a study of the Southern secession commissioners and the causes of the Civil War.

 BODY:

 Ben Tillman and
 the Reconstruction
 of White Supremacy
 By Stephen Kantrowitz.
 Illustrated. 422 pp. Chapel Hill:
 The University of North Carolina Press.
 Cloth, $49.95. Paper, $19.95. 
 BENJAMIN RYAN TILLMAN came of age in 1876, Stephen Kantrowitz writes in this thoughtful biography. As the commander of Edgefield County's Sweetwater Sabre Club, a paramilitary unit dedicated to terrorizing Republican officeholders and restoring white rule in South Carolina, the 29-year-old Tillman, with his red-shirted troopers, participated in the Hamburg Riot on July 8, an occasion marked by the coldblooded murder of a number of black militiamen who had had the effrontery to conduct a celebratory parade through the mostly black town of Hamburg, S.C., four days earlier on the Fourth of July. As Tillman himself would later put it, "The leading white men of Edgefield" had decided "to seize the first opportunity that the Negroes might offer them to provoke a riot and teach the Negroes a lesson" by "having the whites demonstrate their superiority by killing as many of them as was justifiable." None of the perpetrators of the Hamburg murders were ever brought to justice.
Tillman's role in the Hamburg Riot established him as a leader of men in that time and that place. His involvement, about which he boasted constantly in future years, was the cornerstone upon which he would build a remarkable political career, first as governor of South Carolina and then, for 24 years, as a United States senator.
How could these execution-style murders of 1876 serve as the springboard for such extraordinary political advancement -- and a legacy of racism that would keep Tillman's name alive as Pitchfork Ben well into the 20th century? The explanation lies, Kantrowitz believes, in the determination of white men in the post-Civil War South to reclaim what they had lost through emancipation and the experience of Reconstruction: their sense of independent, unfettered manhood. "Tillman sought to transform the slogan 'white supremacy' into a description of social reality, reconstructing white male authority in every sphere from the individual household to national politics," Kantrowitz, who teaches American history at the University of Wisconsin, Madison, writes. Tillman's constituents responded to his leadership because they too believed that the end of slavery and the enfranchising of blacks had set loose a threat to white society that had to be checked by whatever means necessary. It took a man like Tillman -- an ideologue, an organizer and a terrorist" -- to give voice to their fears and to translate their determination into physical and political action.
Tillman proved to be a master at pillorying his well-bred political opponents -- white Negroes," he called them, or effete urban "dudes" produced by aristocratic institutions of higher learning like the Citadel or the University of South Carolina. When it came to reforms that might actually help to relieve the farmer's economic plight, however, Tillman offered precious little: an agricultural college for white men (Clemson), a new school for white women (Winthrop College) and a state-run dispensary system to regulate liquor sales. Almost everything else he proposed had a single goal: the suppression of the state's black population to a position of permanent inferiority.
In 1892, a group of Tillman's supporters in Abbeville, S.C., prepared a banner anointing the governor the "Champion of White Men's Rule and Woman's Virtue." Earlier that year, Tillman had coupled a statement opposing lynching with a declaration that he would "willingly lead a mob in lynching a Negro who had committed an assault upon a white woman." His "lynching pledge," as this promise became known, was never personally carried out, but it reveals a great deal about Tillman's rhetorical and political strategy. The black man, in Tillman's words, "must remain subordinate or be exterminated." An epidemic of mob killings broke out in South Carolina in the 1890's, and in the upcountry counties of Abbeville, Edgefield, Laurens and Newberry, lynchings outnumbered legal executions during that decade.
When Tillman went to Washington, his message went with him. Now known as Pitchfork Ben -- in 1892 he had threatened to stick a pitchfork in that "bag of beef" Grover Cleveland -- Tillman became the "resident wild man" of the Senate. His record was a model of negative consistency. He opposed woman suffrage (the vote would "rub the bloom off of the peach," he said). He opposed American overseas expansion (building an empire comprising nonwhite peoples he looked upon as a form of insanity). And he opposed any exercise of federal authority that would allow the national government to intrude in a state's "domestic affairs." This ensured his opposition to any measure that might actually provide some economic relief for the farmers back home.
Tillman also became a star on the national lecture circuit. His lecture on "the race problem" was by far the most popular, aiming to preach "the gospel of white supremacy straight from the shoulder," and preach he did, year after year, from one end of the country to the other. He offered up a witches' brew of bare-knuckled, no-holds-barred racism and earned a handsome annual income from these performances.
When the 70-year-old Tillman died in 1918, he left behind a political legacy almost totally devoid of positive achievement. But, Kantrowitz reminds us, he left a powerful and tenacious legacy of another sort. In South Carolina, Tillman and his political allies "fatally undermined the possibility of the development of a race-neutral language of manhood and citizenship." The consequences of this perversion of democratic doctrine would burden the South deep into the 20th century.
"Tillman's true legacy lives on wherever Americans continue to shore up the battered foundations of white supremacy," Kantrowitz notes at the end of this thoroughly researched, brilliantly argued book. "It lives on wherever dissent is met with violence, wherever white men are the only first-class citizens, wherever 'populism' is reduced to what one contemporary called Tillman's 'gospel of discontent.' "
"Ben Tillman and the Reconstruction of White Supremacy" is a rich and insightful dissection of the rise of American racism in the late 19th and early 20th centuries. Kantrowitz has given us the best study we have of Benjamin Tillman, but he has also given us a way to understand how racism took hold in the post-Civil War South and gradually spread its tentacles to the rest of the country. "White supremacy was hard work," he observes, and no one worked harder at it than Pitchfork Ben Tillman.

HEADLINE: Chinese Puzzle

BYLINE: By Barry Gewen; Barry Gewen is an editor at the Book Review.

 BODY:

 Profits and Principles
 Global Capitalism and
 Human Rights in China.
 By Michael A. Santoro.
 241 pp. Ithaca, N.Y.:
 Cornell University Press. $29.95. 
 Who could have imagined that so wonkish a subject as trade with China would turn into the kind of overheated political issue that, like abortion and gun control, splits people into noisy warring camps? Lines have been drawn in the sand, with choices reduced to stark either-ors: human rights or expanded commerce, worker protection or globalization. But to anyone looking for reasoned discussion instead of rhetorical posturing, Michael A. Santoro's "Profits and Principles" is a fine place to start. Santoro, who teaches at the Rutgers Graduate School of Management, has been visiting China every year for nearly a decade. He has spoken with hundreds of businessmen, workers, government officials and human rights advocates inside and outside China. The stiffness of his prose will doubtless limit his readership, but his solidly grounded analysis deserves a wide audience.
Santoro begins with a valuable distinction. American companies doing business in China can be broadly divided into two types: those seeking to expand their operations by establishing themselves in the increasingly lucrative Chinese market, and those in a global marketplace wishing to reduce their production costs by taking advantage of the country's low-wage labor. The first group makes a firm, long-term commitment to China. Motorola, for instance, has invested more than $1.5 billion in state-of-the-art facilities. Santoro reports that the company's Tianjin plant, which employs about 10,000 workers, is "spacious, clean and well lit." None of the workers "appear to be in the least bit haggard or oppressed." It is, he concludes, "a place that a young graduate of Purdue, North Carolina State or Cal Tech would find congenial."
The businesses of the second group, on the other hand, are responsible for the sweatshop image that dominates American notions of Chinese workplaces. They tend to be in low-tech, labor-intensive, cutthroat industries like apparel and toys, where the economic pressures are constantly downward. In their "race to the bottom," these companies (or, more often, their local subcontractors) provide the lowest possible wages in the grimmest possible conditions.
Santoro's distinction immediately complicates the human rights question. The first group, the market builders, are improving human rights in China, he points out, simply through their presence there. They are changing their workers' values by teaching individual initiative. Outside the factory, they foster a business environment that adheres to rule by law. Perhaps most important, they are creating a meritocratic middle class with a power base independent of the Communist Party. The market builders, Santoro says, are "doing good while doing well."
It is among the second group that the human rights problem is most acute. After reviewing proposals for voluntary regulation, Santoro urges the World Trade Organization to adopt an enforceable code of international labor standards. His impulse is honorable, but one wishes he had been tougher-minded.
Santoro notes that third world governments consistently oppose international codes -- not because they are eager to exploit their own citizens but because they see the codes as a kind of hidden protectionism: if wage, health and safety standards are set too high, these countries lose their comparative advantage. As usual with such matters, the Chinese present the most dramatic illustration of the issue. It is estimated that China will have to create 18 million jobs each year for the foreseeable future simply to stay where it is. In a Malthusian world where millions of Chinese are faced with the alternative of jobless desperation or employment under what the West considers sweatshop conditions, the sweatshops win every time. Attempting to define wage and safety levels that are not so high as to jeopardize job opportunities for people already living at the edge -- and to do so under a system of fluctuating exchange rates -- is a task to try the capacities of even the wisest of men, women and computers. Just how many Solomons are there at the W.T.O. anyway?

LENGTH: 1042 words

HEADLINE: Mexican Standoff

BYLINE: By John B. Judis; John B. Judis is a senior editor at The New Republic and the author of "The Paradox of American Democracy."

 BODY:

 The Selling of
 "Free Trade"
 Nafta, Washington, and the Subversion
 of American Democracy.
 By John R. MacArthur.
 388 pp. New York:
 Hill & Wang. $25. 
 You would have to go back to the 19th century to find a trade battle in Congress that was as divisive as that over the North American Free Trade Agreement in 1993. What has been needed is a dispassionate study that gets past the sound and fury. John R. MacArthur's study, "The Selling of 'Free Trade,' "is not really that. It mixes a passionate attack on the treaty with a journalistic account of its passage and effects. Die-hard opponents of the agreement will probably like this book. Others may find it irritatingly one-sided.
Nafta emerged from at least three different impulses: first, Mexican officials, frightened by a growing foreign debt that was crippling their economy, wanted to attract American investment; second, American businesses wanted to be able to invest in Mexico free from export restrictions and domestic content rules, and from the ultimate threat of expropriation; and third, American officials and policy makers, worried about political instability and a torrent of illegal immigrants, wanted to incorporate Mexico into a Common Market-type arrangement that would lead to the revival of its economy, the reform of its government and the reduction of cross-border tensions.
MacArthur understands the first two impulses. He understands that Nafta was primarily an investment agreement rather than a free trade treaty. But he plays down or ignores Americans' broader concerns. Nafta, he insists, was "entirely about money."
MacArthur, the president and publisher of Harper's Magazine, is at his best describing the lobbying that occurred after the treaty was signed and went to Congress in August 1993. He shows how business lobbyists worked hand in glove with the treaty's Congressional supporters. But he has surprisingly little to say about the negotiations themselves, or about the domestic political conflicts that occurred while the treaty was being negotiated. His account of these tends to render shades of gray as black. When the Bush administration proposed that Congress agree to a fast-track vote (up or down without amendments), Richard Gephardt, the House majority leader and a Democrat, backed Bush on the condition that the treaty contain rules on labor standards and environmental protection. MacArthur dismisses this position as nave and opportunistic. (Gephardt "was presumably ambitious to be liked by the sort of people, honest or not, who can make you president.")
A year later, during the presidential campaign, Bill Clinton, under the influence of Gephardt and two advisers, Derek Shearer and Richard Rothstein, adopted the same position. MacArthur treats Clinton even more contemptuously than he does Gephardt. He says Clinton "had already made up his mind on trade to the point where there was no substantial difference between his position and Bush's." Clinton's stand, he says, was primarily based on fund-raising. That assertion leaves little middle ground between those adamantly opposed to Nafta and those enthusiastically in favor. MacArthur may be right, but when I covered the negotiations I found otherwise.
In the Nafta negotiations, Clinton and Mickey Kantor, the United States trade representative, earnestly attempted to get Mexico and Canada to agree to set up commissions that would have significant punitive powers. They failed, primarily because of Mexican and Canadian opposition, as well as opposition from the Business Roundtable and Republicans in Congress. But they also failed because the A.F.L.-C.I.O., instead of trying to work with the administration, took a position of unequivocal opposition to the treaty in any form. Clinton and Gephardt found themselves caught between business-style internationalism and labor protectionism.
The resulting treaty was flawed. MacArthur's view, which also became Gephardt's, was that it should have been rejected, but MacArthur now criticizes Gephardt and John Sweeney, the A.F.L.-C.I.O. president, for failing to press for Nafta's repeal on the grounds that it has worsened the condition of Mexican and American workers. In drawing this conclusion, MacArthur ignores two important considerations.
He acknowledges that Mexico was in difficult straits on the eve of Nafta, but he attributes these problems to the Mexican government's abandonment of older high-tariff import substitution policies. Under these policies, MacArthur writes, there was "less social inequality and more purchasing power for the average Mexican." But he fails to note that before the 1980's, the Mexican economy was propped up by oil earnings. When oil prices began to fall, the economy began to stagger, and it is still not on its feet. Nafta may not have improved Mexico's economy, but it is not clear that it has made things worse.
The second consideration has to do with the impact of American investment in Mexico on American jobs. Investment increased somewhat after Nafta was signed, but the boom in American investment in Mexico predated Nafta. And if that investment had not gone to Mexico, it might have ended up in Central America or Asia, not in the United States. If Nafta depressed American wages, it did so indirectly -- by giving credibility to corporate managers' threats that if a union organized or demanded too much for its workers, the company would move to Mexico. Modifying Nafta to strengthen its labor and environmental commissions could benefit both American and Mexican workers, but repealing the treaty doesn't hold any obvious promise for Mexico, the United States or Canada.
To MacArthur's credit, he has tried his best to make a potentially dull subject interesting by treating himself as a character in his narrative; by interspersing long interviews with lobbyists, politicians and affected workers; and by telling the story of one factory in New York that was affected by Nafta. But he is not the most artful author, and the book sometimes drags. It would have been much more lively at half the length. But it probably would not have been any more accurate a portrayal of the choices facing American policy makers and citizens in 1993.

SECTION: Section 5; Page 6; Column 1; Travel Desk 

LENGTH: 2337 words

HEADLINE: FRUGAL TRAVELER;
Outside Tucson, A Family Goes Underground

BYLINE: By BETSY RUBINER; BETSY RUBINER, a freelance writer based in Iowa, visits Arizona frequently.

 BODY:
I NEVER knew something could be so cool," my 8-year-old son, Noah, whispered as we stepped into the huge "Throne Room" at Kartchner Caverns State Park, Arizona's latest geological gem, which was unveiled just in time for my family's annual spring trip to Tucson.
There it was: the "Kubla Khan" -- the tallest known column in an Arizona cave. It looked like a Dr. Seuss concoction: a majestic 58-foot-high pillar of hardened mineral built by drop after drop of water falling into the cave for thousands of years. It was impossible not to gawk. 
 When I read last November that the cave -- a rare living and growing one -- was finally opening for tours (25 years after its discovery) I snagged a mid-March reservation. I'm glad I did. By the time we got to Tucson -- 40 miles northwest of Kartchner Caverns -- tours were booked through May. "I hope you have a reservation," a rental car agent warned us.
Hands down, the cave was the highlight of our two-day trip around the Tucson area. But as we have learned in other visits to see my parents (who spend winters in southern Arizona), Tucson can't promise economical travel during the peak tourist season. Tickets to favorite spots like the Arizona-Sonora Desert Museum and comfortable family-friendly lodging for me, my husband, Dirck, and our children, Lily, 7 and Noah, can add up. We try to cut costs elsewhere -- picnicking when possible and hiking in glorious Catalina State Park, just north of Tucson (entry fee: $5 a car).
Kartchner Caverns was worth the price of $10 to drive into the remote 550-acre park in the Whetstone Mountains and another $40 total for the 70-minute cave tour. What makes the seven-acre cave system special is that it is so unspoiled. Strange as it sounds, Kartchner Caverns was opened to tourists to protect it. The two spelunk ers who discovered the cave on the Kartch ner family's land in 1974 feared that with out making it a state park (which turned into a $28 million project) and regulat ing the number of visitors, Kartchner Caverns would be overrun and ruined like others.
This helps explain the pricey admission, the tightly controlled access (three tours per hour, 18 people per tour) and the high-tech gadgets, including a misting system that keeps the cave moist as outsiders enter. It also explains why the tour guides watched us so closely.
My family easily spent three hours at the park, starting with the hands-on exhibits in the Discovery Center. Noah and Lily made a beeline for the 80,000-year-old bones of a Shasta ground sloth found in the cave. They also had fun squeezing through a replica of the cave hole that the founding spelunkers used. I passed. We all fingered a fake stalagmite -- touching the real ones is forbidden.
By the time we left for our tour, Noah and Lily had grown very quiet -- a bit spooked, I suspected, after learning about the original spelunkers' crawl through tight tunnels and cold mud into a very dark place. I had the jitters too as we entered the cave through a series of six huge steel freezer doors that help keep out the dry desert air.
Not to worry. The three cave rooms we visited were wide-open spaces, discreetly lighted so we could see their many treasures. As two guides with flashlights ushered us along a paved, dimly illuminated path wide enough for a wheelchair, it felt like we were in the upper balcony of a dark opera house.
Looking down, we saw the original spelunkers' footprints in the mud. Looking up, we saw countless mineral formations in countless colors and shapes. We were surrounded by stalactites and stalagmites in reds, grays and browns. Some resembled carrots, fried eggs, popcorn and well-done bacon; others looked like delicate hollow "soda straws."
Our guide treated us more like geology students than sightseers, making interesting observations in terms we all could readily grasp. One drawback: because the tour was so choreographed and clinical, the cave didn't seem quite spooky enough. That changed when we got to the Throne Room, where the Kubla Khan (named after the Samuel Taylor Coleridge poem about a terrestrial paradise) presides. There, a brief light-and-music show helped us experience the cave's intrinsic mystery and romance. The show began with the cave dark and silent enough to hear a drop of water land. Then, like a spelunker's flashlight, hidden lights within the cave illuminated one marvel after another.
After we stumbled back out into the sunlight, our clothes strangely moist, Noah and Lily were "sworn in" as junior rangers, earnestly repeating an oath to protect the caves.
Next? Fresh apple pie. We found it 12 miles northeast at the Horseshoe Steakhouse and Cantina in the dusty town of Benson. Four slices of pie with wonderful flaky crust and four drinks came to $14.49, a splurge after our prudent picnic back at the park.
Driving back north, we scrapped plans to stop at Tucson's famous 18th-century Mexican Baroque church, the Mission San Xavier del Bac, when we discovered Lily and Noah asleep in the back seat. (Rule No. 1 when traveling with kids: Don't wake them up.) But by the time we got to our hotel in north Tucson, they were ready for the pool. Our two-room suite at the cheerful Windmill Inn at St. Philip's Plaza, a swanky shopping complex, cost $129 a night, including tax. Had I started looking earlier, I might have done even better, but we liked what we got: a bedroom with two double beds plus a living room with a small eating area, microwave and mini-refrigerator.
Dinner got off to a shaky start that night when we found an almost two-hour wait at El Charro Cafe, a lively Mexican restaurant downtown. (Unfortunately, we hadn't made reservations.) The apologetic host promised us a table the next night. Moving on, we drove with my parents about 25 minutes east to the Hidden Valley Inn, a bustling restaurant popular with families. The lavish Western decor was more clever than cheesy and the kids loved it -- especially the glassed-in displays of Western scenes featuring moving miniature cowboys carved from wood.
In a lounge that looked like Miss Kitty's Saloon, we enjoyed listening to Jess Hawk Oakenstar croon Patsy Cline songs at the edge of a busy dance floor. Hidden Valley is the kind of steak place that lists a half a barbecued chicken ($9.99) on its light menu, and mine was delicious. So were the ground sirloin steak ($9.99) and the kids' "cowpoke chicken" strips ($4.99). Choosing carefully and skipping liquor, we kept our bill to $66.21 for six. We needed no dessert.
We stayed above ground the next day, driving 12 miles west from downtown Tucson to the Desert Museum through landscape that really was straight out of a western movie. We passed Old Tucson Studios, where many westerns were filmed. Snaking through winding passes in the jagged Tucson Mountains, we had a breathtaking view of the desert valley that is home to the museum. Hundreds of saguaro cactuses waved at us like happy Gumbys.
We paid $33.35 for five tickets (my mother joined us, my dad played golf) to the Desert Museum, which is part zoo, botanical garden and natural history museum. Although it was crowded, the Desert Museum is mostly open-air so there was plenty of elbow room. All the animals -- coyotes, javelinas (which look like pigs), even the mountain lions -- were out. So were the enthusiastic docents with their animal skulls and geology models. Lily and Noah got to pet a small gopher snake. Three hours whizzed by. It was time for another picnic, this one at a secluded table outside the museum.
We were reminded how miserable a southern Arizona family vacation can be when a sudden storm rumbled over the Santa Catalina Mountains north of Tucson, where we'd hoped to take an afternoon hike in Catalina State Park. Instead we drove past the park about 20 miles northeast to an attraction that's long been on our "maybe" list: the Biosphere 2 Center, where eight adults lived in isolation from 1991 to 1993 and now a scientific research center run by Columbia University. We discovered you couldn't see much from the entrance gate and that the tour was a budget-buster ($12.95 each for adults; $6 each for Noah and Lily). So we skipped it and gladly returned to the hotel.
That night, the host at El Charro kept his promise. For $57.75, the six of us ate well, thanks to the restaurant's enormous portions and delicious signature dish, carne seca: strips of beef marinated in lime and garlic and sun-dried in cages atop El Charro's roof. For dessert, we spent $12.77 at an ice cream shop near the University of Arizona.
By morning, our last at the inn, the storm had cleared. Dirck took Lily window-shopping near the hotel. Noah and I borrowed some of the hotel's one-speed bikes, hit the dusty trail behind St. Philip's Plaza and rode off into the sunshine.
 
The bottom line on a family trip around Tucson
Our family of four spent about $260 a day on our hotel, meals and sightseeing during a two-day March trip to the Tucson area to visit Kartchner Caverns State Park. Both dinners were for six people, including my parents. Lunch and sightseeing the second day was for five people, including my mother.
 
Transportation
We rented a four-door compact car from Alamo, (800) 327-9633, at the Tucson International Airport for about $50 a day; rates are substantially lower now.
 
Hotel
We stayed at the Windmill Inn at St. Philip's Plaza, 4250 North Campbell Avenue, Tucson; (520) 577-0007; fax (520) 577-0045. It is a three-story pink stucco Southwestern-style hotel with 122 suites, situated in an attractive north Tucson shopping complex. We paid $120, plus $9 tax a night. The suite originally cost $135 a night during peak season from January through April but I got a lower rate with a casual inquiry. In May, rates are $99 or $120 poolside for a similar suite, dropping further in June.
Our bedroom had two double beds and a handy extra sink. The living room had a small eating area, mini-refrigerator and microwave. We also got muffins, hot drinks and juice delivered to the suite for breakfast, a courtyard pool and Jacuzzi, plus bikes, board games and books on loan.
 
Activities
Tours of the cave at the new Kartchner Caverns State Park are already so popular that reservations must be made months in advance; in early May, tours were fully booked through July. The seven-acre cave system is an easy 45-minute drive southeast from Tucson, nine miles south of Interstate 10, off Highway 90 in Cochise County. To book a tour, call (520) 586-2283. The tour lasts 70 minutes and the walk is about a third of a mile.
Open daily, the park offers three cave tours an hour (limited to 18 people and two guides), with the first at 8:30 a.m., the last at 4:30 p.m. The tours cost $14; $6 for children 7 to 13. Park officials do not recommend the tour for children under 7 but there is no charge for those who take it.
The cave is wheelchair accessible, but no electric chairs are permitted; the park can supply a push chair if needed. Walkers are not allowed. There is an additional $10 charge to drive into the 550-acre park, which also has an interesting Discovery Center with a 15-minute film and interactive exhibits, plus two hiking trails, a hummingbird garden and picnic tables.
Mission San Xavier del Bac, 1950 West San Xavier Road, (520) 294-2624, is about nine miles south of downtown Tucson. The glistening white church, finished in 1797, is full of exquisite baroque Mexican art and recently underwent a six-year restoration for interior cleaning; exterior restoration is still going on. Admission is free. Open 7 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Sunday Masses are at 8 and 11 a.m. and 12:30 p.m.
We visited the Arizona-Sonora Desert Museum, 2021 North Kinney Road, to learn about the plants and animals native to the Sonoran Desert region, which includes parts of Arizona and California as well as northern Mexico. The 21-acre museum, a 25-minute drive from downtown Tucson, has almost two miles of paths, two restaurants and two snack bars. It is open seven days a week from 7:30 a.m. to 5 p.m. March through September; 8 a.m. to 5 p.m. October through February. On Saturday nights June through September in the summer, it is open until 10 p.m. Admission is $8.95 March through September, $9.95 the rest of the year; $1.75 for children 6 through 12; free for children under 6. Information: (520) 883-2702.
Columbia University's Biosphere 2 Center, 32540 South Biosphere Road, (520) 896-6200, is in Oracle, about 20 miles north of Tucson on Highway 77. Admission is $12.95; $8.95 for ages 13 to 17; $6 for ages 6 to 12; free for children under 6.
 
Places to Eat
The Hidden Valley Inn, 4825 North Sabino Canyon Road, (520) 299-4941, is a Western-style restaurant and entertainment spot about 15 miles east of downtown Tucson. This is a big barn of a dining hall lavishly outfitted with wagon wheels and saddles. We spent $66.21 for six, without drinks, by ordering carefully. The children's menu has selections in the $4 to $6.50 range including "little bronco burgers" and "gunslinger grilled cheese." Open daily, for lunch and dinner, Hidden Valley also has dinner musical shows in a separate room two or three nights a week ($30, including the meal).
Tucson now has three branches of El Charro Cafe, but we stick with the original, which opened in 1922. It's a hopping place downtown at 311 North Court Avenue, (520) 622-1922. Reservations must be made at least a day in advance. We ate enormous burritos and tacos made with the house specialty, carne seca (strips of beef marinated in lime and garlic, then sun-dried). The total came to $57.75 for six, including a couple of margaritas. El Charro is open for lunch and dinner daily.
After our picnic at Kartchner Caverns, we drove 12 miles to Benson, for apple and cherry pie at the Horseshoe Steakhouse and Cantina, 154 East 4th Street, (520) 586-3303. Four slices of pie, two iced teas and two glasses of milk cost $14.49.

HEADLINE: Birding at the End of Nature

BYLINE: By Jonathan Rosen; Jonathan Rosen is the founding culture editor of The Forward and the author of the novel "Eve's Apple." His next book, "The Talmud and the Internet: A Journey Between Worlds," will be published in September.

 BODY:
Early this spring, long before the trees had leafed, I found myself standing in the rain in a dark field in southern New Jersey waiting for woodcocks -- shy, chunky, long-billed birds -- to rise out of the shadows and begin their mating dance. Sometimes called timberdoodles, woodcocks are not the most graceful birds on the planet. Their eyes are spaced so far apart that you might wonder how they can see the trees in front of them. As the late winter days begin to lengthen, they throw caution to the wind, and at dawn and dusk the males rise straight up into the air some 200 or 300 feet and then spiral down, uttering a plaintive, musical series of notes. Although deterred by cold, they don't seem to be bothered by rain -- and that's a good thing, too, because this "sky dancing" is how they maintain themselves as a species. The mystery is what was I, a devoted urbanite, doing there?
I've been watching birds for six years. It all began at a brunch in Manhattan when someone happened to mention that soon the warblers would be arriving in Central Park. I didn't know what precisely warblers were, but I knew in some uncanny way that when they arrived I would go out to find them. The next day, I signed up for a course in beginning bird-watching at the New York City chapter of the Audubon Society. There were two classes and two field trips -- one to the Jamaica Bay wildlife refuge and one to Central Park. To get to Jamaica Bay, I took the A train to Broad Channel in Queens, where I saw glossy ibis and snow geese and egrets rising against the Manhattan skyline, sharing the air with jets taking off from Kennedy Airport. On the trip to Central Park, not two blocks from where I live, I saw warblers -- tiny, colorful neotropical migrants, flitting with mysterious life in the trees and bushes of the Ramble, the 36-acre woodland at the heart of the park. 
 Some 300 of North America's 700 bird species pass through New York City each spring on their way north. Discovering these birds in the park where I had played as a child was a revelation. I had not known at the time that nature was missing from my life, but this newfound connection to something wild made me feel, for lack of a better word, whole. It was as if I had never seen the stars and someone tapped me on the shoulder one night and told me to look up.
With a convert's zeal, I began spending countless hours stalking birds with my binoculars, and as soon as spring was over, I began to look forward to fall, when they would come back on their return flight. I began subscribing to mainstream periodicals like Audubon and Natural History and then to specialty journals with names like Birder's World, Birdwatcher's Digest and Winging It. I bought Birding by Ear tapes and Peterson's guide to Eastern birds, then the more comprehensive "National Geographic Guide" and species-specific volumes like "Warblers of the Americas" and "Hawks in Flight." I began to plan my vacations and even my work assignments to birding hot spots like Madera Canyon in southern Arizona, Bosque del Apache in New Mexico, the Orkneys in Scotland, the Everglades.
I had stumbled into a vast, largely invisible world. It seemed like a private discovery, until it dawned on me that I was part of a quiet revolution. The first time I traveled for the express purpose of birding I went to Point Pelee in Ontario. Pulling into the bed-and-breakfast where my wife and I were staying, I saw a car with vanity plates that read "Birder." At 6 a.m. in the packed parking lot of the nature preserve the next morning, I found hundreds of people wearing sun hats and binoculars; though somewhat taken aback by the crowds, I felt a thrilling shock of recognition. Like the birds themselves, the world of bird-watching had simply been hidden from me. Once I was initiated, I found a whole complex culture waiting to receive me.
According to the U.S. Fish and Wildlife service, somewhere between 42 million and 50 million Americans over the age of 16 watch birds, far more than the numbers of people who hunt and fish combined. Birders spend some $20 billion a year -- on travel and optics and gear and seed -- and scores of birding festivals have sprung up in the last few decades, reversing the fortunes of small coastal towns in Texas and rural backwaters in regions that were once neglected. There are now more than 400 franchise stores, like Wildbird Unlimited, specializing in birding gear and birdseed, and some 600 more independents. Twenty years ago there were almost none. This August, Houghton Mifflin -- which, since publishing Roger Tory Peterson's first field guide in 1934, has sold eight million Peterson bird guides -- will publish a new field guide to the birds by Kenn Kaufman with a first printing of 150,000 copies, making it Houghton Mifflin's biggest book of the year. In October, Knopf will bring out "The Sibley Guide to Birds," created by the master bird artist David Allen Sibley, with a print run of 100,000.
The appeal of birds may be mythically ingrained -- think of the bird gods of Egypt -- but there are also practical explanations. For one thing, they're still here. Remnants of wild America may lurk in corners of the country, but birds, thanks to their ability to fly, span the continent. "There is probably no place in North America where you can stand and not hear birds," Pete Dunne, director of the Cape May Bird Observatory, told me recently. Even from my apartment, I hear blue jays and mourning doves and house finches and the occasional downy woodpecker. In the heart of downtown, pigeons pace the windowsills in memory of their cliff-dwelling rock dove origins, and sparrows peep out of the hollow metal crossbars of virtually every traffic light. For Dunne, the environmental movement of the 1960's "left its imprint on everyone," so that grown-up baby boomers with time on their hands are not simply discovering nature but returning to something that touched them when they were teenagers learning about the effects of DDT.
Dunne, 48, himself typifies the new sort of birder; he has helped popularize the pursuit with lively books like "Tales of a Low-Rent Birder" as well as serious field guides. He is also the creator of the World Series of Birding, a freewheeling annual event that takes place the second week of May in which participants have 24 hours to find as many bird species as possible using the entire state of New Jersey as the playing field. The team with the most sightings at the end of the day wins. Begun in 1984 with 13 teams, the World Series now attracts more than 50 teams from all over the world and raises about half a million dollars for conservation groups. The World Series and numerous similar events, like the Great Texas Birdathon, gratify the naked competitive energy that fuels a certain sort of bird-watching -- sometimes referred to as "birding," distinct from bird-watching. Birders are more likely to keep "life lists" of what they have seen and are known to travel great distances to add a single bird -- a lesser prairie chicken in, say, Kansas or a rose-throated becard in Arizona -- to their lists.
I am neither a fanatical "lister" nor a casual backyard bird-watcher but something in between. Of course, birding itself is an in-between activity, half science and half pastime, half sport and half conservationist crusade. Born of an ancient impulse, it required the 20th century, when binoculars replaced the shotgun, to be fully realized. Some primal, conquering hunter's urge is never far below the surface when I'm out with my binoculars, even though the living bird is all I'm after. Linked to the natural world, bird-watching nevertheless forces me to stand at a slight remove. It is more about the interplay of the human and the natural -- naming, labeling, fitting the wild world against the ordering grid of human understanding, even as I am simultaneously lured farther out into animal habitats. I am left with something both untamed and ordered -- a weirdly satisfying, deeply human mixture of elements.
But things may not be as satisfying for the birds. "The owl of Minerva flies only at dusk" -- Hegel's comment about civilizations flourishing as they move toward the brink of extinction -- has an eerie echo for bird-watchers. Just as nature was, in some sense, beginning for me, Bill McKibben was foretelling "The End of Nature." The inexhaustible, self-renewing environment of our fantasies died with the Industrial Revolution, and unless we change our ways, he posited, rising temperatures, acid rain and a host of other ills will carry off what's left of the natural world. Bird-watching, alas, is not necessarily an indication of the health of the bird population. George Fenwick, president of the American Bird Conservancy, a small but important advocacy group, points to the fanaticism of British bird-watchers, well known in this country because so many show up at American birding spots. "The best birders are there and everyone's obsessed with birds," he told me, and yet "there's hardly a wood lot left -- everything's been developed and redeveloped. I'm glad the Brits are so interested, but I hope that's not our fate."
Bird-watching, in other words, may be what you do at the end of nature. According to Frank Gill, director of science for the National Audubon Society, one out of every six species in North America is in trouble, declining 2 to 10 percent a year; over 20 or 30 years, that means whole species would be cut in half -- or worse.
On the wall of my study, near a multiplying collection of bird books, hangs a reproduction of Audubon's portrait of two passenger pigeons. Although these birds roosted communally and flew in flocks so vast that they darkened the sky for hours while passing overhead, Audubon has given them individual life, a male and female, touching bills. I find these birds, peach and blue and gray, not merely beautiful but haunting, a sort of avian memento mori. One hundred years ago, on March 24, 1900 (and it adds a weirdly modern element that we know the exact date), the last wild passenger pigeon ever recorded was shot out of the sky in Pike County, Ohio. Fourteen years later, the last surviving member of the species, a bird named Martha, died at the Cincinnati Zoo.
Today's imperiled birds include the Bicknell's thrush, a modest species that nests on mountaintops from New York to Canada and winters on the island of Hispaniola in the highest elevations of the Dominican Republic -- where 90 percent of the land has already been deforested. Development and population pressures there are such that there is a real danger of extinction, not merely for the Bicknell's thrush but for other species wintering there as well. The grand migratory flights of birds that I found so exhilarating because they carried my imagination in all directions, even standing in Manhattan looking up, began, as I became more aware of their imperiled status, to darken the sky with danger -- and with politics.
Paul Kerlinger, an expert in bird migration who studies the economic impact of birding, wants bird-watchers to wake up to their enormous spending power. They might agree to a tax on birdseed, he says, or endorse legislation like the Conservation and Reinvestment Act, which would use revenues from offshore oil drilling to support habitat conservation. His studies have shown that ecotourism often brings more money to an area like the Delaware Bay than a local industry like horseshoe crab harvesting, which has a directly adverse effect on the birds. But his economic approach has had only limited appeal. "I don't know if they're all Luddites or Socialists or what," Kerlinger says in frustration, alluding to the deep-seated fear among some bird-watchers that market forces are at odds with environmentalism.
However birders feel about economic strategies, it is not easy to organize people who do something so solitary and so individualistic. Unlike hunting or fishing, birding requires no license -- you need only slip out the door with a pair of binoculars, which is why Kenn Kaufman, who dropped out of high school and hitchhiked across the country looking for birds, calls bird-watching a "subversive" activity.
Make a birder, make a conservationist, Roger Tory Peterson said. All I really wanted was to look at birds -- but that won't be possible if I don't give in to this secondary duty and make my thinking as global as the birds themselves are. It remains to be seen if the rise in bird-watchers can somehow stop the disappearance of the birds -- since saving the birds means saving the places they live, which is to say what's left of the natural world.
The great biologist Edward O. Wilson coined the term "biophilia" to describe the inborn need of human beings to affiliate with nature because as a species we evolved within the natural world. We may have an urge to conquer nature, but we still need it around us for our mental and even our genetic health. If this is true, then conservation is really only a form of self-interest. And bird-watching, as I have long suspected, isn't really a hobby, any more than rearing my daughter is a hobby. It's just a way of participating in the natural world that produced me, if only in a token, postmodern manner.
In his poem "The Oven Bird," Robert Frost made this small warbler with a stripe of orange down the middle of its head (easily seen in Central Park in May) a metaphor for the vanishing natural world. "The question that he frames in all but words," the poet wrote, "is what to make of a diminished thing." That is still the question bird-watching poses. I think of this in my field in southern New Jersey, where the light is failing, my patience is waning and the woodcock, as a chill wind kicks up, is making itself scarce.
Nature itself may be failing -- and we may be failing it. But from out of the darkness, I suddenly hear the call of the woodcock -- a buzzy, nasal "peent" not altogether unlike the "meep meep" sound the roadrunner makes in the cartoon when he sees the coyote. Everyone in my group falls breathlessly silent, and then there is a whir of wings that make their own music as the bird launches himself from a nearby patch of scrub straight up into the air. When he reaches the apex of his flight he begins to drift down in a wavering series of spirals, singing as he goes. If his song is successful, then when he lands, in the exact spot he took off from, a female woodcock will be waiting for him and they will mate.
The woodcock is dimly visible against the dark sky, and for a moment philosophy and ecology and poetry and politics all go out the window. What to make of a diminished thing? It will take a lifetime to figure that out. But for one brief, heart-stopping second, the bird itself seems like answer enough.

HEADLINE: Green Acres, and How They Stay That Way

BYLINE: By CHRISTINE WOODSIDE 

 BODY:
PARKS, golf courses and beaches have two qualities in common.
Looking at them is relaxing, and maintaining them so that people will want to look at them requires long hours, dedication and specialized equipment. The maintenance experts at three beautiful Connecticut recreation sites know this all too well. 

Elizabeth Park
Nine city workers and at least 150 volunteers maintain the pastoral scene at Elizabeth Park in Hartford, the only public botanical garden in Connecticut. This 102-acre city park is the former Charles Pond estate, named for his wife in the late 1800's.
Visitors stroll through two and a half acres of roses, a tulip and annual garden, perennial beds, a rock garden and two herb gardens. All of this requires constant grooming by the workers and volunteers.
The pastel beauty of the rose garden consists of 15,000 bushes of 800 to 900 varieties. Donna Fuss, the rosarian, invites anyone to count them, as she has often in her job tending the garden for the Friends of Elizabeth Park. The Friends formed in 1977 by some members of the Federated Garden Clubs of Connecticut at a time when the city, running out of money, was about to raze some of the gardens.
Resources are not lavish even with the Friends to help. Mrs. Fuss said she quickly uses her yearly rose bush replacement budget of $8,000, which comes from donations.
The rest of the plants in Elizabeth Park come from the park's labyrinth of greenhouses, where Robert Prill, the park's maintenance supervisor, grows 25,000 seedlings (of 50 plant varieties) each year. The plants from the greenhouses also go to other city gardens, such as those around City Hall.
Each week, year-round, Mr. Prill and his staff mix at least four bags of peat moss and pearlite into four wheelbarrow loads of topsoil and two wheelbarrow loads of sand to make a starting mix. There is no time of year when they are not nurturing some little thing in the greenhouses.
Around the gardens are the grass. The staff uses two specialized mowers that can weave around plants. They also own about a half-dozen regular push mowers and two riding mowers. Most parts of the park get mowed once a week which means something is being mowed almost daily.
"It's like a maze out there and you have to have a certain kind of machine that can make the turns without taking out the bushes or the flowers," Mr. Prill said.
 
Hammonasset Beach State Park
Six workers and a supervisor sweat over a fleet of heavy machinery to tame the 940 acres that make up this state park in Madison. One person spends four hours a day, from Memorial Day to Labor Day, just raking the beach. The worker rides a tractor dragging metal fingers along the two miles of sandy waterfront. The rake is attached to a conveyer that pulls in everything in its path -- cigarette butts, cans, diapers, old forks and the like.
But the tractor can't handle some of the bigger junk that ends up here. Once the workers found about 50 tires had washed up during the night, said Lori Quirk, the maintenance supervisor. It is common in the early spring to find tree trunks that floated down the Connecticut River and then washed west to the park. This spring they had to dispose of a dead beaver.
Once summer comes, another laborer does nothing but mow all day, five days a week. The job involves driving a tractor with three 7-foot-wide mowing arms that can be lifted up and down as the need arises. The behemoth whirs its way over 400 acres of fields where people set up tents, play ball, or otherwise romp.
Workers also prune bushes and trees. A real struggle for them in recent years is to try to get rid of non-native plants, like autumn olive and Oriental bittersweet, that are choking trees and native plants. The problem is worse in the last few years, Ms. Quirk said, possibly because the maintenance crews were smaller for several years and had less time to cut back the weeds.
She said the addition of two workers this year has improved the situation but the crew still is not as large as it was in the late 1980's. The park's 1.5 million visitors need to park their cars, drink water and use restrooms, and the maintenance crew must deal with those problems, too. They repair walls and plumbing in 22 bathhouses, maintain the boardwalks and make improvements in the parking lots. This spring a new layer of gravel will fill in ruts in one of the dirt lots.
While most of the work runs on a predictable schedule, nature brings surprises. One year the winter storms left the parks water main exposed along the beach. The crew had to repair damage to the pipe, but the state does not truck in sand here. Luckily, later storms covered it over again.
 
Clinton Country Club
Inside a brand-new 3,000-square-foot maintenance building sits the fleet of mowing equipment that keeps this private golf course looking so beautiful. Each spring the pressure is on to get the fairways, greens and even the rough in shape for more than 300 members who play on the par-72 course.
They must like this 100-acre, 18-hole course and driving range, which are on an otherwise wooded road in the waterfront town of Clinton. People who want to join are put on a waiting list. Right now it takes 10 years to get off it. From early April to mid-May, Michael Decker, the superintendent, and staff of three full-timers and three seasonal workers, are deep into the rush to get things ready. Mr. Decker has a $500,000 budget to pay workers and buy supplies and equipment. He also is linked to a weather satellite that reports conditions every 15 minutes.
Mr. Decker said the economy is so good right now that it is hard to attract young people to work at the course in the summer. This year workers planted new trees near the entrance, placed sod on a new driving range and began the season's relentless schedule of mowing the grass to the exacting lengths designed to enhance the game.
Three times a week, workers ride the fairway mowers to clip the grass to nine-sixteenths of an inch. Why nine-sixteenths of an inch? That is the length that works best here, he said. (Some courses cut to a half-inch.) A four-foot-wide swath between the fairways and the rough gets clipped to 1 1/2 inches.
Two days a week, another worker rides the articulator, a mower that can go over bumps to mow the rough to a woolly 2 inches deep -- long enough to be a challenge, short enough so the golfers can see the balls. The rough used to be 3 inches deep, but people couldn't find their golf balls, Mr. Decker said.
The club owns two spraying machines. Workers ride on these to dispense anything water-soluble, including grub killers, fungicides and growth regulators. Mr. Decker said he keeps such applications to a minimum because no one likes to be around chemicals, least of all the workers. The grass is well established and requires very little insecticide, he said.
Then there are the two specialized riding mowers that cut and roll the greens. Every day a worker trims the greens to one-eighth of an inch. Every other day, the grass around the tees is trimmed to same length. The machine's rollers press down the blades to a smooth, faster surface. Mr. Decker said people occasionally ask him if its imitation grass.
The maintenance crew also has to rake the bunkers, or sand traps. This year they made a new bunker at the second hole. The old one was so deep that golfers were having too hard a time getting out of it.
Mr. Decker said few people realize the amount of care and attention that goes into caring for a golf course. His main concern is the grass itself, which he describes as a never-ending battle. He combines two varieties of grass, one a native variety of bluegrass that is robust and another, known as bent grass, that is softer and does not sprout seed heads the way the bluegrass does.
The way he handles it at Clinton is by constantly overseeding with the softer variety of grass. Periodically the crew rolls an aerator over the grass and inserts new grass seed in the holes.
