HEADLINE: Pigs, Quilts, Tomatoes: It Must Be Fair Time

BYLINE: By ROBERT A. HAMILTON 

 BODY:
FROM July to October, if you want to tout your prize tomatoes or brag about your baking skills, promote your photography or show off your string beans, there is an agricultural fair somewhere in Connecticut where you can do it.
Agricultural fairs started as a day off, a time at harvest when farmers could socialize with their peers, when their children could enter their prize animals in competition and quilters could compare their handiwork. Though agriculture represents a shrinking sector of the economy, the tradition continues. 
 "People are still growing things out in their yards, and they still want to find out how they did compared to everyone else," said Raymond Schaer, president of the Cannon Grange Agricultural Fair, which is held on the last Sunday of August every year in Wilton. "It's a fascination with the basic life style, sort of back to the earth. I think sometimes, for some people, on a Sunday, it's a nice way to go back to a simpler time."
The fairs range from gatherings of a few thousand people in a single day in Orange to crowds approaching a quarter-million over long weekends in Durham and Woodstock. Prize money could be as little as $200 at the smaller fairs to $80,000 or more at the state-level events.
Every fair has the standards: produce competition, livestock judging, probably a beauty pageant, square dancing and a tractor pull. But many develop their own specialty. It might be a flea market at one, a horse show at another, or a pie-eating or nail-driving contest, perhaps an egg toss. There are usually picnic areas, and live entertainment of some sort, ranging from local magic acts to national headliners at the Durham Fair, which in the past has offered country singers such as Billy Ray Cyrus, Patty Loveless, Loretta Lynn and Boxcar Willy, and the rock artists .38 Special and Three Dog Night.
And it can be had pretty cheap in most cases, from free admission to a high of about $5 for adults; most fairs admit children free. This year the fairs run from July 13, when the North Stonington Agricultural Fair opens, until Oct. 15, when the Riverton Fair closes.
Paul R. Schweitzer is president of the Harwinton Fair, the last major fair, always the first weekend in October, this year Oct. 7 and 8. "About 12 years ago, we got snowed out on Sunday," he said. "We literally had to shut the fair down. Then other years, we've had temperatures in the 80's."
James M. Zeoli, president of the Orange Country Fair, Sept. 16 and 17, said the men generally head for the doodle bug pulls -- a doodle bug is sort of a homemade contraption on the chassis of a heavy truck -- while the women are partial to the antique dealers and arts and crafts, and the children check out the police and fire department booths and the animal exhibits.
"It's more chickens and rabbits than larger animals, but we usually get a couple of dozen cows, some goats, and maybe a sow with piglets," Mr. Zeoli said. "Sometimes we set up an incubator with chicken eggs, and when word gets around that a hatch is in progress, the kids gather around. Years ago, you took for granted that everyone had seen a chicken hatch, because everyone kept them. But it's not something most people have an opportunity to see today."
One way to keep people coming back, Mr. Zeoli said, is to offer something new. This year for the first time the Orange Country Fair will bring in the Old Time Indian River Lumberjack Show, which features sawing and chopping competitions and a log-rolling contest.
For a first-timer, a fair could easily produce sensory overload: the one-lunger engines chugging away to power a shingle mill, the bellowing of a tractor pulling a huge concrete block, the cackle of chickens or the grunting of pigs. Then there are the smells from the food booths: fried dough, sausage and pepper grinders, five-alarm chili or clam chowder or deep-fried onions and potatoes. And, from the animal barns, the earthy scents of cattle and horses, sheep and goats, chickens and rabbits, perhaps even a llama or two these days.
"Those are sounds you don't hear anymore, scents that are no longer familiar," said Charles J. McCullough, president of the Norfield Grange Fair in Weston, held each year the first Sunday after Labor Day.
His is a small fair, attracting 3,000 to 3,500 people. Others are much larger, such as the Woodstock Fair, which drew more than 216,000 people over the Friday-to-Monday Labor Day weekend last year, and would have topped 250,000 if it had not been for rain the last day, said Annette M. Hamilton. This year, Mrs. Hamilton finishes her fourth and last year as president. She is the first woman elected to the job in the 137-year history of the fair.
Until a few years ago, vendors pitching kitchen aides and encyclopedias filled the main exhibition hall at Woodstock, but they were relegated to a smaller building when some thought the fair was becoming too commercial. Now,the vegetables, flowers, photography and crafts take center stage. "You need your vendors because that's what pays your bills and allows you to open the doors," Mrs. Hamilton said. "But you can't let them overrun the fair. Our main goal is that people get the culture of agriculture, that they get the feel for what it is to be a farmer."
With fewer farmers in the state, some fairs are finding it more difficult to fill the exhibition halls, she said. "We're drawing from Rhode Island and Massachusetts and New Hampshire and even Maine," Mrs. Hamilton said. "It's not just Connecticut farmers anymore.."
Planning goes on year-round, she said, with monthly meetings increasing to once a week as fair weekend draws near. She estimated that there are 200 volunteers with the fair association, and another 1,800 who show up to staff booths for the Lions, Elks, volunteer fire departments and other community groups. Even with all that labor, though, the fair has had to hire a year-round general manager, concession manager, secretary and assistant manager.
"It never ends," said Mrs. Hamilton. "We have all of the things set up for this year already, and we're already planning for 2001."
Even the fair officers are elected in a succession from second vice president, to first vice president, to president, holding each of the jobs for four years; when a new president takes office, the succession is pretty much assured for the next 12 years. But it's getting harder to put on the fairs, because most of the active members are getting old, and there are no young people coming in behind them.
"At our meeting last night I told the members we were going to have a site on the Internet, and you'd have thought I was talking about Star Wars," said Mr. McCullough of the Norfield Grange Fair. "The average age of the members is probably well into their 60's, and we've got some into their 80's. If we're going to survive, we've got to get young people involved."
John H. Hauser, president of the Greenfield Grange Fair in Fairfield, agreed. He said when he joined the Grange 14 years ago, there were 12 Granges in the county; today, it has dwindled to 6. Generally, fewer than 20 people are at the monthly meetings, down from about 40 when he started. When he was growing up in the 1950's there were 150 active members.
"They keep losing membership because young people just aren't joining, and when they don't have enough they just close the doors and turn their charters back to the state," Mr. Hauser said. "We're hanging in there, but just barely. If the Grange goes belly up, most of the agricultural fairs will go with it."
For a list of Connecticut fairs, visit the state Department of Agriculture site on the World Wide Web at www.state.ct.us/doag/ pubs/fairs.htm, or the Association of Connecticut Fairs at www.ctfairs.org.

HEADLINE: The Way We Live Now: 5-21-00: ShopTalk;
Very Early Admission

BYLINE: By Anemona Hartocollis 

 BODY:
This is the season when many parents begin the perilous journey of getting their toddlers into the right preschool and face the possibility of their social and intellectual rejection. As applications for the fall of 2001 loom, two of New York City's veteran preschool directors, Marlene Barron, head of the West Side Montessori School, and Jean Rosenberg, founder and director of the Chelsea Day School, offer an inside view of the dreaded admissions interview.
Barron: We had a 2-year-old program, and we got rid of it because we were turning down families with children we had interviewed at 18 months, and I just could not do that, ethically. I could not live with myself. I could not deal that ego blow to a family. 
 Rosenberg: I had a Japanese family who applied, and they didn't get in. The day after the letters went out, this woman arrived in my office. She came to me while I was greeting my kids and broke down in tears and said, "What did I do wrong?" Culturally, it was probably devastating to her to stand in front of an authority figure and say that. Those kinds of things break my heart, they kill me, every year.
Barron: Parents have the mistaken idea that there's one thing their child does that means he's in, or there's one thing their child does that means he's out. There's no such one thing.
Rosenberg: I tell my families, "You're coming to have a visit -- I'm not screening your child."
Barron: We want people who are not trying to sort of act their way into it.
We had a family one year, and Mom comes in and is interviewed and her whole posture was around ethnicity. She's really interested in families that have different ethnic backgrounds -- racial backgrounds, I mean -- because she knows that's important here. And hers is a white family. The interviewer at that point was white. And we felt that it was an oversell. We did not accept the child. The following year she applied again, and this time we gave her a black interviewer. Little did she know, it was a very wealthy black interviewer. And then she started going on about -- well, trashing, in a subtle way -- rich people. You know, she likes the school because there's an economic mix. She kept trying to give the right answer, and it was artificial. Why couldn't she have just been herself? What was her point in all this? And though we laughed about it behind the scenes, this woman wasn't comfortable in her own skin.
Rosenberg: And unfortunately that impacts on her child.
Barron: That's right. The child was fine, perfectly acceptable. But we felt
this family would always be trying to second-guess. And it wasn't needed.
There is no school that just does six items with a child, six test kind of items, and says, O.K., this makes or breaks it.
Rosenberg: Kids are being trained to pass these tests, so that the test doesn't mean anything after a while. If everybody's taking a course to take the test, it doesn't work anymore. So the rules are going to be different.
Barron: Everything is subjective. We're all looking through our own eyes, our own history. There is no perfect. There's no perfect husband, there's no perfect wife, there's no perfect apartment, there's no perfect restaurant. Everything is a matter of negotiation and making some sort of adjustments. And parents have to think about that in a school. That notion of perfect -- we've got to get rid of it.
Rosenberg: Yeah, life does not begin and end in the place that you go to school.
Barron: And they won't have perfect children, either. No child is perfect. Children are an ongoing process. Moderated by Anemona Hartocollis

HEADLINE: The Way We Live Now: 5-21-00: The Ethicist;
Worse for Not Wearing

BYLINE: By Randy Cohen 

 BODY:
I often ride my motorcycle without a helmet. Our state helmet law basically applies to motorcycle riders under 18. I figure I'm not putting anyone but myself at risk. My friends say that this is tantamount to suicide. But isn't it just one of many risks all of us take everyday? -- Kelly Krebs, Minneapolis
 If riding without a helmet affected only you, then helmet laws would be intrusive and paternalistic, and you'd be doing nothing unethical by riding bareheaded. An autonomous rider living free of the larger society is an attractive and romantic idea, but like most romantic ideas, it has little correspondence with actual life. Should you get in an accident, you are likely to be more seriously injured than you would be wearing a helmet, and thus you'll consume enormous medical resources. And should you die, your dependents might need a variety of public assistance. In other words, all sorts of social costs will increase, from insurance to emergency services; other people will be paying the price of your riding with the wind. And that is unethical. So I'm afraid that, law or no law, you've got to wear the helmet. However, if you remain determined to feel the wind in your hair, you can ride without your pants, which will not greatly augment your chance of dying, except of embarrassment. 
 I am a 17-year-old who is half Hispanic and half Caucasian. I am in no way disadvantaged, but neither are many other blacks and Hispanics. Would it be unethical for me to list my race as Hispanic on college applications?
-- Anonymous, New York
Colleges ask about the ethnic backgrounds of their applicants not only because they want to compensate them for presumed disadvantages or the effects of past discrimination, but also out of a belief that it is in the school's interest to assemble a diverse group of students. Remember, the application asks a great deal about you -- your address, your high school, your financial situation -- so the college has a pretty good idea of what hardships you may or may not have overcome.
If you would like to be particularly scrupulous, you could always write on the form what you've written here -- half Hispanic, half Caucasian. But if the application limits you to marking a single box to denote your ethnic origins, you may check "Hispanic" with a clear conscience.
In planning for a conference, I registered for an evening event for an additional $45. I did not attend this event for personal reasons (which included gorging on cable, something I do not have at home). However, I still put the charge on my expense report. Should I have swallowed the cost myself?
-- Rebecca Petruck, New York
Everyone is allowed -- or should be allowed -- a personal day now and then. If you enrolled in this event with every intention of attending, you were right to include it in your expense report, just as you would have had you missed it because you were ill and had taken a sick day. However, each company has its own policy about personal days, and you might want to clarify this with your boss.
Of course, if what you mean by "personal reasons" is a chance to see Mel Gibson naked on cable TV, then you might write to the F.C.C. asking why free network television deprives a hard-working woman like you of this viewing pleasure and thereby deprives her company, and the American economy, of her full attention.

HEADLINE: FILM;
What's It All About? The Kids Know. Do You?

BYLINE: By MARCELLE CLEMENTS; Marcelle Clements's most recent book is "The Improvised Woman: Single Women Reinventing Single Life."

 BODY:
GOING to the movies used to be no big deal for kids. Many of us would see films the way we read books: because it never occurred to us not to. I remember walking, every Saturday, to the RKO or the Loew's on East 86th Street. There'd be a double bill, and no one was too particular about what was playing or what time it started. "This is where I came in" still had meaning then, and often it wasn't until the movie ended and began again that you learned what the title was. My friends and I saw every single movie that was made for us, and many that weren't. And later, we also occasionally sat upstairs in the balcony and necked and sneaked cigarettes, but that's another story. Or perhaps not.
Nowadays -- in these much more salubrious, enlightened days of ratings and $5 popcorn and clean, no-smoking, no-talking theaters -- when people take their children to the movies, what do they want to get out of it? Perhaps it just happens to be the shape that an American family outing takes, especially when the weather isn't fabulous. 
 Judging by the amount of complaining and the lack of specificity, it seems that many people know only what they don't want. They don't want to be left flat. They want to have fun with their kids. That's all, really, that people demand of the movies for their families: they want to be happy.
"How was it? Was it violent? Was it scary?" you'll hear one adult say to another. And they're talking about "Stuart Little." Surely, there must be a correlation between the huge number of new books on parenting and the extraordinary concern about so-called family movies. Worried parents have taken to wandering in a maze of intricacies of what is and isn't appropriate -- appropriate language; appropriate amount of violence, sex, fear, diversity; appropriate amount of stimulation and lack thereof; appropriate amount of play of the imagination; appropriate amount of good and bad news about life.
Well, then, parents of small and mid-size children had better strap themselves in. Getting ready to zoom, glide, slide, swat, trundle and chug-a-chug-a onto their neighborhood screens this summer is a particularly vexing collection of movies, buttressed by colossal ad campaigns, marketing deals, tie-ins, link-ups, crossover and franchising strategies. Why vexing? Because each is like a discrete galaxy. How do you tell, ahead of time, whether you're going to be happy outside the Milky Way?
"Chicken Run" (June 23), "The Adventures of Rocky and Bullwinkle" (June 30), "Pokemon the Movie 2000" (July 21), "Thomas and the Magic Railroad" (July 26) -- and some of the more adventurous parents will want to add "X-Men" (July 14) -- are all big-budget, big-big-concept entertainment. A "family" film these days is not only 90 minutes in a theater, it's a design universe and a lifestyle. It trails in its wake not only the highly visible logos endlessly appliqued, stickered or hologrammed onto junk-food wrappers, mugs, T-shirts, pajamas, CD-ROM's, books, Game Boy cartridges, soundtracks, trading cards, Web sites and heaven knows what else, but also a language, an attitude, an ambience and a technological ideology.
It was at a recent press presentation for "Dinosaur" (which opened on Friday) that I realized something new and really different was going on. In part, I was taken aback by the extraordinary effects: Disney's "Dinosaur" is a Herculean enterprise combining computer graphics and live action that took about a decade to assemble. An entire team of animators, we were told, worked solely on the fatty tissue problem, and a second team then layered on muscle bulges and jiggling flesh, effecting "breakthroughs" in portraying skin and musculature. Millions of dollars went to the problem of the fur of the lemurs who pal around with the dinosaurs. At one point, every lemur's coat contained 1,200,000 hairs, each with a serial number -- so that it could sway with the wind, for example, when the script called for it. All that fur hogged so much memory, however, that the computers slowed down too much and the process had to be set aside.
B UT what really amazed me was when a journalist asked whether a "single" -- a "Dinosaur" theme song -- would be released at the same time as the movie, and the producer, Pam Marsden, answered "No."
"Not even over the titles?" insisted the journalist. The others laughed.
"No," said Ms. Marsden. "At least none is planned."
So there was no intention to hedge the bet here. Was there that much faith in the movie?
Family pictures have completely changed in the last 10 years," said Brian Levant, the director of both Flintstone movies. "The Flintstones in Viva Rock Vegas," which opened April 28, was shot, with the help of some 4,500 extras, on the biggest set since Cecil B. DeMille's "Ten Commandments"; it was built -- or, rather, Flintstonized -- from scratch. In preproduction for close to a year, it employed a crew of 1,000. "You get to create the whole world," said Mr. Levant, "a civilization. Those things that made 'The Wizard of Oz' such an incredible voyage visually we can do very easily now. So many films being made now tax the imagination of both the filmmaker and the audience. There are no stories that cannot be told."
There are no stories that can't be told. What does that mean for our children?
In the good old days of straightforward dualities, there were two neatly opposing theories about storytelling for children. On the one hand, according to psychoanalysts, mythologists and literary types, children use tales to enlarge the span of their own imaginative play and also to learn to live with the dark side of themselves. On the other, according to the excessively sentimental and purple television star, Barney, "I love you, you love me, we're a happy family."
While parents' concerns are understandable, any attempt to bring the problem back down to a nicely manageable pro or con sort of proposition is a Sisyphean task.
For while some adults remain obsessed with issues of appropriate and inappropriate, or with the big bad evil marketing specialists, filmmakers and kids have gone on to embrace a much more complex, multilayered experience, of which the film is only one aspect.
"We should have had a full education for the parents saying this is what the world is," says Norman Grossfeld, the American producer of the first Pokemon movie. "We never warned them that the Pokemon only spoke their own names." Released theatrically last year and recently out in video, it consists of a 22-minute short and a 76-minute feature.
"The adults barely watched the first movie," Mr. Grossfeld continued. "It wasn't enjoyable to them because they were not prepared for a 20-minute movie without dialogue. And here we were thrilled because we got the characters to emote without speaking. So they didn't have an open mind when they got to the main feature, and it didn't get the attention that it deserved."
The kids, of course, all knew. They knew because they had fully inhabited the whole Pokemon world long before the movie came out. In the press, there was much talk at the time about the economics and the consumerism of it all. (And parents may well have resented the hit on their wallets.) But among kindergartners, the talk was of the Pokemon themselves -- their names (all 151), families, types, exotic powers and weaknesses and how some evolve. Unlike their adults, the kids going to see the Pokemon movie knew what the characters were capable of, whether they were good or bad guys and what their relationships were to the others.
I remember being struck, watching the first movie, by a panorama of the Pokemon characters flying together looking -- of all things -- quite beautiful. Seeing them in formation like this I realized how reminiscent they were of characters from Greek mythology. Many adults remain fixated on the violence in Pokemon, but closer scrutiny would perhaps persuade them that conflict is amply accounted for by a clear system of morality in which integrity is rewarded, and honorable heroes are attractive to children (thereby fulfilling the time-honored terms of fairy tales, which may be essentially immoral, but which feature an alluring moral hero with whom the child will wish to identify).
Undoubtedly, the Pokemon also spend a good deal of their energy and powers preparing for and engaging in some quite original (and not at all gory) battle, and they display a considerable amount of aggression -- perhaps as much, say, as your average kindergarten class at recess. But in addition, kids are certainly taken by the themes of quest, valor and honor, by the nurturing friendships between the trainers and their Pokemon. And of course part of what attracts kids is what confounds adults, which is that the whole thing is so byzantine. There are so many of them, so many alliances and back-stories and subplots to keep track of. No wonder children are mesmerized.
In the new movie, the world is thrown out of balance when an eccentric collector captures the various birds of the Pokemon myth, each of which controls a separate part of the balance of the universe -- the bird of ice, the bird of fire, the bird of electricity. Ash, the Pokemon hero, has coincidentally been chosen to be king of a festival, and as the balance of the world becomes disturbed he is called upon to become the hero he represents in the festival.
He teams up with a new Pokemon called Lugia, a big, serpenty, white-and-blue bird with psychic powers. Five other brand-new Pokemon will appear in the movie, trailblazers for the more than 100 silver and gold theme characters that will be released in the fall.
"Kids can absorb so much more information and language than when they get older," says Mr. Grossfeld. "We don't write down to them -- we have a healthy respect for what kids can handle. They're not being marketed to or at, they're being entertained."
The first Pokemon movie was never intended for export, and its animation is offbeat and somewhat dark by American standards. Mr. Grossfeld says the new movie will be brighter. "The first movie had one story line," he says. "This one has a subplot and more characters and many more stories converge at the end."
To my suggestion that the first movie had been underestimated, Mr. Grossfeld responded that it was perhaps too cerebral for most adults. "What kind of a movie has a main character who has to figure out what his reason for being is?" he asked, rather apologetically, and definitely rhetorically.
O NE adult with no trouble grasping the need for these themes in children's lives is Britt Allcroft, the director of "Thomas and the Magic Railroad" -- a film many would see as the antithesis of "Pokemon" and the boat it came in on. "Thomas" is based on the tranquil character whose principal ambition is to be a very useful engine. The little blue wooden train is well known to boys and girls from the prize-winning television series "Shining Time Station," which Ms. Allcroft created in Britain in the late 70's.
As I told Ms. Allcroft -- who seemed the sort of person one could confide in -- my son, Luc, had been for a hefty portion of his total of nearly 6 years a passionate admirer of Thomas the Tank Engine: a singer of the Thomas the Tank Engine theme and the owner of a Thomas the Tank Engine railroad set, of Thomas memorabilia, videocassettes and pajamas. Indeed, in his closet now there are still boxes containing Thomas the Tank Engine trains, tunnels, bridges, underpasses, roundhouses and clickety-clack tracks, all of which he refused to surrender.
But he'd moved on in his viewing interests. I thought he never would, but he did -- to Fred Astaire musicals and Billy Wilder comedies like "Some Like It Hot" and Jacques Tati farces like "Playtime" and adventure movies like "The Swiss Family Robinson" and also, of course, to every sort of superhero movie -- be it trashy or transcendent.
And why shouldn't he? My hope is that he will be able to use them all to activate different locales in his fantasy life. Sometimes, he might want to hark back to the serene days of tooling about the British countryside with Thomas, the really useful engine. On other, more active days, he might want to be fuming with the rather ill-tempered Gengar or Mewtwo (or whatever his current favorites are among the Pokemon), or feeling helpless and adorable with Stuart Little, or scowling along with Batman or Superman (or Wonder Woman? Where is she, producers of America?).
"I'd like my son to be able to watch both 'Thomas' and 'Pokemon,' " I told Ms. Allcroft.
"Exactly!" she said. "Why shouldn't young children enjoy both? On my shelves, I've got 'Auntie Mame' there and here I've got 'Memories, Dreams and Reflections' and over here I've got 'Greatest Mountain Journeys in the World.' If he kind of tucks the Thomas times of his life away and then he comes back to them, I would be very happy.
"The core viewers of Thomas start at about 18 months and go up to about 7 or 8, but they enjoy these stories at different levels," Ms. Allcroft continued. "And what I think is very important to the longevity of those stories is that they're stories the grownups can enjoy along with the children."
"Thomas and the Magic Railroad" actually features grown-up actors -- and they're not just voice-overs. In the movie, the 11-year-old Lily (Mara Wilson) takes the wrong train on a visit to see her grandfather (Peter Fonda), a once happy railway engineer who now lives a solitary life. She ends up in the scenic town of Shining Time, where she meets the magical Mr. Conductor (Alec Baldwin), who of course takes her on an adventure to the Island of Sodor, a toy world where Thomas, the tiny blue steam engine, lives.
Mr. Baldwin, who succeeded Ringo Starr and George Carlin as the narrator of the television show, got on board the Thomas bandwagon in part because Thomas is a favorite of his daughter's. Similarly, "Thomas and the Magic Railroad" is produced and distributed by Destination Films, which is headed by Barry London -- who worked for years to acquire the rights because he, too, had a little girl who loved Thomas.
And that seems to be what it's about, really, all the fuss. It's very moving and more than a little disturbing to watch your child fall in love with a character other than yourself. Like their first blankies, these "transitional objects" accompany children to worlds that are not of our own making. Real or imaginary, they are the places where our children play and dream.
But this is not what people talk about when they talk about kids' films. Should we or shouldn't we let our kids see "The Nutty Professor II: The Klumps"? This is the sort of decision about which contemporary parents seem to think they need to develop a tough moral framework. "I would rather have my kids laugh at humor about flatulence," I heard someone say recently (though she used a much less fancy word), "than watch gratuitous violence. Of course, you have to explain this is something that happens in a movie, not something that's appropriate in real life."
Of course. And while plenty of parents would think nothing of taking a child to an Eddie Murphy movie, others would have them arrested. This time around, the decision was taken out of our hands by the film's PG-13 rating, but many people give up going to the movies once they have children, and among them there are further subdivisions about what to watch on tape. Books, magazines and Web sites now rate films, breaking them down for each age group and grading them by category, according to how they depict not just sex and violence, but also drinking and drug use, profanity, scatology.
Among parents, the sole comfortable and unanimous point of agreement is on the subject of gratuitous violence. (Against!) But alas, this is not all that useful, since it is difficult to find any in a big-budget film that bills itself as a family picture.
In the end, none of this arguing addresses the only real question, which is this: Now that we really understand how vulnerable children are, how do we best protect them? By showing them the world or by shielding them from it? It seems logical to conclude that there is no one answer, only a balance.
Of course, there are movies in which technology takes over, in which violence seems to spring out of nowhere, everywhere, as if an anonymous, mechanistic, amorally vengeful environment will confound and ridicule man, robbing him of dignity and volition. I am thinking, for example, of Charlie Chaplin's "Modern Times," which Luc and I have now watched several times, finding it funnier on each occasion.
Perhaps we displace onto movies our feelings of powerlessness about so much else -- our children's schools, friends, choices, the frighteningly complex and confusing society in which they must navigate and the even less controllable future. But it's too bad to set up such a simplistic yes-no argument here, when something so much more profound and resonant is at stake.

SECTION: Section 2; Page 1; Column 1; Arts and Leisure Desk

HEADLINE: THEATER/THE TONY AWARDS;
The Award Theater People Hate and Love

BYLINE: By ROBIN POGREBIN 

 BODY:
FOR die-hard theatergoers -- the kind of devoted fans who gnawed their cuticles over the battle between "Dreamgirls" and "Nine" in 1982, or agonized over which actor from "Two Trains Running," Laurence Fishburne or Roscoe Lee Browne, to root for in 1992, or pulled for "Pacific Overtures" to upset the popular favorite, "A Chorus Line," in 1976 -- the Tony Awards have been as exciting as the Oscars.
And here it is again, that theatrical rite of spring: Tony time, when this season's actors, directors, playwrights, choreographers and designers get to enjoy their brief anointed status as nominees, and producers can salivate about the prospect of being able to plaster "Best Musical" or "Best Play" above the titles of their shows and hear their box office cash registers go ka-ching. 
 Many theater professionals say the Tony Awards are a prestigious prize that celebrates Broadway's talent and sells Broadway shows, and that the awards' marketing power is potent, particularly on the road.
But these same professionals concede that Tony season has also become an annual opportunity for carping and soul-searching within the industry, not only about the theater but also about the Tonys themselves. This year, the debates seem to point to a fundamental shift in the conception of what constitutes live theater on Broadway.
The controversy over whether "Contact," a dance show with no singing or live music, should be considered a musical goes to the heart of a larger question about the direction of the American musical. The three other shows besides "Contact" nominated for best musical this year also defy conventional definitions. "James Joyce's 'The Dead,' " which recently closed, is a play in which the characters sing Irish songs for one another at a Christmas party. "Swing!" is a dance revue that mixes classic swing music with new pastiche pieces. And Michael John LaChiusa's "Wild Party," like his other new musical this season, "Marie Christine," features virtually no dialogue at all, blurring the lines between musical theater and opera.
Indeed, this year's Tony Awards suggest a rejection of the traditional book musical, given that Disney's "Aida" was not nominated for best musical, although it received five other nominations.
The nominators were apparently hard pressed to fill out the category for best musical revival, nominating "Tango Argentino," a dance show, which has closed, and "Jesus Christ Superstar," which received almost universally poor reviews, in addition to Cole Porter's "Kiss Me, Kate" and Meredith Willson's "Music Man."
Two members of the Tony nominating committee resigned this year. A. R. Gurney, the playwright, said he resigned because he was not permitted to abstain from the vote on whether Mandy Patinkin should be nominated for best actor in a musical. Mr. Patinkin had been absent from the performance Mr. Gurney attended of "The Wild Party." "I just didn't think it was fair to vote for or against him if I hadn't seen him," Mr. Gurney said. (The playwright elaborates on his concerns about the Tonys in an article on page 9.)
Jack Goldstein, the executive director of the Theater Development Fund, resigned over objections to "Contact's" being considered a musical.
Some nominators expressed frustration that they were unable to award something special to the two actors who alternate roles in "True West," Philip Seymour Hoffman and John C. Reilly. Even though the nominators had taken the trouble to see both versions of the production, they said they were forced to vote for best actor based only on the play's opening night casting.
"They're both superb and they both share the play," said Frances Sternhagen, the actress, who serves on the nominating committee. "So why do we have to have this rule?
"Theater so needs a boost that you don't want to be difficult," Ms. Sternhagen continued. "But it's just so hard when you want to give credit where credit is due."
The Tonys this year also had to grapple with the notion of what is a Broadway show. For example, "Dame Edna: The Royal Tour" and "Jackie Mason: Much Ado About Everything" were deemed ineligible despite their popularity with audiences. One way the Tony administrators have handled unorthodox shows is to give them special Tony Awards, as they did this year with "Dame Edna."
The nominations this year also speak to the dearth of new writing on Broadway. Two revivals -- "Kiss Me, Kate" and "The Music Man" -- led the nominations, with 12 and 8 respectively. Two of the four productions nominated for best new play are actually old, though they are new to Broadway: "True West" by Sam Shepard was originally produced Off Broadway in 1980, and "The Ride Down Mt. Morgan" by Arthur Miller was first produced in London in 1991. Similarly, Noel Coward's "Waiting in the Wings" is eligible for consideration as best new play because it has never before been on Broadway, even though it was written in 1960.
Despite various complaints about the selection process, most people associated with New York theater agree that the Tonys are no more problematic than any other awards show in which an industry honors itself.
Although there are many other theater awards given out around this time -- the Outer Critics Circle Awards, the Obies, the Drama Desk Awards and the Drama League Awards -- producers say the Tonys are the only ones that sell tickets. Winning best musical or best play, they say, means money in the bank.
"To win a Tony is a powerful calling card," said Rocco Landesman, the president of Jujamcyn Theaters.
Added Emanuel Azenberg, the producer: "It's industry-created to hype an industry. And in that it succeeds."
But what exactly is that industry these days? Since Broadway has become dominated by revivals and British imports, is some of the best work happening elsewhere? And what exactly are the Tony Awards intended for? To honor the best of New York theater generally, or to promote Broadway specifically?
Last year, the League of American Theaters and Producers, the national trade organization for the commercial theater industry, which presents the Tony Awards with the American Theater Wing, established a long-range planning committee to examine the future of the league, including Tony matters.
"I'm in the thinking stage on all this right now," said Elizabeth I. McCann, a longtime producer who serves on the committee. "You have to look at the season as it plays itself out. You can't force it into rigid rules that were created when theater was different.
"I would like an impartial panel of three people who would view the situation and make recommendations to the committee based on this season on Broadway," Ms. McCann continued. "Why jam 'Riverdance' into the category of best musical when it is really basically a dance revue?" The show had been termed eligible by the Tony administration committee, though it did not receive a nomination from the Tony nominating committee.
When producers want to get actors or shows considered for certain Tony nominations, they must petition the Tony administration committee. This year the producers of "True West" petitioned to have Mr. Hoffman and Mr. Reilly considered jointly so they would not compete against each other for a nomination in the leading actor category. The request was denied. In another case, the producers of "A Moon for the Misbegotten" asked that Roy Dotrice, who plays the heroine's father, be considered in the featured actor rather than the leading actor category. That request was granted.
Such efforts notwithstanding, Jed Bernstein, president of the league, said the process generally worked. "It's easy to take potshots at individual rules and individual outcomes," he said. "But once you start to understand the ultimate goal -- that there ought to be a level playing field -- whether it's right or wrong, at least it's fair."
Some producers beg to differ. Since 1994, Roy Gabay has produced, or been general manager for, three Pulitzer Prize-winning plays -- "Three Tall Women," "How I Learned to Drive" and "Wit" -- all Off Broadway, none Tony eligible. "That to me is wrong," Mr. Gabay said. "I don't understand how that can be, that plays that were honored for excellence in the theater are not eligible for an excellence award."
The Off Broadway industry itself has in the past resisted the idea of becoming Tony-eligible because of logistical and financial obstacles. Trying to get all the Tony voters into the multitude of small Off Broadway houses to see every production would be almost impossible. In addition, it could drive up the costs of producing, due to the loss of revenue that would result from having to give away seats to Tony voters, and because the unions might then demand Broadway rates -- or at least a higher wage scale -- for their services.
Some theater executives suggested creating a few Off Broadway Tony Awards and appointing a special Off Broadway Tony committee so that every voter would not have to see every Off Broadway show. "I don't know if it's feasible," said Daryl Roth, an Off Broadway producer who has also produced on Broadway. "But it feels like the right thing to do and where we're heading."
Because Off Broadway productions are excluded from the Tonys, Ms. Roth said they miss out on national exposure during the Tony Awards show. This is particularly critical to productions that can barely afford their own marketing. Broadway producers often counter that Off Broadway has its own prizes. But others say these do not have the prestige of the Tonys in terms of what they can do for a show's fortunes and a performer's reputation.
"Careers change when they get a Tony Award," said Virginia P. Louloudes, the executive director of the Alliance of Resident Theaters/New York, a service group for nonprofit theaters. "And God knows, the actors deserve the recognition. So do the directors and designers."
What it comes down to, it seems, is what the Tonys are really about. "If the point of the awards is to promote Broadway, then keeping Off Broadway out of the awards is appropriate," said Todd Haimes, artistic director of the Roundabout Theater Company, an Off Broadway house that also produces on Broadway. "If the point is to award excellence in the theater in the New York metropolitan area, then to keep Off Broadway out is ridiculous."
Broadway executives say the Tony is not an equal-opportunity perk; it is reserved for those foolhardy enough and financially able to gamble on Broadway. Big risks, this argument goes, deserve the biggest potential reward.
"No business is going to give away its franchise for nothing," said Mr. Landesman, the producer. "Would Rolls-Royce say, 'Here's our emblem, go put it on a Chevy?' I don't see why we're expected to do that."
Mr. Gabay said the major flaw of the Tonys was who rules on eligibility. "You're looking at people with completely vested interests," he said about the 24 members of the Tony administration committee. "It's not a group of people who can make a fair decision. They are theater owners, they are producers. Why would I want 'Wit' to be eligible when I'm producing 'Art' or 'The Beauty Queen of Leenane'?"
Mr. Gabay said that when a producer appears before the administration committee to argue his case, as he has, the deck is stacked. "You feel like you're just going through the motions," he said, "because it's completely political in there."
Producers who serve on the committee defend the selection process, saying, essentially, welcome to the real world. "Is it any different in this industry from the television industry or the recording industry or the film industry?" asked Barry Weissler, who, with his wife, Fran, has produced several of Broadway's biggest hit revivals. "It's the same. Everyone has self-interest."
Moreover, Mr. Azenberg, the producer, said, the Tonys make no pretense of being about which artist or project is better than another; it isn't like winning a track meet because you ran the fastest. "We have an artificial competition," he said. "Shows don't compete. It's just a subjective choice between people."
Mr. Bernstein, of the league, pointed out that many of those who criticize certain rules are not prepared to present viable alternatives. Some people in the industry, for example, have objected to considering "True West" a new production because, although it was written in 1980 and produced Off Broadway, the play has never been produced on Broadway. But then, Mr. Bernstein asked, what does the definition of a new play become? A production that was never done in New York City but might have been done in Connecticut or New Jersey? A play that has never been given an "important production"? And if that is the case, what defines important?
As to what constitutes a musical, that appears to be up for grabs these days. With shows like "Smokey Joe's Cafe," "Fosse," "Riverdance," "Swing!," "Contact" and "James Joyce's 'The Dead' " stretching the boundaries of a traditional book musical, it is hard to know what a musical is anymore.
SOME theater professionals suggested creating more specific categories, along the lines of London's Olivier Awards or Hollywood's Golden Globes -- like Tonys for best solo performance or best entertainment -- though this would mean more to squeeze into the already crowded broadcast.
Then there are those who argue that there are not enough voters with the appropriate expertise in each category, like craftspeople who can judge design. But critics of this idea caution that the voting pool is already bloated and adding voters is not the answer.
"I think there are too many people voting," Mr. Azenberg said. "You can't get a lifetime franchise by producing one play. Some of us still want to be judged by our peers." He said he had given Tony voters $125,000 worth of tickets to "The Iceman Cometh," which he produced last year in a limited run starring Kevin Spacey (who was also a producer of the play). "If I'm going to do a play for 12 to 14 weeks, that's giving away 25 percent of the potential profit if the play is successful," Mr. Azenberg said. ("Iceman" orchestra tickets were $100.)
With increasing numbers of new people dabbling in Broadway, "it will get out of hand," he warned. "It is out of hand."
Two years ago, the league stepped up its enforcement of a policy mandating that only producers who have produced a show in the previous four years could remain active members and therefore have a Tony vote, though they may retain their league membership -- a decision that angered several voters, about 30 of whom have drafted a complaint against the league that has been sent out to members of the group for approval. This reduced the number of Tony voters from 825 to 705, a figure that will jump slightly, because the league recently lengthened the required time period within which someone must have produced to six years and decided to create a new lifetime membership category for inactive theater veterans to honor their service.
Nevertheless, there are still a lot of voters, each of whom is entitled to a pair of tickets per show, which amounts to a potential loss of about $100,000 for each production. Moreover, many producers complain that some voters give their tickets away but cast their votes nonetheless -- a violation of rules that producers nevertheless feel unable to enforce without alienating voters.
"I don't want to be offensive and cost myself a vote," Mr. Gabay said. "Will they get really annoyed and not vote for me if I put the screws in?"
When the Tonys were created by the American Theater Wing in 1947, the ceremony took place at the Waldorf-Astoria. The award consisted of a scroll and women got a monogrammed sterling silver compact; men a cigarette lighter or an engraved gold money clip. Some people miss the old days.
"I enjoy the intimacy and the feeling of family in the ballroom that we had then," said Isabelle Stevenson, chairwoman of the American Theater Wing.
Ms. Stevenson makes no secret of her belief that the Tonys have become too concerned with commercial interests. "The Tony Award was created to reward excellence in the theater," she said."There was no thought of it being of economic value.
"You can't be blind to the fact that it is an important economic boost to the theater. On the other hand, it cannot become just that. The commitment to excellence must remain. You cannot use it only as an economic marketing tool."
Even those who believe that bigger is better for the Tonys complain that the show has not found its own identity. "If you're going to go on network television, you're going to try to ape the Oscars and use what happens on television to sell tickets," said Ms. McCann, the producer. "It's a tough problem for the theater to compete against the Emmys, the Grammys, the Oscars. Yet CBS expects us to."
With ratings a struggle, and Broadway actors radiating considerably less star power than movie actors -- with the exception of actors who visit Broadway from Hollywood -- the pressure has increased to make the Tony Awards show more of a draw for viewers (the first hour is broadcast on PBS, the second two hours on CBS).
Thus, it has now become not just an advantage but something of a necessity to present the awards at a glitzy location like Radio City Music Hall rather than in a theater or ballroom, and to have Rosie O'Donnell as host. (When she did not appear last year, the overnight ratings dropped considerably -- to 7.9 from the 10.3 when she presided in 1998.)
Some industry insiders say the awards have become overly concerned with the promotion potential and star power of the television show rather than simply with honoring outstanding work.
Ms. Sternhagen, who is in the second of her three-year term as a Tony nominator, said the Tony administrators expressed disappointment last year when she and her colleagues failed to nominate Nicole Kidman for her performance in "The Blue Room," because the movie star would have boosted television ratings.
Nominators said they were frustrated by having to nominate a certain number of musicals to satisfy the CBS contract that specifies a minimum of seven "entertainment segments" on the Tony broadcast. Some suggested featuring musical numbers without having to nominate the musicals.
Then there is the "damned if you do, damned if you don't" problem of honoring straight plays on the broadcast. When they are excluded, some argue that the awards do not reflect the true picture of a Broadway season. But producers have yet to come up with an effective way to feature straight plays; last year's delivery by Mr. Spacey and several other actors of a montage of lines from various plays was widely criticized as a mishmash.
"The wing is concerned with excellence," Ms. McCann said. "Broadway producers are concerned with selling tickets. So everybody has a different agenda for that show."
Although some people in the theater worry that CBS may drop the Tonys because of low ratings, Leslie Moonves, the network's president and chief executive, said CBS remained committed. "I still think the Tony Awards is one of the most prestigious events on television," he said. And, he added, "We have some very loyal sponsors who feel the way we do."
Similarly, William F. Baker, president of New York's WNET, said he was proud to carry the PBS presentation of behind-the-scenes awards (i.e., costumes, lighting) "to celebrate and provide an understanding about the people who create the plays and are in some ways unsung heroes."
Winning a Tony is still a significant achievement in the industry, producers say. Even Peter Schneider, chairman of Disney Studios -- which would hardly seem to need a Broadway award to enhance its worldwide fortunes -- said he was excited when "The Lion King" won best musical in 1998.
"We were thrilled," he said. "It was an acknowledgment from our peers that the show was good."

HEADLINE: In the Region/Westchester;
Starwood Leases a White Plains Building for Its HQ

BYLINE: By MARY McALEER VIZARD 

DATELINE: WHITE PLAINS

 BODY:
THIS city's rebounding office market has received another major boost with the announcement this month that Starwood Hotels and Resorts Worldwide plans to lease more than 200,000 square feet, occupying an entire office building along the Interstate 287 corridor, where it expects to establish its world headquarters.
"This is the biggest lease we've seen in Westchester in several years," said Frank Tomasulo, a first vice president with the CB Richard Ellis brokerage company. "It's way beyond the size of the leases we've been seeing lately, and is indicative of what's happening now in Westchester's market. Lots of companies that are now looking for large blocks of space are looking in Westchester because they can't find them in Fairfield County or in New York City anymore." 
 Starwood had been looking for an appropriate headquarters location for about three years, according to Rob Martin, a senior managing director for Insignia/ESG, which had been representing the company in its search, which also included lower Fairfield County. Starwood eventually settled on 1129 Westchester Avenue, along what is known as the county's Platinum Mile, a stretch of corporate parks bordering Interstate 287 that is considered one of the most prestigious office locations in the county.
Although most recently used as a corporate headquarters for Nine West, the shoe company, 1129 Westchester Avenue was built on speculation and designed for multitenancy.
"Starwood wanted a prestigious Class A building," Mr. Martin said. "That was the most important thing, since they have clients coming in from all over the world and need the right image. It also has good visibility from the highway and is convenient."
Starwood will sublet the space for 12 years from Nine West, which had once occupied a total of 366,000 square feet at 1129 and 1109 Westchester Avenue. Nine West recently downsized to 90,000 square feet at 1109, and sublets 30,000 square feet in that building to Ameritrade, an Internet trading company.
Nine West has offered Starwood the option of expanding into 1109 if space becomes available. Starwood is "a growing company," Mr. Martin said, "and it was important to them to have the possibility of expansion."
While they looked for permanent space, Starwood took out short-term leases in two other White Plains buildings, at 777 Westchester Avenue and 44 South Broadway. "We were always shuttling back and forth between meetings," said Seth Ruzi, associate general counsel for Starwood. "We needed someplace to consolidate. And staying in White Plains was desirable since it will make things easier on our employees who already work here."
STARWOOD expects to complete its move into the new building in the second and third quarters of 2001. And it expects to retain its present Westchester work force of 300, and add an additional 300 employees by 2006.
Starwood, which recently acquired the Sheraton and Westin hotel chains, is now one of the largest hotel and leisure companies in the world. Through its subsidiaries, it now owns and operates 700 hotels in 80 countries, said Dan Gibson, a senior vice president of corporate affairs. In May 1998, the company relocated its headquarters from Phoenix.
A major inducement in selecting Westchester for its permanent headquarters, Mr. Ruzi said, was the "cooperation of the state and county governments," as well as a package of economic incentives that include tax abatements worth $775,000, provided by the Westchester County Industrial Development Agency, and a $500,000 jobs-creation grant from the state.
The state grant is contingent on Starwood's maintaining its current Westchester work force and adding 150 more jobs by 2003, said Maura Gallucci, a spokeswoman for the Empire State Development Corporation.
Although Starwood's may be the largest lease signed in Westchester in many years, it is part of a trend toward larger leases that has been established in the last several quarters, according to Mr. Tomasulo. "Anything over 200,000 square feet is, of course, rare," he said. "But we've seen several large leases recently."
Last year Atlas Air leased 120,000 square feet at Texaco's headquarters building, at 2000 Westchester Avenue in White Plains. Also in recent months Towers Perrin leased 108,407 square feet at 100 Summit Lake Drive in Valhalla; AT&T took 95,000 square feet at 500 Mamaroneck Avenue in Harrison; and Metromedia leased 80,000 square feet at 360 Hamilton Avenue in White Plains.
"There's been a 50 percent increase in the last 18 months in leases in excess of 25,000 square feet," said Al Gutierrez, a senior associate with CB Richard Ellis.
"The leases now are way beyond the sizes we had been seeing in the market," he said, where average leases had been around 7,000 square feet.
Mr. Tomasulo said that "companies looking for large blocks of space are now looking at Westchester."
THERE are still several large blocks of space available," he said. "And we know that major companies are now looking at them."
Some of the large blocks left include the former Kraft Food headquarters at 333 Westchester Avenue in White Plains, with more than 500,000 square feet; Mount Pleasant Executive Center in Mount Pleasant, with 380,000 square feet; and 445 Hamilton Avenue in White Plains, with 350,000 square feet.
Westchester's office vacancy rate in the first quarter of this year reached its lowest point in a decade.
The countywide rate of 12.5 percent was down from 17.6 percent at the end of last year, according to CB Richard Ellis. And the amount of vacant space dropped by 458,423 square feet in the first quarter of 2000, compared to a drop of 181,174 in the last quarter of 1999.
As a result, rents have been creeping up, but are still a comparative bargain in relation to Fairfield County and Manhattan, where rents can be 30 percent to 65 percent higher respectively.
Average annual asking rents in Westchester are now $24.48 per square foot, relatively unchanged since the end of last year, but up from $20.94 in the first quarter of 1999, according to CB Richard Ellis.
"If we had been able to find the right property for Starwood in Fairfield, it might have won out and they'd have moved there," said Mr. Martin of Insignia/ESG. "But the economics of Westchester sort of evened the playing field. In White Plains, they're saving 30 percent, and could even expand if they want to. As it turned out, that was very significant."

HEADLINE: IN PERSON;
Simply 'Writer' Will Do

BYLINE: By ROBERT STRAUSS 

DATELINE: PRINCETON

 BODY:
LAN SAMANTHA CHANG cringes when she's told she's the next Amy Tan or Maxine Hong Kingston -- that she is the next great female Asian-American writer.
"When my book came out, immediately there were two reviews that put me in this group with these Asian-American women writers," said Ms. Chang, crinkling her face and cringing at the thought. "Others started comparing me to Jewish writers. I don't know how to feel about all of it." 
 What has raised expectations about Ms. Chang is "Hunger" (Penguin Books, $12.95), a novella and story collection that has earned a collection of outstanding reviews.
All this for a woman who didn't take a writing course until she was in graduate school, whose career has blossomed late -- fortunately so, in her mind.
"I was older, well past the age where you could be said to be precocious," said the 35-year-old Ms. Chang, who is at Princeton University on an Alfred Hodder Fellowship, given to allow young artists to pursue their work with freedom for a year.
"I was a precocious violin player, but then adolescence came," she said over lunch at the elegant Lahieres Restaurant in downtown Princeton. "Adolescence weeds out those with a true calling from those who are just talented. I'm glad I didn't write until later, so I didn't have to go through the same thing with my writing."
Ms. Chang's tales are primarily of Chinese immigrants to America and their tribulations about leaving one culture behind for a new and often strange one. Typical is the beginning of "The Unforgetting," one of the short stories in the collection:
"On the summer day in 1967 when Ming Hwang first saw the eastern Iowa hills, he pulled his car off the road and stopped the engine. He felt overwhelmed, as if he had arrived once more at the sea that he had crossed to reach America and his destiny lay again upon some faraway shore. The neat, green fields rolled out to meet the sky. The narrow strip of highway looked barely navigable. Surely no Chinese man could ever have laid eyes upon this place before."
Despite spending most of her adult life on the two coasts -- she has degrees from Yale and the Kennedy School of Government at Harvard and was a Wallace Stegner writing fellow at Stanford -- there is a great feeling for the Midwest in Ms. Chang's writing.
In fact, she grew up in Appleton, Wis. -- home of Harry Houdini and Senator Joseph McCarthy -- where her father was a chemical engineer, researching paper science at Lawrence University. Hers was one of two Chinese-American families in the small city, both of whose children were all girls.
"It's intrinsic to her work that her parents were immigrants," said Peter Rock, who was a Stegner Fellow with Ms. Chang at Stanford and now teaches writing at the University of Pennsylvania. "But it's more important that she grew up in Appleton.
"When she came to speak at my class, she named several influences in her writing who were white males," said Mr. Rock. "The Asian-American women were upset, saying, 'Aren't you selling out?' All of the people who I know who have had success writing and who are ethnic have to put up with that."
Ms. Chang is using her year at Princeton to research and write a novel, to be published by Norton, based on events in Hang Zhou (Hang Chow) and Chong Qing (Chung King), China, in the 1930's and 40's. She has spent hours poring over old maps and guidebooks in Princeton's Oriental collection.
"When my parents came to visit, we all went over there," she said. "They helped me with the Chinese. It was great fun for all of us."
Her father had wanted Ms. Chang and her three sisters to become doctors, so they would never have to worry about security. But uninterested in medicine, she pursued a degree in Asian studies at Yale and then went to the Kennedy School. Eventually, one sister fulfilled her father's wishes.
"I knew I would come out of there with my dream -- the kind of job where you would wear pantyhose," she said. "Life would make sense if I took these economics courses. Unfortunately, I came to the realization that I hated it."
She decided to take a writing course, but not at Harvard.
"That would have been too hard," she said. "I would have been too insecure to show my writing to Harvard undergraduates."
Instead, she went to the Cambridge Center for Adult Education. She wrote and wrote and, after getting her Harvard degree, went straight to the University of Iowa writers program. She published a story in The Atlantic Monthly, and agents called her saying they could get a book contract.
"I was 28 and I wasn't ready for a book," she said. "I was afraid of being that young writer whose acclaim surprised me into silence. I wanted to wait until I knew what and who I wanted to be as a writer. I wanted to be, well, serious.
"Being a young writer of color, I'm lucky to have had the time to find my voice," she said. "The bridge between the first and second book is difficult. There are now expectations."
Even now, some of those expectations come from her parents. When they visited last month and Ms. Chang gave a reading from "Hunger," Joyce Carol Oates, the practiced and prolific author who teaches at Princeton, was there to meet them. And in the Oriental library, Ms. Chang found out something new about them.
"It turns out they were just like me, loving stories and looking at history," she said. "It's just that they hid it much of the time. We didn't have books around when I was a child. To my parents, they were too much baggage. But it turns out they were just too heavy to carry when they were escaping from the Japanese invasions, when they would have to move quickly.
"When we came to the library together, they took out books and loved the whole experience," she said. "Being a close-knit family and somewhat isolated in Wisconsin, they are what I draw from for my stories. So it is wonderful to find a new aspect with them."
Ms. Chang's novel will not appear until next year, by which time she will be on another fellowship at Radcliffe. But she has already given thought to coming back to New Jersey.
"Princeton is a wonderful kind of place, where you can feel both anonymous and part of a greater world," she said, pointing out several accomplished faculty members in Lahieres. "It's a quiet place with intense people, which, despite appearances is what a writer is -- quiet and intense."
 
A Sternness Born of Love
An excerpt from "Hunger" by Lan Samantha Chang.
Ruth grew tall and almost painfully slender; in the sixth grade, she began to practice on Tian's full-sized violin. At 14, she won a citywide competition for young musicians. As the winner, she would perform a concerto, accompanied by the orchestra that had sponsored the competition. Tian had chosen the Sibelius concerto, and for many, many months he and Ruth practiced those wondrous loops of sound, the joyous slithering movements of Sibelius.
He treated her as cruelly as he did himself with complete disregard for her age and temperament. But she did not complain to me or Anna. She would play and sob for hours, but emerge from the room without a word. She believed, she had known from infancy, that she held him in her hands. Now he had replaced his tenderness with this stern passion and she followed him there, believing the source of his sternness lay in love. In this blindness, I began to see, she and her father were alike.
All morning during summer vacations, plus two evenings a week, he sat in the tiny room for hours and helped her practice. I remember the way he looked at her when things went well; intense, prideful, the dispassionate yet hungry stare that I learned to recognize on television in coaches or trainers as they watch the taut bodies of their favorites. They exchanged few words; just an occasional "no," or "again," or "tone." "Bad fingering." "Again, again."
Ruth did not grimace or stop to complain. To this day I hold an image of them practicing under the skylight: Tian in the corner with his impenetrable and hungry gaze, and Ruth, stark-faced, her clear features lit gold or gray from above, lips pale and nostrils flared; her half-closed eyes, shadowed beneath.
Her long-sleeved T-shirt flapped as she moved her arms. Her days were filled with school and practicing, carrying some enormous weight. It must be difficult to find some time to think, living as she was under the spotlight of her father's fierce attention.

HEADLINE: PERSPECTIVES;
HUD Moves to Shore Up Section 8 Subsidy Program

BYLINE: By ALAN S. OSER 

 BODY:
A METAPHOR helps to explain what the "marking down to market" program is all about, said the housing official. Then he launched into an elaborate one.
Picture a fleet a ships floating gently down from Washington. Each one is a housing development, built with federal mortgage insurance under the Section 8 program, the name for a national subsidy system that assists low-income people.
"Those that are listing we take out, and once we right them they go back into the HUD portfolio," said Patrick Eckman, who is acting director for the New York region of the Office of Multifamily Housing Assistance Restructuring, a branch of the United States Department of Housing and Urban Development. The office was created under the Multifamily Assisted Housing Reform and Affordability Act of 1997. 
 The buildings that the act is designed to assist were built either new or as substantial rehabilitations from the late 70's to the mid-80's. They received insured mortgages running for 40 years, but the Section 8 subsidy contracts that supplement the rents that the tenants pay typically run for only 20 years.
Many of these housing ships are listing because they are supporting high mortgages, which were required to get the housing built. In negotiating new contracts the government is seeking to make rents reflect market rents. In most cases this will mean reducing subsidies and lowering the building's mortgage burden. But it may also involve raising subsidies, HUD officials say. Eight applications from New York City buildings to "mark up to market" have already been received by the branch of HUD that handles them, the Office of Housing, the officials said.
Under the Section 8 program, tenants pay 30 percent of their modest incomes as rent. The subsidy pays the additional amount required to make total rental income sufficient to meet operating expenses, local taxes and mortgage payments. The total authorized rent is called the contract rent.
For example, the tenant might be paying $500 a month on an income of $18,000 a year. The contract rent might be $1,200 a month, with the government paying $700 to supplement the tenant's payment.
The true market rent, however, might be $800 a month, not $1,200. HUD would therefore want to mark the contract rent down to $800. The tenant would still pay $500, but the subsidy would be $300 a month, not $700.
The Government's fiscal stake is substantial. Its insurance portfolio has $12 billion in project-based Section 8 loans outstanding.
The new contracts will also provide the money to pay for the major building improvements required after 20 years.
With the signing of a contract in March by the housing company that owns a cluster of three buildings in East Harlem, the city now has an example of the mark-to-market program in action. The East Harlem contract was negotiated under a national demonstration that was set in motion before the permanent program went into effect, with the city's housing finance arm, the Housing Development Corporation, acting as HUD's agent. The demonstration reveals some of the issues that the permanent program faces.
HOUSING professionals predict that most of the Section 8 buildings will stay in the program. But in strong market areas, including Manhattan and some other city neighborhoods, others may decide to leave it. This would not deprive the low-income tenants in those buildings of access to subsidized apartments, though not necessarily in their own buildings.
If a building leaves the Section 8 program, its tenants are assured of one more year of occupancy. If the tenant cannot afford the new market rent, and the owner will not accept voucher tenants, the tenant is eligible to participate in a HUD relocation program to move to another building that does take vouchers.
The process of "opting out" of the Section 8 program would nevertheless diminish the total inventory of apartments reserved for low-income tenants. Vacated apartments would be reoccupied by tenants paying rents too high for low-income households.
According to HUD, 448 projects in the city, with 111,300 apartments, are benefiting from project-based Section 8 subsidies. Staying in the program might lead to better, or at least more secure, economic results for the building than leaving it, housing professionals say, since an owner is assured of steady, adequate rent payments through any market cycle over 20 years, without the need to hunt in the private market for conventional financing that current tenant rents will probably not support.
"We don't think that New York City properties will opt out," said Ira G. Peppercorn, director of the Office of Multifamily Housing Assistance Restructuring. "We give something in exchange for rent reduction. We will restructure the mortgage if necessary and we will contribute 80 percent of the rehabilitation cost. If we do the job right, the owner will have no financial incentive to leave."
There are skeptics, however. Among them are the representatives of state housing agencies. They object to HUD's detailed 400-page rule book and the agency's one-size-fits-all compensation schedule, which they say has forced agencies in high-cost states and localities, including the city's Housing Development Corporation, out of the implementation process.
"It was the clearly Congress's intent that state and local governments should be the restructuring agents, which would be the best way to preserve as much low-income housing as possible," said John B. McEvoy, executive director of the National Council of State Housing Agencies in Washington.
OTHERS foresee problems in the law itself. Under the original Section 8 program, Congress committed the funds to fulfill the 20-year contracts up front -- in the first year. But under the permanent program enacted in 1997, the funds must be appropriated annually, subject to the terms of the 20-year contracts. "Owners may figure they would be better off with vouchers rather than playing Congressional roulette every year," said David A. Smith, president of Recapitalization Advisors, a low-income housing consultant in Boston. They could abandon project-based subsidies but still accept voucher tenants, he noted.
In addition, the new act requires owners to put up 20 percent of rehabilitation costs, and pay 50 percent of the substantial transaction costs in negotiating a new contract, without providing an incentive by which general partners can induce their investment partners to provide additional capital.
"Even if I want to stay in the program, how do I finance it?" asked J. David Page, a principal in Southport Financial Services of Tacoma, Wash., an owner-operator of 8,000 subsidized and market-rate apartments across the country. "There's no compensation for the restructurer. How is he supposed to get it done -- and why?"
Southport was the owner's consultant and also the provider of new capital in the mark-to-market demonstration in East Harlem. Now a partner in the ownership, it assisted in the negotiations with the Housing Development Corporation. The buildings are 1775 Houses, A. K. Houses and M. S. Houses, a total of 543 apartments on the west side of Lexington Avenue between 126th and 129th Street.
The buildings are managed by Marion Scott Real Estate, a Manhattan firm that runs 15 Section 8 buildings in New York City and Newark. "It's a difficult process," said David H. Berezin, a senior vice president of Marion Scott in charge of the East Harlem buildings. "The demonstration program is certainly a lot easier for an owner to participate in than the permanent program appears to be at the present time."
Marking down to market in East Harlem meant a reduction of 23 percent in the contract rent, Mr. Berezin said, and the elimination of 27 percent of the mortgage debt. The repayment schedule for the balance due was strung out over 27 years. A $7 million rehabilitation is under way.
"We now have the capital to replace all the buildings systems -- roofs, heating plants, windows, elevators," Mr. Berezin said. All the kitchens and appliances will also be upgraded. Tenants' rents will not be affected.
But Herbert D. Freedman, a principal in Marion Scott, predicted that about 20 percent of the buildings that get project-based Section 8 subsidies in New York City would withdraw from the program. "Any owner who has the option to get out of the program, because of the location of the property and its condition, undoubtedly will," Mr. Freedman said.
One possible outcome in New York City, housing specialists say, is that neighborhood-based nonprofit companies may come forward to purchase Section 8 buildings from owners who want to leave the program. And further Congressional action is still possible to provide the tax or other incentives to make it easier for owners to sell to other entities, nonprofit or otherwise, that would keep the buildings as low-income housing.
The Office of Multifamily Housing Assistance Restructuring itself expresses optimism. So far 33 projects in New York City have come forward to negotiate lower contract rents, said Mr. Eckman, the acting director of the regional office. "We are happy with the level of participation so far," he said.
