HEADLINE: Built-In Grills in a Comeback

BYLINE: By ELZY KOLB 

 BODY:
BRICK and mortar is making a comeback. Elaborate brick and stone barbecue fireplaces are starting to appear in backyards around the region.
"We began to have people asking for them about four years ago," said Trish Calabrese, office manager of Creative Stone Works Inc., in Park Ridge, N.J. "This year, there has been a huge increase. It's amazing what people are doing in their yards right now." 
 The booming economy is at least in part behind the resurgence of interest in these backyard behemoths. Higher disposable income makes it possible, even desirable, to dress up the mundane things in life. "The stonework has an Old World feeling, and it definitely looks a lot better than the plain, black-box gas grill," Ms. Calabrese said.
There's some nostalgia involved, too. Simple but pleasant childhood memories often bring clients to the offices of stonemasons and landscape architects. During the planning stage, "customers will mention the little old fireplaces, like they had in parks or in rest stops on the Thruway," said Tom Ciccariello, owner of Seven Sons, a stone-working company in East Hampton on Long Island. "For many of us, those cookouts were a big part of growing up."
But today's manifestation of those memories typically goes far beyond the basic wood-fired, single-grill units of cookouts past.
Cameron Brand, a certified landscape architect and office manager of Oliver Nurseries in Fairfield, Conn., views the stone barbecue as the open-air equivalent of a commercial range, saying, "It's the Viking of outdoor products."
Florence Bogart, a landscape architect at Sprainbrook Nurseries in Scarsdale, agrees. "What I'm seeing is elaborate outdoor cooking spaces. Really, it's like an outdoor kitchen."
Most are fueled by natural gas rather than wood or charcoal. And most are "elaborate fireplaces tied to something, not just a lump of stone," Mr. Ciccariello said.
There's an extensive wish list of things that can be tied to such a setup. The brick or stone barbecue might have a top-of-the-line stainless steel cooking unit with an enormous grilling surface and be topped off with a tall chimney with a flue. Many cooking areas contain rotisseries, gas burners and a hooded cooking surface.
"These are big, sophisticated units," Mr. Ciccariello said. "People cook corn on the cob and lobster. You can have a clambake along with the grilled food."
Counters surrounding the cooking area are topped with marble, ceramic tile, granite, bluestone slate or Corian. Beneath those counters you might find built-in storage units or cabinets with wood or stainless steel doors. Other amenities include running water for wet bars or preparation sinks, under-counter refrigerators and lighting fixtures.
The surrounding area gets tied in, too. Because of its imposing size and stature, the barbecue is almost always the focal point in a landscaping plan, and its look is carried over into other elements in the yard. The cooking unit is sometimes built into a stone wall, or matching walls are built to shelter the cooking area.
"It could be a seating wall, a retaining wall or a freestanding wall to separate, say, the lawn from the patio," Mr. Ciccariello said. "It gives the sitting area more privacy. You can also add a stone table -- a big slab of natural stone." Granite-topped bench-style seating is another add-on.
This may seem like a lot of trouble to go to, to cook outdoors twice a year. But that's not the case, said Matt Horn, owner of Matterhorn Nursery Inc., in Spring Valley.
"With gas, everyone's cooking outside, all year round," he said. "These fireplaces are great for entertaining; they have a great ambience. More people want to be outdoors, even if they only have a small area. People will sit out all evening. We're even installing some fire pits -- people can sit around, cook, talk and be warm, even in the spring and fall."
Ms. Brand explained the attraction this way: "It's a way of getting back to nature, even if you're outside a mansion. It's like being around the campfire; you can be at one with nature at the barbecue."
If you build it, they will come. And they will want to participate, too. "When friends come over, cooking at the barbecue gets people involved," Mr. Ciccariello said. "Everyone congregates around the grill and takes turns flipping."
Mr. Brand said: "When you have guests, it's much more social than standing around the stove inside. It's a very active way to cook. It gets you outside and gives you a feeling of participation in the gathering. It's a way for men to feel they're participating in the dinner hour, without feeling inept in front of the stove."
What's the bottom line on this wonderful combination of conspicuous consumption, nostalgia, ambience and bonding? "These things are not cheap," Mr. Horn said. "You might start at $10,000 for a decent one; allow about $4,000 for the mechanism, plus the masonry."
Mr. Ciccariello said: "It could be $6,000 to $14,000 for a grandiose project. It's a statement; it's not about function at that level. It's a hold on our past."
Mr. Calabrese said: "Quality is a consideration over price. People want to get something that's going to last. I can't imagine people spending like this in the late-80's."

HEADLINE: In the Region/New Jersey;
Bridgewater Commons Is Entering the Home Stretch

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

DATELINE: BRIDGEWATER

 BODY:
A STRONG economy and a strong office market are pushing forward plans for the final component of the 120-acre Bridgewater Commons mixed-used center here, 16 years after the project was first announced.
The Hines Interests Limited Partnership, an international real estate firm based in Houston, is buying the last 20 acres at the site and plans to build 600,000 square feet of office space. The first of two eight-story buildings is to get under way this fall. 
 A 347-room Marriott hotel is now under construction at Bridgewater Commons, the 900,000-square-foot shopping mall that opened in 1988. The mall is close to Interstates 287 and 78 as well as Routes 202-206 and 22, at the heart of this 32-square mile Somerset County township.
The mall's owner, the Rouse Company, the real estate investment trust in Columbia, Md., plans to expand it in phases by as much as 750,000 square feet. Rouse bought Bridgewater Commons 18 months ago from TrizecHahn Centers, the retailing division of the TrizecHahn Corporation of Toronto, and its partner, the Prudential Realty Group, the real estate arm of the Newark-based insurer.
At the time of Rouse's purchase, Marriott was already on board to build the hotel, which will be completed in 18 months, according to Jeff Spilman, a vice president for hotel development at Marriott. But the office component was still to be decided.
Plans for office space were part of Bridgewater Commons when it was first envisioned in 1984. But those plans were modified in 1997 to expand the mall and to rearrange the size and mix of the hotel and office space under a new agreement between the township and TrizecHahn and Prudential. The new plans still called for a full-service hotel, but they reserved space for the mall to grow. The plans also gave the owners flexibility: they could reduce the office space to 300,000 square feet, or they could replace it with an all-suite hotel or with 160,000 square feet of retail space.
Michael Sarkissian, Bridgewater's planning director, said that the center is proceeding along the lines of the original plan, except that the mall has been expanded. "The township is developing as envisioned by its master plan," he said. What was envisioned, said William Lanigan, the lawyer for the township who was its mayor in 1961 when the Bridgewater Commons site was rezoned for a regional shopping center, "was a multiuse facility that would serve as a town center for Bridgewater."
The site for the new offices is across Commons Way from the mall and next to the 8.5 acres where the hotel is rising. Robert Byrne, a vice president of Rouse, said while his company builds office space, it generally does so where it has set up one of its development groups, which is not the case in New Jersey. "It was logical for us not to build the office space, but rather to sell the land," he added.
Enter the Hines limited partnership. The privately owned company outbid several other developers for the Bridgewater Commons site, buying it for $14 million.
Location was a crucial factor. "It is in an office market that is achieving rents that are high enough to support new construction," said Jeff Spiritos, a vice president in Hines's Manhattan office and a manager of the $120 million project, which will be called Bridgewater Crossing. Financing for the project, which still must get final approval from the township's planning board, is coming from the $427 million Hines U.S. Development Fund, in which several pension funds have invested to develop suburban office buildings.
Michael Pride, another project manager at Hines, said that the fund "favors suburban core locations that are amenity rich." The Bridgewater project fits that description, given its proximity to the mall and the hotel and its access to highways, he said, adding that such access "provides the greatest catch net for tenants to retain and attract employees."
The project will be the first in New Jersey that Hines is building for its own account. But in the last decade, the partnership has served as the development manager for office projects for a number of corporations. For example, Hines is the development manager for the 1.6-million-square-foot complex Goldman, Sachs is planning on the Hudson River waterfront in Jersey City.
Somerset County's office market is rebounding from the surfeit of space that came to market nine months ago, particularly in the submarket in the Interstate 287-78 area where Hines wants to build. "That was more or less a passing phenomenon," said Stephen P. Jenco, the research manager at the Fairfield office of Grubb & Ellis, the national commercial brokerage company. That space is being absorbed as corporations, particularly those in the financial, pharmaceutical and telecommunications industries, expand or consolidate into new quarters, he said.
For example, the Pharmacia Corporation, formed by the merger of Monsanto with Pharmacia & Upjohn, is leasing a 115,000-square-foot building constructed by Gale & Wentworth, the real estate services company in Florham Park, in partnership with the J. P. Morgan Investment Company of Manhattan. It is one of two similar-sized speculative buildings the partners built at their Somerset Financial Center on Route 206 at Lamington Road in Bedminster.
Mark Yeager, the president of Gale & Wentworth Commercial, said the partners also expect to announce a lease soon for the 130,000-square-foot speculative building they are developing as the first structure at MountainView, their 169-acre corporate campus at Interstate 78 and Martinsville Road in Bernards Township. Eventually, the campus could accommodate up to 850,000 square feet of space in six buildings.
"Fundamentals like highway access that made this a strong submarket still exist," Mr. Yeager said, "It can handle new product, in moderation."
In Bridgewater, across from Hines's planned office project, the last 65,000 square feet of space at a 250,000-square-foot speculative building at the Somerset Corporate Center has been leased by Siemens Financial Services, which is expanding. The building is the second that SJP Properties of Parsippany has built and leased at its 125-acre campus, where two more buildings, totaling 620,000 square feet, are under construction for Aventis Pharma, formed by the merger of Hoechst Marion Roussel and Rhone-Poulenc Rorer.
LEASING in the I-287-78 market is expected to continue. Douglas A. Gaffney, a vice president in the Chatham office of the Trammell Crow Company, the commercial brokerage, development and management company, said, "There are six to eight tenants with requirements of over 100,000 square feet looking for space."
Mr. Spiritos of Hines said the size of the buildings planned at Bridgewater Crossing would be an advantage, given that "there are not a lot of options for large users since the Aventis lease."
Sam Buckley, a director at the Saddle Brook office of Insignia/ESG, the project's leasing agent, described it as "the only project offering 600,000 square feet of contiguous space."
Although some real estate executives expressed concerns about traffic congestion at Bridgewater Commons, Mr. Spiritos said that $20 million in road improvements were completed before the shopping mall was built and that Hines would widen the portion of Route 22 in front of the office project.
The buildings at Bridgewater Crossing, designed by the Hillier Group of Princeton, will have an exterior of two shades of reddish granite and will feature floors of 37,500 square feet with 45 feet between columns. The buildings will offer high-tech wiring, including high-speed Internet access and two sources for telecommunications and electricity. M. Arthur Gensler & Associates' Parsippany office designed the interiors.
Mr. Spiritos said construction of the first 300,000 square foot building would begin once 20 to 25 percent of the space is preleased, probably in October, about the time that final approvals are expected from the township. Rents are projected to be $32 to $33 a square foot a year, which brokers said would be competitive for new buildings in the area.

HEADLINE: Commercial Property/Long Island;
From Defense Plant to Telecommunications Center

BYLINE: By DIANA SHAMAN 

DATELINE: LAKE SUCCESS

 BODY:
A BLUE sign outside the mammoth industrial plant here on Marcus Avenue still reads "Lockheed Martin." But a new owner, i.park Lake Success, which bought the property from Lockheed in March for $21 million, has already begun demolishing interior partitions as a first step toward transforming the 1.4 million square feet into a sophisticated center for telecommunications and dot-com companies.
Leasing through Cushman & Wakefield of Long Island, a division of the national real estate brokerage company, has begun, and the first tenants are expected to move in by early fall. Annual rents of $23 to $25 a square foot include taxes and common-area charges, but not utilities, which will be separately metered. Tenants must take a minimum of 50,000 square feet, but incubator space for start-up companies is also planned. 
 The availability of large blocks of space will allow companies whose operations are scattered in several locations to consolidate under one roof and to have access to fiber optics and heavy-duty power supplies, said David C. Leviton, a senior director at Cushman & Wakefield of Long Island. A single tenant is being sought for the three-story office building on Marcus Avenue that is connected to the plant, he said.
Development of the Internet and of Internet service providers is creating opportunities for the redevelopment of industrial sites like the former Lockheed plant, said Lynne M. Ward, a vice president of i.park Holdings of Greenwich, Conn., one of the partners in i.park Lake Success. The second partner in the Lake Success venture is the Apollo Real Estate Investment Fund IV of Manhattan.
"The defense companies in many ways have had their time, and the information companies have their time now, so we think this project is almost symbolic," Ms. Ward said. She estimated that the partnership's total investment in the Lake Success project would be $70 million, including the $21 million purchase price.
The Apollo fund, which has $1.1 billion in assets and is one of a group of similar real estate funds, will provide 95 percent of the cost. I.park Holdings, which was formed by principals in National RE/sources of Greenwich, an experienced real estate developer, will be responsible for the remaining 5 percent. It will also handle the development, leasing and day-to-day operations of the project.
The Lake Success complex occupies 93 acres stretching from Marcus Avenue south to the Union Turnpike Extension. Lakeville Road borders the property to the west. The site is notable for its history: The United Nations had its first home in the Marcus Avenue office building from 1946 to 1951. Lockheed Martin was the last of a series of defense contractors to own the site, where a variety of navigation, radar and fire-control and surveillance systems were manufactured for almost 60 years. Just before it shut the plant in 1998, Lockheed was making navigation systems for Trident submarines.
ALL the existing space will used for the new technology center except for some smaller buildings facing Union Turnpike, about 75,000 square feet in all, that will be demolished to expand the parking lots, which can currently accommodate 4,500 cars.
The office building on Marcus Avenue has about 73,000 square feet on three floors, with 1.35 million square feet to the rear, most of it in a sprawling one-story industrial building. About 140,000 square feet is in a separate building, the former foundry.
Because of its former manufacturing use, the property already has heavy-duty electric service. Tenants will be given a choice of multiple carriers, keeping prices competitive. Alternative electric power routes will be added to the building "because these companies can't have their computers go down even for a second," Ms. Ward said.
Mark A. Tsocanos, a principal in the Apollo investment group, said the i.park project would provide a collaborative environment for the very technical telecom switching and Internet hosting services and the creative activities of Web site and software developers.
The Long Island Technology Center in Great River, which opened about a year ago in a manufacturing plant once owned by Northrop Grumman, offers a similar concept: space devoted to high technology and occupied by tenants who can share ideas and create a synergy.
But Great River is 50 miles from Midtown Manhattan, and Lake Success is only 16 miles away. In fact, the i.park project's location will allow employers to draw workers from the entire metropolitan area, said Richard J. Mack, another principal in the Apollo fund, and the proximity of La Guardia and Kennedy International Airports will help draw national and international companies.
Interior demolition work has begun on a 350,000-square-foot portion of the main industrial building. With partitions ripped out, the 640-foot-by-220-foot area gives potential tenants an idea of what the space can offer.
Steel supporting columns are spaced 40 feet apart in one direction and 80 feet in the other, allowing for very open floor plans. The ceiling heights are 16 feet and 22 feet. The raised areas of the roof were originally designed to accommodate large vehicles and also to provide light monitors, the vertical skylights that suffuse the interior of the building with large amounts of natural light. The wood-block floors are being replaced with carpet over the existing concrete. Additional light flows in through two rows ofhorizontal windows that extend along the exterior of the building. New partitions will be installed and interior renovations will be tailored to individual users.
"A lot of industrial buildings like this are perfect for new office-space layouts because they have very tall ceilings and as in this case, very large spans between columns," said Michael M. Samuelian, a project designer and an associate at Hellmuth Obata & Kassabaum, the Manhattan architectural firm that is handling the renovation.
New entrances will be added to the main industrial building. The goal is to give each tenant its own front door and also to add architectural interest. The former plant is 1,440 feet long and 640 feet wide. The design of the new entrances will reflect the "midcentury late Art Deco style of the former administration building," Mr. Samuelian said.
The new plans for the grounds, which Hellmuth Obata & Kassabaum will also handle, include a new ring road with access points to each entrance. Existing trees will be saved and new trees will be planted along the ring road to form a boulevard. A small park of three to four acres will be created on the southern part of the site near Union Turnpike. The property also contains retention basins surrounded by a grove of trees, where some groundwater contamination is being cleaned up.
"I think the developers of the i.park will be successful because technology is growing rapidly, not only on Long Island but also in New York City, where 25 percent of leases executed during the first quarter of 2000 were with dot-com companies," said Dr. Pearl M. Kamer, the chief economist for the Long Island Association in Commack, a nonprofit organization that represents some 5,000 businesses and civic groups.
Many of New York City tenants are outgrowing their current spaces and are now facing annual rents of $30 to $40 a square foot, Dr. Kamer said. "So the next step for a lot of these technology and new-media firms in Manhattan is to move into the outer boroughs, which is already occurring in Long Island City, and then into Long Island, where rents are 30 percent to 40 percent below those in Manhattan," she said.
The federal government originally built the Lake Success plant. Sperry Gyroscope moved in as the first tenant in 1941. Ten years later, Sperry bought the property, later selling off 50 of its original 143 acres to an office developer. Sperry became the Sperry Rand Corporation, and in 1986, it merged with the Burroughs Corporation to form Unysis. In 1995, when the Loral Corporation bought the defense electronics division of Unysis, it became the property owner. Then Lockheed Martin acquired Loral in 1996.
Lockheed shut down its Lake Success operation in 1998 as part of a plan to dispose of surplus properties that it owned around the country. Lockheed originally wanted to be its own developer and came up with a plan to demolish the buildings and to sell off the land for offices, a hotel, housing and retail development. But rezoning could have taken years.
"We liked a lot of the Lockheed Martin plan because it offered a lot of opportunities to do a lot of different things," said May W. Newburger, the town supervisor of North Hempstead, where 50 of the site's 93 acres are situated. "The i.park concept has the advantage of creating jobs without the upheaval of getting permits and site plan approvals," she said.
Ms. Ward of i.park Holdings said her company, in partnership with the Apollo investment group, hoped to complete similar speedy conversions from industrial to telecommunications space around the country.
"We are looking for existing facilities that can be retrofitted because of the speed with which that can be done," she said. "The opportunity is now. These companies need the space yesterday."

LENGTH: 2974 words

HEADLINE: Discovering Bed-Stuy's Brownstones

BYLINE: By TRISH HALL 

 BODY:
WHEN brownstones were constructed on block after block of Brooklyn in the late 19th century, they provided housing for well-to-do people whose live-in servants, usually immigrants from Italy, Ireland or Germany, would dust the intricately carved moldings and cook in the ground-floor kitchens, sending food upstairs to the dining room by dumbwaiter.
Eventually though, brownstonesin much of Brooklyn became associated with the working class, and then the poor, who moved in when the buildings were divided into rooming houses. People with money, by and large, didn't want brownstones in Brooklyn; they wanted to live in apartment buildings in Manhattan or houses in the suburbs. 
 All that of course has changed. Brownstones are chic. They're appreciated. And of course they're appreciating. Houses that were affordable to the middle class not long ago are now homes for the rich, some selling for $1.1 million and more in well-established brownstone neighborhoods like Park Slope, and $750,000 in Fort Greene and Clinton Hill.
There is however, a section of Brooklyn that is close to Manhattan and still has hundreds of town houses and brownstones occupied by regular working and professional people: Bedford-Stuyvesant. To the people who live there, mostly African-Americans or those with Caribbean roots, it is a tight-knit, family-oriented community that has been saddled with a negative image that does not reflect the reality there.
To real estate brokers it is a gold mine, just waiting to be discovered by newcomers who have no idea of its charms, of its thousands of historic homes just 15 minutes on the A train from downtown Manhattan.
Everett H. Ortner, chairman of the citywide Brownstone Revival Coalition, says Bed-Stuy may have as many as 6,000 brownstones, perhaps more than any other neighborhood. "The quality is superb," he said. When houses go on the market, brokers say they are often priced at less than $300,000.
Walking the streets of Bed-Stuy, it feels like many other brownstone neighborhoods did 10 or 15 years ago, before they became home to chic little shops and restaurants. Lovely homes fill block after block, but the commercial activity consists mainly of beauty parlors, nail salons and other prosaic services and products.
Some of the main commercial streets are dotted with vacant storefronts. On a hot day, it is hard to find a shop selling sandwiches or ice cream cones. "You can go block after block and not see a grocery store," said Kenneth Adams, president of the Brooklyn Chamber of Commerce. "There's a lag on the commercial side."
That disparity between the quality of the housing and the variety of stores is something that is starting to change, and if it does in any significant way, the neighborhood will become more appealing to people who associate city life with a convenient cup of coffee.
Recently, local people have started the kinds of enterprises they want to patronize. Jean Williams-Cutler, a native of Jamaica, and her husband, Timothy Cutler, an Englishman, opened a small, casual restaurant at the corner of Marcy and Putnam Avenues last fall called Doctor's Cave Cafe, after the beach in Jamaica where they met 11 years ago. Ms. Williams-Cutler said they decided to open a cafe in the building they have owned and lived in for 10 years because the space had been occupied by a "greasy spoon" and they believed the neighborhood needed better restaurants. Ms. Williams-Cutler, a nurse, and her husband, a lawyer, serve things like homemade pizza, quiche, roasted oxtail, pastas and curry.
Not far away, on Lewis Avenue, Monique Greenwood and her husband, Glenn Pogue, have bought a building with five commercial spaces, all to be rented by local entrepreneurs, and six apartments above. A bookstore called Brownstone Books is scheduled to open, as is an antiques store called the Parlor Floor. And in July, when the new stores open, Ms. Greenwood and Mr. Pogue will start a cafe, named Mirrors by their 8-year-old daughter, Glynn, "so people can come in and see their beauty," Ms. Greenwood said.
They already own a restaurant on the same block, Akwaaba, opened two years ago, and a few blocks away on McDonough Street, the Akwaaba Mansion, where they cater to a bed-and-breakfast clientele in four elegantly furnished rooms in their 18-room house. "Akwaaba" means "welcome" in Ghana.
MS. GREENWOOD, who is also the editor in chief of Essence magazine, said she and her husband became entranced with the neighborhood when they went on a tour of historic homes 11 years ago that was sponsored by the local Brownstoners. "First we fell in love with the houses," Ms. Greenwood said, "and then with the people who lived in the houses." The community, she said, "has everything I would ever want, except some amenities."
Her passion for the neighborhood is typical among many of those who own the brownstones, many of them with their original details intact and some of them part of the official Stuyvesant Heights Historic District. It is not unusual to meet people in Bed-Stuy with extended family in their homes or on the same block. Houses tend to stay in the same family for decades.
It is that stability that seems threatened by the sudden interest by brokers in selling the homes to people who are not from the neighborhood. Residents complain of aggressive door-to-door solicitations by brokers seeking listings, and offering to pay cash. Brokers who have for years done business in Bed-Stuy say they have to find more listings in the neighborhood to satisfy potential buyers who can't find anything they can afford in neighboring Clinton Hill or Fort Greene.
Eva M. Daniels, who has her own real estate company in Fort Greene, says escalating prices have put houses in Clinton Hill and Fort Greene beyond the reach of many aspiring buyers. "Bed-Stuy," she said, "is a very hot community right now. I cannot tell you how many calls I get every day asking for Bed-Stuy."
But prices are rising quickly. She said she received a call from a mortgage broker recently looking for comparables for a house that was selling for $365,000. Last year, Ms. Daniels said, she sold eight houses in Bed-Stuy, and the one that went for $265,000 was considered high at the time. Now, the same house might be $310,000.
Right now, she said, "I have three listings in Bed-Stuy, and it's not enough. I'm setting out to increase my listings. You write letters. You make calls. I know a lot of people. I get a lot of referrals." Her two grown sons live in the neighborhood, and she said it's a place that has "only gotten better, and it was never as bad as people thought it was."
A few years ago, she said, people from outside the neighborhood were typically uninterested in renting there. Now, she said, she is renting floor-through apartments for $900 a month or so, and duplexes for as much as $1,800.
Brokers say that people interested in Bed-Stuy rarely ask about schools, but that if clients do ask, the brokers refer them to books that evaluate local public schools.
The area is also receiving a new focus from the Corcoran Group, a large and aggressive Manhattan-based broker that has been expanding its Brooklyn operations and expects to open a new office in Fort Greene in late September. Jerry Minsky, who will be the managing director of downtown sales for that office, said Bed-Stuy has as many as 20 blocks in its historic district alone of "fabulously intact town houses."
For the entire neighborhood, he estimates that the average selling price of a town house last year was $180,963, up from $156,006 the year before. He believes he has customers who can pay between $350,000 and $399,000 who would buy in Bed-Stuy because they can't afford Clinton Hill or Fort Greene, and they want "museum condition" brownstones.
That is exactly the kind of price hike that will make it difficult for young people who have grown up in Bed-Stuy to remain. "Bed-Stuy is a community of extended family," said Tohma Faulkner, a member of the Brownstoners of Bedford-Stuyvesant, the local group dedicated to preserving the old housing. She owns a house with her sister, which they share with their mother. "Young people are having problems coming back," she said. "My goddaughter is going to law school. When she comes back in three or four years to buy a house, she's priced out."
Bed-Stuy may not be known to outsiders for its tight community of brownstone owners, but that community has existed for years. "There have always been middle-income and upper-income African-Americans there -- sophisticated, well-educated people," said Jerome Krase, chairman of the sociology department at Brooklyn College and the Murray Koppelman professor. But, he said, because of racism, and because Bed-Stuy was populated by blacks, "people figured it was a slum."
The area has had a high percentage of poor people for decades, as well as problems with abandoned housing. But the city, as well as nonprofit groups like the Bedford-Stuyvesant Restoration Corporation and the Bridge Street Development Corporation, have made progress toward solving some of those problems.
The New York City Department of Housing Preservation and Development has, in partnership with nonprofit groups and developers, had 700 two- and three-family houses built in Bed-Stuy in the last decade, and 2,800 housing units rehabilitated. The commissioner, Richard T. Roberts, said that the city had also encouraged retail development, particularly on Fulton Street, that has led to some services people in the neighborhood said they needed, like a sit-down restaurant, Choices by Oasis.
The city has contracted with developers that have successfully renovated and resold most of the 79 brownstones that the city owned in the neighborhood.
Charles Brass, president of the New York City Housing Partnership, said the buyers of the 900 new homes his group has completed are stable, employed people earning incomes up to $70,000. "There haven't been any defaults to speak of," he said. "In all of our projects, there's still strong demand."
THOSE houses let people know that the neighborhood is not being ignored. "The infrastructure has gotten much better," said Bryant Johnson McInnis, who has published a book with photos and text about Bed-Stuy, called "Glory in a Snapshot."
The rehab of vacant buildings has made a major change," said Mr. McInnis, a homeowner in the neighborhood who is the assistant director of Neighborhood Housing Services' Bed-Stuy office.
The biggest change now needs to come in the commercial area, according to Charles Atwell, a longtime broker and property manager who owns Stuyvesant Heights Realty. Mr. Atwell is disappointed that more local people are not starting businesses. A space that's 900 square feet, he said, rents for only $1,200 a month. With the influx of brokers from elsewhere and the rising residential prices, he fears that when businesses do arrive to cater to the newcomers, they will be run by outsiders, or national chains.
It is difficult to generalize about crime in Bedford-Stuyvesant, because the area is covered by several police precincts. But crime figures for the first four and a half months of this year, a police spokesman said, show that incidences in all the major categories, like murder, robbery and burglary, are down from last year at the same time, for the area bounded by Fulton Street on the south, Halsey Street on the north, Tompkins Avenue on the west and Stuyvesant Avenue on the east, which includes the historic district. Only the incidence of rape has increased.
The changes in Bed-Stuy are taking place in an area with strong block associations and so many churches that some blocks have more than one. In fact, it was the presence of the churches that led Laurie Cumbo to open Bed-Stuy's first museum this year.
Ms. Cumbo, a graduate of Spelman College in Atlanta with a master's in arts administration from New York University, did her thesis on Bed-Stuy's ability to support a museum. Studies showed, she said, that people of African-American descent who attended museums regularly were also dedicated churchgoers. That was one thing that led her to believe that the community -- with by her count 82 churches -- was ripe for a museum.
Ms. Cumbo, 25, circulated her thesis to local politicians and church groups and found interest from Bridge Street Church, a black congregation now located on Stuyvesant Avenue that was formed in 1766. This year, in 1,000 square feet of the church's newly renovated space, she opened Mocada, an acronym for Museum of Contemporary African Diasporian Arts. Her current show, of work by Melvin Clark, attracted 300 people to its opening reception.
The museum is just one outlet for artists. Some Bed-Stuy artists are showing their work through a relatively new group calledSonya, which stands for South of the Navy Yard Artists. Gigi Stankiewicz, an artist who creates works based on the human genome project, lives on Classon Avenue in Bed-Stuy. Although people associate lofts with artists, she says brownstones provide good working space because of the high ceilings on the parlor floors.
Ms. Stankiewicz moved to New York after receiving her master's degree from the Rhode Island School of Design, and says she is particularly charmed by Bed-Stuy because she lived in Newport for six years and likes the historic houses and quiet streets in both places. "There is a renaissance going on here," she said. "Homes are getting fixed up. We're at the beginning."
Some of the significant art activity in Bed-Stuy isn't immediately obvious, but it is there, and growing. Benjamin and Elaine Antonetty recently opened an art gallery on the parlor floor of their Jefferson Avenue brownstone, which they bought two years ago. It had been a rooming house occupied by 13 tenants, many of them not even paying rent, said Mr. Antonetty. Over a year, first by persuasion and then by legal action, he removed the tenants, and when they were gone began restoring the house.
Now, their new home is a showplace. Mr. Antonetty worked as the general contractor, having all of the wainscoting stripped and the carved wooden moldings returned to their original state. "Everything was painted," he said, even the subtly colored tiles in front of the fireplaces.
Everything is returned to its original glory, with mahogany on the parlor floor, cherry on the second, and beech on the top. Mr. Antonetty has a passion, he says, for wood, which may be the source of his strong feeling for these 19th-century houses. "To me, wood is strength," he said.
Mrs. Antonetty, who grew up in Fort Greene, and Mr. Antonetty, who grew up in a public housing project in Bushwick, moved to Bed-Stuy 15 years ago, and before buying their new house lived in one next door that they still own. "We fell in love with brownstones," she said. Their new house reflects the melding of Victorian and African influences, with a new stained-glass image in their front door that is an African symbol for belief in god.
They run their art business, which includes a framing shop, the gallery -- Aviva Arts, which is open by appointment only -- and a mobile gallery, where companies allow them to sell directly to the employees. They sell mostly lithographs, serigraphs and original paintings by people of African descent.
NEARBY, Doreen de Leon, a native of Grenada, lives in a brownstone on Jefferson Avenue that she bought in 1984 for $60,000. She also has her own real estate company in Brooklyn, which she started shortly after retiring from her job as a bacteriologist. She also has occasional art shows on the parlor floor of her home.
Ms. de Leon said she does a lot of sales and rentals in the area. Apartments that rent for about $1,000 a month, she said, would be $1,500 in Fort Greene, and they are drawing people with their fireplaces and parquet floors. "The majority of calls are people coming from Manhattan," she said.
For longtime homeowners, the new attractiveness of their neighborhood is both annoying and gratifying. Demetrice Mills, who works in computer systems on Wall Street, lives with his wife and three children on Classon Avenue. He came to New York 27 years ago as a teenager on his own from North Carolina and moved into a rooming house. He fell in love with the owner's daughter; they married, and eventually bought the house from her parents. They still own that house, as well as another on Classon that they now occupy.
The influx of real estate people looking for listings, he said, is grating on longtime residents. "There's a door-to-door campaign by realtors," he said, started in the last year. People have even posted notices saying they will pay cash for houses.
"A lot of the neighbors are quite upset with that," he said. "It's like an invasion. There's the sense that white people are coming to buy our houses, that we are being pushed out of our neighborhood."
It's disturbing, he said, that family members who might want to keep a house won't be able to afford to buy it from relatives. The neighborhood has a family feeling, he said, that is most evident in barber shops, where young boys and old men and every age in between hang out, talking, even if they're not getting haircuts.
He hopes, he said, that newcomers will become part of this open, friendly neighborhood, and that they will send their children to the local schools. He tries, too, to look at the economic benefits of the change that is just beginning.
African-American homeowners, he said, will have property that is far more valuable than it has been, property they can leverage, through home equity loans, into cash to improve their lives, to send their children to college. And maybe, to help them buy the more-expensive homes in their old neighborhood.

HEADLINE: THE RIGHT THING;
Tellingthe Truth, or at Least Most of It

BYLINE: By JEFFREY L. SEGLIN; Jeffrey L. Seglin teaches at Emerson College in Boston and is the author of "The Good, the Bad, and Your Business" (John Wiley & Sons). His column on business ethics appears the third Sunday of each month. E-mail may be sent to: righthng@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
WHEN the results of an annual honesty and ethics poll were released last fall by the Gallup Organization, I had just begun a stint as a college professor and was feeling quite smug. There among the 10 professions ranked most honest by the American public was my new calling, with 52 percent of respondents judging its honesty as high or very high.
Then, after just a few minutes of basking in professional glow, I saw where the survey ranked another of my incarnations, that of online journalist: firmly among the bottom 10 on the list of 45, with only one respondent in 10 giving people in that line of work a good score. Talk about professional disconnect. 
 The findings present a puzzle. When introducing myself, what do I tell people I do? If I want them to trust me from the get-go, do I just say "college teacher" and withhold the part about writing for online publications?
If disclosing the complete picture leads people to an unfair conclusion about me, isn't it right, not to mention advantageous, to withhold some information? In a legal context, the answer is no. "It's better to include and explain than to omit and cast doubt," said Andrew J. Sherman, a lawyer at Katten Muchin Zavis in Washington. Of course, it is the job of a good lawyer to look through the lens of legal vulnerability and to caution against anything that may lead to trouble. But real life is rarely so simple.
Imagine that you are applying for a job during the McCarthyite 1950's. Years earlier, in college, you flirted briefly with radical politics. Should you disclose it and risk having the interviewer unfairly take you for a subversive, or hide it and be surer of getting the fair treatment you deserve?
Those pernicious days are behind us, thankfully, but ethically analogous situations still crop up. A few years ago, when a colleague was on vacation in the northern part of Ireland, he wanted to rent a car and was asked the name of his employer (an American newspaper). The rental agent told him that the company could not rent to people in certain "risky" occupations, including journalists. My friend swallowed hard and pleaded, somewhat disingenuously, that his job -- preparing maps, charts and diagrams for the newspaper -- was really more that of a commercial artist and not of a journalist. He got the car.
"We all practice selective disclosure," said Daryl Koehn, director of the Center for Business Ethics at the University of St. Thomas in Houston. "If we have been a professor at both Iowa State and the University of Chicago, we tell people we taught at the latter, because it is more prestigious. There is simply not enough time in the day to divulge our entire past history."
The ends figure in how we view these means. Sacrificing integrity to save a life is often, usually rightly, seen as heroic. Trimming the truth for personal gain -- landing a plum contract, for instance -- is difficult to justify. Somewhere in between is withholding true information that you think will lead people to false conclusions.
"We've stopped saying we are consultants, because as soon as we do, we find ourselves faced with a barrage of negativity and preconceived notions," said Michelle L. Reina, co-author with her husband, Dennis, of "Trust and Betrayal in the Workplace" (Berrett-Kohler), as well as, well, a consultant: the Reinas are principals of Chagnon & Reina Associates in Stowe, Vt. Too often, she said, people have difficulty separating individuals from professions and assume that any journalist is like all journalists, that any consultant is like all consultants. Now, she tells prospective clients she "works with organizations that want to bring trust into the workplace." As words go, "trust" strikes a better chord than "consultant."
Trust is also the key to solving the puzzle. Gallup polls notwithstanding, in all but the most extreme cases we simply cannot know with certainty how what we say will be perceived. Deciding to be less than honest about something trivial because we think the truth might provoke an unfair judgment of us is just a few steps away from deciding that deception for naked gain is appropriate any time we think we "deserve" it.
"Trust by its very nature is an act of reasonable faith," Professor Koehn said. "It exists precisely because we cannot control all circumstances. We should not make the mistake of thinking that all trust is contingent upon full disclosure." When in doubt about how the facts will be perceived, she advised, look gently for more clues. Otherwise, she said, she would proceed on the assumption that most people can be trusted to draw fair conclusions about us, regardless of what we do for a living.
Good advice. Did I mention that I was an online journalist?

HEADLINE: WEDDINGS;
Lisa Jacobson, Chris Jones

LENGTH: 1157 words

HEADLINE: Those in the Know Pick the Wine for That Summer Meal

BYLINE: By HOWARD G. GOLDBERG 

 BODY:
THE East End of Long Island is famous for duck, just-picked corn unloaded from burlap sacks and cornucopias of farm-stand vegetables christened by the morning dew.
As the langorous days of summer proper and then Indian summer dwindle down, backyard chefs and other stay-at-homes who rarely see the inside of a restaurant carry back to the city afterimages of relaxed, inexpensive feasts. 
 On the North and South Forks the opportunities for matching local wines with turf dishes at home are limited less by dollars than by imagination. (Surf meals are another story.)
Professional chefs, who spend their lives as culinary marriage brokers, offer some of the best recommendations around.
"I hardly ever cook duck at home," said Eberhard Muller, the chef and an owner of Lutece in Manhattan. "But if I did, I would roast the whole bird." By home he meant Satur Farms, in Cutchogue on the North Fork, where he and his wife, Paulette Satur, raise 15 acres of vegetables that are sold to restaurants and stores.
"With duck, I would serve cabernet franc," Mr. Muller said. "Schneider's would be great; they make a fabulous cabernet franc. Or a cabernet sauvignon. I'm torn: the '95 Paumanok or '95 Lenz cabernets, if you can still get them. Or a '97 Lenz. Or '95 or '97 Bedell.
"With the corn," Mr. Muller went on, "Lenz '97 gewurztraminer, because it's my favorite wine of the moment out there. It would go well with the sweetness of corn, I'd imagine. It goes well with everything.
"Salads are typically difficult to match with wine. The easiest to match are still off-dry rieslings -- and that's Paumanok."
Since its founding in 1973, Ross' North Fork Restaurant, in Southold, has championed Long Island cuisine and wines. More particularly, John Ross, the chef and an owner, said: "We've emphasized North Fork cuisine. We use everything possible local that we can. I've built my menu around these ingredients."
In the restaurant, "I serve roast duck with plum sauce," Mr. Ross said. "I like merlots with that. Bedell Cellars -- the '95, if you can get it. It was a great vintage. I am sorry to see those merlots go. The '97 is very good, too.
"Over the last four seasons," Mr. Ross continued, "we have served corn on the cob that is guaranteed three hours from the vine -- not from the stand but from the vine. With corn, I would go with our new viogniers, Macari's and Martha Clara's; Macari's and Hargrave's sauvignon blancs; and stainless-steel chardonnays: Lenz and Corey Creek I like a lot.
"With veggies, stainless-steel chardonnays are the best choice," Mr. Ross concluded. "That lemony-crisp acidity is refreshing to the mouth. Spring vegetables clash with wine, so you don't want to introduce a lot of flavors. The crisp acidity and cleansing is kind of nice. The vegetables stand up and taste like vegetables."
Todd Jacobs offers separate suggestions with duck recipes. As chef and owner, he is consolidating Tierra Mar in Westhampton and Atlantica in West Hampton Beach into one restaurant that will open this month in the Westhampton Bath and Tennis Hotel in West Hampton Beach.
For ambitious cooks who like canard a l'orange, Mr. Jacobs suggests a cherry brandy and cabernet franc sauce finished with sour cherries, and the same wine in a glass. "Schneider cabernet franc would be my choice," he said. "It's over the top. Palmer would be second."
With smoked duck breast, he would reach for a pinot noir -- primarily the '97 from Osprey's Dominion, then Jamesport's or Hargrave's -- or Lenz's gewurztraminer, or, from the South Fork, the reserve chardonnay from Wolffer/Sagpond.
As for corn on the cob, "white would come to mind," Mr. Jacobs said. "I'd like something crisp and light, maybe a sauvignon blanc, to offset the butter and salt. Again, Jamesport; in that category, they do a wonderful job. Also, Paumanok's chenin blanc, a great light summer wine.
"I'd love to do a salad" at home, Mr. Jacobs continued. "I'd go to a farm stand and get what's available. Zucchini, eggplant, tomatoes, scallions. I'd slice them, marinate them with olive oil, add salt and pepper, and grill them. I'd add fresh chopped chives, and then serve them on a bed of greens, with a squeeze of lemon. I'd use Palmer's '98 pinot blanc, a very light wine: For a light meal like that, you don't have overpowering flavors on either side."
What about the cost of wine?
For the budget-conscious, it's elementary that homebodies can drink and eat more thriftily (and often better) than restaurant-goers.
Consider, for example, a Long Island red wine that retails typically for $15.
Bought separately in a store, each bottle, with the 8.25 percent sales tax, costs $16.24. A 12-bottle case, with a standard 15 percent discount and the tax, comes to $165.62, or $13.80 a bottle; with an often-found 10 percent discount, to $175.37, or $14.61 a bottle.
Depending on a restaurant's standard markup, the $15-at-retail bottle can cost, with tax, $32.48 (with a 100 percent markup) to $64.95 (with a 300 percent markup). If a 15 percent tip is applied to the bottle, pre-tax, the costs rise, respectively, to $36.98 or $73.95.
Outside the restaurant, the savings would rise if you found a merchant who, in addition to holding periodic shelf-clearing knockdown sales, favored his cash-only customers with a supplementary discount, too. Pick up the wine yourself, and you save a possible delivery fee.
Case purchases of a single wine can be a recipe for boredom. But the arithmetic of stores' mix-and-match cases -- say, three merlots, two cabernet francs, one cabernet sauvignon, one pinot noir, three chardonnays, one sauvignon blanc and one pinot blanc -- can still save you money.
Remember, too, that magnums -- 1.5 liter bottles, which are twice the size of regular bottles -- sometimes can be found, and almost always cost less than two regular 750-milliliter bottles.
Moral No. 1: The economics of warm-weather entertainment argue for both careful study of wine ads and catalogs and the cultivation of dependable merchants who are grateful for the repeat business.
Some excellent New York City retailers deliver wine to Long Island customers, but, the ease aside, there is a benefit in buying from Island merchants, especially those who take big positions in East End wines and enjoy heavy turnovers. The proximity of Suffolk County producers to stores Islandwide ensures frequent deliveries, and, since producers store their inventories carefully in temperature-controlled cellars to avoid spoilage, consumers are likely to get steady flows of fresh goods.
Moral No. 2: As you fire up the grill for an afternoon or evening of family-and-friends pigging out or socializing -- or if sensibly, you, and not a caterer, have supplied the wine for a wingding under a striped tent -- you can feel good about having pursued a businesslike approach to wine planning and buying that keeps your hard-earned money at home.

HEADLINE: BRIEFING: ECONOMY;
UNEMPLOYMENT RATE

BYLINE: AP 

 BODY:
New Jersey's jobless rate edged up slightly in April, going from 3.7 percent to 3.8 percent, according to labor statistics released last week. The rate has remained below 4.5 percent for the past six months. New Jersey employers actually added about 11,600 jobs in April. But with more people looking for jobs, the unemployment rate rose, Labor Commisioner Mel Gelade said.

HEADLINE: Happy Caterers, Many Frantic Customers

BYLINE: By LINDA SASLOW 

 BODY:
NOBODY is likely to go hungry this summer in the Hamptons, but that is small consolation to hosts and hostesses with many mouths to feed.
"I've never seen a year like this," said Brent Newsom, a Bridgehampton caterer. By the end of April, business at Brent Newsom Caterers was up about 80 percent from last year, he said, with every Saturday in July and August booked, as well as the whole month of September and the latter part of June. 
 "People have been calling earlier to book their parties," Mr. Newsom said. "They smell the scent of panic in the air and are beating each other to death for dates. We're selling dates for parties the way houses sell in Silicon Valley: on who wants to bid the highest for the date."
As early as February, Cheryl Stair, chef and partner of Art of Eating in Amagansett, called regular clients to warn them they had better choose their dates for summer events, or risk being shut out.
"Weekends have booked up early this year, which has created a longer summer season that now stretches from May right through the last weekend in October," she said.
By January several clients had locked in their dates with Christopher Robbins, a caterer who owns Robbins Wolfe Eventeurs in Bridgehampton. By last month, more than half the Saturdays through the summer were booked, he said, either with several large parties or up to 10 smaller ones.
Last-minute party planners may be hard-pressed to find a free Saturday in July or August. And forget about June and September.
"This year people seem to want the biggest and most important wedding, benefit, cocktail party or corporate function," Mr. Newsom said. "The weddings and benefits this summer are crawling all over each other, and some benefits have changed their dates because they were competing with another big one."
Michael Castino, owner and chef of Pacific East in Amagansett, said, "I've had to turn people away, and even when I suggest other places, they're also often already booked."
With so many weekend dates filled, Charlotte Sasso, co-owner of Stuart's Seafood Caterers in Amagansett, has been encouraging clients to plan parties during the week.
"I try to suggest something different," she said. "How about a Thursday or a Monday? Thursday is a great day because it's the start of the weekend. Some people are receptive; others insist on Saturdays."
Even if the caterer is available, there are still the challenges of finding entertainment, rental items, a tent, valet parking and other services, which are also tight.
"The busy season is wonderful for us," said John Kowalenko, co-owner of Art of Eating, "but for people planning an event this year, they'll be fortunate to have all their needs met."
Surprisingly, September is the first month to fill up, said Ms. Stair, mostly with weddings. "The weekend after Labor Day is going to be insane," she said. "We've already turned away about 50 couples."
Mr. Newsom's September calendar is also filled with weddings. "September in the Hamptons has turned into the nuptial capital of the Western world," he said. "Every bride wants to be married in the Hamptons in September. It used to be that at the end of August, everybody went home and the crush of summer people was over. But now the crush of September people is just as big."
Why the boom? Many attribute it largely to the strong economy and the flourishing stock market, and caterers were pleasantly relieved by the nonreaction to the recent dip in the market. "There was not a whimper," Mr. Newsom said, "not even a sniggle of a call asking to cut back on anything."
Aside from the economy, the millennium has also contributed to an unusually busy season.
"There was a lot of romance in the air on New Year's Eve because of the millennium," Mr. Kowalenko said. "There were more engagements than we can ever remember in the past because so many people wanted to be married in the year 2000. This has created a great need for wedding dates this year."
The fact that this is an election year has also added benefit parties to the Hamptons calendar, added Jim McManus, executive director of Party Rental Ltd. in East Hampton. "There are many fundraisers for political causes, competing for the limited time and resources of the caterers," he said. "This is contributing to the gridlock."
For caterers, gridlock also means that many of the same people will be going to more than one party on any given night, Mr. Robbins said. "If more than one party is on our books for the same night, we ask the clients if they know each other and if there are any of the same guests," he said. "Then we have to be sure not to serve the same menu."
Caterered events this summer range from formal sit-down dinners for 700 to home parties with a Caribbean or Hawaiian theme to casual clambakes on the beach. Of the growing popularity of clam bakes, Ms. Sasso said: "While there is an element of the Hamptons that is 'see and be seen,' there's another side that is 'kick off your sneakers and have fun.' People love to wear shorts and lobster bibs with butter slothered all over their chins."
At the other end of the spectrum, some parties are more sophisticated and stylized.
"Everybody in the Hamptons wants to make a statement," Mr. McManus said. "People have high-quality taste and many are looking to upgrade and spend more money on details like tablecloths, china and even chairs. We now have to offer choices, including more than 30 different patterns of china, a new line of embroidery for monogramming on napkins and chairs in 28 different colors. We're taking it up a notch."
Then there are the clients who want caviar and lobster on a hamburger budget, said Greg Deger, general manager of Red Horse Catering in East Hampton. "We can't give them foie gras and truffles for $20 per person," he said, "but we find a way to work out something that works for everybody."
For Red Horse Catering, one of the highlights will be the wedding of Jodi Della Femina, a daughter of the restaurateur Jerry Della Femina, and John Kim, whose family is Korean. Mr. Della Femina is also the owner of Red Horse Catering.
Planning a wedding between an Italian bride and a Korean groom has kept the caterers busy, Mr. Deger said.
"We've been working for eight months to create a wedding that brings the two nationalities together," he said. "There will be a traditional Korean ceremony on the beach, followed by a Korean cocktail hour, then a family-style Italian dinner."
Summarizing the pre-season frenzy, Ms. Stair said, "We're all dancing as fast as we can."
 
On the Side
 
It takes more than shrimp and chardonnay to make a summer cull of parties work. Here are other details on the checklist of one of the Hampotons' busiest caterers, Art of Eating Catering and Event Planning.
 
Renting more than 20 locations in excess of $200,000 for parties and weddings.
 
Donating more than $75,000 in products and services to more than $20 charities.
 
Interviewing more than 250 people for jobs as waiters, bartenders, and other positions.
 
Making more than 10,000 cups of coffee.
 
Ordering more than 100,000 glasses; 12,000 plates; 40,000 knives, forks and spoons from rental companies, as well as 20,000 napkins.
 
Going through more than 150,000 beverage napkins, 16,000 liters of soda and juice and 10,000 pounds of ice.
 
Using 1,500 gallons of gasoline, 6,000 pounds of propane and 5,000 trash bag.

HEADLINE: Some Menus Without Meltdown Prices

BYLINE: By RICHARD J. SCHOLEM 

 BODY:
THE tens of thousands of tourists who troop onto Long Island invariably gravitate to restaurants to savor the season, particularly places that offer outdoor, waterfront and water-view dining. Unfortunately, such locations, especially prime by-the-sea sites, are expensive and the cost of such real estate is passed on to patrons in the form of high food prices.
Yet many in-the-know, year-round residents find the foods of summer without experiencing budgetary meltdown. Summer on a shoestring dining can be pursued on two gently priced paths. First, there are weather-beaten fish markets offering fresh seafood, funky little outdoor ethnic spots, rough and tumble country roadhouses and ramshackle near-the-water old favorites, specializing in simple, satisfying seafood dishes. Another possibility exists for those with a good eye and self-restraint: creating an upscale experience for a downscale price by carefully scrutinizing the menus of more glamorous, atmospheric eating places. 
Bistro Blue, in the Sterling Harbor Marina, at 1410 Manhasset Avenue in Greenport (631-477-3940), falls midway between these two routes. Its commendable food, sharp young servers, waterfront site and spectacular marina and harbor views make it appear more expensive than it is. This summery, year-old East End entry is a place of sun-bright yellow walls and deep blue ceilings. The restaurant's many picture windows offer diners a floor show, boats gliding in and out of the marina.
A big bowl of the soup of the day costs $5, meal-sized hand rolls or wraps, served with salad or French fries, go for $6 to $9, six-slice pizzas are in the $7-to-$9 range, pastas are $10 to $14, four of the six desserts cost $5 or $6 and meat or fish entrees start at $14.
Among the blue-ribbon appetizers were a peppy, refreshing gazpacho ($5); a warm goat-cheese salad ($8) resting in a tangy toasted-tomato vinaigrette that boasts four or five types of lettuce (none of them iceberg); a couple of lively seasoned no-filler crab cakes ($8) served with savory corn salsa and vibrant remoulade sauce and a New Yorker entree-sized pizza ($8) large enough to be an appetizer for four.
Bonbori, a Japanese gem at 14 Elm Street in Huntington (631-673-0400), isn't a bargain, but it is a beauty, especially the enchanting Asian garden behind the restaurant. Thrifty diners can concentrate on page one of the menu, with its skewered seafood, vegetable and tofu appetizers and its soups, salads and noodle entrees, all of which are priced from $3.50 to $9.50.
During the warm weather months, except on nasty days, that garden is the restaurant. Diners enter through wooden pagoda-style doors and walk a path lined with plants, lanterns and Japanese artifacts to the secluded garden, which is bordered by rhododendron, shaded by trees, with its and soothed by the sound of gently trickling water.
Mix, match and share the starters, sushi and entrees from the restaurant's pocket-sized kitchen. The bold and fresh Bonbori salad ($6.50) blends its standard lettuce, tomatoes, cucumbers and endive with raisins, walnuts, bacon bits and shredded daikon (white radish) and carrots. The salad serves four, as does the bowl of udon ($9) with its thick, white noodles presented either in a hot broth or chilled dipping sauce.
Another opener for four, found on the separate sushi and sashimi menu, is the $7 sampler containing four pieces made from that day's freshest ingredients. (Tuna, fluke, sea bass and silk snapper one day with not a clunker in the bunch). Recommended appetizers are six oysters age-dashi ($8.25), shrimp-vegetable tempura $6.75), sauteed vegetables ($6.25), angry shrimp ($9), yakitori (($6.25) and shrimp kushi ($8.25). The batter on the fried oysters is not the ho-hum bread crumb variety, but kuzu starch. Speaking of batter, the feathery, crisp-covered tempura shrimp and vegetables is as good as it gets. Those four angry shrimp, pan fried in egg batter, sported a vibrant, though not incendiary, ginger sauce.
The Cull House is a seafood shack near the Fire Island Ferry in Sayville that serves consistently good food at easy-to-take prices. Keep it simple with straightforward American fish dishes and you will be rewarded. This rustic, 17-year-old spot, at 75 Terry Street (631-563-1546), has undergone some sprucing up during the off season, but its down-to-earth nautical ambience (ship's wheels, lobster aquarium, mounted fish, ship boat models) remains.
So do the bargain prices. Although a one-and-a-quarter pound lobster dinner is listed at $14.95, a lobster can be purchased during "Lobster Madness" every Monday through Thursday for $8.99. An additional $1.95 buys vegetables and potatoes, resulting in a $10.94 meal. During the first four days of the week, when "Shrimp Silliness" is in effect, patrons can purchase seven lightly breaded jumbos for $6.99.
Artie's South Shore Fish and Grill, near the water in Island Park, is wedged in sideways along Austin Boulevard (4257 Austin, 516-889-0692). It opened 25 years ago as a fish market. It still is, but two years ago Artie Hoerning, who always caught most of the fish, expanded and opened an unpretentious little cafe. He recently hired Jared L. Binns of Long Beach, a graduate of the Culinary Institute of America who has worked at Mulligan's at Hampton Bays, Borderline Cafe, the Discerning Palate and Villa Lombardi.
You can't eat much fresher fish than those at Artie's. And that's the way to go. Tuna is $11.95, swordfish $12.95, salmon $8.95, halibut $9.95 and whole broiled fluke $10.95. All are cooked with a vigilance and respect that many local restaurants, including fancy ones, have yet to master..
Ignore the two tables in front of the Hampton Chutney Company, at 74 Montauk Highway in Amagansett (631-267-3131), that make it look like just another hot dog and hamburger drive-in. Instead, go behind the building to the lovely 12-acre, landscaped garden of the adjacent Bayberry Nursery, where interesting, sometimes exotic Indian and American dishes are served at six picnic tables.
Many of the dosas (airy sourdough crepes made with rice and white lentil flour), uttapas (pancake-like dosas made with the same ingredients) and sandwiches feature fresh cilantro, tomato, mango, curry, peanut and pumpkin chutneys. A good place to start is the basic Masala dosa ($6.50), a warm crepe, about 10 inches long, that is wrapped around a savory spiced (though not spicy) potato filling. The most expensive items on the menu cost $10.50.
Paddy McGee's is the fish house in everyone's mind's eye, with its dark wood paneling, checkered tablecloths, aproned waiters, life preservers and lobster aquarium. An authentic seaside touch is added by its waterfront locale on the Reynolds Channel in Island Park.
Fortunately Paddy McGee's, at 6 Waterview Road (516-431-8700), isn't as expensive as it looks. Although appetizers can cost as much as $8.95 and fish dishes top out at $18.50, two diners can enjoy a light, lovely meal by ordering the feast of the sea ($12.50 a person). This briny array of shellfish from the raw bar contains 10 fresh clams and 9 pristine oysters on the half shell, 8 peel-and-eat shrimp, 5 mussels, 2 tender sea scallops and a clump of tangy calamari.It is preceded by a substantial plate of carrots, celery, new pickles, cabbage and olives, long reedy bread sticks and warm bread. Add a soda or ice tea for $1.50 or a glass of wine for a bit more and you have an ideal summer on a shoestring dinner.
For those who crave more, there are bowls of peppy Manhattan clam chowder and soothing New England clam chowder ($3.50). Two gently priced fish entrees are worth ordering: mild broiled New England scrod ($14.95) and savory seared brook trout ($15.50).
The wide wrap-around deck at Steamboat Landing faces the Jude Thaddeus Glen Cove Marina and straddles Glen Cove Creek. The setting, at 76 Shore Road, Glen Cove (516-759-3921), is perhaps the loveliest, low-priced possibility for waterside dining on the Island.
Midday on Sunday is one of the best times for a visit. The $16.95 brunch, which includes drinks, is being scaled back to $12.95 (without alcoholic beverages) this summer. Tthe brunch is a retro buffet that offers predictable choices of ordinary fare -- fettucine a la vodka, eggplant parmigiana, breaded pork cutlets, sausage and onions, fried potatoes, made-to-order omelets, chicken in wine sauce, bagels, Jell-O and fruit salad.
Also available is the bar menu. Its choices, which are actually the appetizers from the evening menu, present more discriminating patrons with a somewhat more sophisticated selection at almost equally affordable prices. Those who opt for quality over quantity will want to share the cold antipasto ($7.95) with its array of tomato, cheese, mushrooms, pepperoni, roasted red peppers, caponata and mozzarella. The seven tiny baked clams ($8.95), topped with tasty oreganata crumbs, is another good choice and the four jumbos in the somewhat pricey shrimp cocktail ($11.95) are first rate.
Two salads, the Caesar ($6.75 and $11.25, with grilled chicken) and the house ($5.50 and $9.95 with chicken) took top honors. Both the Caesar, a cascade of fresh romaine, homemade croutons and creamy Parmesan dressing presented in a pastry seashell container and the house, a large tangle of tender baby greens with a good red wine vinaigrette were substantial enough to share, especially when they are topped with a generous helping of chicken.
Although its open-air deck, next to an often active boat-filled creek is the choicest spot at Steamboat Landing, the airy dining room with its high ceiling and many windows, is a desirable bad-weather alternative that also offers a marine vista.
When a mist rises from the Great South Bay or its waves cast a spray along the shoreline, they reach Babylon Fish and Clam, a half block from the water at 458 Fire Island Avenue in Babylon (631-587-3633).
It opened 33 years ago as a clam shack and remains a rustic knotty pine kind of placey, despite expansion that includes a restaurant, a fish market, an open deck with umbrellas, a covered porch and a clam bar -- all determinedly nautical in decor.
Savvy patrons target the basics. They order starters like the spirited, highly seasoned, dense-with-ingredients Manhattan clam chowder and the thick, rich New England clam chowder (both $1.95 cup, $2.95 bowl), or the shrimp cocktail with its six shrimp for only $5.95 and the 18 or so big chowder-type steamers for $6.95.
Entrees make appetizers unnecessary since their price includes either of the chowders or garden salad and a choice of baked potato, French fries, onion rings and vegetables. Some of the least expensive entrees are among the best, including crisp, greaseless fried clam strips ($9.95). Flat fish range from $10.95 (broiled or fried codfish) to $18.95 for specials like striped bass provencale.
To experience summer on Long Island, order a bottle of white wine for $13, pair it with a dozen clams on the half shell ($8), that shrimp cocktail or fried clams and head for the open-air deck.

HEADLINE: The Barbecue Grill Reaches a Higher Level

BYLINE: By ELZY KOLB

 BODY:
BRICK and mortar are making a comeback. Elaborate brick and stone barbecues are starting to appear in backyards around the region.
"We began to have people asking for them about four years ago," said Trish Calabrese, office manager of Creative Stone Works Inc., in Park Ridge, N.J. "This year, there has been a huge increase. It's amazing what people are doing in their yards right now." 
 The booming economy is at least in part behind the resurgence of interest in these backyard behemoths. Higher disposable income makes it possible, even desirable, to dress up the mundane things in life. "The stonework has an Old World feeling, and it definitely looks a lot better than the plain, black-box gas grill," Ms. Calabrese said.
There's some nostalgia involved, too. Simple but pleasant childhood memories often bring clients to the offices of stonemasons and landscape architects. During the planning stage, "customers will mention the little old fireplaces, like they had in parks or in rest stops on the throughway," said Tom Ciccariello, owner of Seven Sons, a stone-working company in East Hampton. "For many of us, those cookouts were a big part of growing up."
But today's manifestation of those memories typically goes far beyond the basic wood-fired single-grill units of cookouts past.
Cameron Brand, a certified landscape architect and office manager of Oliver Nurseries in Fairfield, Conn., views the stone barbecue as the open-air equivalent of a commercial range, saying, "It's the Viking of outdoor products."
Florence Bogart, a landscape architect at Sprainbrook Nurseries in Scarsdale, N.Y., agrees. "What I'm seeing is elaborate outdoor cooking spaces. Really, it's like an outdoor kitchen."
Most are fueled by natural gas, rather than wood or charcoal. And most are "elaborate fireplaces tied to something, not just a lump of stone," Mr. Ciccariello said.
There's an extensive wish list of things that can be tied to such a setup. The brick or stone barbecue might have a top-of-the-line stainless steel cooking unit with an enormous grilling surface, and be topped off with a tall chimney with a flue. Many cooking areas contain rotisseries, gas burners and a hooded cooking surface.
"These are big, sophisticated units," Mr. Ciccariello said. "People cook corn on the cob and lobster. You can have a clambake along with the grilled food."
Counters surrounding the cooking area are topped with marble, ceramic tile, granite, bluestone slate or Corian. Beneath those counters you might find built-in storage units or cabinets with wood or stainless steel doors. Other amenities include running water for wet bars or preparation sinks, under-counter refrigerators, and lighting fixtures.
The surrounding area gets tied in, too. Because of its imposing size and stature, the barbecue is almost always the focal point in a landscaping plan, and its look is carried over into other elements in the yard. The cooking unit is sometimes built into a stone wall, or matching walls are built to shelter the cooking area.
"It could be a seating wall, a retaining wall or a freestanding wall to separate, say, the lawn from the patio," Mr. Ciccariello said. "It gives the sitting area more privacy. You can also add a stone table-a big slab of natural stone." Granite-topped bench-style seating is another add-on.
This may seem like a lot of trouble to go to, to cook outdoors twice a year. But that's not the case, said Matt Horn, owner of Matterhorn Nursery Inc., in Spring Valley, N.Y.
"With gas, everyone's cooking outside, all year round," he said. "These fireplaces are great for entertaining; they have a great ambience. More people want to be outdoors, even if they only have a small area. People will sit out all evening. We're even installing some fire pits-people can sit around, cook, talk and be warm, even in the spring and fall."
Ms. Brand explained the attraction this way: "It's a way of getting back to nature, even if you're outside a mansion. It's like being around the campfire; you can be at one with nature at the barbecue."
If you build it, they will come. And they will want to participate, too. "When friends come over, cooking at the barbecue gets people involved," Mr. Ciccariello said. "Everyone congregates around the grill and takes turns flipping."
Mr. Brand said: "When you have guests, it's much more social than standing around the stove inside. It's a very active way to cook. It gets you outside and gives you a feeling of participation in the gathering. It's a way for men to feel they're participating in the dinner hour, without feeling inept in front of the stove."
What's the bottom line on this wonderful combination of conspicuous consumption, nostalgia, ambience and bonding? "These things are not cheap," Mr. Horn said. "You might start at $10,000 for a decent one; allow about $4,000 for the mechanism, plus the masonry."
Mr. Ciccariello said: "It could be $6,000 to $14,000 for a grandiose project. It's a statement; it's not about function at that level. It's a hold on our past."
Mr. Calabrese said: "Quality is a consideration over price. People want to get something that's going to last. I can't imagine people spending like this in the late-80's."

HEADLINE: Making a Statement With a Grill

BYLINE: By ELZY KOLB

 BODY:
BRICK and mortar is making a comeback. Elaborate brick and stone barbecue fireplaces are starting to appear in backyards around the region.
"We began to have people asking for them about four years ago," said Trish Calabrese, office manager of Creative Stone Works, in Park Ridge. "This year, there has been a huge increase. It's amazing what people are doing in their yards right now."
