Because of its imposing size and stature, the barbecue is almost always the focal point in a landscaping plan, and its look is carried over into other elements in the yard. The cooking unit is sometimes built into a stone wall, or matching walls are built to shelter the cooking area.
"It could be a seating wall, a retaining wall or a freestanding wall to separate, say, the lawn from the patio," Mr. Ciccariello said. "It gives the sitting area more privacy. You can also add a stone table-a big slab of natural stone."
Granite-topped bench-style seating is another add-on.
This may seem like a lot of trouble to go to, to cook outdoors twice a year. But that's not the case, said Matt Horn, owner of Matterhorn Nursery in Spring Valley, N.Y.
"With gas, everyone's cooking outside, all year round," he said. "These fireplaces are great for entertaining; they have a great ambience. More people want to be outdoors, even if they only have a small area. People will sit out all evening. We're even installing some fire pits-people can sit around, cook, talk and be warm, even in the spring and fall."
Ms. Brand explained the attraction this way: "It's a way of getting back to nature, even if you're outside a mansion. It's like being around the campfire; you can be at one with nature at the barbecue."
If you build it, they will come. And they will want to participate, too. "When friends come over, cooking at the barbecue gets people involved," Mr. Ciccariello said. "Everyone congregates around the grill and takes turns flipping."
Mr. Brand said: "When you have guests, it's much more social than standing around the stove inside. It's a very active way to cook. It gets you outside and gives you a feeling of participation in the gathering. It's a way for men to feel they're participating in the dinner hour, without feeling inept in front of the stove."
What's the bottom line on this wonderful combination of conspicuous consumption, nostalgia, ambience and bonding? "These things are not cheap," Mr. Horn said. "You might start at $10,000 for a decent one; allow about $4,000 for the mechanism, plus the masonry."
Mr. Ciccariello said: "It could be $6,000 to $14,000 for a grandiose project. It's a statement; it's not about function at that level. It's a hold on our past."
Mr. Calabrese said: "Quality is a consideration over price. People want to get something that's going to last. I can't imagine people spending like this in the late-80's."

HEADLINE: GRASS-ROOTS BUSINESS;
OlderOffice Space For the New Economy

BYLINE: By JOEL KOTKIN; Joel Kotkin is a senior fellow at the Pepperdine Institute for Public Policy. His column on the Main Street economy appears the third Sunday of each month. E-mail: grassrts@nytimes.com

 BODY:
FRESH out of New York University Law School, Andrew Segal moved to Texas in the early 1990's to seek his fortune. Although he started with an inheritance of roughly $1 million, he felt that New York was too tough and expensive a place to build his own business empire.
Instead, he went looking where the pickings seemed easier, moving first to Dallas, where he bought some "see through" office buildings left virtually vacant after the oil crisis in the early 1980's. Yet as the real estate market improved there, he had to dig deeper for new opportunities, and began buying aging office buildings along Houston's downtrodden and dangerous Main Street. 
 That made some locals think that he was out of his mind -- or at least a very gullible outsider. "At the time," Mr. Segal recalled, "it looked like it was just another holdup on Main Street."
Now, his strategy of buying old, unwanted office buildings seems more like a stroke of genius. In the last five years, his Boxer Properties, based in Houston, has bought some 70 of them, 17 of which are of pre-World World War II vintage, in cities that also include Baltimore, Hartford, Dallas and Tulsa, Okla., as well as Hempstead, N.Y. Nearly all the deals have proved successful, with occupancy rates, rents and property values multiplying by two, three or more.
Mr. Segal, 33, appears on the verge of becoming a king of the once-disdained niche of so-called class B urban office space. His method is simple: he buys older buildings, fixes them and puts signs on them offering space for rent. As word gets around of the improved conditions in the buildings and of the low rents, which are sometimes as little as half those offered by landlords of fancier space nearby, tenants come and stay.
The entrepreneur, whose low-cost business style includes extensive traipsing from Baltimore to Tulsa and places in between on budget flights, may have seized the right niche at the right time. According to statistics from Reis Inc., a real estate information firm in New York, class B vacancy rates nationwide have dropped to roughly 11 percent from an average of nearly 20 percent in 1995. In some key urban centers, like San Francisco and Seattle, the rates are as low as 3 percent. Even in long-distressed markets like Tulsa, Baltimore and Houston, they have dropped by as much as half.
Mr. Segal credits the recovery of this niche in the last five years to broader changes in the economy -- including the explosive growth in the number of Internet, media and related businesses. These young companies may initially be attracted by the lower rents, but they also see these older buildings -- some of them stunning examples of Art Deco or Beaux-Arts architecture -- as reflecting their image as creative, nonhierarchical and unconventional.
Of course, Mr. Segal notes, the appeal of such buildings is not unconditional. To make them as functional as their more modern rivals, they often require upgraded telecommunications infrastructure and central air-conditioning systems, fresh coats of paint, and sometimes the removal of outdated features like carpeting over hardwood floors.
In many cities, such structures also benefit by being in or near districts that attract the young people who are so vital to many new-economy companies. Unlike high-rise buildings, these structures -- often less than 10 stories -- were usually built to accommodate ground-level businesses that open to the street. They also tend to have more light, and therefore less of the "concrete canyon" coldness found in many post-1950's downtown areas.
Throughout the country, districts dominated by class B buildings -- like Lower Manhattan in New York, Deep Ellum in Dallas, the Leather District of Boston and the South of Market section of San Francisco -- have first re-emerged as magnets for artists and denizens of hip clubs, then become hotbeds of Internet and other new-media activity. And with loft and other residential spaces available nearby, they create the kind of vibrant, 24-hour-a-day, seven-day-a-week environment sought by dot-com employees.
"It's where the single people are, where you go to a bar to meet them," Mr. Segal said. "That's what makes it work. In Houston there are few places for people to walk around and promenade; downtown is the exception."
The movement of Web-related companies into these districts, he said, enhances their appeal for more traditional white-collar companies that he calls "dot-com wannabes." In that group are advertising agencies, publishers, fashion design companies, executive recruiters and even small law firms that seek out the latest "cool" space to impress both clients and prospective employees with their new-economy savoir faire.
OTHER pioneers include Richard Kirshenbaum, founder of Kirshenbaum Bond & Partners in New York, an ad agency that prides itself on being hip. Kirshenbaum Bond moved from Midtown to Lower Manhattan more than a decade ago, in part to identify with the image of the area.
"If you are in a traditional area, you say you are a traditional business," Mr. Kirshenbaum, 40, said in his art-filled headquarters on Hudson Street. "It's taking risks, but we're a young agency and the area has sprouted up. It's having your own point of view and knowing your own mind."
For Mr. Segal, who tends to be a bottom-fishing King of the B's, markets like New York, San Francisco, Seattle and Boston, where class B rents can now reach $50 a square foot, have become too expensive. He prefers places like Tulsa, where he has bought seven prewar structures in the recovering downtown area; Kansas City, Mo.; and Baltimore. Space there can still be rented for as little as $10 a square foot and class B buildings bought for $1 million or less.
Mr. Segal is the first to acknowledge that these markets barely exist on the radar screen of big-name speculators and real estate investment trusts. He sees that as a plus, particularly if the market has falling vacancy rates, gradually rising rents and a growing community of high-technology companies. "I think the market will reward places that are cheaper and still offer a unique urban experience," he said.
These markets, he added, offer him the chance to duplicate the kind of windfall he has enjoyed on Houston's Main Street, now that downtown Houston itself may be getting a bit too expensive.
WITH the $525,000 he spent in 1996 to buy two 70-year-old office buildings in the city, he has made money two ways. Last year, he sold his 711 Main Street building for $2.1 million to a condominium developer. Each of the 40 lofts there, he estimated, is now worth more than the entire building was five years ago.
At the other Main Street building, which he still owns, the rental income has soared as commercial tenants have flooded in. Its vacancy rate, near 80 percent in 1996, has dropped to the single digits. New Web companies like SalvageSale.com, have moved in, helping to push rents from $6 a square foot to closer to $15, a big increase since 1996 but still at least $5 cheaper than nearby class A structures.
The growth of restaurants and clubs around the area, said Charlie Wilson, SalvageSale.com's president, has greatly enhanced the value of the office space -- a phenomenon seen in other cities as well.
"It's different, it's cool and it has history," said Mr. Wilson, 32, whose company now occupies 10,000 square feet in the building. "If you're going to be in Houston, this is where we want to be."

SECTION: Section 14; Page 5; Column 1; The City Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 994 words

HEADLINE: NEW YORK BOOKSHELF;
Vendors' Tricks, Water Woes and Upward Growth

 BODY:
NEW YORK has long been a subject of study by scholars and fare for academic as well as popular publishers. Here are excerpts from three recent books from university presses that explore various aspects of the city: a collection of essays from that quintessential New York observer, William H. Whyte; a history of how the city created its amazing water system; and a sociologist's view of how New York, along with Chicago and Los Angeles, take their place in the global economy. 

THE ESSENTIAL
WILLIAM H. WHYTE
Edited by Albert LaFarge
Fordham University Press
(Hardcover, $39.95, Paper $19.95)
Street vendors sell everything. There are perennial staples: junk jewelry, watches, umbrellas, plastic raincoats, toys. But the vendors are always trying out new items and occasionally most of them will be riding one fad, or whatever the jobbers are loaded up with. Several years ago it was leather belts. So many vendors took to selling them that it looked like the point of saturation had surely been reached. But supply created demand, and the sight of all those leather belts on the sidewalks drove people to buy more leather belts. They are still buying them.
The vendors have been growing in number. They have been broadening the range of the merchandise sold. To the aggravation of merchants, they have also been staking out more of the sidewalk space, that in front of stores especially. They have been doing more selling in winter and more night selling. Some illumine their racks and table with battery-powered fluorescent lamps.
Whatever the merchandise, the pitch is much the same. It's cheaper on the street. Ten dollars inside. One dollar here. Why pay more? The pitch is often made in a furtive manner, as if the deal were shady. Many vendors look shady. Many try to. It is to their advantage. There is a widespread assumption among knowing New Yorkers that much of the merchandise is stolen. Vendors do nothing to discourage this idea. As in a con game, the latent dishonesty of the customer is all for the good. He wants the goods to be stolen. That explains why he is going to snare a bargain. In actual fact, very little of the goods sold by vendors is stolen. They pick up their stuff from the jobbers in the Broadway-30th Street area who specialize in novelty merchandise. But if you ask the vendors where the goods came from, they may look at you slyly and wink.
 
WATER FOR GOTHAM
By Gerard T. Koeppel
Princeton University Press
(Hardcover, $29.95)
New York did not fare well during the Revolution. A fire two years into the British occupation destroyed much of what the 1776 fire missed, leaving the city "almost half Burned to Ashes." Shelter, food, and fuel were in short supply. In the winter of 1780, river traffic was blocked by ice and people froze to death from lack of firewood; during a 1781 reconnoiter, George Washington reported the island "totally stripped of trees."
Drought and deforestation played havoc with the groundwater. There was no rain for two months in the spring of 1780; in the summer of 1782, the town wells were dry and Hessian soldiers dug holes forty feet deep without striking water, arousing fears of death from thirst.
Sanitation, moderately efficient since the 1740's, had broken down by the first summer of occupation. A newly arrived Englishman believed a "treatise upon stinks" could be written about New York; a 1780 proclamation ordered all garbage dumped into Beekman's Swamp, an unhappy prospect.
Maintenance of the public wells and pumps fell to an ad hoc vestry. As civic order was breaking down just before the Revolution, control of well and pump overseer appointments had passed from the Common Council to the city's secular, elected vestrymen, whose primary responsibility since the 1740's had been ministering to the poor, collecting and distributing the poor tax, and overseeing the almshouse. This ward-based vestry disappeared under occupation, replaced by a group of loyalist citizens appointed by the British commandant of New York. The occupation vestry eventually took over the duties of the elected vestry, as well as most of the functions of the disbanded Common Council. Without tax collection, the appointed vestry did what it could about the poor, the pumps, sanitation, and other government duties by collecting donations, exorbitant rent on abandoned houses, criminal fines, and tavern license fees. This was no easy task; by the end of the war in 1783, the occupied town was bloated with some 30,000 people, most of them impoverished loyalist refugees.
 
NEW YORK, CHICAGO, LOS ANGELES: America's Global Cities
By Janet L. Abu-Lughod
University of Minnesota Press
(Hardcover, $39.95)
By the early twentieth century, it had become absolutely impossible to extend New York City's boundaries. This meant that its legal jurisdiction fell increasingly short of its metropolitan extent. Coordinated developments became more difficult, and different mechanisms, outside existing political structures, had to be invented. It was then that special districts and "authorities" were institutionalized to supplement and even substitute for municipal rule, and informal "regional" plans were advocated to guide a metropolitan expansion that could no longer be encompassed by city government. Because of New York's unique constellation of waterways, ports, and "inconvenient" state boundaries, this required inventiveness of the highest order.
Paralleling the process of horizontal expansion was a shirt upward in the vertical scale, and here, too, the "role of the state" was central. True skyscrapers came to dominate the skyline of lower Manhattan, as steel-frame structures and elevators became the taken-for-granted cliches of new construction. Zoning, first experimented with in New York City in 1916, was adopted as a planning mechanism for controlling densities and land uses in the city. It also had a forming effect on the skyline of Manhattan.

SECTION: Section 9; Page 1; Column 1; Style Desk 

LENGTH: 1570 words

HEADLINE: VIEW;
Asian 'It' Girls Say So Long to the Dragon Lady

BYLINE: By JENNIFER TUNG 

 BODY:
IN the Old Navy commercials shown during the Academy Awards in March, a new spokeswoman was promoting the cheap, cheerful clothing line: Lisa Ling, 26, co-host of "The View" on ABC. Ms. Ling, wearing red capris and a white T-shirt, said cheekily, "A good pair of shorts is hard to find, unless you know where to look." Behind her, a group of hunky young men sprinted by in cargo shorts.
I was amazed. Not at the sexual innuendo but at the sight of a young Chinese-American woman representing an enormous clothing company, on national television, on Oscar night -- the ultimate convergence of celebrity, glamour and fashion. Suddenly, Ms. Ling, with her crisp looks and newscaster-like delivery, was a style icon. 
 That might not sound like a big deal today, but I remember seeing a very different Ling (played by Tsai Chin) on television as a kid in the 1970's. My sisters and I were in our family room watching a rerun of the 1967 James Bond movie, "You Only Live Twice." One of the first scenes takes place in Hong Kong, or more precisely, in a bed in Hong Kong, where Agent 007 kisses a long-haired Chinese woman with blunt bangs.
"Why is it that Chinese girls taste different from all other girls?" he asks her.
"You think Chinese girls bet-tuh, huh?" she replies.
"Not better, just different -- the way Peking duck is different from Russian caviar, but I love them both," Bond says.
"Dah-ling, I give you very best duck," Ling says.
Then she jumps out of bed right before two men with machine guns burst in and try to riddle Bond with bullets.
Bond's Ling was the amalgam of almost every Chinese female stereotype: a submissive sex nymph speaking in breathy, broken English, and a calculating dragon lady. (If she'd leapt out of bed and into a lab coat and thick glasses, the cliche would have been complete.) She is also the only representation of Asian women in film or television that I remember from my childhood -- aside from the "ancient Chinese secret" laundry lady in the Calgon commercials. At the time, I didn't know enough to be angry or offended. I was just embarrassed.
But lately there has been an Asian population explosion in the pop culture landscape. In Hollywood, there's a new kind of A-list that includes Asian It Girls like Ming-Wa, Bai Ling, Michelle Yeoh and Lucy Liu. Beaming from a billboard in Times Square is CoCo Lee, the Hong Kong-born, San Francisco-reared singer whose first United States album, "Just No Other Way," was released two months ago.
There has also been an Asian style invasion: Vera Wang, the fashion designer, on the cover of Town & Country this winter, Ahn Duong, the artist, on the cover of Banana Republic's new catalog just last week. Fashion models like Devon Aoki and Ling are fixtures on the runways. Asian faces are even infiltrating society pages. The actress China Chow and the Visionaire editor Cecilia Dean are downtown scenesters who appear regularly in Vogue's party pictures. W magazine's May issue alone features a profile of Wendy Deng discussing the Asia Society and marriage to Rupert Murdoch, a story about Hong Kong-born Grace Leo Andrieu, owner of the celebrity-studded Hotel Lancaster in London, as well as a 12-page swimsuit portfolio starring Ms. Aoki.
But if Asian women are busting out of the China doll stereotypes, their new image does tend to borrow some of the old cliches. They may no longer be mousy math whizzes, but they're still brainy. Clawed dragon ladies might be out, but style queens with sharp tongues and sharp wardrobes are very in. "We're never portrayed as bimbos," said the Malaysian-born designer Yeohlee. "It's because of our flat chests."
That does not mean they aren't physical. On screen, Asian women often combine sexiness and action heroism with unusual ease, like Michelle Yeoh, the actress whose long, glossy hair flies as she leaps tall buildings in the Jackie Chan movies. Lucy Liu, the acerbic Ling Woo on "Ally McBeal," will be a kickboxing cop in the film version of "Charlie's Angels" in November alongside Drew Barrymore and Cameron Diaz. (It's somehow harder to imagine the neurotic Calista Flockhart chasing bad guys with a gun.)
Despite such new, cool roles, the effort to create a hip identity that can include Asian-ness rather than try to hide it is still pretty new and often self-conscious. When I met Lisa Ling at an event for Nutrisse home hair-coloring products two months ago, she said: "What I try to convey to other Asians with my sense of style is that we can defy the stereotypes that we are submissive and not gregarious. We don't have to conform. I can be obnoxious and blunt." As if to prove her point, Ms. Ling added, "So many Asians are label whores. Have you noticed that?"
But even Ms. Ling's bravado set in only a few years ago. "I hated being Chinese as a kid!" recalled Ms. Ling, who was born in California. "I was teased mercilessly. I went to public school, and the kids called me 'Risa Ring.' Kids would come over to my house, and it would smell like Chinese food, and that was embarrassing. Or if I had friends over, my dad would say, 'Tell them to go home' in Chinese, right in front of them."
I nodded vigorously in agreement, remembering the time a classmate of my younger sister's came over after school, smelled rice cooking and asked if we had pet gerbils. My sister explained the odor by saying that our heating system was broken.
It wasn't always clear, growing up in Albuquerque, how to bridge the divide between my Chinese heritage and my desire to fit in with the tall, tanned set at the tennis club. My parents, a scientist and a classical pianist, spoke Cantonese to each other, and to us, when we were small. In our house, high style was my grandmother wearing a cheongsam and singing Chinese opera as we kids padded around the house in our embroidered Chinese pajamas with frog buttons.
But away from home, being Asian could be nerve-racking. My white and Hispanic classmates flattened their noses with their fingers to mock my wide features. When we had to line up by height, I was always shortest and last. My beauty ideals were the blond models in Seventeen and in the ads for Ocean Pacific, the Southern California clothing company. When Madonna hit the charts, I wore crucifixes, black lace gloves and rubber bracelets up to my elbows. My New Wave phase followed: head shaved on the sides, dyed orange hair forced skyward with gel and diluted glue.
If only I had had a role model like Margaret Yang, the quirky high school girl in last year's film "Rushmore" who played rock guitar, acted in avant-garde school plays and got the boy in the end. Why the sudden embrace of Asian women and culture?
The designer Vivienne Tam, who was raised in Hong Kong (and whose style guide "China Chic" will be published in September by ReganBooks), links it to the new global economy and the opening up of Asia. "When Hong Kong went back to China in 1997, I think there was more awareness around the world of Asian culture," she said on the phone from her Seventh Avenue office. "And then Prada and Miu Miu started the whole chinoiserie trend."
Phoebe Eng, the author of "Warrior Lessons: An Asian American Woman's Journey Into Power" (Pocket Books), said it's not the rest of the world but Asian women themselves who have changed. "We are the crop of daughters who finally had choices," Ms. Eng, 37, said. "We didn't have the same sense of duty and boundness of our mothers, so we took our own paths and went into acting, comedy and entertainment. The number of Asian women entering F.I.T. and Parsons is amazing."
Ms. Eng also pointed out that Asians are not only fashion forward, but also have an ethnicity that is integral to their style. "You see lots of 15-year-olds wearing Hello Kitty and chinoiserie," she said. "And older Asian women have an androgynous look, and that is what makes the look sensuous. We used to think of Asian models as chiseled and Eurasian-looking. Now, some have very small eyes, and others have square jaws. Anything goes."
It didn't occur to me that my ethnic looks could be a style advantage when I took my first job after college, as an editorial assistant at a beauty magazine. Once again I was surrounded by lithe blondes, now with expensive haircuts and dressed in black. But it turned out to be a propitious time. One of my first writing assignments was a story about "universal beauty" and featured Irina Pantaeva, a Siberian model with northern Chinese features. Doling out advice on how to beautify the flat lids and sparse lashes of an Asian eye, I began to feel more in control of my looks and less concerned about fitting in.
Then something unexpected happened. I found myself part of an Asian style clique, a bunch of trend-happy editors and writers who introduced me not only to sample sales, but also to the soup dumplings at Joe's Shanghai in Chinatown. We often meet there after work, shove our Lambertson Truex totes under our chairs and order (mostly in Mandarin) greasy noodles and "lion's head," giant, gelatinous meatballs drenched in brown sauce and surrounded by a mane of greens, which we share, pecking at the communal platters with our chopsticks. In between bites of noodles and media gossip, I can rant freely about my family and my boyfriend, then gloat over the three $25 string bikinis I just bought from Old Navy, the store Lisa Ling represents on television.
 
http://www.nytimes.com

LENGTH: 1276 words

HEADLINE: THE BUSINESS WORLD;
Jordan's Long Road To the Free-Trade Club

BYLINE: By WILLIAM A. ORME Jr. 

DATELINE: AMMAN, Jordan

 BODY:
MOHAMMED A. HALAIQAH'S trip to Seattle last November was to have been the culmination of his career. As Jordan's most experienced trade negotiator, he had spent five years arduously preparing for his country's entry into the World Trade Organization.
After a thorough and painful overhaul of its tariffs and investment rules, putting domestic industries like pharmaceuticals at risk, Jordan was finally poised to become the W.T.O.'s next full member. As the only country scheduled to join the group at its Seattle summit meeting, it hoped to attract worldwide publicity -- and American investment in the high-technology industries it sees as the key to its future. 
 It wasn't to be. Mr. Halaiqah (pronounced ha-LYE-kah) was stunned to find himself trapped in a hotel lobby as the police fought protesters with tear gas and rubber bullets.
"We were expecting something, but we didn't expect it to be so fierce," he said. "We were literally besieged in the hotel."
The chaos outside and policy clashes inside the meeting forced Jordan off the suddenly truncated Seattle agenda.
"Waiting for that big moment, we felt that Jordan was the victim of the contradictory interests of these different groups," said Mr. Halaiqah, now Jordan's minister of industry and trade.
Last month, at its Geneva headquarters, the W.T.O. ratified Jordan's entry, making it the 136th member and just the seventh Arab state to join. While Egypt, the United Arab Emirates and several North African nations are members, many Jordanian trading partners, including Iraq, Saudi Arabia, Syria and Kuwait, are not.
Jordan won some important concessions: Agricultural subsidies can be maintained at their current high level for a 10-year transition period, and majority ownership of retailers is still reserved for local investors.
But most barriers to foreign investments and products must be phased out, exposing many Jordanian companies to international competition for the first time. For an economy that still depends on potash, used in fertilizer and chemicals, from the Dead Sea for the bulk of its export income, exploiting the opportunities of W.T.O. membership will be a challenge.
W.T.O. membership was granted almost a year after Jordan's new king, Abdullah II, summoned Mr. Halaiqah for a briefing on the effort to join the W.T.O. King Hussein, Abdullah's father, had died two months earlier, and the new monarch was determined to make economic growth his focus.
The king was convinced that Jordan needed to open up quickly. Per capita income had been declining. The Persian Gulf war in 1991 disrupted the flow of money sent home by Jordanians living and working in the gulf states, and sanctions against Iraq -- Jordan's biggest trading partner -- reduced trade to a trickle.
As the king saw it, Jordan's only alternative -- a quick foreign capital influx from privatization sales and high-technology industrial development -- would require strict adherence to international trade rules.
Mr. Halaiqah told King Abdullah during their April 1999 meeting that after more than four years of talks, Jordan was still far from complying with W.T.O. demands. After the Seattle assembly, he warned, the organization would begin a new round of global trade liberalization, raising membership hurdles higher.
Another reason to move quickly: "There was a lot of sympathy for Jordan after the death of His Majesty King Hussein, and I thought that we should take advantage of that," Mr. Halaiqah said.
So King Abdullah gave Mr. Halaiqah an ambitious order: Get Jordan into the W.T.O. in time for Seattle. For his part, the young king promised to ram a set of new trade and investment laws through the balky legislature. They had only six months.
As Jordanian officials concede, it would have been hard to find a country that was a less likely candidate for such a rapid turnaround. Fuzzy law and lax enforcement had made Jordan a capital of counterfeiting and patent piracy. Software, books, videos, cassette tapes -- all were produced and sold without copyright permission or royalty payments, often for export to neighbors. Media and computer industry lobbies in Washington and Brussels put Jordan near the top of their lists of intellectual property violators. Governments friendly to Jordan warned that without drastic changes, W.T.O. entry would not even be considered.
Most problematic were prescription drugs. By estimates of Jordan's own pharmaceutical industry, at least 15 percent of its patented drug output was manufactured without the patent holders' consent. Foreign analysts said the proportion was far higher. American drug companies calculated that Jordanian piracy cost them $25 million to $50 million a year.
"The pharmaceutical companies here were living in cuckoo-land, thinking that you could keep on stealing and stay in business," said Bassem I. Awadallah, the chief economic adviser to King Abdullah.
BUT with more than 4,000 employees and $140 million in export sales, the drug companies were one of this small economy's few growing sources of skilled jobs and foreign currency. Mazen S. Darwazah, the president of the Jordanian Association of Pharmaceuticals Manufacturers, says few of these companies are prepared to compete under W.T.O. rules, which make patent infringement grounds for costly trade sanctions. "Half of them will close down, and the families of 2,000 breadwinners will be out on the street," he predicted.
Yet as Mr. Darwazah acknowledged, his own company, Hikma Pharmaceuticals, is a potential model. Specializing in generic drugs on which the patents have expired, and with modern production facilities, Hikma exports to 30 countries from plants in sites including Eatontown, N.J.
"We have recognized that in order for us to survive, we need a niche," he said. "The world is run by the big corporations, whether we like it or not."
But few companies have the capital or technological sophistication to manage this transition, he said. And many Jordanians cannot afford imported medicines. "If we make Jordan a safe haven for intellectual property rights, we know that health care prices will rise dramatically," Mr. Darwazah said.
A few months ago, Jordan became one of the few Middle Eastern nations to be removed from the United States Commerce Department's watch lists of intellectual property violators. Its new patent protections are lauded by former critics in the computer and pharmaceutical industries. In March, dozens of American executives traveled to a Dead Sea resort to hear King Abdullah itemize incentives for software and telecommunications investors. Jordan offers high-technology companies a significant but underemployed pool of English-speaking engineers and technicians.
With W.T.O. membership in hand, Jordan is now negotiating free-trade pacts with Europe, having already reached agreements with other Arab states. Jordan's main goal now is a free-trade deal with the United States, an advantage already enjoyed by Israel and the Palestinian Authority.
Jordanian officials know from their Seattle experience that any free-trade proposal will meet resistance. Mr. Halaiqah is still irked by the contentions of American demonstrators that they were defending poor countries like his against the predations of the global trading system -- a system Jordan had labored to join.
"I understand the fears of environmentalists, of labor, but they should do their homework," he said. "No country has benefited more from international trade than the United States. These people cannot speak on behalf of the world, and certainly not on behalf of developing countries."

HEADLINE: ECONOMIC VIEW;
Lighting Up A Lesson In China Trade

BYLINE: By TOM REDBURN 

 BODY:
WANDERING through a flea market in Shanghai earlier this year with Craig Smith, The Times's new correspondent there, I stopped at a stall that was selling cheap cigarette lighters with pictures of Mao Zedong pasted on them. Flick one open, and it plays the tune of "The East Is Red." I don't smoke, but I couldn't resist buying a handful.
Not far away, another merchant offered hundreds of hand-painted posters from the days of the Cultural Revolution. I bought one dated 1976, showing a smiling Mao leading a parade of workers and students into the promised land. We bargained a bit before settling on a price of about $5. 
 Say what you will about capitalism, but you must admit it has a marvelous way of turning even the most violent and earthshaking upheavals into safe, salable kitsch.
And that, above all, is why it is worth continuing to encourage Beijing to move along the path toward freer markets, private investment and open trade. Karl Marx (remember him?) said it as well as anybody in, of all places, the Communist Manifesto:
"The bourgeoisie, by the rapid improvement of all instruments of production, by the immensely facilitated means of communication, draws all nations, even the most barbarian, into civilization. The cheap prices of its commodities are the heavy artillery with which it batters down all Chinese walls, with which it forces the barbarians' intensely obstinate hatred of foreigners to capitulate."
What does this have to do with today's debate over China? Plenty.
The choice facing Congress this week over granting China what is called "permanent normal trade relations" -- part of a deal to admit China to the World Trade Organization -- turns on conflicting views of how to best induce change in China's authoritarian regime.
On one side -- opposed to normalizing trade -- are those who argue that Congress should vote every year on China's trade status, thus maintaining outside pressure on Beijing to respond to complaints of human rights abuses. The annual vote should not be given up, they say, because it is Washington's only stick for persuading China to ease repression and to free dissidents. Treating China as a normal trading partner, they say, will just entrench the current regime and encourage its belligerence.
Opposing that view are those who believe that change inside China can exert greater leverage for reform than any diplomatic pressure. Through broader trade and contact with the outside world, the Chinese people will be exposed to the full range of Western life, from the sublime to the ridiculous. In the end, the temptation will prove irresistible. Treat China as a normal country, this side argues, and it will eventually turn into one.
"Openness is a two-way street," Nicholas Lardy, a senior fellow at the Brookings Institution, said last week in a telephone interview from Beijing. "Already there are thousands of foreigners living in China and interacting on a daily basis across a very broad spectrum. That will only grow as China joins the W.T.O. At the same time, tens of thousands of the most promising Chinese have gone to the West as students. They've come back -- often to very high positions in government, banking and business -- changed for good."
I VISITED China for the first time this year. But even without an earlier point of reference, it was clear that though the economy remains very basic, the country has changed immensely in the last two decades.
As recently as the early 1980's, nearly everybody in Shanghai, the most Westernized city in China, still wore the famous blue Mao suits. Only top officials had cars; everyone else pedaled bicycles or rode buses. Lights were dim. Public restaurants and private enterprises barely existed. Architecture seemed frozen in a pre-World War II time warp. Today, everything is different: jeans and khakis are ubiquitous; cars and taxis compete with bikes on crowded streets; glass-sheathed skyscrapers abound; Shanghai throbs with activity day and night.
"We tend to forget," Mr. Lardy said, "how much change has already occurred."
As private enterprise spreads and markets open to real competition from domestic and foreign companies alike, tens of millions of Chinese are shedding their dependence on the state. They are richer and freer. It's not democracy, but it is the first step toward a genuinely pluralistic society.
And that is just the beginning.
"China now feels competitive heat across continents and oceans," Robert Wright wrote in a recent issue of The New Republic. "It must face the same logic the rest of the world faces. In the age of the Internet, even more than in the age of industry and print, granting enough liberty for cutting-edge prosperity while denying political liberty is a tall order."

HEADLINE: INVESTING WITH: Neil Barsky and Scott Sipprelle;
MRG Nucleus Fund

BYLINE: By ALEX BERENSON 

 BODY:
IT would have been easy for Neil Barsky and Scott Sipprelle to just join the crowd three months ago.
The two men run a $120 million hedge fund, the MRG Nucleus fund, from a modest office suite in Midtown Manhattan. They opened MRG Nucleus in July 1998, a few months after striking out from Morgan Stanley, where Mr. Barsky was a well-regarded casino industry analyst and Mr. Sipprelle a top investment banker. By February, 19 months into the fund's life, they found themselves stuck in the middle of the pack in the hotly competitive hedge fund business. 
 Hedge funds try to produce above-average investment returns using tactics ranging from traditional stock-picking to complex derivative and arbitrage plays. High minimum investments, redemption restrictions and aggressive strategies make them suitable mainly for more sophisticated and well-heeled investors.
MRG concentrates on overlooked and undervalued newly public companies, chosen eclectically without a particular sector bias. By ordinary standards, its returns have been solid -- 63.5 percent from inception through February, a 19-month stretch.
But over the same period, the Nasdaq composite index rose 151 percent. And many hedge funds posted even stronger returns with the help of aggressive leverage and heavy bets on technology -- techniques that Mr. Barsky and Mr. Sipprelle avoided. MRG fell further behind the index in February, when the Nasdaq rose a scorching 19.2 pecent, triple MRG's gain.
To be sure, with a return of 42 percent in 1999, MRG was not exactly facing a wave of redemptions from investors angry at missing the technology runup. Still, "it's always difficult in the investment business to underperform," Mr. Sipprelle said.
So when the two managers sat down to draft their monthly letter to investors after the February results came in, they felt compelled to explain: "We are not Luddites. We are huge believers in the power of technology to accelerate the efficiency of commerce, the productivity of workers."
What they did not believe in, they warned, was the market for technology stocks, which they concluded had gone seriously haywire.
"We have not drunk from the Kool-Aid that has mesmerized the market into thinking that 'growth at any price' is a sound investment strategy," they wrote. "We are underweight technology today, and expect to remain so as long as valuations stay at current levels. We think the stock market is in the midst of a dangerous game of 'chicken' with tech stocks. We suspect it will end badly; we don't know when."
They also spelled out a series of specific concerns, including accelerating price declines in software and hardware, and the explosion in initial public offerings.
"If there is one verity of the I.P.O. market that has proved itself over the years," they wrote, "it is that when capital becomes too available, a hot sector ends up gorging itself, overinvesting, and ultimately lowering returns for the entire industry."
Eleven weeks later, they look smart. The Nasdaq has fallen almost a third from its early March high, but MRG is up 15 percent since then. Mr. Barsky and Mr. Sipprelle say they try not to gloat, but they acknowledge feeling pretty good. "If you're building a long-term business, you have to weigh the easy money against the responsibility you have not to take outsize risk," Mr. Barsky said.
WHAT is MRG bullish on now? The fund is still staying away from high-growth technology stocks, which mostly remain expensive by traditional valuation measures even after their tumble over the last two months. Instead, the managers prefer small-capitalization companies that offer relatively strong growth on the cheap.
Consider Argosy Gaming, which runs midsize riverboat casinos and hotels across the Midwest and South. Drawing on his years as an analyst, Mr. Barsky keeps a close eye on the casino industry, which fell into a painful slump from 1996 to late 1998 before turning around last year. He expects the gains to continue, at least for smaller operators like Argosy.
Several macroeconomic trends are combining to invigorate the industry, Mr. Barsky said. The long economic boom has given adults more disposable income for gambling. It has also put local government finances into surplus, making states where gambling remains illegal less inclined to legalize it. With capacity constrained and demand rising, companies that do have licenses are seeing profits rise.
In addition, many states where Argosy has boats have recently relaxed regulations on their operation, allowing the company to cut costs and increase profits. Illinois, for example, dropped a rule that boats must actually cruise the rivers on which they float, rather than remain permanently docked.
Factoring out a one-time charge related to a debt financing, Argosy's net income soared from $5.7 million, or 23 cents a share, in 1998 to $41.7 million, or $1.44 a share, in 1999. Revenues grew from $507 million to $595 million.
Analysts expect continued growth this year and are now forecasting earnings of $1.73 a share, an estimate that has been rising recently. Yet Argosy closed on Friday at $16.50, less than 10 times expected 2000 earnings and barely five times the company's cash flow.
Argosy "is so cheap it's not even funny," said Mr. Barsky, who called the multiples "inexplicably low."
AT these prices, Argosy could be takeover bait for larger casino operators like MGM Grand or the Mandalay Resort Group, which now focus mainly on the Las Vegas Strip. The spread of Native American-owned casinos in California threatens companies with big investments in Las Vegas, making them "feel some need to diversify," Mr. Barsky said.
He thinks Argosy, which has accumulated a large database of gambler-customers and is among the strongest of the midsize riverboat operators, makes an inviting target.

HEADLINE: PERSONAL BUSINESS;
For Bank C.D.'s, a Return to Fashion

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

 BODY:
TEMPTING, tempting . . . .
It has been a long time since the prospect of putting cash in the bank held any attraction for most people. Interest rates were paltry, and the eager money forsook income investments to chase capital gains in the stock market. That drove prices so high that the average dividend paid by companies in the Standard & Poor's 500 is now barely 1 percent. 
 But the Federal Reserve's drive to head off any surge in inflation is returning the luster to the word "yield" -- on bonds, of course, but also on such prosaic and convenient products as certificates of deposit and money market funds, especially for consumers willing to shop a little.
And, surprisingly, a bit of negotiating -- even a ploy as simple as inquiring whether your bank might be willing to improve on the rate posted in the window -- can also pay off.
"If you've got more than $50,000 or so, you can always get 25 to 50 basis points more, often by just asking," said Warren Heller, research director at Veribanc, which analyzes banking trends. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
Not surprisingly, banks do not advertise or even acknowledge that this goes on, but some customers of major banks have found otherwise.
For many of the most succulent rates, the place to look is the Internet -- both the electronic offshoots of traditional banks and the stand-alone cyberbanks like Wingspanbank.com, E-Trade Group's Telebank, X.Com and USAccess Internet Bank.
A survey of online banking published last Wednesday by Consumer Action, an advocacy group in California, found "much better interest rates, not only on savings accounts but on checking and money market accounts and certificates of deposit," than were found elsewhere.
Their examination of 19 virtual banks, all federally insured, and 10 traditional ones showed, for example, that online operations paid about a half-point more interest on six-month C.D.'s, and that 4 of the 19 required smaller minimum deposits than any of the ordinary banks.
As promotion-minded as many a dot-com, Wingspanbank is temporarily offering an eye-popping 10 percent interest rate on checking accounts that Kevin Watters, its senior vice president for marketing, called "probably the highest in the country." The rate applies to amounts from $100 to $10,000 and runs until Sept. 1; after that. the accounts will pay 3.10 percent for deposits of at least $2,500 and 4.50 percent for $10,000 and up.
"We can pay such high rates because we don't have the physical infrastructure that brick-and-mortar banks have," Mr. Watters said, adding that Wingspanbank's computer system, built from scratch, avoided the technical incompatibility problems that traditional competitors face after numerous mergers.
ON 12-month certificates of deposit, Wingspanbank immediately echoed last week's half-point increase by the Federal Reserve for overnight money, bringing its rate to 7 percent. The average bank in the country offered 5.47 percent on 12-month C.D.'s after the Fed move, up from 5.42 percent the previous week, according to Bank Rate Monitor.
Wingspanbank, owned by Bank One, is based in Wilmington, Del., but you may not have to look beyond your hometown institutions for newly enticing deposit rates.
Citibank in New York, for example, has a cyberspace facility that it calls Citi f/i (for financial interactive). A visit to citifi.com, its Web site, found its insured money market account paying a 5.50 percent rate, for an annual yield of 5.65 percent, with a $1,000 minimum. As is common with Internet banks, Citi f/i reimburses any A.T.M. fees charged to its depositors by other institutions for withdrawals from its accounts.
Citi's online rates are well above the 4.59 percent rate (4.70 percent annual yield) offered at Citibank branches on "preferred" money market accounts, which require deposits or loans totaling at least $50,000 in a customer's accounts. Customers with $25,000 to $49,999 in their accounts get a 3 percent rate, yielding 3.05 percent annually.
The difference reflects "lower infrastructure costs," said Maria Mendler, a Citibank spokeswoman.
Textbook economics, however, holds that prices are made by supply and demand, not costs, leading analysts to suggest that Internet banks' rates are high because they are little known and because consumers hesitate over the idea of a bank they cannot visit.
"If something goes wrong with a transaction, it's not like just driving down to the branch and taking it up with the manager," said Mr. Heller of Veribanc, noting that credit unions often combine very close proximity with high rates.
And local banks sometimes bid so aggressively for money that there is no need to send it away to get a higher rate, he said. "Sometimes there's a pleasant surprise."

SECTION: Section 4; Page 17; Column 1; Editorial Desk

HEADLINE: RECKONINGS;
Workers vs. Workers

BYLINE: By PAUL KRUGMAN 

 BODY:
In the 1920's, South Africa's Communist Party campaigned under the slogan "Workers of the world unite for a white South Africa!" This wasn't quite as incongruous as it sounds: the political movement that eventually imposed apartheid had strong populist, even socialist roots. It was sincerely concerned with improving the economic status of the Afrikaner worker, and protecting him from the depredations of international capital. Unfortunately, the movement improved the lot of white labor mainly by preventing capitalists from offering industrial jobs to nonwhites, whose intense poverty made them willing to work for less.
The U.S. labor movement is not as brutally direct in its slogans. Probably its leaders don't even admit to themselves that their increasingly vociferous opposition to imports is, in effect, an effort to improve the condition of American workers by denying opportunity to workers in the rest of the world. But when the Teamsters' president, James P. Hoffa, declares, as he did on this page not long ago, that "American workers should not be asked to compete with foreigners who are not paid a living wage," the implications are clear. Given the low productivity of workers in third-world countries, their nations' lack of infrastructure and general lag in development, to insist that such workers be paid what Americans would regard as a living wage is to insist that they price themselves out of their jobs. And that is no accident: any policy that didn't price those workers out of the market would offer no relief to workers here. 
 There is a sort of tragic inevitability about the way labor has reached this moral impasse. The U.S. labor movement has every right to feel that American workers have gotten a raw deal. By standard measures, the real take-home pay of blue-collar workers is lower now than it was a quarter-century ago. You can quibble with the statistics, but without question blue-collar workers have been largely left behind by the nation's economic growth. And far from fighting this inequality in rewards, policy has in general reinforced it: taxes have become less rather than more progressive, public schools for those who can't afford to live in the right places have gotten worse, and so on.
A well-meaning economist can give you a list of things that might help America's working class: some form of national health insurance, bigger and better wage supplements along the lines of the earned-income tax credit, etc., etc. But if I were a labor leader, I would sneer at my professorial naivete. You know and I know that such proposals are pipe dreams, that in America today the left, such as it is, has its hands full holding back efforts to tilt the tax-and-benefit system even more toward the interests of the affluent. And the labor movement -- whose influence is far less today than it was even 20 years ago -- is in no position to reverse the political tide.
So what's a labor leader to do? Choose a fight that he might be able to win: a fight to limit imports that compete with the workers he represents. Voters might not see protection as a direct threat to their pocketbooks (though it is). The payoff may be limited -- the arithmetic suggests that even a total ban on manufactured imports from third-world countries would raise blue-collar wages no more than 3 or 4 percent -- but who's counting? And if the target is unattractive enough -- if it is, say, a nasty regime in China -- labor's limited but not negligible lobbying power just might pull off a victory.
In other words, it's understandable that labor has decided that it must try to help American workers by denying opportunity to even needier workers abroad -- while, of course, denying that it is doing any such thing. If I were a labor leader I would probably be a protectionist too. But to understand this political strategy, even to accept its inevitability, is not to approve.
Those who would like easy moral certainties -- which means all of us -- wish that it were simpler, that corporate greed were the only enemy, that people like Mr. Hoffa were standing up for the rights of workers everywhere. It's hard for liberals to admit that the U.S. labor movement, with its noble tradition, is now working against the interests of most of the world's poor. But it is. 
http://www.nytimes.com

HEADLINE: Detroit Journal;
Mexican Immigrants Lead a Revival

BYLINE: By NICHOLE M. CHRISTIAN 

DATELINE: DETROIT, May 20

 BODY:
When he was a boy growing up in west-central Mexico, Jesus Lopez and his brothers would load agave leaves onto the backs of donkeys and haul them to factories to be converted into tequila. Along the way, he would dream of living in a place with electricity and abundant water.
But the dream never included Detroit. Mr. Lopez had not even heard of it until the day that his brothers and many in Jesus Maria, his hometown, packed their bags and headed to America's Motor City. When an 18-year-old Jesus Lopez arrived here, he said recently, he was convinced that those who had come before him were crazy. 
 "In those days, over here there was only burned-out houses," he recalled. "Who would want to live here? It was not good."
But today, 18 years later, the view is much different in southwest Detroit, where many of this city's immigrants from Mexico live. So much has changed that it is being hailed as the nation's new Mexican boomtown.
Scorched shells of houses are being bought and resurrected by scores of skilled Mexican tradesmen. They have snapped up dozens of the old Victorians and duplexes for as little as $20,000, and they have nearly doubled the population to 90,000.
Their impact is undeniable. The three local Roman Catholic parishes have each added two weekend Masses in Spanish to accommodate the wave of new arrivals, who started showing up here six years ago, most directly from Mexico. They say they came to escape rising costs and growing hostilities against immigrants in Arizona, California and Chicago, and to reunite with older relatives who had been cashing in on Detroit's labor shortage for more than a decade.
West Vernor Avenue, the main strip here, is lined with evidence: Mexican bakeries, paleta (Popsicle) shops, taquerias, tortilla factories, Mexican grocery stores. Since 1994, about 35 businesses have opened and dozens have expanded, business groups said. An $8 million mercado and welcome center will be built next year. Amid the abundance of Spanish signs, it is easy to overlook the golden arches of McDonald's.
"Nobody over here saw the opportunity we did," said Mr. Lopez, who left a 10-year construction career five months ago to open his own taqueria. "Where we come from, you work all your life to have a house, a business, and you still don't get nowhere. That's why we work hard to make this good for us."
The Rev. Donald Hanchon of Most Holy Redeemer Catholic Church said: "These are people who are determined to be an asset. You see it in the churches, where they're helping with children and services. They genuinely want to make this a better place."
Father Hanchon said he believed that the renovation of run-down houses here was forcing drug dealers to find new dens.
Like Mr. Lopez, the majority of the families settling here come from villages in Jalisco, the Mexican state renowned for producing tequila, mariachi music and rancheros, Mexican cowboys. More than 40,000 of the people who live in southwest Detroit are either from Jalisco or have relatives there, said Maria Elena Rodriguez, who is a Detroit native and president of the Mexicantown Community Development Corporation.
Some of the businesses are named to honor Jalisco and its towns, like Arandas, Jesus Maria and San Ignacio. The connection is so strong that caravans of adults and children load up their cars each January and return to the towns to celebrate las fiestas patronales, a 10-day festival held in honor of patron saints.
"We go back, so they know we are proud to be from Mexico, from Jalisco," said Guadalupe Guzman, 70, who moved here to work in the steel factories in 1950. He and his family return to Jesus Maria every year.
It took two decades for 32-year-old Jose Zamudio to believe the stories that his brothers and sisters told about the untapped opportunities in Detroit. Even after five of them came here from San Ignacio, bought homes and found steady jobs, Mr. Zamudio refused to follow.
"It was too ugly," he said. Mr. Zamudio and his wife, Anna, chose instead to go to Oakland, Calif. But after four years of working for $10 an hour and living in cramped apartments, they gave up and moved back to Mexico. They built a home and had three children.
Then two years ago, when the whole family had obtained visas, they decided to give the United States another try, in Chicago this time. They stayed three months. The pressure of having five people in a $600-a-month one-room apartment was too much. Now they are gambling on Detroit.
So far, their gamble has paid off. Mr. Zamudio is earning $18 an hour as a bricklayer for a construction company. Six months ago, he and his wife bought a three-bedroom duplex for $40,000. But what thrills Mr. Zamudio most is seeing how much his family -- 5 brothers and sisters and 19 nieces and nephews -- and others from back home have done to help rebuild southwest Detroit.
"Look at it, it's like little Jalisco," he said. "We never knew people of our towns building this kind of business. They show if you fight and fight, you reach your dreams."

HEADLINE: Labor and the China Vote

 BODY:
John Sweeney, the president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., is doing his country and the labor movement a disservice by fighting so hard against permanently establishing normal trade relations with China. Of all the groups lobbying on this issue, none has made a greater historic blunder than organized labor. By bludgeoning Richard Gephardt and the Democrats into sticking with labor on the issue, which the House is set to vote on this week, Mr. Sweeney is squandering much of the good will he has built up in recent years and damaging the interests of American workers. House Democrats should back the bill, which deserves bipartisan support.
President Clinton has had trouble finding a sure footing in his approach on China. He began in 1993 by making tough demands on human rights and now too often looks the other way on these issues. But the administration has reached a formula that is basically sound. Human rights are served, not hindered, by opening China to more foreign goods, particularly in telecommunications and technology, which are bound to bring more information from abroad to the Chinese people. China's membership in the World Trade Organization will allow more scrutiny of its treatment of workers, its record of piracy and even its treatment of the environment. 
 Since the late 19th century, the Democratic Party has stood for workers' interests, and it interpreted their interests as being served by free trade. It used to be that big American corporations favored high tariff barriers to protect themselves against cheaper foreign goods, but Democrats saw that workers are served not by insulating their employers from competition, but by food, clothing and other necessities sold here at low prices.
The bill before Congress does not open the United States to more Chinese products. Rather, it opens China to more American goods and investment, and imposes a mechanism that can be used to challenge unfair Chinese practices. Labor fears that more investment abroad will lead to less investment at home, and fewer jobs. But if American technology and manufacturing companies are not allowed to compete in China with other foreign investors, they will be less able to serve as healthy employers in the United States. Some American workers will doubtless be hurt by foreign competition. But the solution is to help these workers, not to try to block the forces of economic globalization that are benefiting the country.
Mr. Sweeney's reasons for taking on this issue may have more to do with his own political interests than those of workers at large. He won his election with the support of the Teamsters union and is now listening to the Teamsters on this issue. Other unions within the labor coalition are less enthusiastic about the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s wrongheaded stance. Many Democrats in Congress are angry that organized labor has also opposed lowering trade barriers for Africa and the Caribbean, where some of the most miserably paid workers in the world would benefit. Organized labor claims it is now standing up for Chinese workers by opposing the trade bill. But workers in the developing world know that trade is one of their only avenues of hope.
The trade bill could be Mr. Clinton's last tough legislative battle as president. His commendable willingness to stand up to labor and most members of his own party on trade belies his reputation as subservient to his party's core constituencies. On the other side of the aisle, Gov. George W. Bush has shown leadership in repudiating the isolationists in his own party. Organized labor's decision to turn this into a make-or-break test of loyalty for its supporters has been shortsighted and destructive.

LENGTH: 592 words

HEADLINE: Mr. Pataki's Nassau Travails

 BODY:
Nassau County on Long Island is one of the nation's wealthiest counties -- and also one of its most poorly governed. Years of irresponsible budget policies have brought it to the edge of bankruptcy. Earlier this month, Gov. George Pataki realized that allowing the county to sink into bankruptcy could damage the whole state's credit rating and undermine his own political standing. His proposal for an infusion of state money and a state financing agency to oversee the county is reminiscent of what Gov. Hugh Carey did for New York City in the 1970's. It was a welcome first step, but Mr. Pataki will have to step in more forcefully to help the county make extremely tough budget decisions in the future.
Like New York City's fiscal crisis of a generation ago, Nassau County's situation has resulted from the elected leaders' habit of piling up debt, rather than forcing taxpayers to foot the bill for their patronage-laden government. The Nassau County Republican organization prospered by handing out generous labor packages and patronage contracts, making it the envy of party leaders, governors and presidents. Last November, realizing that the cost of this system might force service cutbacks and tax increases, Nassau's voters revolted and elected the first Democratic legislature in modern history. Since then, Republicans and Democrats have been squabbling and barely nibbling at the edges of their problem. 
 Mr. Pataki appointed Frank Zarb, chairman of the group that runs Nasdaq, to make an independent review. He concluded that the county will need at least four years of stringent fiscal policies to reduce its budget deficit. Mr. Pataki's proposal of an oversight agency to issue debt and superintend budget savings could be taken up this week in the county legislature and later by the State Legislature in Albany. Democrats are supporting it in order to ensure that the governor bears some of the political heat for administering the bitter medicine. However, the governor, who would dominate the panel with his own appointees, should modify the plan to include participation by State Comptroller Carl McCall, a Democrat. Mr. McCall has been calling for reform in Nassau County for years and has an intimate knowledge of its finances.
Mr. Pataki's proposal would provide $100 million over five years to help the county out of its budget mess and require the county to present a plan to balance its budget in four years. Fiscal experts agree there is no way to achieve that goal without service cutbacks, major sacrifices by unions in the form of layoffs or givebacks on their contracts, a drastic cutback in other contracts that have been the patronage lifeblood of both parties, and very likely a tax increase of some kind, despite Governor Pataki's assertions that no tax increase will be necessary. In the process, the county has to thoroughly revamp its property tax system, which is riddled with unfairness and is costing $100 million each year in tax rebates.
The lesson of bankruptcy crises in New York City, Yonkers and Troy over the years is that tough steps must be negotiated in a spirit of shared sacrifice. Mr. Pataki is right to demand that the squabbling elected leaders in Nassau County try to come up with their own plans. But he may be naive to think they can avoid the need for him to intervene more firmly. New Yorkers throughout the state will understandably bridle at financial aid for such a rich county. But they may be willing to help if they see that the county is willing to change its ways.

HEADLINE: DATABANK: May 15-19;
How Much Higher Can Interest Rates Go?

BYLINE: By VIVIAN MARINO 

 BODY:
Wall Street just couldn't shake its interest-rate jitters last week, even though the Federal Reserve did what many had expected when it raised interest rates for the sixth time since last June.
 Investors are uncertain about whether the Fed will continue to increase rates and about the impact tighter credit might have on corporate earnings and stock prices. In raising short-term rates half a percentage point, the Fed indicated that inflation was still a risk because the economy continues to grow steadily. 
 Investors are concerned about how high interest rates are going, said Alfred E. Goldman, chief market strategist for A.G. Edwards & Sons. Is there some level where interest rates could derail the economic recovery?
 Such worries, Mr. Goldman said, slowed trading activity, which accentuated the market's volatility.
 The Nasdaq composite index ended the week at 3,390.40, down about 4 percent. The Dow Jones industrial average closed slightly higher, at 10,626.85, up 17.48 points.
 Financial stocks, which are vulnerable to interest rate fluctuations, were among the losers, including Merrill Lynch. VIVIAN MARINO

HEADLINE: Rallying Round the China Bill,Hungrily;
Rallying Round the China Bill, Hungrily

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

 BODY:
WHEN the House of Representatives this week tackles the issue of liberalizing trade ties with China, the voice of American business will be heard loud and clear.
Not since Newt Gingrich tried unsuccessfully in 1995 and 1996 to make liability laws more favorable to corporations have so many types of American companies banded together to lobby for a single issue, according to Bruce Josten, executive vice president of the United States Chamber of Commerce. From agricultural processors to Internet businesses, and from automakers to movie studios, corporate America sees profits in China. 
 In the lobbying effort, the bigger fish are leaning hard on the smaller ones. Companies that sell everything from cleaning supplies to titanium to Boeing -- even hot dogs to its employees -- may not seem like exporters. But with Boeing increasingly reliant on overseas aircraft sales, and convinced that China will become the world's fastest-growing aircraft market, the company has enlisted its parts makers to badger members of Congress.
The effort could be potent, for there is a supplier in nearly every pot. Boeing's 10,000 suppliers are spread across 420 of the nation's 435 Congressional districts -- a distribution that rivals that of even the most politically durable military program -- and Boeing has contacted them all.
"Every one of those suppliers is an exporter and should understand the importance of China, and we think they do," said Philip M. Condit, Boeing's chairman and chief executive, who has made 10 trips to Washington this year. "You're just running an all-out campaign."
Trying to counter the corporate effort, unions and environmental and other advocacy groups have organized demonstrations, started letter-writing campaigns and sent supporters to Washington by the busload. But American business has responded with its own mobilization, using connections to lawmakers forged over years of nickel-and-dime lobbying.
The pact has wide corporate support because it would require China to lower tariffs, end restrictive business rules and dismantle many other trade barriers. The United States, in turn, would halt its annual Congressional reviews of China's access to the American market. Those reviews have often focused on human rights and have made some American companies leery of long-term investments.
Farmers and equipment makers want lower tariffs on American grain. Insurers, banks and brokerage houses want to eliminate licensing requirements that turn any hope of entry into China into a multiyear marathon of wining and dining government officials.
Automakers want an end to China's requirement that 80 percent of the parts in any car built there be made in China. Retailers are eager to import far more low-priced clothing from China. Hollywood, drug makers and high-technology businesses want improved protections against the illegal copying of movies, medicines and software.
"In terms of government regulation and intervention, we'd like it to be the minimum necessary," said Robert M. Kimmitt, vice chairman and president of Commerce One in Pleasanton, Calif., which has already set up business-to-business Internet exchanges in the United States and is trying to do so in China, too.
The normalization of trade would bring all this and more as China seeks to integrate its economy more closely with the global market by joining the World Trade Organization. Membership in the W.T.O. would require Beijing to comply with extraordinarily detailed free-trade rules, which extend far beyond tariffs and duties to cover most everything from intellectual property rights to the freedom granted to companies to set up their own distribution networks. Proponents say full entry into the world market will make China more prosperous, more open and less prone to abusing human rights.
"We tend to favor free trade and we also think that if we really do want to progress in human rights within China, one of the ways to do that is to actually open up trade," said Jacques Nasser, the chief executive of the Ford Motor Company.
American labor leaders and their allies reject the executives' reasoning. The United States, they say, would lose its ability to influence human rights in China, particularly because the bill would eliminate the annual votes in Congress on trade ties -- votes that have sometimes prompted China to ease policies.
Still fuming over the North American Free Trade Agreement, which they blame for a loss of jobs to Mexico, union presidents are even more fearful of free trade with the world's largest low-wage country. Stephen Yokich, president of the United Automobile Workers, said Congressional approval would "give American corporations an incentive again to ship jobs, this time to China, which is even cheaper."
But while unions worry about losing jobs, American companies fret about losing markets. "We have the potential of a 100-fold increase in travel per person in a country of 1.2 billion people, and that's a huge market," Mr. Condit said.
The trade deal, he contended, poses a question from China to America: "Is the U.S. a reliable trade partner and can we buy airplanes from Boeing, or is it not a reliable trade partner and do we look to Europe?"
Following are closer looks by reporters for The New York Times at how various industries would be affected by a new China trade agreement.

HEADLINE: Rallying Round the China Bill, Hungrily: Entertainment;
Hollywood Wants A Bigger Box Office

BYLINE: By RICK LYMAN 

 BODY:
The entertainment industry -- especially Hollywood -- has been enthusiastic about easing trade barriers with China and has been pushing hard for the trade bill. There are two reasons: China is a huge potential market, even if few American movies are now released there. And studios worry that rejection of the bill would prompt Beijing to spitefully cancel the fledgling trade agreements already in place.
"Our trade with China is minuscule," said Jack Valenti, president of the Motion Picture Association of America, which represents studios. "The reason we are passionately in favor of the trade bill has far more to do with the long-range future." 
 Until last summer, China limited United States companies to exporting 10 movies a year there, with the studios keeping half the revenue and China the remainder. On the other hand, there was no limit to how many films the studios could simply sell to Chinese distributors. In recent years, 40 to 50 films made outside China, mostly small independent ones, have been sold for flat fees there.
Hollywood studios, however, are not interested in flat fees. They want a continuous share of the loot.
Last summer, President Clinton's trade negotiators reached a new deal that doubled, to 20, the number of American movies that could be imported, with promises of further increases in future years. That is still small potatoes by Hollywood standards, but a step in what the studios consider the right direction.
The studios now do about $25 million of business a year in China. That is a tiny fraction of what would start flowing in if most movies were given a Chinese release and if lower trade barriers continued to expand a Chinese middle class hungry for such diversions.
Some entertainment conglomerates have negotiated separate commercial deals with China. Disney is planning a new theme park in Hong Kong, and Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation has an extensive telecommunications agreement.
Another issue is theaters. Most in China are in sad shape. The nation has been eager to attract foreign investment in new cinemas, but foreigners are limited to a minority share of any operation.
Again, not good enough for Hollywood. "We're not going to buy any theaters until we own them," Mr. Valenti said. "And we're not going to put more money into theaters if they're not letting in more American pictures." Under a new agreement, foreigners could own a controlling interest in new Chinese multiplexes within three years.
Video piracy is also a source of irritation. Even Hollywood films not released in China are often quickly available through bootleg sources. Then, of course, not a penny of revenue flows back to the studios.
In recent years, American trade officials say, the Chinese have clamped down more vigorously on bootleggers. Bringing more Hollywood movies into China, along with more multiplexes, would give the Chinese authorities reason to crack down harder, entertainment executives contend.
"If Congress votes no, my judgment is that all the agreements we have made will be null and void," Mr. Valenti said. "I mean, would you keep an agreement with someone who just exiled you and kicked you on the backside?" RICK LYMAN 
http://www.nytimes.com

HEADLINE: Rallying Round the China Bill, Hungrily: Textiles;
Cheaper Clothing, But at What Price?

BYLINE: By LESLIE KAUFMAN 

 BODY:
Americans love to get fashion on the cheap. Even with the economy booming, they are snapping up more $4.99 cotton T-shirts and Indian print sundresses than ever.
And shoppers are not being tricked into getting less. They have actually been winning the war on costs. Over all, apparel prices have fallen about 1 percent a year throughout most of the 1990's. Last year, prices fell even more. 
 The main reason that Americans pay so little for products from blue jeans to sneakers is that manufacturing jobs have been shipped wholesale to countries with cheap labor -- countries like China. Long before the trade agreement was negotiated, employment in the American apparel and textile industries was already plunging. Together, the two industries employed 1.2 million people in this country as of January of this year, according to the Union of Needletrades, Industrial and Textile Employees. That is down from 2.5 million in 1973, the peak employment year for apparel workers.
There is little doubt that the trend toward exporting sewing jobs has been helped by earlier trade agreements that lowered tariffs and expanded quotas. Union data shows that in the 36 months before Nafta took effect, the United States lost 2,000 apparel jobs. During the following 36 months, the loss was 134,000.
But because so many jobs have already disappeared, the effect on manufacturing still based in the United States may not be as severe in the future -- even the union predicts a loss of 15,000 jobs a year at most. The real impact of the China agreement -- which allows it to participate in the phasing out of nation-by-nation quotas on clothing imports to the United States by 2005 -- is likely to fall mostly on other Asian countries that will not be able to compete with China's even lower-cost labor.
When judging China's importance, consider that Wal-Mart Stores, the nation's largest importer, already gets 53 percent of its clothing imports from China, according to a study of United States Customs Department documents by the Citizens Trade Campaign, which is critical of the company and opposed to the China trade agreement. Wal-Mart refuses to give specifics on its imports, but a spokesman, Jay Allen, acknowledged that the company contracts directly with "several thousand factories."
Once China joins the World Trade Organization, the retail industry says, there will be gains at home to offset the job losses abroad. Most important, executives argue, are the tariff cuts will allow them to sell more to China. "We see a great market opportunity," said Candyce Cummings, general counsel of the VF Corporation, maker of Lee and Wrangler clothing. LESLIE KAUFMAN
 
http://www.nytimes.com
