HEADLINE: Rallying Round the China Bill, Hungrily: Financial Services;
Investment Capital And Car Loans, Too?

BYLINE: By PATRICK McGEEHAN 

 BODY:
It would be hard to find legislation that has been embraced so unconditionally by America's financial institutions as the China trade bill. Whether they think they have more to gain from its passage or to lose from its failure, they have been lobbying hard.
Companies with commercial banking operations, like Citigroup, salivate over the prospect of providing auto loans and other services. Investment banks are more concerned that rejection could chill relations with Chinese officials who have begun to tap foreign capital markets. 
 New York companies have played leading roles in raising capital for several state-run enterprises, including the initial public offering this month for PetroChina.
Fresh from political skirmishes over that underwriting, Henry M. Paulson, chairman of Goldman Sachs, said rejection of the bill could hurt his firm's chances of advising on future privatizations. But he is more worried that client companies would not play as big a part in China's economic development.
"We don't need any changes in the rules to work on privatizations and other assignments," he said.
Goldman Sachs advises the Chinese government and sells foreign securities in China. But the firm does not have an investment bank there, as it does in Japan, because the American company would be limited to a minority stake.
Commercial banks are much more eager to expand their physical operations in China. Citibank has only four branches there and cannot do business in local currency.
"There essentially is no consumer banking system in China," said Lionel Johnson, Citigroup's director of international government relations. "People have very limited relationships with banks, limited opportunities to invest their savings."
While China is expected to remain wary of anything that threatens the stability of its state-run banks, all that is supposed to start changing within five years under the trade pact, potentially giving Citibank and other foreign banks an even chance to compete with domestic banks for tens of millions of consumers. The banks see an opportunity to lend money to Chinese customers for big-ticket purchases, especially cars. They also anticipate being able to decide where to put branches, instead of having the government assign the sites.
"For the first time," Mr. Johnson said, "market forces will make those decisions." PATRICK McGEEHAN

HEADLINE: Rallying Round the China Bill, Hungrily: High Technology;
Intellectual Property And Other Issues

BYLINE: By SARA ROBINSON and SETH SCHIESEL 

 BODY:
To the high-technology industry, China is a vast emerging market that is virtually out of reach. Analysts estimate that China will soon be one of the three largest markets for computers, software and Internet products. While companies like Motorola, Advanced Micro Devices and Intel have some operations there, they say Chinese regulations and lax intellectual property protections significantly interfere with their ability to do business.
If the trade bill does not pass, the industry says, China will become a World Trade Organization member but will not be treated as such by the United States and thus will not have to follow the group's rules when dealing with Washington. 
 "What we negotiated will go to our non-American competitors," said James F. Whittaker, chairman of the U.S. High Tech Coalition on China, a lobbying group based in Washington. "We will be at a severe disadvantage in one of the most important markets in the world."
Critics, including labor organizations, are concerned that high-technology companies will exploit China's large pool of skilled engineers and weak labor protections and move jobs overseas. Chuck Mulloy, an Intel spokesman, noted, however, that while 60 percent of Intel's revenues came from abroad, 70 percent of its work force was in the United States. "Success in China," he said, "can help create jobs in the United States."
Telecommunications is also seen as a potential bonanza for American companies. Arthur L. Kobler, president of the China operation for AT&T, expects China's roughly $50 billion communications market to double by 2004, fueled largely by an explosion in wireless telephone use.
"Sometime this year or next year, China will become the second-largest wireless market, behind the United States but ahead of Japan," Mr. Kobler said. "China is a market that you cannot not be in."
For now, though, China's extensive restrictions on foreign business operations severely limit American high-technology and telecommunications companies. Foreign-made products are subject to high tariffs. Yet foreign companies that want to produce in China face restrictions on what parts they can buy from abroad and are permitted to distribute their products within China only through local distributors. State-owned enterprises control a significant share of the trade in electronics goods, and American companies complain that they give preference to higher-cost Chinese suppliers.
That could change soon. In the bilateral pact reached in November, China agreed to phase out tariffs and other restrictions and to immediately become subject to the W.T.O.'s patent and copyright rules. That provides tremendous opportunities not only to the United States but also to China, said David I. Levine, a professor at the Walter A. Haas School of Business at the University of California at Berkeley.
"High tech," he said, "is one instance of the general theory that if you want to learn from the rest of the world, you trade with them."
Communications services are likely to be an important part of that trade. Moreover, the opportunity to sell services to Chinese businesses and consumers may well be surpassed by the chance to win over big foreign corporations that want to link their Chinese operations with their other units. SARA ROBINSON and SETH SCHIESEL
 
http://www.nytimes.com

GRAPHIC: Photo: In a ceremony in Shanghai last September, the 10,000th Buick produced at the Shanghai General Motors plant rolls off the assembly line. (Associated Press)
 
Chart: "Trade Concessions"
If the United States agrees to end its Congressional oversight on human rights issues, China will knock down many barriers to foreign trade and investments.
 
CHINA AGREES TO...
 
TARIFFS -- China will reduce average tariffs from 22.1 percent to 17 percent.
TELECOMMUNICATIONS -- American telephone companies may own 49 percent of Chinese telephone service providers, increasing to 50 percent in two years. The United States had wanted 51 percent.
INTERNET -- Foreigners may invest in Chinese Internet businesses.
DISTRIBUTION -- Foreigners may establish their own product distribution systems and sell directly to Chinese consumers.
SERVICES -- Foreigners may establish their own repair and maintenance service businesses in China.
FILM IMPORTS -- China will double the number of American film imports, to 20 annually.
BANKING/FINANCIAL SERVICES -- Foreign banks may offer services to Chinese customers in two years. China will allow foreigners to own 33 percent of other financial service providers, and later 49 percent.
VEHICLE SALES -- China will reduce taxes on imports and permit foreign automakers to sell to Chinese customers and finance their purchases.
FARM PRODUCTS -- In addition to lowering tariffs, China will eliminate subsidies of exports.
 
U.S. AGREES TO...
HUMAN RIGHTS -- United States will drop its annual Congressional vote on the issue, putting in its place a commission to regularly review China's human rights record.
ANTI-DUMPING -- The United States will retain safeguards for 12 years to prevent a surge in inexpensive Chinese imports.
TEXTILES -- In joining the World Trade Organization, China will receive the benefits of a global pact that calls for the United States to phase out by 2005 quotas on all apparel and textile imports.

HEADLINE: Study to Develop Way to Monitor Cancer Care

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE K. ALTMAN 

DATELINE: NEW ORLEANS, May 20

 BODY:
Responding to a call to improve the quality of cancer care in the United States, a leading cancer organization said here today that it was working with other groups to develop a national system to monitor how well each cancer patient is treated.
The effort will begin this summer when researchers from Harvard University and the RAND Corporation begin examining the medical records of 600 patients to determine their outcomes from two types of cancer. 
 The first phase will be conducted in Cleveland, Houston and Los Angeles and will involve 300 people with breast cancer and an additional 300 patients with cancer of the colon and rectum, the study's leaders said at the opening of a meeting here of the American Society of Clinical Oncologists, the leading group of cancer specialists in this country.
The ultimate goal is to develop specific measures of quality spanning the entire course of care, from diagnosis to cure or death. Such measures could then be used to hold health care providers accountable for the quality of cancer care. An estimated 1.2 million Americans will develop cancer this year. Cancer is second to heart disease as a cause of death among Americans and one of the most expensive diseases to treat.
Breast and colo-rectal cancers were chosen because consensus for their care is greater than for other major cancers, said Dr. Deborah Kamin, the oncologist group's director of public policy.
The Susan G. Komen Breast Cancer Foundation is the study's major sponsor, paying about half of the $2 million cost. Other contributors are groups representing surgeons, radiation therapists, nurses and the drug industry.
The three cities were chosen to provide a representative look at how different minority populations are treated. The study may be expanded to other cities to include 2,000 patients and possibly lung cancer if an additional $1 million is found, Dr. Kamin said in an interview.
Cases will be chosen at random among those whose cancer was discovered two years ago, thus allowing enough time to complete a first round of therapy. Some patients may be in relapse and others may be dead.
Because each patient may have received care at more than one medical center, the study could involve as many as 10 hospitals in each city. As is standard, the researchers will obtain permission from an ethics committee at each hospital before examining records and interviewing patients.
After determining whether therapy was intended for cure or palliation, the researchers will seek information about the therapies offered and given at each critical decision-making step in the patients' care.
Among the questions: Did surgeons recommend consultations with an oncologist? If treatment involved chemotherapy, were the correct drugs chosen and given in the proper amount? Was pain relief achieved? Was hospice care offered? And how well managed were other end-of-life care options?
Also, the researchers will interview the same patients to correlate what they say they were told with what doctors, nurses, nutritionists and other health professionals wrote in the records.
Patients and their families will be asked: Were all appropriate medical options explained and choices given? For example, were the patients offered radiation therapy after breast conserving therapy? Were doctors available when needed to answer questions and offer care? Did doctors recommend entering a clinical trial to evaluate newer therapies? Did the patients join a support group?
The oncology group's president, Dr. Joseph S. Bailes, who practices in Houston, said the effort was in response to a report released in April 1999 by the Institute of Medicine of the National Academy of Sciences. In addressing issues in the prevention, control, diagnosis, treatment and palliation of cancer, the institute said that there was "a growing lack of public confidence" in the nation's system of fragmented cancer care.
"There is no national cancer care program or system of care in the United States," the report said. It also said that the government had numerous cancer programs and research, "but in no one place are these disparate efforts coordinated or even described."
A substantial, but unmeasured, number of cancer patients do not receive care known to be effective for their condition, the medical institute said, and the reasons for failure to deliver high quality care could come from overuse, underuse or misuse of proper therapy but have not been studied adequately.
Conducting clinical trials to determine the safety and effectiveness of therapies is a first step in assessing quality. But too few patients participate in such trials even though studies show that routine care costs in cancer clinical trials are no more than in standard care, cancer experts have said. 
http://www.nytimes.com

HEADLINE: Washington Mayor Gets Things Done Quietly

BYLINE: By FRANCIS X. CLINES 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 20

 BODY:
If all continues to go well, the nation's capital will be allowed out of the intensive care ward fashioned by Congress sometime next year. The District of Columbia will not only regain home-rule prerogatives lost in its profligate past; it will also confirm the stewardship of Mayor Anthony A. Williams, an unlikely politician as bland in his style as the paint on the municipal walls.
"There's a sea change from four years ago," the mayor said, his zest characteristically masked as he pursued a budget fight with the district council and tackled a school crisis. He hailed these problems as a healthy sign of the revival of local respectability. 
 "Here we are debating not whether we're going to spend the city into the ground or not," Mr. Williams said. "The new question is how much we're going to invest in the future."
This city-state by the Potomac, the perennial ward that Congress seems delighted to scold and micromanage, is clearly moving to a higher ground of civic morale. Constituents' confidence about the city's direction has more than doubled in the less than two years of the Williams administration, with 7 in 10 residents feeling positive about the city's course, according to polls of the district's often demoralized public.
Even more important, some of the watchdogs of Capitol Hill are snapping less.
"Mayor Williams is making real progress in turning around Washington," said Senator Kay Bailey Hutchison, the Texas Republican who heads the District of Columbia subcommittee.
Mr. Williams arrived here in 1995 as a grim technocrat and emergency budget cutter when Congress created a board of financial overseers to halt the capital's spiral of deficits and mismanagement and hired him as chief financial officer. From that narrow opportunity, he molted into a competitive politician and became the people's choice in a difficult time.
In his 16 months of incumbency, the 48-year-old mayor has labored to replace the city's wastrel image of the flamboyant Marion Barry era with his own jot-and-tittle devotion to quiet executive techniques. In a way, the best measure of Mr. Williams's initial success may be the fact that he is sometimes criticized for lacking the populist flash of Mr. Barry.
"He suffers from terminal caution," complained Mark Plotkin, a relentless civic goad and the political commentator for the local public radio station WAMU. Mr. Plotkin made the mayor sound like Calvin Coolidge, complimenting him for installing "rectitude and calm" in the city but faulting him for failing to fully tap the energy of his electoral mandate and "take us to another plane" by fighting with passion for needs like full self-rule and voting rights for the city's Congressional delegate.
"Well, we've had flair before," the district council chairwoman, Linda W. Cropp, said of the Barry era. She expressed no regret for the businesslike Williams style, even as she confronts him in the budget fight.
"He's given the district a sense of hope that things can happen," Ms. Cropp said. "He has many wonderful ideas, although when it comes to implementing them he's still on a learning curve."
Major problems like the tattered school system and persistent youth violence are far from solved. But the mayor and the council seem resolved to innovate: they are presenting the voters a referendum next month to give the mayor a role in school management through the power to appoint some members of the school board. They are also on the way to delivering four balanced budgets in a row, the required formula for regaining home-rule powers after years of chimerical bookkeeping.
In this endeavor, Mr. Williams has assiduously avoided what in the Barry era came to be known as "the race card" -- harvesting the vote of the divided district's black working-class majority by playing off the affluent white minority.
"I would never personally use race as an excuse for anything," said Mr. Williams, a Yale graduate. In an interview, he emphasized his obligation to unify and not to deal with the criticism, by now a cliche, that he might not be "black enough" for a city that is 60 percent black.
"I'm not saying it's not appropriate for others," he said of racial complaints. "But I've been given a lot of opportunities and advantages where I'm sure I can personally say race plays a role."
The mayor stressed that Washington "is still very fractured and divided." But he insisted that unheralded programs of mutual good will crisscross the Anacostia River, the city's main racial dividing line. He maintained that a recent increase in auto registrations indicated the viability of his goal of gaining 100,000 residents in this decade, including returning suburbanites attracted by the district's walkable neighborhoods and burnished housing stock.
Across the Anacostia in one of the low-income southeast wards that are part of the black political power base, the new mayor, despite his ruling-class aura, occasioned no great complaint at Brace's Unisex salon on Minnesota Avenue.
"Mayor Barry was a great people person," Alice Taylor said. "This new mayor is working at a different angle. But he's doing O.K."
Her friend Clara Sherrod agreed. "Barry was a street politician who knew our problems," she said. "But I'd say the streets are really looking better with Williams. He's having grass planted around here and cleaning up things."
Over in Georgetown, part of the district's white power base in the northwest quarter, there is palpable pleasure at the way the Williams bow tie is replacing the Barry dashiki as a D.C. signature. "He's made the city a lot more presentable," said Pat Scanlon, a volunteer at the Christ Child Opportunity Shop, a consignment store on Wisconsin Avenue that finances local charities.
Nearby, a white customer who would not give his name grumbled: "He still thinks this is a black city and packs the payroll with his own. What about us?"
"Well, it is a black city," Ms. Scanlon responded. "So what's wrong with hiring your people who are qualified so they work and pay taxes and have nice houses?"
In the Barry years, the payroll for the district, which must provide a mix of state and city services, was criticized as a strategic patronage trough when it ballooned to 50,000 employees for a city of 550,000. It has been cut since the fiscal crisis was declared five years ago; this year it reached a Congressionally authorized level of 32,719, a reduction of 1,450 from last year, although Mr. Williams wants it still lower.
"Running this city is like Roebling trying to build the Brooklyn Bridge and digging and digging for the bedrock," he said in frustration. He said he kept uncovering the "muck" of old corruption as he tried to reform such scandal-ridden agencies as the mental retardation treatment program, whose lethal failures were laid bare by The Washington Post.
"My answer is what I call agency bypass surgery," he said of a radical plan to create an entire new treatment agency alongside the existing failed system to supersede it.
The depth of these past failures has prompted Eleanor Holmes Norton, the district's Congressional delegate, to caution that any criticism of Mayor Williams "should be tempered by the disaster disguised as a city" that he inherited.
"He's making this city work," Ms. Norton said. "He's what we needed -- a mayor who came to office who had done something other than run for office."
While he is portrayed as an un-politician who is making the city forget the slick Barry era, Mr. Williams actually apprenticed seriously in practical politics as an elected member of the New Haven board of aldermen when he was studying at Yale for his undergraduate degree in economics. Twenty years later, he is not above artfully stroking his Capitol Hill watchdogs; he even attended a fund-raiser for an influential conservative Republican, Representative Ernest Istook of Oklahoma.
"I've got to look out for my people, you know," the mayor explained, unapologetic about becoming the complete practitioner in the nation's ultimate political city.

HEADLINE: Former Critics Of Trade Bill Are Swaying Vote in House

BYLINE: By JOSEPH KAHN 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 20

 BODY:
If the China trade bill slips through Congress this week, as some supporters now expect, Sander M. Levin, a Democrat who has voted against all of President Clinton's major trade initiatives, will -- ironically -- take some credit for helping provide the margin of victory.
Mr. Levin won backing from House leaders late last week to amend the bill granting China permanent trade ties to establish a human rights and trade policy monitoring commission for China. Vote counters on both sides of the aisle said the proposal, co-sponsored by Doug Bereuter, a Nebraska Republican, has helped recruit perhaps two dozen undecided lawmakers into the pro-trade camp. 
 China has called the proposed commission an interference in its internal affairs. The Republican leadership had been cool to the idea. Clinton administration officials had kept their distance. Labor unions and some human rights groups have called it weak.
But Mr. Levin's proposal has proved crucial to Democrats, and a few Republicans, who have found it politically impossible to vote for trade deals in recent years because labor unions and consumer groups oppose them so strongly. If critics call it a fig leaf, supporters are hailing it as an innovative tool to keep political pressure on China even while granting it long-sought guaranteed trade access to the United States market.
"I waited to see what he would come up with before I decided," said Diana L. DeGette, a Colorado Democrat who announced her support for the Clinton administration's top remaining legislative priority after Mr. Levin detailed the commission's structure on Friday. "My constituents care a great deal about human rights and want to see something done on this front."
The idea was modeled on the Helsinki Commission, which inspected human rights conditions behind the Iron Curtail during the cold war. Mr. Levin envisions that Congress and the White House will appoint high-level commissioners, including members of Congress and distinguished outsiders, who could monitor conditions in China and report to both branches.
Each year, the commission would issue a report recommending legislative or administrative steps that might help raise pressure on China to improve its human rights conditions, though it would not have the power to enforce its recommendations. The commission could study ways of turning up the heat on Beijing that are not inconsistent with the World Trade Organization, including some kinds of sanctions and United States policy toward loans from international aid agencies.
A second part of the Levin-Bereuter proposal enacts into law provisions that would help the United States fight sudden surges of imports from China. Both provisions won backing from the Republican leadership last week, which agreed to include them as part of the bill that would grant China permanent trade status. A vote in the House is expected to take place Wednesday.
Mr. Levin represents a heavily unionized district of Michigan. With unions increasingly wary of trade deals that open markets and threaten industrial jobs, he has not met many trade agreements he likes. He voted against the North American Free Trade Agreement in 1994.
He said he decided late last year to find an alternative to a straight vote on China's trade status. He said he wanted to "reshape globalization" so that trade deals would promote human values, not just the free shipments of goods.
"It seems to me that trade and globalization can be forces for good, and we can't stop them," Mr. Levin said. "But we have to shape them. In China's case, you can't just vote yes and trust that social and economic changes will come along together."
Labor unions and consumer groups have criticized the proposal as ineffective.
"It's a well-meaning effort," said Thea Lee, a senior official at the A.F.L.-C.I.O. and an outspoken opponent of the China trade bill. "But it's redundant with what's already done and may even be counterproductive."
Some human rights groups are less dismissive, though many say that the Levin commission could be much stronger if it had the power to force a Congressional vote on its recommendations each year.
"It could be stronger, and we think that there's a chance it will be stronger before this is finished," said Mike Jendrzejczyk of Human Rights Watch in New York.
Mr. Jendrzejczyk said the Helsinki Commission had real influence on Soviet bloc nations, but that China, unlike the former Soviet Union and Eastern Europe, had not signed a treaty permitting review and inspection of human rights.

HEADLINE: As Political Crisis Mounts, Peru's Leader Relishes Fight

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS 

DATELINE: LIMA, Peru, May 20

 BODY:
Taking a moment's break from a boisterous campaign rally the other day in the colonial city of Cajamarca, President Alberto K. Fujimori pointed to a dark cloud gliding over his head and cried, "Let there be rain for the farmers!"
Within moments, the sky poured open, and thousands cheered. 
 "Don't worry," Mr. Fujimori laughed into his microphone. "Everything is coordinated."
It has often seemed that way over the last 10 years, as Mr. Fujimori effectively confronted an array of plagues -- from hyperinflation to terrorism to an invasion of narcotics traffickers, from war with Ecuador to massive flooding caused by El Nino.
But only a day after Mr. Fujimori played with the clouds over Cajamarca, he faced a mounting political crisis that will surely challenge his considerable pluck and power. Alejandro Toledo, his opponent in the May 28 runoff presidential election, dropped out of the race on Thursday. Mr. Fujimori was left with an open field for victory and the prospect of a third five-year term, but one in which his legitimacy and credibility would be questioned both here and abroad.
Mr. Fujimori now faces the possibility of unending protest marches, criticism from Washington and other foreign capitals, and even, perhaps, economic sanctions from the United States Congress and the Organization of American States that could impede his fight against drug trafficking and unemployment.
The 61-year-old president, who is the son of Japanese immigrants, was able to face down international pressures after he suspended the operations of his own Congress and Supreme Court in 1992 because he had overwhelming popular support. But now Peru is badly split, with university students and labor unions preparing to mount the biggest street protests in more than a generation.
Mr. Fujimori, in effect, has become a victim of his own success. Now that he has virtually defeated the terrorists of the Maoist Shining Path, a growing number of Peruvians are seeking an easing of his authoritarianism. In the last three years, even as the terrorism waned, Mr. Fujimori did not ease his hold on power. He tightened it.
Mr. Fujimori decided he could run for re-election this year even though the Constitution prohibits three consecutive terms. He had three judges dismissed by Congress when they disagreed with his legal interpretation that the constitutional term limit did not cover his first term because it was completed before the Constitution itself. He then established control over several television networks through legal maneuvers, and withdrew Peru from the jurisdiction of a regional human rights court.
Mr. Fujimori's powers were amply on display in the first round of the presidential race when all television networks, save for one cable channel, virtually boycotted his opposition.
"He has been manipulating so much that even if he won fairly, people wouldn't believe it was a fair process," said Enrique Zileri, editor of the political magazine Caretas. "Whatever happens, Fujimori becomes a much weaker president who will be discredited internationally."
Hernan Chaparro Melo, a pollster, said, "With 57 percent of the people continuing to believe the election process is unjust, we are entering difficult times."
But Mr. Fujimori has had his back to the wall before, and he has always shown himself to be a leader of great resourcefulness and impeccable timing.
Over the last few weeks, Mr. Fujimori suddenly emerged from his early campaign slumber and appeared eager for a fight. He told enthusiastic campaign rallies with growing crowds that he would not accept a postponement of the election even before Mr. Toledo demanded that the vote be put off several weeks to give foreign election observers time to test new computer software installed to count the vote.
Mr. Fujimori sharpened his message on television and on the stump, arguing more forcefully that he is the one candidate strong enough to lead this desperately poor and often chaotic country. Taking on his greatest weaknesses, he pledged an all-out attack on unemployment and confronted his foreign critics with diatribes designed to inspire Peruvian nationalism.
"We don't need foreigners to tell us how to hold elections," Mr. Fujimori told a crowd in the city of Trujillo shortly after Mr. Toledo's announcement that he was dropping out of the race if the election was not postponed. "We're sovereign Peruvians and we have the right to hold our democracy."
And after underestimating Mr. Toledo, an American-educated business school professor who rose meteorically in the weeks before the first round vote, Mr. Fujimori finally began taking him on -- calling him a rudderless, indecisive leader who only knows how to turn to Washington, Buenos Aires and European capitals for political direction.
Mr. Fujimori's old magic was amply on display this week as he toured the north of the country. He laughed, danced and gleefully tossed cassettes of his campaign songs to passersby who thrilled at seeing their president.
As his campaign caravan twisted through the streets of Chiclayo, a local witchdoctor livened the proceedings by cavorting before the president's campaign truck, waving a giant pumpkin and spritzing some alcoholic brew through his teeth and onto the swelling crowds.
And as a brass band played his campaign theme song, Mr. Fujimori went into a fevered jig on the stump as a throng of more than 10,000 went wild. "My advisers tell me I shouldn't dance," President Fujimori laughed, "but I can't help myself!" It was the kind of populist touch that led him to landslide victories in 1990 and 1995.
Speaking in his heavily accented English for effect, he told the crowd, "They ask: 'What is happening in Peru?' " Then answering the question firmly in Spanish, he said, "We've had a government the last 10 years that has been decisive and has never ducked the tough issues."
To crowds that filled the central plaza of Cajamarca, a highland city of magnificent baroque churches, luscious cheeses and lyrical poets where the Incas made their first stand against the Spanish invaders in the 16th century, Mr. Fujimori called on the crowd to cheer loud enough so the Argentine government could hear.
Donning a tall straw hat popular with the Indian peasants here, he snickered at Mr. Toledo for traveling earlier in the week to Buenos Aires to consult with President Fernando de la Rua and former President Raul Alfonsin.
Speaking of his opponents, he said: "If they were really democrats and really trusted the people, they wouldn't complain all the time in Washington and Buenos Aires. They show by going abroad that they don't care about the votes of the Peruvian people."
Sharpening the nationalistic argument is Francisco Tudela, a former foreign minister and Mr. Fujimori's vice presidential candidate. "I think there is a fear, an ideological fear, of a very independent government in Latin America that is outside the establishment," Mr. Tudela said in an interview. He added, "The fact that President Fujimori did not negotiate with terrorist groups irritates some abroad."

HEADLINE: THE RACE FOR SENATE: THE MAYOR;
A Legacy in the Balance

BYLINE: By JOYCE PURNICK 

 BODY:
If Rudolph W. Giuliani quit the mayoralty tomorrow, he would leave behind a city that is safer and more prosperous than it was when he took over City Hall in 1994.
A solid legacy, but a narrow one, especially since New York City's prosperity is linked closely to the thriving national economy and crime is down all over the Giuliani-less country. And the mayor's image is marred by a reputation for insensitivity, especially racial insensitivity. 
 So it makes perfect sense that Mr. Giuliani wants to devote the next year and a half to being "a better mayor," as he said on Friday when he withdrew from the Senate race -- to build on his successes and knock down the barriers he concedes he may have erected between his administration and many minority New Yorkers.
If revising his legacy is indeed the objective of the newly introspective-sounding mayor, the issues are out there waiting for him. He faces the skepticism of people who have heard similar commitments from him before, only to see them go nowhere. He may also find that he gets less attention than he used to. Nothing collapses as quickly as the prominence of a politician about to lose his platform.
"Who cares what he says?" asked H. Carl McCall, the state comptroller and likely candidate for governor in 2002. "He's a lame duck. He's on his way out. People are going to focus on the Senate race and who is going to be the next mayor. If he'd done this two or three years ago, fine, but he has already put his mark on history."
The comptroller recalled the mayor's pledge to reach out to minorities when he was running for re-election in 1997. He did not do so for a year, until Amadou Diallo, an unarmed African immigrant, was killed by police officers. Then he met with Mr. McCall and others. "Then I never heard from him again," Mr. McCall said.
But Mr. Giuliani still has 19 months in office. His health allowing, he can do a lot even if hampered by skepticism and the dimming of the spotlight. There is everything from the symbolic -- removing all those barricades around City Hall before the next mayor does -- to matters as complex as expanding health insurance coverage, a new Giuliani goal.
Some issues have been pending a long time. One of the most problematic for this mayor has been improving relations between the Police Department and minority groups in the city, especially in the aftermath of the shooting deaths of Mr. Diallo and Patrick M. Dorismond.
"I wrote to him last week, said this is the time to drop his opposition to the independent police board," said Peter F. Vallone, the City Council speaker. "That would be great not only for the future of the city, but would have a strong impact on the city right now." Creating an oversight board might also be a way of responding to a recent report by the United States Civil Rights Commission, which accuses the police of racial profiling.
But the police commissioner, Howard Safir, rebuffed Mr. Vallone last week, and the speaker has yet to hear from the mayor, who is still fighting his idea in court.
Many other matters are before the mayor now, especially one that always tops the list of issues people care about in public opinion polls: education. The city's contract with the United Federation of Teachers is in negotiations, as are all municipal union contracts. The mayor has focused on a merit pay plan for teachers -- rewarding individual teachers with bonuses tied to higher student test scores. That is anathema to the teachers' union, which considers merit pay divisive and subjective. Nobody familiar with the powerful teachers' union gives the idea a realistic chance of success.
"He can say, 'I'd like individual merit pay, but I know it's a nonstarter, so let's come together on a group plan,' " suggested Mark Green, the public advocate, referring to merit pay for the faculties of entire schools rather than for individual teachers.
The mayor could also call for reduced class sizes and find the financial resources to make that possible -- dropping his proposal to cut the income tax surcharge and dedicating the income to schools, for instance.
He has often said he wants to eliminate the Board of Education; so does Mr. Vallone. Both want the school system to be under direct city control. The two could lobby for change in Albany, on schools and on another central issue -- getting the State Legislature to raise New York City's debt limit and allow the city to borrow more. If it cannot, projects like construction of schools are in trouble. "Now that he no longer has to worry what they think of him in Syracuse and Buffalo, he could do more; he's never been up there with me," Mr. Vallone said.
Mr. Giuliani said on Friday that he had become more sensitive to the importance of expanding health insurance coverage. That is not exclusively a city issue. But the mayor could channel more city money to the municipal hospitals, the refuge of many poor uninsured New Yorkers. The hospitals have lost a great deal of city financing in the last decade.
He could mobilize city agencies to encourage more people to enroll in a newly expanded state program for low-income New Yorkers -- Child Health Plus and Family Health Plus. Health care experts estimate that a half-million city residents are eligible but unenrolled.
As he reconsiders his mayoralty, Mr. Giuliani might look again at his policy requiring single homeless adults to work in exchange for shelter. That was shot down by a State Supreme Court judge, but the decision is now on appeal by the Giuliani administration.
The city is also still planning to deny shelter to parents who do not comply with city requirements -- participating in workfare, for instance; their children would go into foster care if shelter were denied. That plan is on hold, pending court action, but is still official city policy.
These approaches have led to broad criticism, and to Leno-Letterman caricatures of a heartless mayor. Mr. Giuliani strongly defended his policies toward the homeless as recently as three nights ago, during a nationally televised town hall meeting. He told his questioner, Andrea Mitchell, that encouraging dependency was cruel, while encouraging independence was humane -- long his approach to welfare and the homeless.
Other elected officials say they doubt that the mayor's plan to govern differently means that he is prepared to change his ideology. But they say just a change in his public temperament could make a difference. Mr. Green, who has been a target of Mr. Giuliani's disdain, noted, with amazement in his voice, that when he called the mayor after Mr. Giuliani dropped his Senate candidacy, the mayor took his call. "We said more than 'hello' for the first time in three years," Mr. Green said.
But can a change not in content but tone -- in itself a difficult thing to pull off for so entrenched a personality -- accomplish the mayor's goal of "reaching everyone in this city"?
After six and a half years of seeing one kind of mayor, some who work with Mr. Giuliani are openly dubious.
"If he is sincere and truly wants to reach out, I think the black community has always been open to wanting to work with the mayor," said C. Virginia Fields, the Manhattan borough president. But there are many skeptics, she added, because the mayor has made similar promises before, and failed to convincingly follow up. He can still keep his own commitment to change, she said. "But not easily."

HEADLINE: THE RACE FOR SENATE: THE DEMOCRAT;
Mrs. Clinton Says She Plans Congenial Discussion of Issues

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS 

DATELINE: MOUNT KISCO, N.Y., May 20

 BODY:
Hillary Rodham Clinton made it clear today that she has no intention of lashing out at her new competitor in the race for the United States Senate.
For some weeks, her staff members have extensively researched the voting record and positions of United States Representative Rick A. Lazio of Long Island, the Republican candidate for the Senate. But after an appearance at the Boys and Girls Club of Northern Westchester, Mrs. Clinton mentioned the congressman in only the most cordial terms. 
 "I would like to welcome Congressman Lazio into this race for the Senate," Mrs. Clinton said, reading more or less verbatim from a statement that had been released earlier by her campaign headquarters in Manhattan.
"I'm looking forward to a real discussion with him of the issues," Mrs. Clinton said. "Because if Congressman Lazio is the Republican nominee, there will be a clear difference between us on a number of issues, because we've taken very different stands on everything from education, to health care, to the future of the economy, to how we take care of our children, as well as our elderly citizens."
The statement offered no specifics about the differences between Mrs. Clinton, the Democratic nominee, and Mr. Lazio, who is expected to be nominated at the Republican State Convention in Buffalo at the end of the month.
But it offered a dramatic contrast in tone to Mr. Lazio's statement on his entrance into the race earlier today.
Mrs. Clinton first told reporters that she would take "one or two questions," but after she read her statement, she left the podium and began shaking the hands of many of the roughly 250 people gathered at the Boys and Girls Club.
While she walked along a roped-off area shaking hands, signing autographs and posing for photographs with guests, reporters occasionally asked about criticisms Mr. Lazio had made of her.
In each case, she offered short responses. When asked about Mr. Lazio's depiction of her as an out-of-state politician, she said: "We'll have plenty to talk about on the issues. That's what's important."
In part, Mrs. Clinton's aides explained, the cautious, almost congenial tone of the first lady's statement reflected her belief that there was no need to inject negativity into a campaign that has more than five months yet to run. As Mrs. Clinton said at the end of her statement, "I think we'll have a lot of time in the next days and weeks and months to discuss those differences."
And with Mr. Lazio's emergence after Rudolph W. Giuliani withdrew Friday from the race, Mrs. Clinton concluded that there was little chance she could command the same level of media attention as the new Republican contender at that time, her aides said.
Moreover, her aides said, Mrs. Clinton wished to stick with the kind of schedule in which she has been immersed over the last few weeks.
Mrs. Clinton came here today from her home in Chappaqua, about a 10-minute drive, to attend the club's Youth of the Year Award program, where she gave brief remarks extolling the Boys and Girls Club. From there, she traveled to a fund-raising reception, also in Westchester County. On Sunday, the first lady is to travel to Albany to attend a convention of the New York State Council of Machinists and a luncheon hosted by the Rensselaer County Democratic Committee.

HEADLINE: A Philosophy With Roots In Conservative Texas Soil

SERIES: GEORGE W. BUSH'S JOURNEY: A Boy From Midland

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF 

DATELINE: MIDLAND, Tex.

 BODY:
The fourth-grade classroom erupted in titters as George W. Bush, one of the class clowns, faced his friends. He had quietly used an ink pen to draw a beard and long sideburns on his cheeks.
The teacher, Frances Childress, grabbed George by the arm, yanked him out of class and marched him down the long outside corridor to the principal's office near the main entrance to Sam Houston Elementary School. 
 "Just look at him," the principal, John Bizilo, recalls Mrs. Childress telling him. "He's been making a disturbance in class."
The next step was pretty obvious for anyone in the 1950's version of the West Texas oil town of Midland: Mr. Bizilo told George to bend over and then reached for his paddle, the thickness of a Ping-Pong paddle but narrower and twice as long. Mr. Bizilo gave George three "licks," and the boy's shrieks filled the office.
"When I hit him, he cried," Mr. Bizilo remembered the other day. "Oh, did he cry! He yelled as if he'd been shot. But he learned his lesson."
So he did.
Many of the roots of Mr. Bush's political philosophy as a presidential candidate -- including his belief in tough love for juvenile offenders -- seem to go back to his childhood. Midland, a conservative, up-from-the-bootstraps town that has grown from 25,000 when he was a little boy to almost 100,000 today, mirrors Mr. Bush's optimism, his faith in business and his doubts about an activist government. While playing Little League baseball, running for class president, or even sobbing in the principal's office, George W. Bush absorbed West Texas values that many old friends say are central to understanding who he is today.
"I think his political philosophy comes completely from the philosophy of the independent oil man," said Joe O'Neill, a fellow rapscallion in childhood. "His homage to his parents, his respect for his elders, his respect for tradition, his belief in religion, his opposition to abortion -- that's the philosophy he grew up with here."
Mr. Bush himself, in a long interview about his roots, made a similar point. "I don't know what percentage of me is Midland," he said, "but I would say people, if they want to understand me, need to understand Midland and the attitude of Midland."
It is in the soil of Midland that Mr. Bush has said he would like to be buried when he dies, and it was to Midland that he returned in the 1970's to marry and start a family. It gave him an anchor in real America.
Mr. Bush has often said that "the biggest difference between me and my father is that he went to Greenwich Country Day and I went to San Jacinto Junior High." That may be an exaggeration of the younger Mr. Bush's populist credentials, because he is also a product of Andover, Yale and Harvard. But there is still something to it.
The father, chauffeured to and from private school in Connecticut in a black sedan, suffered politically because of the perception that he was a blue blood who could not relate to ordinary people. The younger Mr. Bush also has been tainted by the idea that he was born into privilege with a visa to effortless wealth and prominence. Yet George W. Bush actually had a rather ordinary childhood, and his years biking around small-town streets in jeans and a white T-shirt left him with a common touch that is among his greatest assets as a politician.
"He understands Bubba because there is more Bubba in him," Karl Rove, the longtime political adviser to the Bushes, told a reporter in 1992, when Mr. Bush's friends were still carefree enough to say colorful things about him. "He is clearly the wild son -- even today. Part of it is rooted in Midland, where he grew up in an ordinary neighborhood, where houses are close together and risk was a way of life."
The Midland childhood is a striking contrast to that of another boy growing up at the same time, Al Gore, who instead of being paddled in Mr. Bizilo's office was attending the elite St. Albans School in Washington, swimming in the Senate pool and listening on an extension as his father the senator spoke on the telephone to President John F. Kennedy.
Midland, impatient with ideas and introspection, was a world of clear rights and wrongs, long on absolutes and devoid of ethical gray shades. It may be the source of some of Mr. Bush's greatest political strengths, the unpretentiousness and mellow bonhomie that warm up voters, and also of his weaknesses, including an image of an intellectual lightweight that is underscored whenever he mixes up the likes of Slovenia and Slovakia.
 
Boomtown in Black and White
It is easy to see why Midland does not support a postcard industry. It rests on an expanse of flat, baked nothingness. Even its residents, searching for a kind analogy, fumble a bit before coming up with "moonscape." The surrounding land, home to tumbleweeds and rattlesnakes, would depress even a camel, but in the 1950's it had one redeeming feature -- it was loaded with oil.
The oil made Midland a boomtown, attracting ambitious businessmen like the elder Mr. Bush and many other out-of-staters as well. These people made for a conservative town but not a redneck one; Midland had a large proportion of geologists, engineers, lawyers and accountants, and Ivy League college graduates were everywhere.
Mr. Bush recalls it in Norman Rockwell pastels, and so do many other residents. Children bicycled everywhere on their own, crime was almost nonexistent and if anyone suspicious -- say, someone with a beard -- showed up in town, then-Sheriff Ed Darnell (known as Big Ed) would stop him, escort him to the edge of town, and tell him to "get out."
Yet what no one volunteers is that it was also rigidly segregated in those days, like most places in the South. Black children went to their own school rather than to Sam Houston Elementary with George Bush. The bus station and train station had separate waiting rooms for blacks and whites, and there were separate, dilapidated drinking fountains marked "colored" at the stations and at the courthouse.
The Bushes' first encounter with West Texas racism came when they casually invited a black man, working for the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, to come by their temporary home in neighboring Odessa. The man had the tact to stay away, but neighbors heard about this and warned the elder George Bush to stop these invitations unless he wanted to be tarred and feathered.
Racial slurs were routine, and young George picked up the words from neighbors. Once when he was about 7 years old he used one in the living room in front of his mother, Barbara.
Michael Proctor, who lived across the street and was playing with George at the time, remembers watching as Mrs. Bush grabbed her son by the ear and dragged him into the bathroom. She washed his mouth out with soap as he spluttered indignantly.
"His family was probably the only one around that didn't use racial slurs," Mr. Proctor said. "I probably didn't realize it was wrong until I saw that."
Alongside the racism directed at blacks, there was a measured respect for the Mexicans who came over the border to work in the oil fields. As a boomtown, Midland needed laborers and welcomed Mexican immigrants, who were regarded as hard-working and thrifty. Some old friends find an echo of that attitude in Mr. Bush's efforts to push the Republican Party to reach out to immigrants.
"We saw these people cross the border and just wanting a good job," recalls Randall Roden, a neighbor boy and best friend. Mr. Roden recalls going out with George and his father to an oil well and spending the night sleeping in the back of the Bushes' station wagon as the crew -- Mexicans among them -- struggled to get the well going.
"I formed the very strong impression, and I think George has the same one, that these people came for economic opportunity and worked very hard," Mr. Roden said. "If you wanted a Mexican worker to have a new pair of boots, you'd have to buy it for him. Because if you gave him money, he'd send it home."
 
Gaining a Foothold in Texas
George W. Bush, though born in 1946 in New Haven, Conn., while his father was still an over-achieving student at Yale, moved to West Texas when he was not quite 2 and grew up in this nurturing environment. These days, as the son of a president and scion of a wealthy family, he is often perceived as a child of privilege, but neighbors in those days insist that in the 1950's that was not the case.
The Bush family in the Northeast had money, but the elder George left all that behind to make his own fortune in West Texas. Equipped with connections but initially without seed money, George and Barbara Bush and little George, their firstborn, settled in a tiny apartment in the hard-driving oil town of Odessa, where they shared a bathroom with a mother-daughter team of prostitutes living next door.
Local people say that you raise hell in Odessa but raise a family in nearby Midland, a much more respectable place. So, after a one-year interlude in California, the Bushes moved to Midland, living in a bright blue 847-square-foot bungalow on a newly built street in which every home was identical -- but painted bright colors to make them seem different. It was called Easter Egg Row, because the houses looked like colored eggs.
The family prospered in the oil business and moved into a series of nicer houses in Midland, culminating in one with a swimming pool. But this was not as much of a draw as it might have been. Just down the street lived Peggy Porter, one of the cutest girls in school, and because she had a pool as well, it was in much greater demand than the Bush family's.
Occasionally George W.'s grandfather, Senator Prescott S. Bush of Connecticut, would visit and cause a mild stir of interest in the neighborhood. But for the most part, the Bush family was regarded as fairly typical of the out-of-staters.
These days, Governor Bush is often seen as a princeling, the son of a president, the scion of a famous family, and Al Gore as more of his own man. But in the 1950's and early 1960's, it was the other way around. Back then, the name George Bush belonged only to an obscure Texas businessman. George W.'s closest connection to the White House was that he was a descendant on his mother's side of Franklin Pierce, America's 14th president. In contrast, in those days "Albert Gore" was virtually a household name, belonging to a prominent senator (the present candidate's father and namesake) who was sometimes mentioned as presidential or vice-presidential timber. The senator lost his seat in 1970 and faded into obscurity.
Yet young George was not some country hick, and he also learned to fit into the world of his Connecticut grandparents. The family regularly spent part of the summer at the family retreat in Kennebunkport, Me., and in 1954 the father took George and his best friend, Randall Roden, to Washington to see the White House, the United States Capitol and a baseball game with the Washington Senators (whose later incarnation would move to Texas and become the Rangers, owned in part by George W. Bush).
They had lunch at the senator's home in Georgetown, and a thirsty Randall promptly demonstrated the distance from Midland to Georgetown by drinking from his finger bowl.
When they are tracked down, the boys and girls who once played dodgeball at Sam Houston Elementary School, while now scattered around the country, offer recollections that are very similar: Midland was an idyllic place in which to grow up, and George W. Bush was a very typical child. In contrast to other recent presidential candidates, Mr. Bush in childhood is remarkable primarily for his ordinariness.
"He wasn't any different from anybody else," recalled Robert A. McCleskey, an old playmate. "You read about Clinton and Gore and how at that age they were planning to be president. Not Bush."
As a boy, Mr. Bush's ambition was to be another Mickey Mantle.
"All George ever wanted to be was a Major League baseball player," recalled a buddy, Terry Throckmorton. "That's all he ever talked about."
 
A Student of Baseball
No one has ever accused Mr. Bush of being an intellectual, and the indifference to books started early. Childhood friends recall Mr. Bush reading only two sets of books for pleasure -- the Hardy boys and a series of mystery books about baseball. As one asks about his reading habits, there are a few snickers.
"Did we sit around in those days reading books?" asked Mr. McCleskey, smiling broadly. "No."
George and Barbara Bush led a drive to build a school library (the school did not previously have one), but books were not a major part of a boy's childhood in Midland. Erstwhile acquaintances, while deeply admiring of the Bushes' goodness and decency, have trouble recalling early signs of greatness in the son.
"Well, no, I never did think about what he might do in life," said Austine Crosby, his third-grade teacher. "He was just a good, well-rounded young man, and he did his work."
And academically? "He was O.K.," Mrs. Crosby said, a bit defensively. "He was O.K."
So was he in the top quarter of his class academically?
"Well, in the upper half, anyway."
Even if he did not distinguish himself as a student, former classmates describe him as smart and blessed with an excellent memory. He had a passion for baseball statistics, a first-rate collection of baseball cards and a reputation as such a shrewd trader that boys were careful not to agree to a trade with George Bush without thinking it over very carefully.
In the mid-1950's, George came up with a scheme that showed remarkable ingenuity and helped make his collection of baseball cards the best around. He began sending baseball cards to famous players, enclosing return postage and a cheery good-luck message, and asking the players to autograph the cards and send them back.
This way, he got autographed cards from Mickey Mantle, Willie Mays and other famous players. Some of those cards are now worth thousands of dollars.
Mr. Bush's lifelong adoration of baseball began when he and other neighborhood boys would go early to school to play ball. Mr. Bizilo, the principal, would take off his jacket, loosen his tie and hit balls for the boys to field.
George was a good ballplayer, friends say, a bit on the small side but making up for it with enthusiasm and aggressiveness. He played catcher for the Cubs, a Little League team, and made it to the town's Little League All-Star team.
 
Becoming a Texan
Midland may not have had the best schools, George's onetime playmates say, but -- like Hot Springs, Ark., where Bill Clinton grew up -- it offered a nurturing environment and self-confidence for life.
"There's an assurance that you have growing up in a place like Midland, a self-confidence and a real genuine interest in connecting with people," said Marge Petty, the other politician in the group (a Democratic state senator in Kansas).
In particular, it was in Midland that Mr. Bush first learned to fit in, even if his parents were Yankees and his grandfather a senator. That ability to adapt and bridge groups has never left him.
Moreover, Midland values were remarkably unshaken by the 1960's. Some Midland alumni say they let their hair grow a bit longer, but -- like George W. Bush -- they mostly stood with the establishment instead of rejecting it. Very few seem to have protested significantly against the Vietnam War, seriously used drugs, thought of police as "pigs," denounced their parents as oppressors or picked up a copy of Das Kapital.
"It's a town of embedded values," Mr. Bush recalled, adding that it had "a heavy dose of individualism and fairly healthy disrespect for government." Asked if his own skepticism about the role for government is a product of Midland attitudes, Mr. Bush paused and finally nodded, saying: "I think there's a parallel there, I do."
Midland was steeped in optimism, and for many people growing up here in the 1950's, the moral of childhood was that the system worked, that anyone who struggled enough in that baking desert had a good chance of finding oil and striking it rich. The trajectory of the Bush family itself, from the apartment with the shared bathroom to the sprawling house and pool, underscored the point.
"The lesson lasted with George W. for years," said Bill Minutaglio, a Texan who has written a biography of Mr. Bush. "I think he truly believes that people can win the lottery if they work hard, that if they put their nose to the grindstone it'll all work out without government help or intrusion."
The antipathy for government seems a little odd, from afar, because in those days the oil business depended heavily on quirks in the tax code to encourage investments. Still, when the people of Midland sought a theater, a hospital and a new baseball diamond, they did not ask the government but raised money themselves and turned out on the weekends to do much of the work on their own.
When Mr. Bush talks about "compassionate conservatism" or "faith-based initiatives," he evokes what old classmates remember as the spirit of Midland of the 1950's. Asked if that is what he has in mind, Mr. Bush interrupts half-way through the question. "Yeah, absolutely," he said.
Those who know Midland are convinced that Mr. Bush is sincere when he preaches compassion and calls for a "responsibility era." But some also admit that it is fair to question the relevance of lessons from a town where raw capitalism made so many people rich and where community spirit wove such a strong safety net.
 
Surviving a Family Loss
In addition to church groups, various civic organizations were also active, and one of the local rituals for children was the meetings with cookies and milk at the home of a nice old lady who represented the Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals.
The cookies were digested more thoroughly than the teachings.
"We were terrible to animals," recalled Mr. Throckmorton, laughing. A dip behind the Bush home turned into a small lake after a good rain, and thousands of frogs would come out.
"Everybody would get BB guns and shoot them," Mr. Throckmorton said. "Or we'd put firecrackers in the frogs and throw them and blow them up."
When he was not blowing up frogs, young George -- always restless and something of a natural leader -- would lead neighborhood children on daredevil expeditions around town, seeing how close they could come to breaking their necks. George also quickly acquired a colorful vocabulary.
"Georgie has grown to be a near-man, talks dirty once in a while and occasionally swears, aged 4 and a half," his father despaired in a letter to a friend in 1951. In another letter four years later, he lamented: "Georgie aggravates the hell out of me at times."
There was one terrible interruption in this relaxed life, occurring when George was 7. He was at school when he saw his parents' green Oldsmobile drive up in the parking lot. At first he thought he saw his 3-year-old sister, Robin, through the window.
But his eyes were playing tricks on him. His parents had come to break the news to him that Robin had just died of leukemia. The loss staggered the Bush family, and some friends say that George's closeness to his mother dates partly from his efforts to comfort her at that time.
His mother's hair began to turn gray, though she was just 28, and she often dissolved into tears. George's father worked hard and traveled frequently, and so the boy spent much more time with his mother than his father -- acquiring in particular her lacerating wit.
Robin's death is something that he has talked about very rarely with friends, and even some of his roommates at boarding school and college did not know about her. But occasionally when the moment was right, he would confide to friends about his tears and grief at the time, about his incomprehension that Robin could have been dying without his parents telling him.
Close friends say he had nightmares for years afterward. The death also left him as a quasi-only child, for his next-oldest sibling, Jeb, was six and a half years younger. Neil and Marvin were 9 and 10 years younger than George, and Dorothy was 13 years younger. So while George occasionally used Jeb as a punching bag in childhood squabbles, and always relished his role as elder brother, most of the time his playmates and confidants were friends and roommates rather than siblings.
Soon after Robin's death, George returned to school. Most of the time, the despair was hidden, and on the surface he soon reverted to the wise-cracking imp they had known before.
 
The Seeds of Leadership
Mr. Bush's political debut appears to have come in the seventh grade, although both he and his wife, Laura, (who was in the same seventh grade but barely knew him) say they have no recollection of it. Classmates recall that he ran for seventh-grade class president against Jack Hanks.
Jack was a formidable candidate, and four years later at Boys Nation he would be elected vice president, defeating a personable candidate from Arkansas named Bill Clinton. Yet in running against George, Jack was less fortunate, and classmates say that George was elected by a narrow margin.
"I voted for George because he was cuter," recalled Peggy Porter Weiss, "and in the seventh grade that's what counted."
Still, former classmates say that if they had been told that one of their number would become a presidential candidate, they would not have thought of George Bush. Instead, they say, the assumption would have been that it would be Bill Wood.
Mr. Wood, as bright and ambitious as he was athletic, beat out George Bush on the football field and was the first-string quarterback on the seventh-grade team (Mr. Bush was the second-string quarterback). Mr. Wood eventually became the junior high school and high school student council president and even headed the statewide association of student councils. If any young man in Midland seemed destined for the White House, classmates remember, it was he.
"Since then, the only thing I ever ran for," said Mr. Wood, now a lawyer and a bit flattered and amused by the memories of his classmates, "was the school board."
 
Political Journeys
Articles in this series will examine the lives of the presidential candidates ast the campaign progresses. The nest article will explore Al Gore's dual boyhood, in Washington and in Carthage, Tenn.

PUB-DATE: May 21, 2000,

SECTION: Section 1; Page 1; Column 6; Metropolitan Desk 

LENGTH: 1802 words

HEADLINE: THE RACE FOR SENATE: THE REPUBLICANS;
LAZIO OPENS RACE WITH AN ATTACK ON MRS. CLINTON

BYLINE: By ADAM NAGOURNEY 

 BODY:
Representative Rick A. Lazio of Long Island came roaring into the race for senator from New York yesterday, attacking Hillary Rodham Clinton as a "far left" candidate who has "no real rationale for serving here other than as a steppingstone to some other position."
"I think her ambition is the issue," Mr. Lazio declared in an interview before heading for the high school from which he graduated in 1976 to formally announce his candidacy in a race that has been upended by Rudolph W. Giuliani's decision to step aside because of health reasons. 
 Mr. Lazio, addressing a whooping and cheering crowd of supporters at West Islip High School, on Long Island, described the emerging contest between a little-known four-term member of Congress and the nation's first lady as a "clear choice" between candidates of competing ideologies and divergent backgrounds.
"My opponent is a liberal and a proud one, and I respect her for that," said Mr. Lazio, who lives in Bay Shore. "But make no mistake: she is no more a New Democrat than she is a New Yorker. She offers the big-government ideology that crippled New York in the 1980's. I do not believe we want to enter this new century pledging allegiance to the liberal ideas that so painfully failed us in the last century."
The remarks came as Republican leaders in New York and Washington lined up behind the candidacy of Mr. Lazio, who had suspended his campaign last year in deference to party leaders who wanted Mr. Giuliani as their candidate. Mr. Lazio announced a two-day state fly-around, an aggressive come-out-of-the-box approach intended to discourage any other Republicans who might be thinking about challenging him. And Michael Long, the state Conservative Party leader, was said to be preparing to endorse Mr. Lazio, as Joseph DioGuardi, a former Westchester County congressman who had been seeking the Conservative Party nomination, told friends that he would quit the race to make way for Mr. Lazio.
Mrs. Clinton's press secretary, Howard Wolfson, assailed Mr. Lazio for his attacks on Mrs. Clinton in the interview. "I'm shocked by the approach they are taking," Mr. Wolfson said. "They are so overwhelmed by their hatred for her. I guess you have to run a negative campaign when you're a Gingrich Republican with a record that's too extreme for New York."
Mrs. Clinton, at an appearance yesterday afternoon, took a softer line, but made it clear that she, too, saw this as a contest of ideologies. "If Congressman Lazio is the Republican nominee," she said, "there will be a clear difference between us on a number of issues because we've taken very different stands on everything from education, to health care, to the future of the economy, to how we take care of our children as well as our elderly citizens."
The tenor of Mr. Lazio's comments in both the interview and the formal announcement speech suggested that the campaign, with the change in candidate, was going to be harsh and fast-paced, with a particular emphasis on Mrs. Clinton's attempt to run for office in a state to which she just moved five months ago, and on what Mr. Lazio described as her liberal ideology. Mrs. Clinton's advisers have moved to portray Mr. Lazio as extreme and conservative, noting that he supported many of the initiatives of former House Speaker Newt Gingrich, as they tried to discredit his candidacy.
Mr. Lazio, 42, said he considered himself "a centrist, a mainstream Republican."
"We're conservative, right-of-center on budget and tax issues, national security issues," he said. "And I think we're realistic on social issues."
He described his Democratic opponent as "far left," adding: "She's part of the discredited philosophy that helped lead New York to ruin during the Cuomo years. I think we've turned the corner, and we don't want to go back to those failed days."
In the interview, Mr. Lazio jumped at almost every opportunity to criticize Mrs. Clinton. He responded vigorously when asked if he would make an issue out of the fact that Mrs. Clinton did not live in New York before this year, a subject that Mr. Giuliani, as mayor of New York City, frequently raised.
"I'm the real thing," he said. "I don't have to try to be someone else. I was born here. I went to school here. I fished in these waters. I clammed in its bays. I graduated from our schools. My children were born in New York State. I've lived here my whole life. There will be no question of my commitment to this state."
Mr. Lazio's announcement speech was scattered with references to his own New York roots and indirect jabs at his opponent. "You can tell from my accent that I am a lifelong New Yorker," Mr. Lazio declared, grinning broadly as the audience responded with laughter and applause. "You see, I don't have to fake it. New York isn't just a place I represent -- it is my home. And I've never needed an exploratory committee to decide where I want to live."
At another point, borrowing from what had been another of Mr. Giuliani's refrains, he said, "I can't call on Air Force One whenever I need a ride."
By contrast, he said in the interview, Mrs. Clinton is hurt both by the fact that she has only recently lived in the state where she wants to serve, and because of the cloistered life she has lived as a first lady.
"You don't know New York if you have bodyguards around you all the time," he said. "You've got to know what it's like to ride the subways, to drive your own car, to buy your own gas, to buy groceries here.
"I think people can see through who Hillary Clinton is, and they will have a chance to know Rick Lazio as the real deal," he said.
The exchanges between the campaigns yesterday suggested that expectations aside, a Lazio-Clinton race could prove to be far harsher than a race between Mrs. Clinton and Mr. Giuliani, and not necessarily by choice. Mr. Lazio is under pressure to establish himself quickly as a credible and tough challenger to Mrs. Clinton, for the sake of party leaders as well as contributors from across the nation who had financed Mr. Giuliani's challenge to Mrs. Clinton and are in danger of drifting away in the next few days.
And Mr. Lazio, because he is relatively unknown, is likely to find it a lot less complicated to attack Mrs. Clinton than Mr. Giuliani had. The mayor always had to be on guard about being portrayed as unyielding or rash, particularly as Mrs. Clinton sought to suggest that his temperament left him unsuited to serve in the Senate.
For Mrs. Clinton, the question is not whether to attack, but when. That said, her aides acknowledged that Mr. Lazio might prove to be a more elusive target than Mr. Giuliani, both because he is a more obscure candidate and because he makes what many Republicans described as a pleasing first impression.
The immediate struggle is a race to see which side succeeds in defining Mr. Lazio first over the next few weeks.
Even before Mr. Lazio announced, Mrs. Clinton's aides had researched his record and were preparing to paint him as a Republican partisan who would vote against New York interests in Congress.
Mr. Lazio has spent much of the last two weeks talking with New York and national Republicans, and that was apparent yesterday. He dismissed suggestions by Mrs. Clinton's aides that he was too partisan as "laughable," adding: "They're going to be talking about the old failed model of, 'Oh yeah, this guy is too this, or too that.' "
On one issue over which the two candidates have some disagreement -- abortion -- Mr. Lazio described Mrs. Clinton as extreme because she opposes a ban on some forms of late-term abortion. "I'm for a woman's right to choose, but I think it's not unlimited," Mr. Lazio said. "I favor the ban on partial birth. I think Mrs. Clinton takes the position to the extreme. I think I reflect where New Yorkers are and where America is. Not criminalizing abortion, but also not allowing a horrific procedure that even Ed Koch and Senator Moynihan condemn. She is on the fringes of this issue." Mr. Lazio also said yesterday that he opposed any public financing of abortions.
In his speech, Mr. Lazio presented himself as an ideological underdog against a candidate of the left. "This is an important race. It seems as though everyone throughout our great nation is watching us," he said. "And every possible liberal group from outside our state has lined up with our Democratic opponent. Well, I say, bring them on. From Washington, from Hollywood, from Arkansas."
Mr. Lazio's announcement came as his campaign sprang almost overnight into full life. Workers at his headquarters answered the phone "Lazio 2000" early yesterday, and Mr. Lazio's Web site urged voters to contribute money.
Newly hired staff members flew up from Washington, with a notable representation from the presidential campaigns of Lamar Alexander, the former governor of Tennessee, and Senator John S. McCain of Arizona. Mr. Lazio's media adviser, Michael Murphy, performed the same role for Mr. Alexander in 1996.
The new Lazio campaign staff members struggled through a chaotic morning as they grappled with questions like where was Mr. Lazio's headquarters located (Bay Shore), and what was the area code (631), from an onslaught of news media that abandoned Mr. Giuliani at New York City Hall for Mr. Lazio's headquarters on Long Island with startling speed.
Across New York State, Republican leaders fell in line with Gov. George E. Pataki and the state Republican chairman, William D. Powers, and proclaimed not only their support for Mr. Lazio, but also their belief that he would prove to be an extremely formidable opponent to Mrs. Clinton, notwithstanding the obvious obstacles he faces. (Some Republicans went so far as to suggest privately that he was a better candidate than Mr. Giuliani would have ever been.)
"The race at the end of the day is going to be about who best can serve New York," said Zenia Mucha, the chief political aide to Mr. Pataki, "and based on his record in Congress, it's clearly going to be him." Drawing a contrast between Mr. Lazio and Mrs. Clinton, she said he "understands what it means to be a New Yorker. She's in the process of learning. His basic philosophy is a smaller role of government for the people. Her basic philosophy is that government has all the answers."
Representative Peter F. King of Long Island withdrew from seeking the Republican nomination. He said yesterday morning that he did not want to cause any division within the Republican Party.
Republicans emphasized repeatedly that Mr. Lazio was more closely in tune with Republican positions on issues than Mr. Giuliani was.
"Personally speaking, I am a little more comfortable with Rick Lazio," said Stephen J. Minarik, the Monroe County Republican chairman. "He is more in line with the party."

HEADLINE: Paid Notice: Deaths
MYERS, PROFESSOR CHARLES A.

 BODY:
MYERS-Professor Charles A., an expert in labor economics, management, and education and development, died April 2, 2000, age 86, in Naples, Florida. Mr. Myers was a professor of economics and management at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology for 42 years and author of more than 85 books and articles. He was born in 1913 in State College, Pennsylvania and graduated from Penn State University. He earned a Ph.D in economics from the University of Chicago. From 1942 to 1945 he served on the War Production Board and the War Labor Board; from 1957 to 1959 on the Federal Advisory Council on Employment Security; from 1960 to 1962 on the Presidential Railroad Commission; and from 1969 to 1971 on the National Manpower Policy Task Force. He was a Fellow of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences, President of the Industrial Relations Research Association, and Charter Member of the National Academy of Arbitrators. His academic work included pioneering studies of U.S. labor markets; of comparitive labor relations in OECD and developing countries; and of the relationship between investment in education and the rate and nature of economic and social development. He leaves his wife of 63 years, Nancy (Nash); a son, Charles N. of Duxbury, MA; 2 daughters, Anne M. Forsyth of Midlothian, VA and Temson M. Ely of Amherst, MA; a sister Christine Ellenburger of Fairfield, CT; seven grandchildren and two great grandchildren.
