HEADLINE: Agent's Role In Music Site May Be ShiftIn Rights War

BYLINE: By MATT RICHTEL 

 BODY:
Michael Ovitz, superagent and former Disney president, has made his name -- and a considerable fortune -- aggressively securing hundreds of millions of dollars in royalties and other payments for artists and studios he represents. But his latest endeavor, a pop culture hub on the World Wide Web, has the potential to drain income from some of those same clients by enabling users of the site to copy music, media and other files from one another.
Last year, Mr. Ovitz and a business partner bought 51 percent of Scour.com, an entertainment site and search engine used to find music and movie files. Last month, though, the site added a feature, Scour Exchange, that lets users exchange one another's multimedia files online, including copyrighted material by some of the world's leading artists, some of them clients of Mr. Ovitz's talent management agency, Artists Management Group. 
 The involvement of Mr. Ovitz in Scour.com would seem to be at cross purposes with his role in Artists Management. But his backing of Scour.com also marks a significant shift in the roiling battle over copyright protection in the digital age.
Until now, the arch-nemeses of the recording industry have been 20-something entrepreneurs creating Web sites that make it easy to exchange copyrighted files over the Internet. Mr. Ovitz's backing for Scour.com's file exchange mechanism suggests opposition may be eroding to technology that, by many accounts, will force the development of new business models for the entertainment industry, changing how artists are compensated for their work and how their work is protected.
Mr. Ovitz declined to comment. But James Ellis, general counsel for Artists Management Group and a director of Scour Inc., said it makes more sense to embrace the technology than to fight it. "In the face of a rapidly changing marketplace, Scour had to respond to maintain and grow its audience and give them what they wanted," he said.
Mr. Ellis said that Scour hoped to find ways to make file sharing lucrative for artists. And he said Scour was vigilant about kicking copyright infringers off the site if Scour was informed of the problem.
Dan Rodrigues, 24, co-founder and president of Scour.com, said Scour Exchange could not be held accountable if some people used the service to pirate copyrighted material. "It's impossible for us to screen, censor or review," he said. "It's not our job to know what is, or is not, infringing."
The Scour.com Web site does include a copyright notice, but practically speaking it is simple to obtain copyrighted material by entering the search term for the desired song or movie.
Some Internet music industry analysts say Mr. Ovitz has a potentially serious conflict of interest in holding a stake in Scour.com and managing artists whose music and movies may be traded freely on Scour Exchange. The works of several of the artists represented by Mr. Ovitz's agency are exchanged on Scour Exchange, including music from the group Blues Traveler and the singer Liz Phair.
"There is a significant potential for conflict," said Kevin Hause, an Internet music analyst with IDG, a market research group. "He is someone entrusted to look out for the best interest of artists."
But Mr. Rodrigues said that Mr. Ovitz is actually building a bridge between the old world media companies and the new business models of the Internet. "He understands both sides of the equation," he said. "He understands what entertainment companies need and what's important to copyright holders and what works on the Web." Scour.com was founded in a two-bedroom apartment near the campus of the University of California at Los Angeles. Traffic to the site grew quickly, and the company eventually attracted the interest of Mr. Ovitz, who read about Scour.com in the school newspaper, and the grocery billionaire Ron Burkle. For $4 million, the pair took a majority stake in the business, said Mr. Rodrigues.
The company reached deals with a number of Internet start-ups and media companies to provide content to include with the search function. Scour is now contemplating a variety of business models, including taking advertisements, selling subscriptions and selling multimedia content. It now features movie trailers and music promotions provided legitimately by movie and record companies, along with some items for sale, like music available for download. The site now receives 2 million visitors each month.
As with Napster, the controversial site offering a service that lets users share and trade their music files online, users of Scour download software over the Internet that allows them to store and catalog multimedia files on their own computers. Scour Exchange posts those catalogs, then enables users of the service to visit one another's computers over the Internet and share and download one another's music, movies, and other holdings. The service does not provide the content, but facilitates the exchange.
Napster, based in San Mateo, Calif., has been sued by the Recording Industry Association of America for reportedly facilitating music piracy in a pending case that many expect to set a precedent. The association, and the five major record labels it represents, say its artists are losing tens of millions of dollars a year because of rampant music piracy on the Internet, a practice the trade group says threatens to undermine the very economics of the creation of music.
Hilary Rosen, the president of the recording industry association, said the group was aware of Scour Exchange's activities and was considering its options. But she said the organization did not want to rush to file lawsuits against each Napster-like service, hoping the decision in that case case might dissuade copycats. "We don't have any interest in litigating our way through the Internet," she said.
But in reality, the industry association might simply lack the resources to file enough lawsuits given the boom in these services and the complexity of the attendant technology. Most recently, a 23-year-old Irish programmer created Freenet, which would enable people to share files online directly with one another in a way that would make it virtually impossible for copyright holders to find a central database or hub to blame for the interaction.
Therein lies a key argument of Mr. Rodrigues and Scour Exchange. They contend that the free exchange of files online may be inevitable, so media companies might as well get on board. "We're trying to work with entertainment companies to help them use it," Mr. Rodrigues said, adding, "Ovitz has been instrumental to us in leveraging entertainment relationships he has."
Scour has some agreements with other companies aimed at helping users to download multimedia files in a way that protects copyright. For instance, Liquid Audio, a company that makes technology to enable digital distribution of music in a way that protects copyright and that is a partner of some of the major record labels has a deal with Scour to enable it to sell several encrypted songs on the site. Andrea Cook Fleming, vice president of marketing for Liquid Audio, said Liquid Audio is providing an alternative to people who might otherwise pirate music, rather than pay for it.
Another company that has signed a deal with Scour is Nettwerk Productions, an independent record label aiming to promote one of its up-and-coming artists, a musician named Brian Transeau who records as BT, on Scour. Cathy Barrett, director of strategic marketing for Nettwerk, said the deal puts the label in an awkward position because the site is promoting the music of BT, but with a single click of the mouse, users can get pirated versions of BT's songs for free through Scour.
But BT said people will inevitablytrade copyrighted music on the Web, so artists might as well try to figure out how to capitalize on the sites making that possible. "It's an uncontrollable situation," BT said. "You might as well embrace it and make the best of it or you're going to go insane trying to prevent it."
Still, some musicians and their agents disagree. Howard King, a Los Angeles attorney who is representing Metallica and Dr. Dre in lawsuits against Napster, said that Mr. Ovitz and Scour have an obligation to stand up to piracy. "Just because some kid in the Philippines knows how to create a devastating virus, doesn't mean we say, 'oh it'll happen again,' and not do something about it," he said.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
The new Land Rover campaign gets personal by highlighting small, everyday acts of courage.

BYLINE: By Stuart Elliott 

 BODY:
TO the British, it is a brand of alcoholic beverage. To fans of John F. Kennedy, it is the subject of profiles. To the Cowardly Lion, it is reason to see the Wizard. And to Land Rover North America, it is the centerpiece of a revamped advertising and marketing campaign, the first created by the company's new agency, GSD&M in Austin, Tex.
The subject? Courage, of course. 
 And what, pray tell, could be the rationale for associating a quality like courage with a line of sport utility vehicles? Maybe the owner of a New Beetle driving on a road crowded with luxury off-road vehicles is courageous.
Actually, to the company and the agency, courage is shorthand for a skein of words that begin with "c" and serve to flatter the would-be buyer: character, conviction, creativity and curiosity.
"It's what we call the maverick mindset," said Roy Spence, president at GSD&M. That mindset, he said, is prevalent among "those who in the 21st century will be the builders, the architects, of the next economy."
In interviews last week, Mr. Spence joined executives at GSD&M and Land Rover North America to discuss the campaign, which expands today into television with commercials on local broadcast stations and national cable networks like A&E and Discovery (natch). The initial two spots -- for the Discovery Series II, the best-selling Land Rover model -- portray courage in unconventional ways.
In one commercial, a demurely clad pregnant woman gamely walks on a beach populated by younger women in revealing bikinis. In the other commercial, a couple on the way to the opera stops on a rain-slicked highway to help a stray dog.
"It's not about describing the attributes and benefits of the vehicle on-road or off-road," said Alicia Kriese, senior vice president and group account director for Land Rover at GSD&M. "It's about taking your own road."
The "Courage" theme is continued through the other parts of the campaign: print, radio, billboards and posters. For instance, a radio spot describes how the vehicles "have driven in the harshest conditions known to man, from the blistering Gobi desert to the oxygen-deprived Himalayas."
GSD&M is a creatively focused shop known for campaigns for blue-chip brands like Southwest Airlines and Wal-Mart. This is the agency's first effort for an automotive client.
"We were looking for an agency with a strong culture and ability to build our brand equity," said Jim Selwa, vice president for marketing at Land Rover North America in Lanham, Md. "We picked GSD&M because of a cultural connect."
GSD&M was selected in late March after a review that had lasted almost three months. The incumbent agency of 13 years, Grace & Rothschild in New York, which introduced Land Rover products to American consumers, declined to take part.
GSD&M was one of three finalists in the review along with two other agencies seeking their initial car accounts: Crispin Porter & Bogusky in Miami and Kirshenbaum Bond & Partners in New York. All three were give an assignment on Discovery to determine which would be awarded the creative duties on the company's account, with billings estimated at $30 million.
"The key insight from GSD&M was that the brand was not being viewed as accessible enough," said Kim McCullough, model manager for Discovery at Land Rover North America. "People thought it cost $50,000, which is what Range Rover costs." That's the more expensive of the two products sold in North America by Land Rover.
"We knew we had to change that price perception," Ms. McCullough said, "and get it in line with where the car is." That's why there are numerous mentions of the Discovery's starting sticker of "$33,975 M.S.R.P.," which several ads cheekily define as "manufacturer's surprising retail price."
The final work from Grace & Rothschild was for Range Rover, Mr. Selwa said, adding: "We're now working with GSD&M on a campaign for the 2001 Range Rover, due in fall 2000. Then in the next 18 months we'll introduce Freelander, which is to be priced around $25,000 to $26,000."
Sales for Land Rover North America last year totaled just under 30,000 vehicles, Mr. Selwa said, fueled by a 50 percent increase for Discovery. The goal for 2000 is 31,000, he added, and then a leap to 45,000 to 47,000 when the lower-priced Freelander becomes part of the lineup.
Media duties for Land Rover are handled by Optimedia International U.S. in New York, part of Publicis S.A. Land Rover is part of BMW A.G., which agreed days before the review ended to sell the brand to the Ford Motor Company.
That could jeopardize the GSD&M hold on the account because the agency is part of the Omnicom Group, which owns shops like BBDO Worldwide and Merkley Newman Harty. They handle brands like Dodge and Mercedes-Benz for a major Ford competitor, DaimlerChrysler. Ford frowns on working with agencies that are part of holding companies owning other agencies handling accounts for DaimlerChrysler or General Motors.
"We see nothing from the creative side of the business" that would warrant concerns over conflicts, Mr. Selwa said. "BMW, a strong rival of Mercedes-Benz, didn't have an issue with GSD&M."
Mr. Spence offered Ford executives some tongue-in-cheek advice based on the new Land Rover credo: "They have to have courage."

HEADLINE: Putin's Move on Governors Would Bolster His Role

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, May 21

 BODY:
It turns out that the most momentous act of Vladimir V. Putin's first days as Russia's elected president has not been his choice of a cabinet, or the internal debate over a sweeping economic restructuring plan, or even the approval of two nuclear arms treaties.
Rather, it is Mr. Putin's mounting of a swift and stunning crusade last week to gut the power and political influence of Russia's 89 governors -- and not coincidentally, perhaps, to enhance his own. 
 If the campaign succeeds -- and that seemed more than possible this week -- then Mr. Putin will have reoriented Russia's federal system toward the Kremlin. And the governors, arguably the most powerful and rebellious politicians outside the Kremlin walls, will have been relegated to truly provincial status.
The Kremlin says that is what Russia needs to pull itself out of the slough that is its 10-year history as an independent nation, and many experts agree. But it will come at the cost of making Mr. Putin, already endowed with czar-like powers by the Constitution, an even more towering figure in Russian politics and government.
In fact, Moscow's all-powerful mayor, Yuri M. Luzhkov, was quick to attack Mr. Putin's plan as arbitrary and potentially illegal. But many political experts here say Mr. Putin is on the right course.
"The general tendency is positive because the major obstacle to reforms is the influence of the oligarchs and the governors, whom I call dictators," said Sergei Markov, one of the country's top political analysts.
Lilia Shevtsova, a top analyst at the Moscow office of the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, said, "The fact that Mr. Putin wants to crush these authoritarian regimes is a very promising sign." She calls the governors robber barons and says reining them in should be one of the new president's top priorities.
Mr. Putin's proposal comes at the peak of his political power now, while he is blessed with a comparatively prosperous economy and a clutch of powerful alliances with the major factions in Parliament. He took quick advantage of it all last week, in effect declaring war on the governors in two prime-time television speeches.
On Wednesday, he proposed to oust, permanently, all 89 governors and the leaders of their legislatures from their guaranteed seats in Russia's counterpart to the United States Senate, the Federation Council. The move would wipe out the current membership of the 188-seat house, replacing it with lesser regional officials.
More than that, Mr. Putin said on Wednesday that he would seek legal authority to personally suspend or fire any governor who flouts federal law or defies the Russian Constitution.
And that's not all: four days earlier, a Putin decree corralled the governors' 89 provinces into 7 new administrative districts, each overseen by a regional official who is answerable directly to Mr. Putin, and no one else.
On Friday, the semi-official Interfax news service called the proposals "an attack, one may even say storming" of the governors' political bastion. Mr. Putin is said to have sprung the plan on top governors last week in a meeting that ran so long that the president's next appointment -- his new prime minister, Mikhail Kasyanov -- cooled his heels for more than an hour.
The governors, still awed by Mr. Putin's popularity, have reacted cautiously. But few Russians expect them to roll over. For taken together, the proposals have the potential not just to end the their long run as regional potentates, but also to wreak vengeance on the most disobedient of their lot.
The seven new administrative districts have been billed as a streamlining of the government, replacing the individual envoys to all 89 provinces who served under President Boris N. Yeltsin.
But they are more than that. Under Mr. Yeltsin, both the envoys and many federal agencies became willing captives of the governors, who supplied them with favors the Kremlin could not or would not provide. Federal officials were dependent on the provinces for everything from office space and telephones to jobs for their families and summer camps for their children.
That will all change under Mr. Putin. The seven new envoys will work from regional capitals with budgets, housing and offices supplied by the Kremlin, as well as the power to bestow perks on federal officials in their districts. The effect, the administration hopes, will be to bring those officials back under the Kremlin's sway, and thus to bring more pressure to bear on the governors to follow federal orders.
The proposed reorganization of the Federation Council is potentially even more far-reaching. While details of the plan were not clear last weekend, Mr. Putin apparently intends to replace the council members with provincial officials elected by their peers, diluting the governors' power to control votes on the council.
The governors, however, stand to lose far more than political power. If they lose their parliamentary seats, they also surrender one of its most coveted benefits: complete immunity from criminal prosecution. And more than a few of them have cause to worry about that.
Russia's governors have lived high for a long time. As a string of crises and Mr. Yeltsin's desultory rule drained Moscow of money and influence, the far-flung provinces have increasingly made their own way, and some leaders have become corrupt, autocratic or both.
On the Pacific coast, 5,000 miles from the Kremlin, the governor of the Primoriye region, Yevgeny Nazdratenko, has taken over private businesses, seized control of the press and judiciary, pumped government budgets dry and, according to Mr. Yeltsin's Kremlin, regularly ignored federal decrees.
Across the country on the Black Sea, Krasnodar Province has been identified by human rights groups as a center of authoritarianism, anti-Semitism and "extreme xenophobia" under Gov. Nikolai Kondratenko. On the nearby Caspian, Kalmikiya has threatened secession, veered toward dictatorship and spent lavishly on a "chess city" under its chess-obsessed president, Kirsan Ilyumzhinov.
Some regions have erected trade barriers, treating each other almost like foreign nations. Mr. Putin claims that a fifth of provincial laws run counter to federal legislation. He need not look far: the city of Moscow, a federal district, has paid little attention to warnings that its regulations counter federal law.
In making his argument to clean up the system, Mr. Putin argues, with some justification, that he won election on a platform of bringing a dangerously undisciplined Russia to heel before it does itself fatal damage, and that reining in such behavior is the first step.
"This is not just correct today; it is absolutely necessary," he said on Wednesday. "The looseness of power is very costly for millions of average people. The cost of the lack of discipline in the state is our personal security, the inviolability of property and housing and, finally, our own well-being and the future of our children."
The president stresses that his proposals conform to the Constitution, that they require Parliament's approval, and that he rejects more draconian options, like arrogating to himself the power to appoint governors.
Mr. Putin is making his case directly to the people, on television, which suggests that he wants the sort of public mandate that past leaders, including Mr. Yeltsin, rarely bothered to seek.
His chances of getting what he wants seem good. Although the Federation Council would seem likely to oppose much of the Kremlin's plan, it appears that the Duma, the lower house of Parliament, will overwhelmingly approve it. Both the Duma's Communists and its right-wing party, the Union of Right Forces, have announced their support.
If the Duma gives Mr. Putin 300 of its 450 votes, a constitutional majority, the Federation Council will be unable to derail the bills even if it votes against them.

SECTION: Section A; Page 9; Column 1; Foreign Desk 

LENGTH: 1352 words

HEADLINE: U.S. Did Little to Deter Buildup as Ethiopia and Eritrea Prepared for War

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 21

 BODY:
When President Clinton annointed the leaders of Ethiopia and Eritrea as princes of an African Renaissance two years ago, he and three of his aides took a special interest in trying to head off one of the continent's biggest and costliest wars.
The behind-the-scenes courting of the Ethiopian Prime Minister, Meles Zenawi, and the Eritrean President, Isaias Afewerki, ended in bitter disappointment 10 days ago when Ethiopia rolled into Eritrea with tanks and artillery and launched trench warfare reminiscent of World War I. 
 The latest offensive was taken after two years in which both countries, among the poorest on earth, spent more than $1 billion on arms. But in trying to forge a peace settlement, the administration never sought economic or arms sanctions. Nor did it seek to slow down more than $1 billion in World Bank loans in the same period.
Instead, it focused on an intensive and sometimes highly personal diplomatic maneuver. At times, the diplomats involved said, Mr. Clinton himself phoned the two leaders and wrote them letters trying to coax them away from battle and into peace talks that could have been held in the United States.
A last-second maneuver this month by a team of United Nations ambassadors who knew the fighting was imminent because blood plasma had just been shipped to the front also failed.
The weapons pouring into the region -- fighter planes and helicopters, tanks, howitzers, shoulder-to-air missiles, and ammunition from Russia, Ukraine, Bulgaria, Romania, China and North Korea -- were easy for Western intelligence agencies to see as they entered Eritrea by sea and Ethiopia overland from Djibouti, by rail.
But the three Clinton administration diplomats who headed the peace effort -- Anthony Lake, a former National Security Agency adviser to Mr. Clinton; Gayle E. Smith, the director for Africa at the agency; and Susan E. Rice, the assistant secretary of state for African affairs -- acknowledge that they were reluctant to chastise the two African leaders.
Former guerrilla leaders who once fought together, Mr. Zenawi and Mr. Afewerki were seen as friends of the United States, men who had promise as reformers, despite their drive to fight each other. They led countries at the bottom of the economic ladder: it seemed heartless to be too tough. And they were considered useful in the administration's efforts to curb the power of the Islamic leadership in Sudan, a government that Mr. Zenawi and Mr. Afewerki opposed.
Now, as 10 days of fighting have dislodged hundreds of thousands of people from their homes in Eritrea and killed unknown numbers of front-line conscripts, the United Nations Security Council has approved a weapons embargo at the urging of the United States.
As the Ethiopians step up their assault by bombing targets near Eritrean Red Sea ports, the diplomats say they are still talking to both sides. But they are also considering more severe sanctions, like limiting the ability of the Eritreans to collect remittances from friends and relatives in the United States and restricting international flights of Ethiopian Airlines, a major revenue earner.
In an interview, Ms. Rice said "different sanctions" were considered at different points.
But she said, "It was our view given the disposition and the psychology of the two governments and the two peoples that external pressure was more likely to drive them in the opposite direction than the desired direction." It was decided to "resort to those pressures only in extremis."
Last October, as the weapons buildup became impossible to ignore, Mr. Lake said there were suggestions to seek an arms embargo. But Mr. Lake said he remained convinced that an arms embargo would have thrown the two countries into war. Mr. Zenawi and Mr. Afewerki had asserted that an arms embargo would bring about a collapse of the peace talks, making war much more likely, Mr. Lake said.
Critics of the policy say it was much too soft. "We should look them in the eyes and growl," said Chester A. Crocker, a former assistant secretary of state for African affairs. "They would blink if they thought we were going to shut them down with the World Bank. We have the power to come down hard on the leadership. No one laid our glove publicly on either of them."
Given the poverty -- and now the shortage of food that has struck both countries -- the governments have spent staggering amounts of money on weapons in the last two years, according to figures from the Institute for International Strategic Studies in London. Ethiopia, a country of 60 million, spent $480 million on arms in 1999; Eritrea, a nation of 3 million, spent $306 million. They spent slightly smaller amounts in 1998.
This year, Ethiopia's defense budget is set to rise to $533 million. Yet before the first outbreak of war in 1998, Ethiopia's defense budget was a little more than $100 million, the institute said.
In the last four years, Ethiopia received $924.9 million from the World Bank, more than two-thirds of it in 1998 after a first round of fighting, according to the World Bank. Eritrea, a much smaller country, received less.
The World Bank never threatened to stop the money, bank officials said, although Ethiopia lost its program with the International Monetary Fund because of excessive military spending.
As well, the Eritrean leader, Mr. Afewerki has been able to complement the foreign aid money by raising funds from the very loyal Eritrean diaspora in the United States. In early March, Mr. Afewerki addressed more than 10,000 Eritreans at the Equestrian Center in Upper Marlboro, Md., and many of them gave generously to his war machine.
The three negotiators who squared off with the African leaders, who turned out to be less princes of reform than warriors for personal honor, were eclectic, each with a point of view.
Mr. Lake, 61, who specialized in Africa as a university student and wrote his doctoral dissertation on Rhodesia, carried the weight of a professional diplomat. Ms. Smith, 44, once a freelance journalist who was on friendly terms with the two leaders from the 1970's and 1980's when she wrote about them from behind the lines, conveyed intimate knowledge of the region's clans and personalities. Ms. Rice, 35, an African-American who has the confidence of Secretary of State, Madeleine K. Albright, carried the authority of that office.
The current fighting represents the third and most expansive phase of the battle between the two countries. The State Department's best guess is that 50,000 to 60,000 people were killed in the first two rounds in the last two years, officials said. The death toll this time could be even higher, they said.
On the face of it, the dispute is about territory around a border between Eritrea and Ethiopia. Eritrea says it was reclaiming its own land when it marched over the line in May 1998; Ethiopia says it must have the territory back before it will agree to a comprehensive peace agreement.
As both leaders amassed their huge arsenals and conscripted wave upon wave of peasants, teachers, engineers and doctors, they were summoned to negotiations in Algiers earlier this month.
There, the talks were convened under the umbrella of the Organization for African Unity, but atmospherics were sour. The two men walked away, determined to go to war, just as they had been at various points all along, officials said.
When a group of United Nations ambassadors, including the American envoy, Richard C. Holbrooke, heard that the countdown for war was under way, they rushed from central Africa northward to see if they could make a difference.
But the envoys found Mr. Meles and Mr. Afewerki impervious to arguments about how they risked the lives of tens of thousands of their citizens and the viability of their fledgling countries.
As the ambassadors left, war broke out, making clear that Mr. Clinton's speechwriters, who chose to compare Mr. Meles and Mr. Afewerki to Renaissance leaders, may have unwittingly been correct. The Renaissance, several Africa hands noted, ended in bloody wars too.

PUB-DATE: May 22, 2000,

SECTION: Section A; Page 8; Column 1; Foreign Desk 

LENGTH: 1712 words

HEADLINE: President Views Success of China Trade Bill as His Foreign Policy Legacy

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 21

 BODY:
For seven years now, very little has gone as planned in Bill Clinton's effort to shape a new relationship with China. Now, amid increasing confidence among White House officials this weekend that they will prevail in one of the most crucial Congressional votes in a decade, the president who came to office knowing little about China may leave claiming he fundamentally altered Washington's relations with Beijing.
For Mr. Clinton, the problem has not been a lack of vision. Once in office, he quickly cast away his campaign attacks on President Bush for "coddling dictators" in Beijing. And since 1994, he has steadily built on his theme that the Internet and China's growing economic ties to the West would ultimately create pressures for political openness that Beijing will not be able to control. 
 The problem has been one of execution. The Chinese have hardly cooperated, jailing more dissidents even as Mr. Clinton argued that economic freedom would eventually produce political freedom. Nor has there been much help from the president's fellow Democrats, most of whom have fought his trade and China policies at every turn.
But in recent weeks, Mr. Clinton has sworn to close friends and colleagues that he will not let himself repeat the same mistake he now blames himself for making at least twice before -- letting the politics of the moment, or even the prospect of a war within his own political party, pull him back from a step he is convinced is the best hope of keeping China from becoming an adversary.
"He knows he blew it in 1995 and again last year," said one of Mr. Clinton's foreign policy advisers, referring to Mr. Clinton's decision to grant a visa to Taiwan's president in 1995 to visit the United States, and then to walk away last year from a sweeping trade deal with China's reform-minded prime minister, Zhu Rongji.
So with the passion of a convert, Mr. Clinton is spending hours each day arguing the merits of a strategic vision he took years to adopt. In small gatherings in the Yellow Oval Room of the White House residence and even aboard Air Force One as he took New York Democrats to his wife's formal nomination for the Senate race, he has offered lectures about competing scenarios of what America's dealings with China may look like in 2025.
In public, his aides say the vote, scheduled for Wednesday, is still too close to call. "We don't have the 218 to pass it, and the opposition do not have 218 at this point, in my opinion, to stop it," Commerce Secretary William Daley, who is leading the administration's lobbying drive, said today on CBS' "Face the Nation."
In private, however, many of Mr. Clinton's advisers suspect the bill to give China permanent trade status -- thus ending an annual Congressional review -- will pass by a margin of 10 votes or more, chiefly because of the support of Republicans. The Republican whip in the House, Representative Tom DeLay of Texas, said today that "we're moving toward that magic number of 218," giving much of the credit to lobbying by the president.
For Mr. Clinton, the vote may be the last hope of making a deep imprint on foreign affairs in his second term. With time running out for a Mideast peace accord or a new arms deal with Russia, the outcome of the vote has taken on huge importance in the president's mind.
"He hates the word, but it's the legacy thing, in a big way," said one cabinet member.
But even if Mr. Clinton wins, the victory may feel incomplete.
Mr. Clinton acknowledges that for all his talk about the benefits for America of economic globalization -- how it opens new markets for American exports and innovation -- fewer Democrats are with him on this than on the1993 passage of the North American Free Trade Agreement. He told a colleague not long ago, "I'm doing this despite my party, not with it."
Even allies say that is because his commitment to rebuilding the China relationship and pursuing a trade policy for a new era of globalized commerce has waxed and waned.
"As in so many things," said Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, a leading advocate of the trade bill, "he too often let the politics of last month or next month affect decisions toward China that go to half-century strategic issues." Only in recent times, he added, "has the president begun to see this in historic terms."
So far, the White House strategy has been fairly straightforward. Mr. Clinton has largely let others argue the economic benefits, and avoided direct engagement with the labor unions that fear that any gains from an increase in exports to China will be outweighed by the movement of American jobs there.
Instead, the president has focused his arguments on national security, saying the real point of letting China into the World Trade Organization is to further economic engagement to give a boost to China's reformers and prevent the two nations from drifting into adversarial roles.
But with the coalition in Congress so fragile, Mr. Clinton's staff has carefully shielded him from much public engagement about the deal. They canceled a television address to the nation this evening, for fear it would anger undecided Democrats. After lengthy discussions, they declined to make him available for an interview on his seven years of dealings with China, again out of concern he might say something that could cost a few needed votes.
To the enormous frustration of the White House, the Chinese are hardly aiding Mr. Clinton's cause. In past years, when Congress was gearing up for a vote on the annual renewal of trading status, Beijing usually released a few long-imprisoned dissidents.
But this time, as Mr. Daley said recently, "the Chinese certainly aren't making it any easier." While they moderated their reaction to the inauguration this weekend of a new Taiwanese president, Chinese authorities have continued to arrest members of the Falun Gong religious group, and recently sentenced a leader of the fledgling Democracy Party to a long term in prison. Mr. Clinton, curiously, has made no recent public comments about those arrests.
Mr. Clinton and his team have tried to turn China's continued crackdowns to their advantage, arguing that the trade deal, by ushering in Western technology, legal systems and ideas, will ultimately undercut the ability of the Chinese government to repress dissent.
At the United States Coast Guard Academy on Wednesday, the president took this argument further than he ever has before, making the case that "when over 100 million people in China can get on the Net, it will be impossible to maintain a closed political and economic society."
"He's right, but it will take a generation," said Sandra Kristoff, who headed the Asian operations of the National Security Council in Mr. Clinton's first term. President Jiang Zemin of China is taking the other side of that bet, hoping that -- like Singapore -- he can reap the benefits of an open economic system while suppressing, or at least managing, true political opposition.
Mr. Clinton will likely be deep into retirement before historians can assess whether he or Mr. Jiang have guessed right. But it is already clear that Mr. Clinton's journey to his strategic vision of dealing with China was a long road with many unintended detours.
His first 18 months in office were spent digging his way out of his own campaign rhetoric. His comments had inflamed the Chinese, and Sen. Max Baucus, a Montana Democrat, said, "I remember telling him one day that the first step was that he had to treat China with respect." Mr. Clinton, he said, "seemed surprised."
By the end of 1993, and a disastrous trip to China by Secretary of State Warren Christopher, it was clear that the president's effort to link China's trading rights to its performance on human rights and arms proliferation was collapsing. It was a short intellectual leap to granting permanent trade status.
"There was no evidence that we ever gained any leverage over the Chinese with annual renewal," said Charlene Barshefsky, Mr. Clinton's trade representative. "It was an empty threat. We knew it, and the Chinese knew it."
Mr. Clinton reversed course, saying he could make more progress with China through engagement than with threats -- the conclusion his predecessors had reached.
Then in 1995, with his re-election looming, Mr. Clinton allowed Lee Tung-hui, Taiwan's president, to make a private visit to Cornell University for a college reunion, over the objections of many advisers. Mr. Clinton feared that denying the visa would prompt Congress to rewrite the Taiwan Security Act, worsening relations with Beijing. But he underestimated the outrage in Beijing.
Mr. Clinton now views that as a mistake. "There were two stages to his learning about China," said one former adviser, who dealt with China policy daily. "After the campaign he learned that China was a lot more complex than he believed. And now he's learned the second part -- that dealing with China means putting the security interests first, and not letting politics get in the way."
If that was the lesson, it was forgotten again in April 1999. By that time Mr. Clinton and Mr. Jiang had exchanged visits to China and the United States, and gotten to the final stages of the 13-year-long negotiations for China's entry into the World Trade Organization. Mr. Zhu, the prime minister who has come to personify China's economic reform movement, arrived in Washington ready to end the wrangling with an offer of a huge range of openings.
Many advised Mr. Clinton to take it; but he listened to Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin and Gene Sperling, the head of the National Economic Council, who feared that if a deal were struck, Congress was in no mood to pass it.
Mr. Clinton realized almost immediately he had made a mistake, but it was too late. Once the United States accidentally bombed the Chinese embassy in Belgrade during the air war over Kosovo just a few weeks later, talks froze. They were not resumed until marathon negotiations in November, and then some of the terms had changed -- for better, and for worse.
"The previous deal couldn't have passed,"' Mr. Sperling said recently, referring both to the details of the pact and the Congressional climate. "This one can."

HEADLINE: Rise in City Pensions Might Kill Tax Cut

BYLINE: By ERIC LIPTON 

 BODY:
The city's efforts to cut local taxes are being threatened by the State Legislature's proposal to increase pension benefits for city government workers, the Giuliani administration and City Council leaders say.
City leaders also say the proposed changes jeopardize their ability to keep the city financially stable and settle contracts with city workers. 
 The proposed state legislation would give automatic cost-of-living increases to retired city employees, cut veteran city employees' contributions toward their pensions, and create a new retirement-incentive program. The battle over the legislation is the latest in an escalating tug of war over who should control how New York City raises and spends its money.
Last year, over the objection of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and the City Council, the Legislature repealed the city's commuter tax, costing New York City about $400 million a year. As a result, tax cuts planned for city residents and businesses were abandoned.
This year, the city has an even larger tax cut plan on the table. But administration officials and the City Council speaker, Peter F. Vallone, are warning that the pension legislation, as well as measures already incorporated in the state budget plan, like a cap on state aid to the homeless in the city, could cost the city as much as $1.2 billion.
That could again force the city to reduce or scale back its own tax cuts, while also perhaps requiring it to spend money it has in reserve just to balance the $37.34 billion budget for the 2001 fiscal year, city budget officials said.
It would also reduce the amount available for the city to earmark for settlements with about 300,000 city workers whose contracts expire in the coming year, the officials said.
"What they are considering doing is absolutely irresponsible," said Adam L. Barsky, the director of Mr. Giuliani's Office of Management and Budget.
Mr. Vallone, who said he intended to join the Giuliani administration in lobbying against the measures, added, "It is not only arrogant, but it is absolutely wrong."
Union leaders defend the proposed pension changes, saying they would give retirees a better standard of living and make their benefits competitive with those approved recently for transit workers and other government employees.
"When inflation goes up, a retiree's pension should go up," said Randi Weingarten, president of the United Federation of Teachers and of the Municipal Labor Committee. "Retired city employees should not have to make a decision between paying their rent or their medical expenses." Nearly 40 states have made similar modifications to their pension plans, she said.
City officials said they were not opposed to considering increased pension benefits for more than 100,000 retirees, but wanted to make their own decisions about what the city could afford and how quickly it could afford it. If the state wants to pay for pension changes with state funds, city officials would have no objection.
"They are taking away our ability to make choices we think will be best for the city, while at the same time threatening our financial stability," Mr. Barsky said, maintaining that the cost-of-living increase for retirees could cost the city $1 billion in the 2001 fiscal year. The city is urging that the program be scaled back so that it would cost no more than $300 million to $500 million.
State officials and legislative leaders acknowledged yesterday that the cost-of-living plan -- which has been backed at least in concept by Gov. George E. Pataki, Comptroller H. Carl McCall and key members of the Legislature -- is expensive, but they said details that could affect the ultimate price tag are still being worked out.
"There is no specific agreement that has been reached, so any projection of a fiscal impact would be purely speculative," said Joseph E. Conway, a spokesman for Governor Pataki's budget office.
Mr. Conway; a spokeswoman for Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver; and Assemblyman Herman D. Farrell Jr., who is chairman of the Assembly's Ways and Means Committee; said yesterday that they were prepared to meet with city officials to discuss their concerns.
The city's financial picture, at least for now, remains extremely healthy, with budget officials projecting another record surplus of about $3 billion when the current fiscal year ends on June 30. Even if state officials enact many of the measures the Giuliani administration is opposing, city budget officials said they were confident they could get through the coming fiscal year without major spending cuts.
But several of the city's planned tax cuts for 2001, including halving the 14 percent surcharge on the personal income tax and eliminating the commercial rent tax, might need to be curtailed or abandoned, city officials said.
"That would be terrible and incredibly unfair to the city," said City Councilman Herbert E. Berman, a Brooklyn Democrat who is chairman of the Finance Committee.
Negotiations over the tax cuts and other aspects of the city's 2001 fiscal budget are to begin in earnest this week, but the uncertainty associated with the pension-related costs will complicate that effort.
The real trouble for the city would come in the next fiscal year, 2002. The current projected deficit for 2002 is $1.8 billion, but if the pension changes are approved, that could grow to between $3.5 billion and $4.4 billion, city budget officials said, a dangerously high level.
The deficit could also grow because of contract negotiations with all of the city workers' unions. Each 1 percent raise offered to employees would cost the city about $160 million a year.
A final major budget risk for the city is the $835 million windfall the city could lose over the next two years if the Giuliani administration and labor unions cannot agree to a so-called restart of the pension fund by the end of next month.
The restart would lower the city's contributions because it would revalue the pension assets after taking into consideration unusually high investment profits in the last three years. The Giuliani administration wants to use those savings to pay for general city services and tax cuts, while the unions want the savings to help pay for raises, as previous pension restarts indirectly did in 1991 and 1995.

HEADLINE: Study Finds Most States Lack System for Monitoring Asthma

BYLINE: By PHILIP J. HILTS 

 BODY:
As the number of asthma cases in the United States rises sharply and researchers scramble to find the cause, newly released data from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention shows that most states have no system to track the number of people with asthma or monitor what happens to them, and only a few states have any recent reports on the illness in their jurisdictions.
The data was reported in a study by Health Track, a new public health group based at Georgetown University in Washington and financed by the Pew Charitable Trusts. The study, to be made public today, says 27 states have no asthma monitoring program, 30 states have no up-to-date information on asthma within their borders, and more than 40 states have no "ready access" to information on how many people get emergency care or whether patients have access to good treatment. 
 The recent rise in the number of asthma cases is a mystery. It appears to be occurring in many spots around the world, and while the number of cases had been rising slowly over many decades the figures have shot up dramatically since about 1980, said Dr. Lynn Goldman, a pediatrician with the Johns Hopkins School of Hygiene and Public Health.
"The explosive growth has come recently, and it is very unusual," Dr. Goldman said. "There are not many things in medicine that rise suddenly like that." The increase -- from 75 percent to 160 percent in different age groups, with the biggest jump among children -- has occurred in less than 20 years.
Asthma is now the most common chronic disease among children, the most common medical reason for school absence and the most frequent cause of trips to hospital emergency rooms, according to statistics from the National Institutes of Health. The last statistic is important, doctors say, because treating asthma in the emergency room is an expensive and inefficient approach that health insurers would like to reduce.
Various studies have shown that certain factors -- including the presence of cockroaches, higher levels of ozone and diesel pollution, and increased smoking among young women -- are associated with asthma, but it is uncertain why. Dust mites, viral infections and breast-feeding have also been linked to the disease.
But in looking for the cause of the epidemic, said James O'Hara, executive director of Health Track, "We have blindfolded ourselves, because most states don't have access to one of the least expensive and most effective tools for preventing the spread of the disease: information."
Dr. Goldman said additional information was essential. "To prevent and treat the disease, we have to know where to look and what to look for," she said.
For example, knowing in what parts of the country and among what groups the disease is hitting hardest can help public health officials target prevention and treatment programs. More important in the long run is the way information on an epidemic can be used to spot its cause.
Researchers have estimated that a national tracking and monitoring program for asthma would cost about $25 million annually, Mr. O'Hara said. He said the cost of asthma to the national economy was about $14.5 billion a year and rising.
The Centers for Disease Control began to watch the rise in cases a few years ago, and in 1998 noted that the increase had reached epidemic proportions. The agency began to survey states, cities and territories about their ability to monitor the epidemic, and finished analyzing the survey results this year.
Health Track, which specializes in environmental issues, combined the data with reports from the National Institutes of Health and the Council of State and Territorial Epidemiologists to produce the current report.

HEADLINE: On AIDS Drugs, a Mixed Blessing

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Re "Cheaper Drugs to Combat AIDS" (editorial, May 15):
The AIDS epidemic in Africa needs to be fought in the same way that the AIDS epidemic in poor communities here should be fought. The primary health concern of a poor person with AIDS in New York City is not AIDS; it is the ability to obtain housing, nutritious food, education, gainful work opportunities and social services. In the case of Africans with AIDS and H.I.V., the problems are, among other things, lack of education, stigma and misinformation. 
 I applaud drug manufacturers in their humanitarian efforts, but we should be mindful that AIDS in Africa cannot be contained, controlled or managed simply by making cheaper drugs available. It must be addressed from the perspective of poverty, not simply the virus.
 
CARMEN PRICE
Director, Agency Services
United Way New York City
New York, May 15, 2000

HEADLINE: Protesting Sweatshops: Who Is Right?

 BODY:

To the Editor:
"Good Propaganda, Bad Economics," by Jaime Sneider (Op-Ed, May 16), misses the point behind anti-sweatshop protests at my campus and elsewhere in this country. While it may be true that Nike's factories in Vietnam provide ample wages relative to other opportunities, the university community is not satisfied with relative fairness.
As major consumers of college-logoed products, the protesters are saying they are willing to support higher prices for these goods, provided they are produced according to fair labor principles. 
 These protests do not harm factory workers. While transnational corporations often move factories when individual countries impose labor standards, university apparel producers cannot evade these rules by shifting production locations because the university will revoke licensing rights to those who do not follow the labor guidelines.
 
TOM GODFREY
Madison, Wis., May 17, 2000
 
The writer is a senior at the University of Wisconsin, Madison.

HEADLINE: A Silicon Alley Street Fair, Until a Virtual One Comes Along

BYLINE: By RANDAL C. ARCHIBOLD 

 BODY:
It was a typical New York street fair in so many ways: cotton candy, silly balloon hats, rock band, stock option raffle.
O.K., it was a little different. With 60-odd Internet companies hawking their wares at the Silicon Alley Street Fair, creativity ruled the day. And the 30-somethings at Asktherobot.com, a job-recruitment company, perhaps best captured the spirit of the day by raffling 500 shares of their soon-to-be-public stock to the winners of a basketball toss. 
 "This is the Internet," explained Michael Vogel, the chief executive of the company, which started nearly four months ago and plans to go public in a year or so. "The big calling card to the world is stock options. This is what the Internet is about."
Mr. Vogel estimated the potential value of the stock at $25,000, depending on the selling price at the initial public offering.
Yes, hyperbole ruled the day, as well.
The fair, after all, was intended in large part to promote Silicon Alley, the concentration of technology and Internet-related companies that have cropped up in and around Manhattan, said Janet Stites, the publisher of the Alleycat News, which organized the fair at Union Square Park with the marketing firm MarketMatch Inc. "People read about Silicon Alley, they hear about it, but they don't come face to face with it," Ms. Stites said. "It's an economic development issue and a curiosity issue."
Curiosity seemed to be winning. Droves of people, despite a chilly drizzle, massed under white tents for demonstrations of all manner of Web sites, brought through a T-1 high-capacity telephone line set up just for the event. And of course, they filled plastic bags with all manner of freebies: T-shirts, flying disks, caps and, of course, software.
Elaine Kimmel, 59, who lives nearby, toted a bag filled with goodies, a powerful lure for her. But she also recently bought an Internet-only computer after months of surfing the Web at a library, so anything "dot-com" would have brought her out. "I'm very obsessed with the Internet now," she said. "I'm just thrilled with it. I have so much clutter and thousands of pieces of paper, so I can get rid of it all because all the information is on the Internet."
J. C. Cohen of Brooklyn picked up a CD-ROM for a financial services Web site, infogate.com, and walked around in wonder at the variety of companies. Many of them were start-up firms like Asktherobot.com, but mainstays like I.B.M. and U.P.S. also got in on the action, as did out-of-towners like mall.com, a retail site based in Austin, Tex.
"It's a wider range of companies than I thought," Mr. Cohen said.
Internet service providers, or portals, and companies offering online shopping, though, seemed most abundant. Or at least made the most noise.
"Come on, lonely Matt here is waiting for somebody to e-mail him!" cried a worker for juno.com, an Internet service provider, as another employee, Matt Daly, sat checking his empty in-box.
Workers at cyberrate.com, a retailing site, beckoned passers-by by flashing a strobe light and throwing T-shirts.
Mariolene Jeanbaptiste, dressed as a big red bean, passed out temporary tattoos for beenz.com, an electronic commerce site.
"They'll try anything," said Marion Rodgers, turning away from the big bean with a handful of tattoos. "It's like when you go to the mall and all these people come up to you. I don't know why I would be surprised that Internet companies would be any different. Maybe because you never see real people on the Internet."
Certainly the paradox at hand -- that everybody there had left his home to visit a fair whose companies promise you won't have to because of the Internet -- was not lost on some people.
"It would be interesting to see if they can have a virtual street fair some day," said Adrian Marsh, a sophomore at New York University majoring in English who is thinking of majoring in computer science. "At least that way they would not have to worry about the weather."
Maybe next year, though organizers have more modest goals like using wireless modems next time, and, of course, drawing more companies. Laura Sabia of MarketMatch said she is working on creating similar fairs for other cities, like Boston and Washington.
New York's fair was enough for Alan Barnes, 33, of Park Slope, Brooklyn. "This place was as crowded and jumbled as the Internet," he said as he left empty-handed and walked into that century-old portal, the subway.

HEADLINE: Mayor Says He Wants to Reach Out to Dorismond Family

BYLINE: By ERIC LIPTON 

 BODY:
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, who upon ending his campaign for the Senate intimated that he would work to improve his relationship with minority residents, said in an interview broadcast yesterday that he had "sympathy, concern and compassion" for the family of a Haitian-American man killed by the police in March.
The mayor made the remarks on Saturday in an intensely personal interview with Tim Russert for broadcast yesterday on NBC's "Meet the Press." Mr. Giuliani also said he had no regrets about his decision to drop out of the Senate race, given that he now realized that politics was "not the most important thing in life." 
 The half-hour interview touched on a broad range of topics, from Mr. Giuliani's thoughts about his political future to his prostate cancer and what he acknowledged might have been bad advice his father once offered him, suggesting that it is more important to be respected than to be loved.
"You know, fathers make mistakes and fathers are human beings, and I tend to think now that love is more important than I thought," the mayor said.
Mr. Giuliani first acknowledged on Thursday that he did not respond properly to the fatal shooting in March of Patrick M. Dorismond, the Haitian-American man, by a plainclothes police officer who had tried to solicit marijuana from him. Mr. Dorismond, a security guard who was standing outside a Midtown bar, was unarmed and was not carrying drugs.
The mayor said in the "Meet the Press" interview that he intended "to find a way" to let Mr. Dorismond's family know about his regrets, including possibly a visit with his parents. But the mayor again defended his decision on the day of Mr. Dorismond's shooting to release his juvenile arrest record.
"What I should have done is to do a lot more to express sympathy, concern, help, assistance, compassion for a situation where, whether justified or unjustified, whatever it turns out, was still a tragic situation," the mayor said. "I think that is where I made a mistake."
Mr. Giuliani also spoke at length with Mr. Russert about his desire, first expressed on Friday, to try to extend the benefits of New York City's current economic boom to more disaffected communities in the city. The mayor said he had not yet decided how he would do that, but he said he was committed to finding a way "to break down the barriers that I've created" as a result of his own sometimes abrasive personality.
"There are people in the city who feel that they haven't been reached" by the progress in the city in recent years, the mayor said. "There are people that feel that I don't care about them, there are people who feel that I don't take them into equal consideration."
Outside predominantly black churches in Harlem and Queens yesterday, city residents said they would be watching the mayor to see if he lived up to his vows. Many said they were skeptical that the mayor, who has been criticized for increasing tension between the city authorities and New York's ethnic neighborhoods, would succeed.
"You know, it is like a leopard changing his spots," said Douglas K. Henderson, 65, outside the Abyssinian Baptist Church in Harlem. "It has got to be some sort of a miracle."
Many said they wanted to see him talk with black leaders like the Rev. Al Sharpton and visit in black neighborhoods, and then to act on what he has heard.
"He needs to lend people of color an ear," said Sharon McClarty, 44, a computer technician from Jamaica, Queens. "He has been talking, but he doesn't listen."
Andrea Summers, a mother of two who said she was cut from the welfare rolls as part of the mayor's workfare program, said the mayor needed to soften his harsh stance on welfare. She said she worked at two jobs but could not earn enough to pay the rising rents in Harlem.
She dismissed the mayor's comments about breaking down barriers. "He never comes to our parades, never comes meet the people," she said. "He is never here."
As the mayor's remarks were televised yesterday, founders of the group 100 Blacks in Law Enforcement Who Care challenged him to compensate the Dorismond family by settling a lawsuit it has filed against the city.
Attempts to reach Mr. Dorismond's parents, Marie and Andre Dorismond, through their lawyer, Johnnie L. Cochran Jr., were unsuccessful yesterday. But on Saturday, Andre Dorismond dismissed the mayor's recent offers of sympathy. "Now it doesn't make sense for him to apologize," he said. "It's been two months since my son died. It's too late."
During the "Meet the Press" interview, the mayor, who said he was still struggling to decide on which cancer treatment to choose, appeared relaxed, laughing and joking with Mr. Russert at times, even offering him one of his trademark Godfather impersonations.
He called the decision to drop out of the Senate race the most difficult of his life, a choice he said he made entirely because of his cancer and not because of the controversy surrounding his relationship with an East Side woman, Judith Nathan, and his decision earlier this month to separate from his wife.
"But for the cancer and the timing of the cancer, I would have gone ahead and done it," Mr. Giuliani said.
Mr. Giuliani, 55, who has 18 months left in office, deferred questions about his own political future, not indicating if he might make a run for governor or accept an appointment to the cabinet of George W. Bush, if Mr. Bush wins his bid for president.
"I love politics," the mayor said. "The thing I felt good about as I made the decision" to leave the Senate race is: "I finally figured out that politics in not my life. My life is about things that are closer to you and deeper than that."
And Mr. Giuliani said he had not yet decided what he would do with the approximately $9 million in unspent campaign contributions he had amassed, noting only that he intended to do as much as he could to support Representative Rick A. Lazio of Long Island.
"I am going to try to do everything I can to help" Mr. Lazio, the mayor said, "if it is advertising, if it's an appearance, if it's figuring out how to make sure they're able to raise money."

HEADLINE: E-COMMERCE REPORT;
Internet businesses may find the global village dauntingly native.

BYLINE: By Bob Tedeschi 

 BODY:
FALLING stock prices are not the only numbers giving e-commerce executives heartburn these days. Equally unsettling to some Internet merchants is the flood of statistics suggesting that to keep their businesses growing, they have to look outside the United States.
A report to be released today by IDC, an Internet research firm, predicts that two-thirds of all e-commerce spending will take place outside the country by 2003. In that year, IDC says, consumer spending on Web sites in the United States will reach $119 billion, but overseas sites will garner $209 billion of business. 
 And yet, with the investment community demanding that Web merchants find a speedier path to profitability, the merchants can hardly justify the expenses associated with rolling out sites aimed at other nations.
Those expenses can be substantial. According to Eric Schmitt, an analyst with the Forrester Research consulting firm, retailers can spend "a couple million dollars in the first year of international efforts."
"And this is a treadmill," he said. "You don't just build the Spanish version and walk away. It's a beast that needs to be fed."
Just last week, Boo.com, a British fashion e-tailer, went out of business a mere six months after its public stock offering. Boo.com had quickly become insolvent -- in large part because of the strain of trying to start up in 18 different countries simultaneously.
Barry Parr, author of the IDC report, said that even when e-commerce companies have the money to devote to overseas expansion, "these markets can be very difficult to address." In addition to the obvious language hurdles, he said e-tailers faced regulatory challenges with import and export rules, taxation and technology issues, and wrinkles in each country's customer service and fulfillment approaches.
Industry executives said that any of these items could, if mishandled, torpedo a company's international efforts. But fulfillment issues are particularly problematic. When the e-commerce trend took off two years ago, some analysts predicted that Web merchants would overturn traditional retailing, which tended to be based on customers who shop within 10 miles of their homes.
Indeed, that revolutionary sentiment partly fueled investors' enthusiasm for companies like Amazon.com and CDNow, which quickly found customers throughout the world who were willing to shop on their sites. But the last year consumers and businesses have acknowledged that many customers prefer to do business with retailers that can serve them both on the Web and in a local store if they want to return items.
At the very least, analysts said, consumers want to shop with an Internet retailer that can handle customer service problems and returns from the same continent.
For Web merchants with global aspirations, that frequently means building and staffing customer service centers on different continents -- as Amazon did when it set up a phone center in the Netherlands this year -- as well as working with local distributors or manufacturers.
Despite such a daunting list of investment and cultural challenges, Mr. Parr of IDC said globalization plans were imperative for Internet retailers.
"I tell companies that before they leap into wireless initiatives, they should figure out their international strategy. It has to be part of the plan."
In devising that strategy, analysts say one crucial decision is how a company manages its foreign Web sites. On one hand, if a company chooses to manage the global operations from the United States, its foreign sites are far more prone to make linguistic and merchandising mistakes -- for instance, selling goods that might be offensive in certain cultures, or offering product instructions that are delivered with the wrong tone.
"In Japan, you wouldn't say 'Don't turn the left knob,' because that's too direct," said Charles Baxter, chief executive of eTranslate, a consulting company. "You'd say something like 'It would be much better to turn the right knob.' "
Such mistakes are less likely if companies hire a team in each foreign market to handle the Web site, analysts said. But that, too, can lead to problems for companies trying to convey a consistent brand message.
"Customers can spot inconsistencies," Forrester's Mr. Schmitt said. "If you have to deal in multiple countries, you don't want 10 sites with a different look and feel at every one, and companies don't want to have 10 different backend systems."
One of the earliest successes in e-commerce globalization was Dell Computer, which began selling on the Web in 1996 and now has sites aimed at 85 different countries and territories. According to Frank Muehleman, senior vice president of Dell's worldwide division, the company uses a decentralized approach with its international sites.
Dell created a common technology platform for each of its global sites, including a template for ordering and product information, which ensures a consistent user experience across the sites. In addition several hundred specialists give advice and training to the local managers. "Then we let the local team handle the rollout," Mr. Muehleman said.
Just as important, Mr. Muehleman said, Dell built manufacturing plants in each of the regions it serves, including Brazil, Ireland, China and Malaysia. And because the company employs local customer service staff, he said, "every time a customer picks up the phone, they're dealing with someone local."
The Internet companies that have been the most active on the global front are the so-called portals, like Yahoo, Alta Vista and Lycos -- last week Lycos agreed to be acquired by Terra Networks, the Internet arm of the Spanish telecommunications company Telefonica de Espana. The portals' expansion into other nations, while not easy, has been a relative snap compared with the travails of companies that must actually move goods across borders.
And even e-commerce companies that do not sell goods on the Web, like financial firms, have encountered plenty of obstacles in other countries. When the online broker Schwab.com started a site for clients in Britain in 1998, for instance, many customers there balked at online trading because they were accustomed to exchanging paper stock certificates in each transaction. Chiefly because Schwab.com refused to give paper certificates to its online customers, the site generated just 15,000 new accounts between June 1998 and June 1999, according to Russ Shaw, senior vice president of marketing for Charles Schwab Europe.
The site then offered 30 days of commission-free trading to new customers last summer, and generated nearly 30,000 new customers in about two months. For both the customers and Schwab, Mr. Shaw said, "it's been an education process."
Analysts say that most e-commerce companies are reluctant to begin that process, given the already steep learning curve they have encountered in the domestic market. But some alternatives may emerge.
American e-tailers, for example, could form partnerships with retailers in other nations that want e-commerce sites of their own but lack the expertise to build them. Mr. Parr, the IDC analyst, said that under such an approach, an American e-tailer could lend its technology, and perhaps its name, to a foreign counterpart, which in turn would offer its local distribution and customer service systems and expertise. The companies would then share the revenues.
Martin McClanan, chief executive of Red Envelope, a gift site, said he had been approached several times with similar offers, but so far he had demurred. "Our plan is to bring this business to scale in the U.S. first," he said. "Then, when we can dedicate a 20-person team to another country, we'll do that." The company might consider global expansion plans after this holiday season, he added.
"It's so easy to want to boil the ocean and do everything," he said. "But in retail it's all about execution. And getting this business to profitability is still first and foremost."

HEADLINE: Ruins Alter Ideas of How Civilization Spread

BYLINE: By JOHN NOBLE WILFORD 

 BODY:
In the northeastern corner of Syria, near the Iraqi border and within sight of southern Turkey's Taurus Mountains, archaeologists have begun excavations of an ancient settlement that lay on a major trade route from Nineveh to Aleppo. The ruins from more than 5,500 years ago are telling them that previous ideas about the spread of early civilization were more than likely wrong.
The first trenches cut into the large 500-acre site, Tell Hamoukar, have yielded strong evidence that centrally administered complex societies in northern regions of the Middle East apparently arose simultaneously but independently of the more celebrated city-states of southern Mesopotamia, in what is now southern Iraq. In the conventional view, civilization was thought to begin solely in the south and then move north through trade and colonization. 
 In an announcement of the new finds, Dr. McGuire Gibson, an archaeologist at the Oriental Institute of the University of Chicago, said, "We need to reconsider our ideas about the beginnings of civilization, pushing the time further back."
Other archaeologists familiar with the research agreed in interviews last week that the Tell Hamoukar excavations confirmed and should elaborate on a consensus that has emerged among scholars in the last decade about the role of northern settlements in Syria and Iraq and in southeastern Turkey in the development of civilization. These settlements exhibited many of the attributes of civilization -- monumental architecture, division of labor, social stratification -- apparently before they had any significant contact with people in the lower valleys of the Tigris and Euphrates rivers.
"It's a very important excavation," said Dr. Gil J. Stein, an archaeologist at Northwestern University. "It fits in really nicely with a picture that's been emerging, based on several other excavation sites."
Even Dr. Guillermo Algaze, an archaeologist at the University of California at San Diego, who had argued for a south-to-north transplantation of early civilization, said that he now generally agreed with the new interpretation. "I've been eating a lot of crow lately," he said.
Excavations at Tell Hamoukar were started last summer by a joint expedition of the Oriental Institute and the Syrian Directorate General of Antiquities. Work will resume next month and will probably continue for many years. The site promises an abundance of artifacts, archaeologists said, not only because of its large size but also because most of the material seems to be close to the surface.
Digging into the oldest layer of ruins uncovered so far, archaeologists found traces of people living in villages at the site as early as 4000 B.C. Within 300 years, the settlement had grown into a prosperous town of at least 32 acres with ample evidence of a well-organized society of the kind associated with the early stages of civilization.
For one thing, Dr. Gibson said, the town appeared to be enclosed by a defensive wall 10 feet high and 13 feet wide. Such walls came with civilization.
Inside the walls the archaeologists dug up the remains of fine pottery and several large ovens, shaped like igloos, evidence of food preparation on an institutional scale. The same areas held pieces of large cooking pots and animal bones and traces of wheat, barley and oats for what must have been a bakery and also probably a brewery.
"Preparing bread and food on such a scale is evidence of a society in which somebody is organizing people and resources," Dr. Gibson said. "You are building up a hierarchy, a social structure that's a mark of civilization."
Some of the most telling evidence for an organized, stratified society, archaeologists said, were the seals the people probably used to mark containers of food and other goods. Some of the seals are small, with only simple incisions or cross-hatching. Others are larger, presumably for higher officials to stamp more valuable goods. One of these stamping seals was in the form of a leopard with 13 spots, and others were in the shape of deer, bears and ducks.
"We would propose that the larger, more elaborate seals with figurative scenes were held only by the few people who had greater authority, while the smaller, simply incised seals were used by many more people with less authority," Dr. Gibson said. "The difference would be something like the signature of the regional director of customs of Chicago compared to the rubber stamps that say only 'U.S. Customs.' "
In southern Mesopotamia at this time, an expanding population and increased food production from irrigation were changing the social landscape even more drastically. Economies were being run by increasingly centralized leadership. Agricultural villages grew into urban centers, some of which were in time ruled by local kings. This became known to scholars as the Uruk period, after one of the more prominent of these southern city-states, more than 400 miles south of Tell Hamoukar, and it was the period that established Mesopotamia as "the cradle of civilization."
The Chicago archaeologists said they had found no pottery or other evidence of Uruk influences on the Tell Hamoukar settlement in the 3700-3500 B.C. period. Some Uruk-type pottery shows up around 3200, by which time there was perhaps a substantial southern Mesopotamian presence at the site.
Other excavations at Tell Brak, also in northeast Syria, and Hacinebi and Arslantepe, in southeast Turkey, have also revealed that complex societies had developed before any significant contact with the Uruk people, Dr. Stein said.
So when southern Mesopotamians did expand into the north in the middle to late fourth millennium, Dr. Stein concluded, they "came into contact with northern polities that were already quite advanced chiefdoms, even though they were not as large in scale as the urbanized states of the south."
Although he now agrees with this view, Dr. Algaze cautioned that it would be a mistake to allow "the pendulum of thinking to swing too far in the other direction" and conclude that the northern societies were comparable in their scale of development with those in the south. Since the first writing presumably developed to handle record-keeping for a centralized economy, he said, the fact that writing originated in Sumer, in southern Mesopotamia, indicated a more advanced society there.
In a publication of the Oriental Institute, Dr. Gibson noted that a few scholars were even suggesting that perhaps civilization began not in southern Mesopotamia, but in the north, and that it gradually made its way south.
"Before we start revising our textbooks, however, we should remember that there was an even earlier contact with people who had come from southern Mesopotamia," he wrote, referring to a southern culture in the Ubaid period, extending from 5500 to about 4000 B.C. Some Ubaid pottery and other artifacts have been found scattered throughout the Middle East.
Dr. Richard Zettler, a University of Pennsylvania archaeologist with extensive experience in Syria, said: "I'm convinced that our real focus now should not be on the Uruk period, but the Ubaid. It's not a terribly well-known period."
For one reason, he said, remains from the Ubaid period are hard to find in southern Mesopotamia. They are presumably buried deep beneath Uruk sites or covered by river silt. Archaeologists may have more luck looking for an earlier transition to complex societies at sites in the north, perhaps including Tell Hamoukar.
Dr. Gibson would make no promises. "It's a very big site and it's going to take a lot of digging," he said.
