LENGTH: 2260 words

HEADLINE: Chancellor's Political Ability Balances His Outsider Status

BYLINE: By ANEMONA HARTOCOLLIS and ABBY GOODNOUGH 

 BODY:
Last week, as Harold O. Levy pulled off the improbable feat of becoming chancellor of the New York City schools, he announced at a cabinet meeting that 30 volumes of chancellor's regulations -- accumulating since 1958 -- had been slashed to 9 volumes. Gone were vestiges like how to help students deal with the assassination of President John F. Kennedy.
Yes, a staff member fretted in a reporter's presence, but shouldn't he run the changes past the 43 district and other superintendents first? "No," Mr. Levy replied. "Just do it. If we have to restore some, we can do that later." 
 "Just do it" could be Mr. Levy's motto. As much as anything, his pragmatic approach to management explains how a high-level corporate lawyer with no experience running a single school became the chancellor of the country's largest school system. In his first 125 days, he has surprised even the savviest insiders by going from dark horse for interim chancellor -- with Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani opposing him -- to unanimous choice for the permanent job, with the mayor instructing his appointees to support him.
From his earliest days as student government president at the Bronx High School of Science to his ascension to international trouble-shooter for Sanford I. Weill, the chairman and chief executive of Citigroup, Mr. Levy is remembered by friends and colleagues as a consummate politician with a shrewd strategic intelligence, honed by his experience as a courtroom litigator.
With knowledge acquired from three years on the State Board of Regents, he has a passionate sense of how to improve the schools, and has promised to hire better teachers, crack down on superintendents and principals whose students perform poorly and lobby aggressively for more state and city aid. As the father of young schoolchildren, albeit children attending private school, he has a sense of what parents want, and has moved quickly to reach out to groups that have felt shut out.
But there may be a flip side to Mr. Levy's cunning, charm and admitted love of the limelight. He has a tendency, associates say, to assume that he knows the answers, even when he may not. And he can be as imperious as he is seductive, sometimes letting his drive to get things done blind him to the distress or disagreement of those around him.
"He could be a chancellor to reckon with," said one longtime superintendent, "if he learns to listen."
Mr. Levy's background as a corporate lawyer with no formal credentials in education, and his skill in making quick decisions, may give him the fresh perspective and brashness needed to make radical changes. But his outsider status could also be a liability. He is the first white full-time chancellor since 1983, in a system that is 84 percent black, Hispanic and Asian, and only 16 percent white.
Indeed, race was in the air as he attended a forum led by the Rev. Al Sharpton in Harlem two Saturdays ago.
"The schools are killing fields," a woman in a turquoise satin turban, calling herself Mother Franklin, boomed into the microphone as Mr. Levy sat on a platform in the storefront auditorium, decorated with paintings of Malcolm X and James Brown. "The school system is nothing but an industry." Another likened Mr. Levy's going to Harlem to talk about public schools to Hitler's defending the Holocaust, a particularly raw remark given Mr. Levy's background as the son of Jewish refugees from Nazi Germany.
But what may have been more telling about Mr. Levy's management style was simply that he was there to visit Mr. Sharpton's headquarters, something, as Mr. Sharpton noted, that the previous chancellor, Rudy Crew, had never done.
Mr. Levy, 47, is the self-made son of a hardware store owner in the Bronx. His father, Hugo, a textile merchant, and mother, Alice, fled Germany in 1939, settling in Washington Heights, then a middle-class neighborhood of German-Jewish immigrants. His grandparents were killed in concentration camps. A sister, Marion, died of kidney disease at age 12 before he was born, but her photo was always prominent in the Levy home and the family visited her grave throughout Mr. Levy's childhood.
Despite his modest roots, Mr. Levy is the product of Cornell and Oxford Universities and has worked his way into New York's corporate and cultural elite. Six feet and 200 pounds, in pinstriped suits, gold cuff links, tasseled loafers and eggheady wire-rim glasses, he works to project a down-to-earth image with a conversational style that is breezy and direct, free of pandering in public, rife with expletives in private.
He works hard to dispel the image of a patrician dabbling in public service out of noblesse oblige. "I have tried to be sensitive," he said. "My way of dealing with it is to say I am going to do the best job I can. I am not going to change my race."
Derided as a Henry Higgins for sending poetry to board members and arranging violin lessons for superintendents, Mr. Levy said he was trying to build teamwork and boost morale, standard practice in business.
"I believe that education is an opportunity for social mobility, me included," he said. "That was a way out, a way up. Children in public school have an absolute right to experience the finer things in life, just as much as everybody else. That's not elitism. That's being a democrat, small d."
As for his pursuit of the chancellorship, he said: "It's not a lark. We've come to the point in our society where unless you explain why you're doing something on a monetary, mock-rational basis, you can't be serious. Our society has lost the ability to encourage people to be altruistic, adventuresome, to submerge themselves at least for a moment in the greater good."
Unlike the last two chancellors, Mr. Levy is a confirmed New Yorker, living with his wife, Patricia Sapinsley, and two children, Noah, 6, and Hannah, 9, on Riverside Drive near Columbia University. Ms. Sapinsley, whose mother, Lila, is a prominent Republican in Rhode Island, gave up her architecture practice when her son was born.
Mr. Levy has drafted two Upper West Side friends and neighbors to be his top deputies: Jonathan Levi, a novelist, and David Klasfeld, a former mid-level City Hall cabinet member.
As a father, the new chancellor tells poignant stories of wrestling with phonics and the ache of a bad fit between child and teacher. He talks about schools in a jargon-free way that every New Yorker can understand. But while he is proud of his own public school education, Mr. Levy sends his children to Dalton, one of the city's most selective and expensive private schools.
He and his wife looked at public and private schools, but chose Dalton because it was the best fit, he said. (Reminded that most New Yorkers of his means reject public school on the assumption, right or wrong, that private schools are simply better, he said their decision was more complicated than that.)
Some say Mr. Levy's lack of on-the-job experience in education could hurt him. At a recent teachers' union convention, Mr. Levy offended guidance counselors by suggesting that historically, their job had been a hiding place for inept teachers.
"It's going to be important for Harold to understand what he knows well and what he still needs to learn," said Ann Marcus, dean of New York University's education school.
Mr. Levy is working hard to woo skeptics. When Diane Ravitch, the acerbic historian of New York City schools, wrote an Op-Ed page article in March attacking Mr. Levy's summer-school program, he called her at 8 the same morning to invite her over, and they talked for an hour about religion, books and education. By contrast, Chancellor Crew refused to shake her hand after she criticized him. "I found his lack of defensiveness impressive," she said of Mr. Levy.
He has also used his candor to cultivate reporters and editors. (He admits to two hours of media training.)
As for his relationship with Mayor Giuliani, Mr. Levy, who so far has tried hard to be conciliatory, would not make any predictions. "I'll make judgments as we go," he said. "There are a lot of things we agree on and a lot of things I can work with him on, but I can't change who I am."
Being chancellor is a dream job for Mr. Levy, friends say. As Citigroup's director of global compliance, he was in charge of ensuring that employees in 100 countries followed proper policies and laws. But in the banking industry, deal makers rule the roost. Lawyers -- no matter how highly paid (his financial disclosure form says more than $500,000 a year, far more than his chancellor's pay of $245,000) -- are on the margins of power. Though he had risen to the top, he was restless.
Mr. Weill, recognizing his political skills, assigned him to special projects like negotiating between the Rev. Jesse Jackson's Rainbow/PUSH Coalition and Wall Street over investment in the inner city and in hardscrabble rural areas.
His prowess as chancellor has amazed and tickled some former colleagues, but others see a pattern. While his college classmates organized antiwar protests, Mr. Levy, at 20, won a seat on Cornell's board of trustees. Three years after being appointed to the board of the University Settlement Society, a social service agency on the Lower East Side, he became chairman.
Over the years, working with chancellors like Ramon C. Cortines, Mr. Levy said he fantasized about what he would do if he were chancellor, but never imagined such a thing could come true. But friends and associates have no doubt that when Mr. Levy put his name forward as interim chancellor in January, he was already angling for the permanent job. "It was like letting the fox into the henhouse," Meryl Tisch, who served with him on the Board of Regents, said affectionately.
Mr. Levy's drive was evident early on. Growing up in Washington Heights, he attended Public School 189, Junior High School 52 and Bronx Science, one of the city's most selective high schools. He got his undergraduate and law degrees at Cornell, and a master's in politics, philosophy and economics at Oxford.
Hired by the civil rights division of the Justice Department, he left in 11 months, he said, because he disapproved of Reagan-era policies. He moved on to some of the city's most competitive legal and investment banking firms: Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom; Philipp Brothers; Salomon Brothers, the Travelers Group and then Citigroup.
At Philipp Brothers, Mr. Levy tracked down thousands of tons of coffee that had disappeared from Mexican warehouses; wrested back Pizza Hut franchises that the company had lost in Taiwan, and cracked down on lawyers who were spending too much and taking too long to settle a huge international case.
"Harold is used to cleaning things up and getting things back under control," said Donald Feuerstein, the chief legal officer at Salomon at the time. "He is good at going into unknown territory, identifying the problem and fixing it without delay."
He was a playground monitor in elementary school, supervising his classmates with a whistle in his mouth.
"Harold was always more controlled and adult than the rest of us," said Ilene Guralnick, who was Mr. Levy's classmate from elementary through high school.
As a high school student in the 60's, he was antiwar, but not an activist. "He was never the guy with the bullhorn or the one who would get into a confrontation with the principal," said Arthur Schwartz, another high school classmate. "He wanted to work through the proper channels to get something accomplished."
As one of 220 associates at Skadden, Arps, as a litigator working on mergers and acquisitions, Mr. Levy got into the habit of rising at 4:30 a.m., a practice he said he maintains to this day. Nearly 20 years later, after becoming interim chancellor, he was introduced to Lewis E. Lehrman, a founder of the Rite Aid Corporation. "Nice to meet you," Mr. Lehrman said, according to witnesses. "I've been with you many times," Mr. Levy replied. "I used to go to the Brasserie at 4:30 in the morning to do paperwork. You came in at 5:15 to read the papers."
Mr. Levy inherited what he calls a familial tremor from his father, which sometimes causes his hands to shake, and is worsened, he said, by fatigue and caffeine. To combat the tremor during grueling exams at Oxford, he began using fountain pens, which require less hand pressure.
Mr. Levy has cultivated powerful mentors.
As chairman of a commission to investigate the city's crumbling school buildings, he forged ties with Jack Rudin, the builder, James S. Tisch, chief executive and co-president of Loews, and Sheldon Silver, speaker of the State Assembly. Two years later, those connections helped him become a regent, where he became close to Richard Mills, the state education commissioner, and Randi Weingarten, president of the teachers' union. Ms. Weingarten lobbied for him as chancellor, but Mr. Levy denies Mr. Giuliani's accusations that he is too cozy with the union and he has pushed for changes in the union, like letting principals demand lesson plans.
Mr. Levy is not given to self-reflection. But in a visit to Bronx Science in April, he indulged in a rare meditation on his life, describing his 25th reunion in 1995. Looking at his middle-aged classmates, he was struck at how many of them had become doctors, lawyers and accountants, professionals like him. Beware of losing your passion, he warned, or "you wind up being disappointed in yourself in later life."
Now he will never be just another lawyer, doctor or accountant again.

HEADLINE: National News Briefs;
Clinton and Speaker Reach Antipoverty Deal

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 22

 BODY:
President Clinton struck a deal today with Speaker J. Dennis Hastert that merges their antipoverty initiatives by expanding the number of empowerment zones and enacting a Republican redevelopment program, officials said.
Mr. Clinton is expected to announce the agreement at the White House on Tuesday with Mr. Hastert. 
 The agreement, which Congress must approve, would expand the number of empowerment zones to 40 from 31 and increase the tax credits, capital gains relief and other incentives offered to investors in poor areas. In addition, it would set up a redevelopment program for 40 so-called renewal communities, which would have no capital gains tax and a variety of other tax incentives.
Gene Sperling, the president's economic adviser, said the programs would cost $15 billion to $20 billion over the next decade.

HEADLINE: After 20 Years, Iranian Caviar Returns to America

BYLINE: By FLORENCE FABRICANT 

 BODY:
CAVIAR from Iran will be sold here for the first time in 20 years. Trade barriers were lifted two months ago, and the first shipment of 440 pounds is expected to arrive in Boston today. 
 Whether Iranian caviar is the finest in the world, as some connoisseurs contend, remains to be seen. But one thing is certain: it is the most expensive. In America, prices will be about 30 percent more than for Russian imports. The Browne Trading Company in Portland, Me., plans to sell a 500-gram tin (a little more than a pound) of Iranian beluga for $1,150. The same amount of sevruga will be $600, golden osetra will be $800. About an ounce of osetra (30 grams), will be $90. FLORENCE FABRICANT

HEADLINE: EATING WELL;
Is Salmon Organic? Not Yet

BYLINE: By Marian Burros 

 BODY:
SENATOR TED STEVENS of Alaska says the wild salmon that swim around the waters of his state are so pure and clean they are entitled to wear the organic label.
As chairman of the Senate Appropriations Committee, he added $75,000 to the Agriculture Department's budget to cover the cost of public hearings to ensure that the salmon are included in the federal organic standards expected to go into effect at the end of the year. The proposed standards will cover everything except aquatic animals and honeybees, but the Alaska salmon industry is pushing for the change in the rules because the organic label generally adds 25 to 35 percent to the value of a product. 
 Since Senator Stevens, a Republican, holds the purse strings for the Agriculture Department and could easily derail the new organic labeling regulation, his request is making the department uneasy. According to documents of the National Organic Standards Board, organic certification standards should not be developed for wild animals, including fish, because the issue is controversial. Organic farming as it has been defined for 30 years is a managed system tracking everything that goes into production, but salmon migrate thousands of miles across oceans and their habitats cannot be carefully monitored.
Instead of the organic label, the department is suggesting labeling to indicate the products were harvested and handled according to certain standards. The Marine Stewardship Council, an accreditation body founded by Unilever and the World Wildlife Fund that has developed ecolabel guidelines, would certify that such fish had come from healthy fisheries and that fishing for them had not hurt the environment.
Katherine DiMatteo, executive director of the Organic Trade Association, said: "We are not willing to come up with a set of standards for organic fish. There is very little control of the system."
Calling Alaskan salmon organic, she said, has nothing to do with the philosophy of organic agriculture and improving the environment, but everything to do with money. "We feel we shouldn't be pressured by an interest group who wants the organic label for marketing purposes," she said. "That's the very wrong reason to ask us to change our 30 years of work. In fact, it cheapens the organic label."
The largest natural foods supermarket chain, Whole Foods, says it will not sell organic fish. "Under no circumstances," said Margaret Wittenberg, the chain's vice president of governmental and public affairs. "Wild is organic by neglect and it's not the same. Wild does need more recognition, but allowing wild fish to piggyback on organic is going to water down organic."
For those who have watched organic grow from a much mocked description of the weeds and seeds sold in grungy stores and eaten by hippies in Birkenstocks in the 1970's to one that confers a premium price, this triumphal moment, when federal organic standards will become a reality, is bringing a new set of problems. Alaska is not the only entity that wants to cash in on the organic cachet. Large food companies are increasingly buying up small organic companies, not to improve the environment but to improve their bottom lines. Organic sales have increased about 20 percent annually for the last 10 years.
"Organic is a useful marketing tool," said Kate Troll, the fisheries specialist at the Alaska Department of Commerce and Economic Development. "This is a way to sell at a better price."
Our salmon "is beyond organic," said Doug Mecum, director of commercial fisheries in the Alaska Department of Fish and Game. "It's totally natural and wild. It's a healthy product, free of pollutants."
In the past, the state has promoted its wild salmon as superior to farmed in flavor and quality. But few people know the difference between wild and farmed salmon and have no idea which kind they are eating. Farmed salmon now account for 60 percent of the world's market and have seriously depressed the price of wild salmon.
Like commercial chickens, farmed fish live in not particularly sanitary conditions. They are fed dye pellets to give them the pink color that occurs naturally in free-swimming salmon. They eat manufactured food that may contain genetically modified ingredients. They are treated with antibiotics because of fish lice.
Ironically, because the farmed fish live their entire lives in controlled waters, they could be certified organic if changes were made in their environment and food. Certified organic farmed fish are already being sold in Britain.
That label for farmed salmon is seen as an additional threat to wild Alaskan salmon. "We saw that the door was going to be opened to farm-raised salmon," Ms. Troll said, "and we thought we needed a level playing field."
Two Pacific Northwest fish processors are now certified organic by two independent organic certifying agencies. Prime Select Seafood in Cordova, Alaska, is selling certified organic Copper River salmon and eventually may sell organic halibut as well. But Susan Laird, its vice president, said she had no idea if the label would be worth the added expenses of certification.
Wild sockeye salmon processed by Capalino Pacific in Bellingham, Wash., has also been certified organic, but the company decided not to use the label after consulting with some leading chefs. The chefs said that organic salmon suggested farmed and that wild salmon was far superior.
"Organic is a lot sexier," said Jon Saarheim, a partner in Capalino Pacific, "but it seems more accurate to say the salmon is wild and that it is sustainable. So we label it 'certified sustainably wild and organically processed,' " the wording approved by the Marine Stewardship Council.
"We're taking the high road by giving up organic," Mr. Saarheim said. "In the long term, it's confusing."
Could Senator Stevens be coming to the same conclusion? "Labeling something organic could be a first step toward wild salmon," he said in an interview, "but organic could also cover farm-raised." And the problem with that, he said, is: "There is a great deal of difference between salmon that spend a great portion of their lives in deep cold waters and those raised on a farm. They are not subject to any kind of runoff from farmlands, pesticides, to the growth of viruses in tanks or ponds. They really are disease free. Wild salmon or 'saumon sauvage,' which we consider superior, comes from the cold deep ocean waters. There may be another classification that will do the same thing."
Now there is an even greater threat to wild salmon lurking in some of those ponds where salmon are farmed: a genetically engineered version that grows quickly. Should those fish escape from their ponds, they could cause havoc to the ecosystem and might signal the end of a truly wild variety. Even an organic label would not help the industry then.

SECTION: Section F; Page 1; Column 2; Dining In, Dining Out/Style Desk 

LENGTH: 969 words

HEADLINE: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK;
Fill It Up, and Check the Olive Oil

BYLINE: By WILLIAM GRIMES 

 BODY:
UMBERTO'S CLAM HOUSE is reopening. I welcome this piece of news, not so much for the food as for the name, which is mercifully straightforward. Umberto's tells me it is an Italian restaurant. Clam House tells me I can get clams there. Both these statements are true, which tells me a third thing, that Umberto's is out of the loop.
These days, Manhattan restaurants no longer sound like restaurants at all. They all have one-syllable or two-syllable names that suggest just about anything but food. Icon, Torch, Coup and Rain come to mind. So do Atlas, Commune, Local, Vox, Pop and Avra. Isla and Rain hover in the vicinity of actual meaning. Isla is Spanish for "island," and the restaurant serves Cuban-influenced food. The two Rain restaurants offer pan-Asian cuisine. There's a lot of rain in Southeast Asia. But what about March? Or Quake? My current favorite is Tocqueville, because, rolling the name around on my tongue, I suddenly realized what the new-wave restaurant names suggest more than anything else: cars. 
 To test my theory, I pitched it to Detroit. I knew you could eat at these places, but could you drive them off the lot?
"Atlas is something we looked at before, for trucks," said Joe Pierucci, the marketing strategy manager for Ford's global products marketing department. "It has the right associations of strength." Beacon, the Midtown restaurant that specializes in wood-grilled dishes, also seems to have potential in Detroit. "That's probably a more economical car, or else it could be something that is just very huge," Mr. Pierucci said. "You think of a beacon as something you can see 10 miles away." Jim Hall, an analyst at the consulting firm AutoPacific Group, likes Beacon too, but he sees a different vehicle. "It would be a sensible car," he said, "just a little bit out of the ordinary, enough to give it character, but essentially a middle-of-the-road car."
And Torch? "After the Pinto, that's not a good car name," Mr. Hall said. "But it would have been viable in the 1960's, perfect for one of those muscle cars with 9,000 horsepower and brakes that wouldn't stop a Plymouth Valiant." Mr. Hall also saw a few possibilities in Avra, the Greek seafood restaurant. "It's not a bad name," Mr. Hall said. "Unfortunately, it would probably be picked up by Hyundai or Daewoo."
Icon is already taken. In India, Ford markets its Fiesta as an Ikon.
The Detroit lens has brought the Manhattan dining scene into focus for me. I couldn't imagine what sort of food Tocqueville might serve, but I could definitely see myself behind the wheel of a 1962 Cadillac Tocqueville, cream with turquoise interior. There's talk that Volkswagen might bring back the old VW bus. I propose Commune as the perfect name for it. Lex 303, a Murray Hill newcomer, sounds ready to drive right off the lot, a high-performance European import with a base price of $38,995. And I almost believe that I once owned a Plymouth Revel.
It doesn't take a genius to figure out why a restaurant owner might go for a name like Icon. It's punchy, easy to read and easier to remember. It seems cool, in a vague way. Brand names in general have been getting less specific and more suggestive, as marketers chase after the elusive, highly profitable conglomeration of ideas, sensations and associations that add up to an image. The same thinking that has given the world companies like Unisys and Verizon was bound to creep into the restaurant business sooner or later.
I sometimes riffle through the pages of "Dining in New York," a guide to the city's restaurants printed in 1930. Back then, diners knew where they stood. The Chalet Suisse served Swiss food. Janssen's Midtown Hofbrau served German. Maison Louis was French. The Chilli Villa was Mexican. Ye Olde English Tea Room was English. Giolito's Venetian Garden was owned by a man named Giolito, featured Venetian food and had a garden.
Life was simple. The food may have been terrible, but at least you knew what to expect when you walked through the door.
Now, the intent is a lot more complicated. Then again, so is the food. Fusion cooking and the new internationalized American cuisine make the naming process doubly difficult. "It's harder than naming a child," said Waldy Malouf, the executive chef at Beacon. His six-month naming odyssey had a starting point: the restaurant's open-fire cooking. He and his partners also wanted their name to communicate New York sophistication, friendliness, informality, accessibility and individuality -- in one word.
Somewhere along the way, Mr. Malouf learned that in the 15th century, the English used to light fires along the coast to guide ships. Bonfire became Beacon.
Explanations for the new names tend to raise more questions than they answer. "Coup is French for 'hit,' " said Davida Dambrosi, an owner of Coup. "So it's like you get surprised when you're hit." Vox comes from the Latin expression vox populi. Fair enough. But why exactly?
Tocqueville pleases the ear, but I can't say that I've cracked the code. An initial conversation with the restaurant's press agent yielded the following: "Just as de Tocqueville wrote the definitive work on American democracy, so the owners wanted to create the definitive restaurant." This sounded like the kind of answer that students the world over come up with when facing a tough essay question on a book they never quite got around to reading.
Marco Moreira, the chef and a part owner of Tocqueville, took a swing at it in a recent interview with The New York Observer, explaining that Tocqueville found Americans to be innovative and progressive, even though their background was European and conservative. "So our cooking is European," he said, "but American in that it's progressive." See?
There's a lesson in this. Don't ask, just eat.

HEADLINE: Reckonings;
The Good News Bears

BYLINE: By PAUL KRUGMAN 

 BODY:
When I was around 8 years old, I had an occasional playmate who was incapable of having a simple good time. If he was having fun, he would overdo it, getting more and more wound up -- until, inevitably, he would burst into tears and throw a tantrum.
Maybe he grew up to become a market analyst. 
 By rights, last week's half-point increase in interest rates should have been a non-event. A rational financial market supposedly reacts only to news -- and last week's move, which had been all but pre-announced by Fed officials and which newsletters had been predicting for a month, came as no surprise to anyone. And indeed on the day of the increase, markets took it calmly. But then the commentary began to take its toll: Inflation is back, we're headed for a hard landing, there's a 50-50 chance of recession. To listen to some of what's being said you would imagine either that Alan Greenspan had suddenly revealed himself as a financial sadist or that the mighty U.S. economy had suddenly been revealed to have feet of clay. So maybe it's time to re-establish some perspective.
The real news -- the background to the rate hike -- came not last week but over the couple of months previous, as it gradually became obvious that the U.S. economy had finally reached the limits of its much-expanded ability to produce. Everybody who wasn't living in a complete fantasy world knew this was going to happen eventually; the amazing thing is that it took so long. And the signs that we have reached our limits, though clear enough, are also fairly subtle: a modest increase in inflation, mainly due to oil but with some uptick in the "core" rate that supposedly excludes transitory factors, an acceleration of wage increases to a rate a bit more than productivity growth. Clearly it's time for the Fed to tap the brakes, to reduce the growth of demand enough to bring it into line with the growth in supply. But what now passes for a slowdown -- reducing growth to, say, 3 percent for a while until the inflationary pressure eases -- would have looked like a boom only a few years ago.
Could we be talking about something much worse than that sort of benign slowdown? Bad things do happen when the Fed is in inflation-fighting mode: the monetary contraction that began in 1979 eventually drove the unemployment rate into double digits. But back then the Fed was dealing with an economy in which inflation had been out of control for years, long enough that expectations of continuing inflation were deeply embedded in the national psyche; the Fed needed to take drastic measures in order to restore price stability. Those drastic measures, and the bad times they caused, wouldn't have happened if the Fed had moved quickly to control inflation before it had time to get established -- if, in other words, the Fed of the 70's had done what Mr. Greenspan is doing now.
True, there are other dangers. Attempts to nip inflation in the bud sometimes lead to the unpleasant discovery that your financial system is weaker than you thought, with nasty consequences for the real economy. That's what happened to Japan a decade ago, and it still hasn't recovered (and won't, if Mr. Greenspan's counterpart at the Bank of Japan -- who apparently is a financial sadist -- follows through on his plan to raise interest rates despite falling prices). But recent events in the U.S. actually suggest that we aren't as vulnerable as some, myself included, have feared. After all, the Nasdaq -- which is where the irrationally exuberant presumably put their money -- has fallen by more than a third, yet stories of sudden bankruptcy, of failed investors jumping from windows or shooting up brokers' offices, have been reassuringly scarce. In a way the bad news -- or rather the financial system's ability to take it in stride -- has been good news: I at least am becoming steadily less worried about a Japanese-style implosion.
This does not abridge the right of investors to bear qualms. If you think that stock prices in general are still too high -- a defensible position, though not quite as compelling now that some of the air has gone out of the tech bubble -- go ahead and sell. But don't blame the Fed.

HEADLINE: World Briefing

BYLINE: Compiled By Jeanne Moore

 BODY:

ASIA
 
JAPAN: DYNASTIC POLITICS -- The youngest daughter of the late prime minister, Keizo Obuchi, announced that she would seek her father's parliamentary seat in elections scheduled for June 25. Mr. Obuchi died on May 14, after suffering a stroke six weeks earlier. The candidacy of his daughter, Yukio Obuchi, 28, a former broadcaster, has revived a debate about the prevalence of inherited parliamentary seats in Japan. Howard W. French (NYT) 

PHILIPPINES: REBELS TALK -- Declaring that they wanted peace, about 100 Islamic rebels holding 21 hostages since April 23 emerged from their mountain lair in the southern Philippines for talks. The unexpected meeting between the Abu Sayyaf guerrillas and the provincial governor, Abdusakur Tan, revived hopes of a breakthrough in the stalled negotiations for the hostages' release. Mr. Tan said that the rebels repeated their demand for an Islamic state -- a demand consistently rejected by Manila -- and that the next meeting would take place at the earliest on Thursday. (Reuters)
 
THAILAND: ROYAL RECORD -- King Bhumibol Adulyadej was declared the country's longest-living monarch, surpassing King Rama I, who died in 1809. King Bhumibol, 72, is also the world's longest-reigning monarch. He was only 18 when his older brother died and he assumed the throne in 1946. (Agence France-Presse)
 
AMERICAS
 
PERU: ELECTION MONITORS QUIT -- Transparencia, a Peruvian election observer group largely funded by the United States government, said it had so little confidence in presidential elections scheduled for Sunday that it was withdrawing its monitors from voting stations as a protest. The announcement came as the head of an Organization of American States observation team was trying to persuade aides of President Alberto K. Fujimori to put the election day off for a few weeks to fix any vote tabulation flaws in government computer software. Clifford Krauss (NYT)
 
MEXICO: GAIN FOR MAYORAL CONTENDER -- A Mexico City court turned down a challenge to the election credentials of Andres Manuel Lopez Obrador, the leftist candidate who has built a wide lead in opinion surveys in the city's mayoral race. President Ernesto Zedillo's governing party and two others had sued to block Mr. Lopez Obrador's candidacy, arguing he did not meet residency requirements. A five-magistrate tribunal disagreed, leaving Mr. Lopez Obrador's challengers four days to appeal the ruling to a federal court. Sam Dillon (NYT)
 
CUBA: DISSIDENT LAWYER FREED -- The government freed Rene Gomez Manzano, a dissident lawyer, from prison in the third early release of a prominent anti-government activist in the last two weeks. The early release of Mr. Gomez, 56, who was serving a four-year sentence for anti-government activities, followed the freeing over the last two weeks of two of his close dissident colleagues, Felix Bonne, 60, an academic, and Marta Beatriz Roque, 55, an economist. (Reuters)
 
EUROPE
 
NETHERLANDS: LOCKERBIE TRIAL DELAYED AGAIN -- Resumption of the trial of two Libyans in the bombing of Pan Am Flight 103 over Lockerbie, Scotland, was delayed again by computer problems in the high-tech courtroom in Camp Zeist. The trial had been adjourned since May 11 to reschedule witnesses. Donald G. McNeil Jr. (NYT)
 
SPAIN: AGREEMENT ON TERRORISM -- Prime Minister Jose Maria Aznar of Spain and President Jacques Chirac of France agreed to step up cooperation against terrorism at a one-day summit meeting in the northern city of Santander. Although Madrid and Paris have long worked together against Basque militants, officials are now concerned at signs that Spanish Basque rebels are collaborating with radical French Breton nationalists. Benjamin Jones (NYT)
 
AFRICA
 
CONGO: TROOP WITHDRAWAL -- Rwanda, Uganda and the main rebel force operating in the Congolese diamond center of Kisangani have all agreed to pull troops out of the city, allowing the United Nations to establish the first neutral center for peacekeeping in Congo. The organization hopes to send South African troops. Barbara Crossette (NYT)
 
ETHIOPIA: VICTORY CLAIMS -- Ethiopia began a major attack on the central front of its disputed border with Eritrea, claiming by nightfall to have made significant advances. Eritrea, however, said it had repulsed the attack, and reported shooting down three Ethiopian fighter planes. Ethiopia said all its planes returned safely. Military analysts say this battle could be decisive: if Ethiopia dislodges the Eritreans from the town of Zalembessa, it will have forced Eritrea from the most important piece of land in dispute in the two-year war between the nations. Ian Fisher (NYT)
 
NIGERIA: NEW VIOLENCE -- Authorities imposed a dusk-to-dawn curfew and heavily armed troops patrolled the northern city of Kaduna after two days of clashes that filled hospital morgues and littered the streets with bodies. The fighting is the worst outbreak in Kaduna since riots in February between Christians and Muslims in which more than 1,000 people died. The cause of the latest violence is not clear. (Agence France-Presse)
 
MIDDLE EAST
 
IRAN: PAPER CLOSED -- Hard-line judicial officials, stung by the victory of reform candidates, shut down a newspaper allied with the reformist president, Mohammad Khatami, a day after it began printing. It was the 19th publication closed in a crackdown that began last month. In the Feb. 18 voting, allies of President Khatami won about three-quarters of the 290 seats, depriving the hard-liners of control of Parliament, which they have had since the 1979 Islamic revolution. (AP)

HEADLINE: U.S. Farm Groups Join Move to Ease Cuba Embargo

BYLINE: By LIZETTE ALVAREZ 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 23

 BODY:
Under pressure from farmers to open new markets, Congress is considering softening the United States trade embargo against Cuba to permit the export of food, medicine and medical products.
Powerful farm groups, sensing a swing in momentum this election year, are pushing lawmakers to reconsider the 38-year-old embargo, arguing that it does more harm than good. Business groups and pharmaceutical companies are also rallying for change. The effort even got unexpected support this year from the Elian Gonzalez saga as some Americans, deluged with stories about Cuba and Cuban-Americans, began to re-evaluate whether the United States' cold war strategy toward the Communist island nation still made sense. 
 Economically, the proposed measure is largely symbolic: It specifically rules out purchase of food using United States government credit, making it unlikely that cash-starved Cuba would be able to buy much from American farmers. And it does little to expand a current provision on exporting medicine and medical products to Cuba.
The measure's true significance is political, in its newfound popularity on the Hill among both conservatives and liberals. That marks an important shift in Congress, indicating a growing impatience with the embargo's failure and a desire to explore different approaches to dealing with the government of Fidel Castro.
"I think Castro has used this scapegoat argument against the United States for years," said Representative George R. Nethercutt Jr., a Washington Republican who faces a tough re-election battle this year. "If we take this argument away from him, we export not only food and medicine but also democracy. He can't then say that America is inhumane. It works to our advantage. We can't do any worse."
The measure, tucked inside a mammoth agriculture spending bill, was approved by the Appropriations Committee this month. It has attracted so many allies that it withstood an attempt by the majority whip, Representative Tom DeLay of Texas, to strip the measure from the larger bill.
Last year, Mr. DeLay killed the measure before it could be voted on in the House.
The provision has also cleared the Senate Appropriations Committee, and faces little opposition there, although Senator Jesse Helms, a North Carolina Republican and Castro foe, has expressed his displeasure. Last year, the Senate approved a similar measure in a 70-to-30 vote.
Although the measure stands its best chance ever this year, it faces a few hurdles in the House, where Republican leaders could still defeat the provision by preventing an up-or-down vote on it. One hurdle, in the Rules Committee, could come as early as this week.
Supporters say killing the language will be more difficult this year. "A fundamental shift has occurred," said Senator Byron Dorgan, the North Dakota Republican who wrote the Senate bill.
The measure would permit the United States to export food, medicine and medical products to Cuba, under certain stringent conditions, which were written into the bill to draw support.
In addition to the prohibition on use of government credit, the bill also specifies that companies wanting to sell to Cuba would have to obtain yearly licenses to export their products and would have to wait six months after the law is enacted to conduct business.
Medicine and medical products are already exported to Cuba under slightly tougher regulations. Last year, the Commerce Department approved 63 licenses to export medicine and medical products.
Although some opponents say the language is written so loosely that it could permit bartering and private financing, many critics say the bill, if passed, would be a hollow victory for farmers.
"It would really be a symbolic gesture," said Representative Ileana Ros-Lehtinen, a Florida Republican and Cuban-American who is fighting the language in the bill. "I have no problem with symbolic gestures, if that makes them happy enough, as long as they are trying not to give more money to Fidel Castro."
Farm state lawmakers argue that the measure would provide at least some help to constituents who have been hit hard by falling commodity prices and a 1996 bill that revamped agriculture rules. And it would allow farmers to position themselves in Cuba, which trades with a host of other American allies, including Canada.
Audrae Erickson, an international trade specialist for the American Farm Bureau, said analysts believe that the Cuban market could be worth up to $1 billion a year.
And because the provision would do little to steer money to Fidel Castro, even some members who fiercely oppose any softening of the embargo view this measure as a relatively harmless way to appease farm belt politicians.
"It's all driven by the farm lobby," said a senior Republican Senate aide. "These people are running around looking for any panacea. They've convinced themselves the solution lies in Havana."
In the House, the measure received extra support this year from the Elian Gonzalez story. The Elian story put Cuba back in the news and painted Cuban-Americans in Miami as extreme, creating a backlash that prompted some lawmakers to re-think American foreign policy toward Cuba.

HEADLINE: BULLETIN BOARD

BYLINE: By KAREN W. ARENSON and ANEMONA HARTOCOLLIS 

 BODY:

Wearing a New Hat
It was a bit like a coming-out party. On Thursday, the day after HAROLD O. LEVY was formally pronounced chancellor of New York City schools, the City University of New York held a reception for him at the Lotos Club. The timing was fortuitous; the event had been planned two months earlier. The reception drew about 150 people, including seven state regents, CUNY trustees and MATTHEW GOLDSTEIN, CUNY's chancellor.
Dr. Goldstein and Mr. Levy were introduced to each other last fall. At the time, Mr. Levy was a regent and Dr. Goldstein was seeking his vote for CUNY's hotly debated remedial policy, which bars students who cannot pass placement tests from its bachelor's degree programs. (Mr. Levy voted for the policy.) Now, they are like blood brothers. 
 So at the party, they talked about their interconnectedness and exchanged caps. Mr. Levy gave Dr. Goldstein a khaki cap with his name on the back and a Board of Education logo on the front. Dr. Goldstein gave Mr. Levy a black cap with his name on the back and the CUNY logo on the front. Then, in honor of Mr. Levy's appointment -- and his affinity for poetry -- Dr. Goldstein read "To Be of Use," a poem by Marge Piercy. One stanza, in particular, seemed to be a metaphor for the job of heading the city schools:
 
I love people who harness themselves, an ox to a heavy cart,
who pull like water buffalo, with massive patience,
who strain in the mud and the muck to move things forward,
who do what has to be done, again and again.
 
How to Feed a Caterpillar
On Monday and Tuesday, the little caterpillar ate his way through one apple and two pears, but today, ERIC CARLE will take the techniques behind his children's classic "The Very Hungry Caterpillar" to Public School 84 in Queens. About 150 teachers are expected to participate in a workshop led by Mr. Carle, who is also the book's illustrator, with an additional 120 teachers from P.S. 149, also in Queens, participating via video conferencing. Mr. Carle's workshop is sponsored by Studio in a School, an organization that brings painters and sculptors to teach in schools.
Help With Online Education Columbia University and New York University are both turning to outside companies for help with developing and promoting their continuing-education programs online.
Columbia said yesterday that it would work with Cognitive Arts, a company that designs technology for online education and corporate training, to offer courses in computer technology and English as a second language. It also plans to develop basic courses in economics and psychology. New York University recently announced that McGraw-Hill, the publishing company, would market and distribute some of the courses it offers through NYUonline, its for-profit digital venture. The courses will be aimed at corporate clients McGraw-Hill reaches through its Lifetime Learning division. GORDON MACOMBER, NYUonline's president and chief executive, said his group had about 100 hours of courses up and running, in areas like conflict management and communications skills for managers.
 
A Tarantella on Livingston Street
As the choreographer ELIOT FELD stage-whispered "Good boy!" and "Ignore me!" from his front-row folding chair, and classical music descended from the rafters, 23 young dancers from Ballet Tech's New York City Public School for Dance pirouetted their way across a portable linoleum floor last week at 110 Livingston Street. It was the start of Arts Monday, a program to showcase arts in city schools, and a good-size crowd turned out, attracted by the spectacle of toe shoes and leotards in the normally grim hall of the Board of Education. After performing Balanchine's "Tarantella," EMANUEL ROBINSON, 15, confessed that he had no idea who the balding man leading the standing ovation might be. But when you have performed at Jacob's Pillow and the Kennedy Center, a New York City schools chancellor is just another curtain call.
 KAREN W. ARENSON and ANEMONA HARTOCOLLIS

HEADLINE: R.T. MacDonald, 69; Led International Herald Tribune

BYLINE: By ERIC PACE 

 BODY:
Robert T. MacDonald, a former publisher of The International Herald Tribune, died on Friday in Sarasota, Fla. He was 69 and lived in Sarasota.
The cause was cancer, his family said. 
 Mr. MacDonald, a former executive vice president of The New York Herald Tribune, was named publisher of The Herald Tribune in Paris in 1966, after The Washington Post acquired a substantial interest in the paper's Paris edition.
In 1967 the Paris-based International Edition of The New York Times was merged with The Herald Tribune's Paris edition to create a three-way joint venture named The International Herald Tribune. Now appearing six days a week, it is owned jointly by The New York Times and The Washington Post; Whitney Communications, the partner representing the old Herald Tribune ownership, sold out in 1991.
With Mr. MacDonald as publisher, the renamed newspaper sought readers everywhere who wanted to follow news from the United States, and the number of advertisers grew.
Mr. Macdonald resigned as publisher in 1977 and for a decade served as chairman of Hudson Research Europe Ltd., an organization based in Paris doing political and economic analyses. From 1980 to 1997 he was also the managing director of MacDonald & Company, an investment firm with headquarters in Stamford, Conn.
Born in Mount Vernon, N.Y., Robert Taylor McDonald graduated in 1952 from Yale, served in the Navy and received a master's degree in business administration in 1958 from the University of Pennsylvania. His 1960 marriage to Christiana Barbara Besch ended in divorce in 1977.
Surviving are his wife, the former Gillian S. Tripier, whom he married in 1978; three children from his first marriage, a daughter, Jennifer L. MacDonald, and two sons, Gregory C. and Michael S.; a sister, Mary E. MacDonald, and a grandchild.

HEADLINE: Russia Opens Doors to Lab That Created Deadly Germs

BYLINE: By JUDITH MILLER 

DATELINE: OBOLENSK, Russia, May 23

 BODY:
The once top-secret research complex where the Soviet Union perfected dozens of strains of deadly bacteria threw open its doors this week to scientists from around the world.
The director of the State Research Center for Applied Microbiology, which is a two-hour drive from Moscow, invited 200 scientists from 10 countries, Western officials and even an American reporter to what was once a crown jewel of the Soviet germ warfare empire, so hidden that it was not listed on Soviet maps. 
 In the Soviet era, 3,000 scientists and technicians worked for more than 20 years to develop weapons from anthrax, glanders, plague, tularemia and other lethal or debilitating diseases.
Now the center is inviting scrutiny to demonstrate its determination to conduct just peaceful work such as preventing bioterrorism and curing disease. Scientists at the three-day conference here discussed the new research and were given an extensive tour of several of the 90 buildings.
The meeting is to close on Wednesday with a conference for the Russian and Western press, another first for Obolensk, and the announcement of $1.6 million in additional American assistance to help the institute chart a peaceful course.
American officials said the United States initiative included $935,000 from the Pentagon to upgrade security at this sprawling complex to prevent the theft or diversion to hostile states of the hundreds of strains of deadly germs that are stored here.
At the opening session, the director of the center, Gen. Nikolai N. Urakov, pledged to open the "curtain of secrecy" that enshrouded the 25-year-old complex and to dispel the "lack of trust" in its conversion from military to peaceful research.
General Urakov said he wanted to expand cooperation with the United States, European nations and other countries that have forsworn germ weapons.
He said although the institute had shrunk by half, to 1,125 employees, and the lab had not overcome the economic crisis caused by the Soviet Union's collapse a decade ago, the staff was stabilizing, and some scientists had even returned after working abroad or in business.
Western officials said international aid to Obolensk provided the means to employ more than half the scientists here.
The United States assistance and other foreign aid, which is administered through an international group that audits grants to insure that they are spent on designated research, has given more than $3.4 million to Obolensk.
Only Vector, the country's other leading former germ warfare center, has received more assistance from the international group, the International Science and Technology Center. Vector once specialized in turning viruses into weapons.
Today, conference participants were given a tour of the complex and its infamous Building No. 1, an austere nine-story glass and metal structure where the most top secret weapons research was once conducted.
Roaming through the labs and chatting informally with their Russian counterparts in areas that were once off limits to anyone not wearing special suits, the scientists discussed the research into peaceful goals, including tuberculosis, anthrax vaccines and molecular genetics.
Floyd P. Horn, director of the United States Department of Agriculture's Agricultural Research Service, called the quality of the presentations superb.
Scientific cooperation between Russian and American scientists would "clearly benefit both parties," he said.
Dr. Horn's agency is providing $325,000 this year for research into pig diseases, along with computer equipment that will give this remote center access to the American National Agricultural Library.
A Defense Department official said the meetings, the tour and the growing American and international access "dispels the suspicion that Obolensk is still conducting offensive germ research."
Several conservative legislators and intelligence experts contend that Moscow is continuing to pursue such research. But a recent report by the General Accounting Office found no evidence of such research here or at Vector.
In interviews this week, Russian scientists said that they were determined to relegate the past work in such areas to history.
"We still are not permitted to discuss the past," a scientist said. "But we know our future lies in fighting the terrorism and diseases that threaten all mankind."
Several scientists said privately they were delighted by their growing contacts with Western counterparts and the end of the isolation that they had once endured as germ warriors.
Life remains difficult in Obolensk, where many top scientists, paid less than $100 a month, are required to have second jobs to make ends meet.
But many scientists said they were encouraged to remain in science not only by the prestige that such employment still brings in this society, but also by new exchanges with American colleagues.
Last month, two senior Obolensk scientists delivered two rare anthrax strains to centers in Atlanta and Fort Detrick, Md., as part of an exchange program negotiated this year.

HEADLINE: Help China And Help Chinatown

BYLINE: By Henry Wong; Henry Wong just completed his junior year at Yale University.

DATELINE: NEW HAVEN

 BODY:
In their fight against granting China permanent normal trade relations, labor unions say they are trying to protect Americans from having to compete with foreign workers who are paid barely a living wage to work in inhumane conditions. But keeping China out of the global economy will actually hurt American factory workers more than it helps them.
Consider my mother, who has been a garment worker in New York City for more than 20 years. Despite being a union member, she is paid the minimum wage or sometimes less. The factory she works in has little ventilation and dirty toilets. My father, who was a restaurant worker, is now 70 and unable to work, and my mother's income is essential. Fluctuating demand for American textiles has threatened to put my family in the streets. Already, several factory closings in Chinatown have forced her into dirtier and hotter factories. 
 Yet my mother encourages me to buy goods made by companies accused of using sweatshops in third world countries. For years, I could not understand why she would do this instead of fighting the global market forces that could put her out of work. But the unfortunate paradox, I began to realize, is this: The products made in factories in developing countries are the only kind factory workers in this country can afford to buy.
My parents and other Chinese immigrants constantly remind me how much more my generation has, living in the United States. "When I was growing up in China, we ate roast pig once a year during Chinese New Year," my father tells me. "Now, we can eat roast pig every day."
Internet-ready computers, video games, Chinese candies, clothes, food, and woks are all made available and affordable by this country's open markets. Lower prices and imported goods may seem like frivolous benefits to many Americans, but to poor immigrant families, they mean a lot.
Moreover, Chinese immigrants like my parents know all too well the consequences of living in an isolated society and closed economy. When I asked my mother why she left China for Hong Kong before coming to the United States, she said: "Everybody was running to Hong Kong then. China was poor. China was Communist." As Hong Kong prospered and grew as a trading hub, China, closed off from the outside, continued to suffer from poverty, famine and political oppression.
Opening China to the global market can only help reduce these conditions, which continue today. While an international labor standard would be useful, it is too idealistic and impractical, and mandated living wages would rob countries with cheap labor of the competitive advantage they need to lift their people out of poverty.
The labor movement has done too little to improve my mother's workplace, and its current international fight seems misplaced. Squeezing globalization with the vise of protectionism helps neither American nor Chinese workers. If the labor movement wins its battle against so-called free trade, it will find the American working class suffering most.

HEADLINE: THE CHINA TRADE WRANGLE: VICE PRESIDENT;
An Embarrassed Suitor: Gore's Courtship of Big Labor Grows Less Ardent

BYLINE: By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 23

 BODY:
On the eve of the China trade vote, while the Clinton Administration was still nailing down support for the bill's passage, Vice President Al Gore flew off to Pittsburgh. The Steel City, one of the nation's last redoubts of big labor, was host to a conference of the service employees union, the home base of the president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., which has devoted itself to killing the legislation.
Heading for union turf at such a juncture is one more sign of Mr. Gore's ambivalence, if not toward the bill, then toward his public association with the bill. 
 Even as the administration is trying to round up last-minute votes, the vice president was engaged with labor out of town rather than working against it on Capitol Hill.
"Which side is the vice president on?" Representative Charles B. Rangel, the New York Democrat, said in an interview. "He doesn't want to offend anybody." Mr. Rangel said that Mr. Gore had called him about the bill but that he was already supporting it and that there was not much point to the conversation.
The service workers' union and its former chief, John Sweeney, who is now president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., have essentially given Mr. Gore a pass on the China bill, but not everyone in the labor movement is feeling so generous.
The president of the United Auto Workers today offered one of the most blistering assessments of Mr. Gore's actions on behalf of the bill. Mr. Gore has been two-faced, the union president said, and is driving the auto workers into the arms of one of the auto industry's enduring nemesis, Ralph Nader, who is also running for president.
"He has tried to have it both ways on China," an outraged Stephen P. Yokich, president of the 1.3-million-strong auto workers union, said of Mr. Gore in a statement today.
"One moment, presidential candidate Gore is telling the labor movement that he believes human rights, workers' rights, and environmental protections should be included in core trade agreements; the next, Vice President Gore is holding hands with the profiteers of the world and singing the praises" of the trade agreement and "lobbying" for it.
Mr. Gore, speaking to reporters in Pittsburgh, brushed aside the attack, saying the election was a long time away and that he would not entertain hypothetical questions.
Still, criticism from a putative ally goes a long way toward explaining Mr. Gore's reluctance to take a more visible role in promoting the trade agreement. The Gore campaign has hoped that the vice president could use the issue to convey that he is not beholden to labor and that he is willing to break with an important constituency over principle.
"I just want to tell you forthrightly I don't share your views on this particular issue," Mr. Gore said to several thousand service workers today.
Mr. Gore has said numerous times that he supports the trade agreement, and he took part in a White House pep rally to advance it. He also has said that he has called members of Congress to lobby on behalf of the bill.
But as he runs with labor's endorsement and seeks to energize union workers behind his candidacy, the degree of Mr. Gore's support has been questioned.
He caused consternation at the White House in February after labor leaders said he had indicated that he would negotiate a tougher pact than Mr. Clinton negotiated. Administration officials were worried that Mr. Gore's stance could give political cover to Democrats who opposed the bill. Mr. Gore then wrote to the nation's chief business lobbying group, the National Association of Manufacturers, to reassure it of his support.
Congressional Democrats who oppose the measure said that many among their number had no sign that the vice president was actively working for passage. And one business lobbyist, who did not want to be identified, put it this way: "The vice president's enthusiasm has been spectacularly underwhelming."
Unlike Gov. George W. Bush of Texas, Mr. Gore's Republican rival for the presidency, Mr. Gore has not devoted a speech to the single topic of the China bill. When Mr. Bush addressed it last week at a Boeing factory in Everett, Washington, his impassioned remarks gave the appearance that he was more closely allied with President Clinton on this matter than Mr. Gore.
Today, Mr. Bush met with Republicans privately on Capitol Hill and reiterated his support for the bill. Members said afterward that he asked those who plan to vote against it to reconsider their vote.
It is not clear whether Mr. Gore's lower-key approach will advance either his beliefs in economic globalization or his political aspirations.
Stephen P. Hess, a presidential scholar at the Brookings Institution, a liberal research organization, said that Mr. Gore's blurry approach raised legitimate questions. But he also suggested that Mr. Gore's posture over the bill has reinforced an impression that the vice president is overly cautious and calculating. "You feel that Gore really is an internationalist, but for heaven's sake, why doesn't he come out and say it?" Mr. Hess said. "Everything has become so calculated."
Mr. Clinton, too, has shown some calculation. He had planned a national television address Sunday night on the trade bill, one of his most important foreign policy objectives. But he canceled it when it was clear that the bill was dividing Democrats and would have raised the awkward specter of Representative Richard A. Gephardt, the Democratic leader from Missouri, who opposes the bill, giving the official response to the president of his own party.
Democrats say the unions have riven the party, in part by running commercials against some members who oppose the bill while they have essentially given Mr. Gore the kid-glove treatment.
"A lot of people are concerned just how committed the unions are to hurting members of Congress and how they use a different standard for the vice president," Mr. Rangel said. "We don't want them to be cruel to the vice president, but we're running for re-election too."

HEADLINE: A Family Dynasty Turns Against Itself

BYLINE: By CHARLES V. BAGLI 

 BODY:
The urbane, soft-spoken Seymour Milstein and his blustery, cigar-waving brother, Paul, used their good cop, bad cop approach to deal-making over the last five decades to turn their father's Bronx flooring company into a vast empire worth an estimated $5 billion.
They made multiple fortunes in real estate, banking and the food industry, fought city officials and preservationists to a standstill and amassed holdings from the Upper East Side to Battery Park City. 
 But now, the seemingly unbreakable ties between the two men are fraying in an ugly rift over control of the empire and succession. It has spawned lawsuits, severed longstanding partnerships and pitted brother against brother, cousin against cousin.
At stake is control of millions of square feet of office space, tens of thousands of Manhattan apartments and the family's crown jewel: Emigrant Savings Bank, one of New York's oldest financial institutions.
One of the sharpest battles is taking place over a parking lot at Eighth Avenue and 42nd Street, whose value has soared with the resurgence of Times Square to more than $100 million in the 16 years since the brothers and their partners bought it for $5 million.
Seymour Milstein and the partners recently blocked Paul's son Howard, 49, from developing the parcel on his own by abruptly dissolving the partnership and putting the land up for sale. Howard counterattacked by suing Emigrant over the role of Seymour's son, Philip, 50, the bank's chief executive.
"They're fighting over the very things they built together," said Stephen B. Siegel, president of the Insignia/ESG brokerage firm and one of the few people who knows the family who was willing to speak for the record, no matter how briefly. "I always find these family battles distressing."
Not one of the combatants was willing to talk publicly about the dispute. But a picture of the infighting between the billionaires emerged from court records and from friends and supporters of the factions who spoke only on the condition of anonymity.
The real estate dynasties that rule New York have certainly had their share of blood-curdling feuds. The family of Sol Goldman, the land speculator, waged a bitter seven-year battle over his billion-dollar estate. And more than one family has seen a son chafe under the bridle of his father's oversized personality and flee the business. But never have the internecine rifts been so deep and over so big a prize.
The fighting has ensnared another large real estate family, that of the late Jack D. Weiler, as well as John E. Zuccotti, the lawyer and former city official who is a confidant to real estate titans, from Mortimer B. Zuckerman to Paul Milstein. Many on the sidelines have reacted with sadness over the squabbling between the once inseparable brothers as they enter their 80's and with amusement as a wealthy family with a reputation for litigious, bare-knuckled tactics turns on itself.
"The Milstein family has a long history of tough and often controversial dealings dating back to the 1960's," said Kent Barwick, president of the Municipal Art Society. "They were respected for their business acumen, but never confused with saints or sweethearts."
Paul and Seymour Milstein went to work for their father, Morris, after World War II. Until recently, the two brothers had a lifelong division of labor, according to friends and real estate executives.
Paul, now 78, was a hard-charging Runyonesque character from the old school of New York real estate who wore pinkie rings on both hands and punctuated his profane talk with a large cigar. He was a builder, a bricks-and-mortar man. An executive recalled how Paul cursed and screamed at Samuel J. Lefrak, an equally voluble builder, for 30 minutes before the conversation wound down; the two men then asked about each other's wives and hung up.
Seymour, who will be 80 in July and has a demeanor more like that of a secretary of state or a corporate executive, handled the economic terms of the projects and the family's critical financial relationships with various banks. Both men were tough, friends said, and neither took a step without consulting the other.
"They seemed to be a perfect combination," said William J. Stern, a former chairman of the state's Urban Development Corporation. "Paul, who commanded attention, was funnier, gruffer and more outspoken. But he had a great deference to Seymour. When Seymour spoke, Paul listened."
They worked with their father at the Circle Floor Company, which later won contracts to make floor tile for Sears and to install flooring at many New York landmarks, like Rockefeller Center, the United Nations, the World Trade Center and Madison Square Garden.
In the 1960's, Paul built the family's first apartment house, the 35-story Dorchester Tower at Broadway and 68th Street, followed by a 42-story building east of Lincoln Center.
The projects established a pattern of conflict with city officials. In 1981, the Milsteins outraged city officials and preservationists by demolishing the landmark Palm Court lounge and gilded clock at the Biltmore Hotel on Madison Avenue, after promising to restore them as part of what is now Bank of America Plaza.
In the 1970's, the family took control of United Brands, the food company, and Starrett Housing Corporation, a real estate company. They later sold the companies for a profit, and in 1986, took over the failing Emigrant Savings Bank. They poured $90 million into the bank, which Bert Ely, a bank analyst, said is worth $1.5 billion to $2 billion.
During the 1980's, the Milsteins built Normandie Court and Windsor Court on the Upper East Side and the Liberty buildings at Battery Park City, but have been quiet in the current real estate boom.
Now the two brothers, who live in apartments high atop the family's Bristol Plaza complex on Third Avenue and still go into work at the family's Midtown offices, are at odds over the question of succession. Friends said Seymour, the older brother, wants out of the real estate business and would rather liquidate the family's holdings than allow his nephew Howard to take control.
Paul's son has adopted his father's bombastic mien to much less effect while working in real estate and pursuing membership, unsuccessfully, in the elite club of National Football League team owners. He is an intensely smart, ambitious man who friends conceded is also arrogant to a fault. Seymour and his son rarely get along with him.
Although Howard was never able to get out from under his father's shadow as a builder, his friends and supporters credit him with devising the marketing plan for the Bristol Court complex on the Upper East Side that enabled the family to double their rental revenue, and reviving the Milford Plaza Hotel on Eighth Avenue. He also created Liberty Cable, a challenger to Time Warner's dominance of cable television in Manhattan, and rebuilt the Douglas Elliman realty company, later sold for an estimated $80 million profit.
Along the way, Howard engaged in public feuds with Time Warner, the developer Peter Malkin and the N.F.L., which rejected his bids to acquire the Cleveland Browns and the Washington Redskins. His highly publicized plan to revive Niagara Falls went nowhere. Meetings with Howard were described as "audiences," and even his friends attribute his imperial style to a difficult relationship with his domineering father.
A real estate executive who considers Howard to be the family's natural heir said: "Howard is the brightest one in the family. Out of insecurity, he has to tell people how smart he is. People think he's too brash, too arrogant, too confrontational. He learned that from his father. The difference is that Howard doesn't know when to back off."
People on both sides of the conflict said Howard's father had been less focused and often forgetful since heart surgery a couple of years ago. After the Milsteins began pouring the foundation for a large apartment tower at First Avenue and 61st Street, Seymour realized that his brother could not handle building another project and sold the property last year for $45 million to Daniel Brodsky, a developer. At the time, Howard and his brother, Edward, were preoccupied with trying to buy the Redskins for $800 million.
"Seymour didn't think Paul was up to it, and he was right," said an executive who has worked closely with the family. "Paul was screaming, 'I'll build it; I'll never sell!' But he's never really said no to his older brother. At the end of the day, Paul knew his older brother had his interests at heart."
With his father less active in the family business, Howard has tried to assert his leadership. That has brought him into conflict with his uncle and his cousin.
The simmering rivalry spilled into court last year after Howard sold Douglas Elliman for a total of about $85 million to Insignia Financial and refused to give Seymour's son a share of the proceeds.
His cousin, Philip, filed suit in Delaware, claiming he had not been notified of the pending sale despite his position as a shareholder and director of the company. He demanded a look at the company's books, raising suspicions that Howard may have used the company's resources to fuel his unsuccessful bid for the Redskins, which friends say Howard denies doing.
At the same time, Howard moved to develop the last open parcel in the Times Square redevelopment area, a 40,000-square-foot parking lot on 42nd Street. But each time he talked to Ernst & Young, the developer Jerry I. Speyer or The New York Times about building a 1.1-million-square-foot tower on the site, Seymour Milstein or Alan Weiler, whose family owned half the parcel, would send an embarrassing letter to the companies stating that Howard did not represent the owners. (The Times is now negotiating over a different site nearby.)
In 1994, the partners worked cooperatively but unsuccessfully to develop a hotel, movie complex and studio for Home Box Office on the site. Claiming that Howard had violated the traditional consensus that governed the parking lot, Mr. Weiler, a lawyer who worked for the Milsteins for more than 20 years, and Seymour Milstein, whose wing of the family had a 20 percent share in the parcel, dissolved the partnership in April and moved to sell the land.
Howard responded by filing court papers claiming that his father had designated him, his brother and Mr. Zuccotti as the developers of the site. "Even though Paul likes to beat up on Howard," said a person who knows Paul well, "he was hoping his son could've done that one on his own."
In a slap at his uncle, Howard described him in an affidavit as a "passive partner in Paul Milstein's real estate ventures," a claim that even Howard's biggest boosters said was inaccurate and unfair. Both sides have now agreed to sell the parking lot, which has attracted nearly every developer in the city.
Last month, the fighting intensified when Howard also filed a suit seeking to oust Philip as chief executive of Emigrant Savings Bank. He accused his cousin of engaging in a "campaign of corporate misconduct" to keep his hold on the bank and reneging on a longstanding promise to make him co-chief executive.
The suit said that Philip had failed to maximize the bank's profits and exposed the company to unnecessary tax burdens. Philip has retained the support of 11 of the 17 bank directors who are not named Milstein, but the gulf between the two wings of the family remains wide open.
"This never would have happened if Paul didn't have some problems," said a person who has known the family for decades. "He was always able to keep the lid on the explosive generational issues."
So far, Philip and his father have rejected a suggestion by Howard and his father that they split the bank into two parts, or hire professional managers. Some people who know the elder Milsteins predicted that the family might start selling property, which would have been unthinkable five years ago.
"They don't really want to be in business with each other," one said. "That's why Seymour wants to liquidate."
