HEADLINE: Swell of Minority Students Is Predicted at Colleges

BYLINE: By JODI WILGOREN 

 BODY:
College enrollment will swell by some two million students -- to 19 million -- over the next 15 years, with black, Hispanic and Asian-American students accounting for 80 percent of the growth, according to a study scheduled for release today by the Educational Testing Service.
The proportion of white students on campuses nationwide will drop from 71 percent in 1995 to 63 percent in 2015, the study predicts. Over that same 20-year stretch, Hispanic-Americans will increase their presence to 15 percent from 11 percent, and Asian-Americans to 8 percent from 5 percent, while African-American enrollment will remain steady at about 13 percent. Whites will be a minority on campuses by then in California, the District of Columbia, Hawaii and New Mexico, and, soon afterward, in Texas. 
 "The fact that so many more minority students are opting for college is great news and underscores minority families' dedication to educating their children," Sonia Hernandez of the California Department of Education said in a statement accompanying the report. But Ms. Hernandez said colleges are unprepared to meet the demand and shifting demographics, both in terms of financial aid and academic programs. "Celebrations are premature," she said. "I am very worried that we could fail these children."
The surge in enrollment follows a steady climb over a half-century -- from 2.3 million students in 1947, to 10.2 million in 1974, to 14.3 million in 1997 and a predicted 19 million in 2015 -- and reflects the rise in births in the United States, increased immigration, and a growing sense that a college degree is a prerequisite for a decent job.
Five states with large Hispanic populations -- Arizona, California, Florida, New York and Texas -- will account for more than half the overall increase in undergraduates over the next 15 years. California and Florida are each planning to build a new state university campus.
But while minority college enrollment is skyrocketing, it is not growing as fast as the black and Hispanic populations ages 18 to 24. The study says that participation by blacks and Hispanics in higher education will actually decrease in proportion to their populations between 1995 and 2015.
"We need to be careful that the growing numbers of minority students ready for college don't give us a false sense that we have achieved our diversity goals," said Richard A. Fry, a testing service economist and co-author of the report. Mr. Fry said that if black and Hispanic students attended college at the same rate as whites, the national economy would grow by $231 billion annually.
Education experts said that they had been expecting the demographic shift, but that colleges and universities -- and the governments that supported them -- were unprepared. Among the challenges, they said, would be addressing the persistent "achievement gap" between white and Asian students and their black and Hispanic counterparts in high school; helping minority families, which are disproportionately poor, afford tuition; and fostering a climate of racial tolerance at historically white institutions.
"There needs to be a fundamental shift in perspective about what educating students of color means," said Jamie Merisotis, director of the Institute for Higher Education Policy in Washington. "We need to treat this as part of the mainstream, and not as an add-on."
Stanley O. Ikenberry, president of the American Council on Education, said his 3,500 member campuses have "been working for a decade" to diversify their student bodies and faculties and "try to make themselves more comfortable places for students who have been underrepresented."
Anthony Lising Antonio, a professor of education at Stanford University who has studied the impact of diversity on college students, said that colleges would risk repeating the racial tensions of the late 1980's and early 1990's if they did not adjust their curriculums and programs to reflect their new students.
"Whether they change their admissions practices or not, there's going to be these floods of students, and it's going to be a much more diverse place," Professor Antonio said. "If we do nothing about it, you're not going to garner the benefits a diverse student body provides you."
Bruce Walker, director of admissions at the University of Texas at Austin, said that the burden was on the state's elementary and high schools to adequately prepare the newcomers for college. But he and others noted that the trend in recent years toward using tax credits and loans to help families finance higher education would need to be replaced with increased grant support.
Scott Miller, the author of a recent College Board report documenting the achievement gaps among the races, said his analysis of test scores over the past decade showed that "our capacity to integrate our most selective universities is not going to enhance very much over the next generation."
"Will more go to college? Yes. Will more graduate? Yes," Mr. Miller said.
"Will we close in a dramatic way, in the next generation, the college graduation rate gaps, and the achievement gaps when people get degrees?" he continued. "It may be that the only gains that will be made will be made through the sheer numbers."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS;
Nasdaq Falls To Its Lowest Level of Year

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
The Nasdaq composite index plunged to its lowest level in six months yesterday as the broad stock market declined for a fifth consecutive day.
Concerns about the economy's strength have left investors jittery, and Wall Street strategists say stocks may have a difficult time taking off again until investors are convinced that the Federal Reserve has finished raising interest rates to ward off inflation. 
 The Nasdaq composite dropped 199.66, or 5.9 percent, to 3,164.55, its 10th-biggest decline ever in percentage terms. It fell below its previous low for the year, 3,321 reached on April 14, a Friday that had capped a terrible week and a record 25.3 percent decline. At its new low, the technology-heavy index is down 22.2 percent for the year and 37.3 percent from its peak in March.
On Monday, stocks rallied late and regained most of what had been steep losses earlier in the day, but yesterday the major indexes took the opposite tack, swooning as the close approached and finishing at their lows for the day.
The Dow Jones industrial average dropped 120.28, or 1.1 percent, to 10,422.27, while the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 26.86, or 1.9 percent, to 1,373.86. Those two indexes remained above their April 14 closing levels. The Dow is down 9.4 percent for the year, while the S.& P. 500 is off 6.5 percent.
Douglas R. Cliggott, United States equities strategist at J. P. Morgan Securities, sees more declines ahead. After visiting money managers across the country for the last six weeks, he has concluded that most of their portfolios are still too vulnerable to higher interest rates. "People own too many tech stocks still, and they probably own too many financial stocks," he said. "We will be wrestling with how high interest rates are going till Labor Day."
In the bond market, prices rose slightly, as yields, which move in the opposite direction, fell. Even with a threat of higher interest rates, bonds often rally when stocks fall sharply as investors move out of stocks. The yield on the Treasury's 10-year note slipped to 6.42 percent, from 6.44 percent on Monday, while the price rose 3/32 to 100 17/32. The yield on the 30-year bond fell to 6.16 percent from 6.19 percent.
Cisco, Hewlett-Packard, I.B.M. and Intel led the technology group down yesterday, but industrial stocks also declined. General Motors has lost 13.8 percent of its value in two days after announcing it was limiting how many shares of its stock it would swap for shares in its Hughes Electronics subsidiary. Other decliners were International Paper and United Technologies. Drug stocks, including Merck and Schering-Plough, rose after the two companies announced a joint venture. Some financial stocks also gained, including American Express.
Several factors are hurting the stock market now, analysts say. One is the belated realization by many investors that the Federal Reserve is determined to continue raising its target for short-term interest rates until the economy slows.
Before the Fed raised its target rate a half a percentage point to 6.5 percent a week ago, many investors had apparently expected the Fed to act cautiously. The cautious approach -- five quarter-point rate increases since June -- had failed to slow economic growth significantly and left investors feeling relatively positive. But last week's bigger rate increase and the accompanying statement that pointed to more increases ahead "dashed whatever remaining hopes there were that the Fed was close to on hold," Jeffrey M. Applegate, the chief United States equities strategist at Lehman Brothers, told his clients this week. "Until there is an end in sight for Fed tightening, we expect that the stock market will continue to churn with little direction and volume."
Lehman Brothers' economists predict another half-point increase by the Fed in June and a final quarter-point increase in August. Stocks will only rally, Mr. Applegate said, when investors are convinced that the economy has slowed enough for the Fed to stop raising rates.
The Fed is now expected to slow economic growth from the current 5 percent pace to 3 percent or 3.5 percent, and as it does, earnings forecasts will fall a bit. Some analysts are already lowering their predictions of earnings growth for the companies in the S.& P. 500.
In addition, investors are grappling with the prospect that the technology sector is not immune to rising rates.
If higher rates dampen stock prices, those companies will find it harder to raise cash in the equity market and to use their stock to buy other companies. And their earnings could also be lowered as old-economy companies trim spending plans in light of a slowing economy.
One question for investors and Federal Reserve officials is whether the lackluster performance of the stock market over the last 12 months is beginning to have an impact on consumer spending. Since a year ago, the Dow has lost 3.8 percent, the S.& P. 500 has gained 3.3 percent and the Nasdaq index, which soared 85.6 percent in 1999, has retained a 25.6 percent gain.
Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Fed, and other Fed members have said that five consecutive years of double-digit returns in the stock market have been the main force behind the consumer spending boom that has propelled the economy to its longest expansion ever. And while Fed officials have gone to great lengths to claim that they are not aiming to drive the stock market lower, they have acknowledged that this wealth effect is making it difficult to rein in economic growth.

HEADLINE: AIRLINE DEAL: THE UNIONS;
Labor Issues Could Thwart Airlines' Plans

BYLINE: By DAVID BARBOZA 

DATELINE: CHICAGO, May 23

 BODY:
For years, labor unions have been a thorn in the side of the UAL Corporation and the US Airways Group, and now that the two airlines are planning to combine, experts wonder if the unions have enough power to squash the deal.
"The unions that were around at the beginning of this industry still have a hammerlock," said Sam Peltzman, an economist who specializes in airlines and regulatory issues at the University of Chicago Graduate School of Business. "The industry is completely unionized." 
 Airline unions are so powerful, experts say, that they could pose huge problems not only in voting to approve UAL's proposed $4.3 billion takeover of US Airways, but in determining how and whether two major airlines can unite. That stumbling block, they say, even more than antitrust questions could be the airlines' No. 1 challenge.
United Airlines employees control more than 50 percent of the airline, and most of its employees are members of one of several unions, like the Air Line Pilots Association.
Last week, United's employee stock-option plan expired. The plan, some experts said, gave pilots de facto control of the airline and made it difficult for the company to dilute the pilots' ownership. Now that the plan has expired, experts say the company may have been granted the freedom to make a deal.
Even so, employee ownership should not prove to be an obstacle to such a deal. The employee shareholders will each vote independently unless a movement develops to organize employees as a group or under the umbrella of the unions, according to the experts.
Spokesmen for the major unions were unavailable to comment.
 The companies have each had labor problems. Most recently UAL had to cancel hundreds of flights this month after pilots refused to work overtime because of a lack of progress in contract talks. And US Airways averted a labor standoff this month when a union representing flight attendants voted to adopt a new contract.
"As bad as labor relations are at United, it's worse at US Airways," said Aaron J. Gellman, director of the transportation center at the Kellogg Graduate School of Management at Northwestern University.
To combine operations, the experts say that the unions that represent pilots, machinists, attendants and others will have to agree on everything from work rules and seniority lists to which hub should dominate a region.
Indeed, these issues are so complicated that several experts say they have their doubts whether two major airlines can be successfully integrated. Airline mergers, they say, have typically involved larger airlines buying regional outfits, making a combination easier to achieve.
"The problems are very formidable," Professor Peltzman said. "The first issue you decide if you put two together is who's the senior pilot. They get at each other's throats over issues like this."
Professor Gellman said he had doubts about whether two major airlines could be merged successfully. The reaction of the pilots will be important, he said.
"Do they see themselves as losing power or gaining in stockholder value?" he asked.

HEADLINE: AIRLINE DEAL: THE OVERVIEW;
Some Big Airports in Northeast Face Changes if Merger Occurs

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN and DAVID LEONHARDT 

 BODY:
The world's largest airline, United, plans to announce today that it will acquire the biggest carrier in the Northeast, US Airways, for $4.3 billion in cash, creating a carrier with by far the largest share of passengers from Boston to New York to Washington.
If the acquisition is approved by shareholders and government regulators, United will carry almost 500,000 passengers a day, have hubs in seven American cities from Baltimore to San Francisco, and employ 145,000 people. The acquisition represents the first merger of two large American airlines since a wave of consolidation in the 1980's, and analysts said United's new strength would force other airlines to consider deals as well. 
 The UAL Corporation, the parent of United, said the combination would allow millions of travelers in the Northeast -- long the company's weak spot in the United States -- to tap into its vast network of flights to the Midwest and West Coast and, on partner airlines, to Europe and Asia. The company also pledged not to raise fares on some domestic routes for at least two years except for price increases needed to cover inflation and higher fuel costs.
In addition, UAL said it would shed many of US Airways' routes at Ronald Reagan National Airport near Washington and sell them to Robert L. Johnson, a member of the US Airways board and the founder of Black Entertainment Television. Mr. Johnson plans to operate a new airline with those planes, employees and routes.
The step, which will not include the lucrative shuttle service between Washington, New York and Boston, is intended to satisfy regulators who might become concerned about market concentration in the Washington area, where United is the largest carrier at Washington Dulles International Airport and US Airways is in a similar position at Reagan Airport.
Even after selling some routes to Mr. Johnson, United would dominate many markets in the East, from Charlotte, N.C. -- where US Airways has a hub -- to Boston. At Dulles, one of the nation's fastest-growing airports, United would fly about 62 percent of all passengers, according to 1999 airline traffic data published by Aviation Daily, an industry newsletter. At La Guardia Airport, United would jump over Delta to become the largest carrier with a 32 percent market share. In Baltimore, it would surpass Southwest and fly more than a third of travelers.
United agreed to pay $60 a share for US Airways, a rich premium over the $25.9375 that the stock closed at yesterday. United will not lay off any of its new employees, the company said, and will instead profit from the deal by winning more of the coast-to-coast and overseas business of the passengers who now fly US Airways.
The merger would complete a flirtation that continued on and off in the mid-1990's, much of it overseen by Stephen M. Wolf, the chairman of US Airways, who was United's chief executive in the early 1990's. United executives have long hoped to gain a better foothold in the East, the busiest region in the United States. United backed away from a deal in 1995 after its powerful pilots' union expressed concerns about combining seniority lists.
Executives involved in the negotiations said objections from UAL's pilots might prove difficult again.
The pilots union, which is represented on UAL's board, is likely to announce today that it opposes the transaction.
"The pilots will not be fully on board," one executive said. "Integration of seniority lists is a particularly difficult issue for the unions, and the issue exists now, as it did in 1995."
UAL employees, which own 55 percent of the company, have three representatives on its board, two of which are representatives from the pilots' and machinists' unions. According to the corporate bylaws, approval of this sort of transaction is required from at least one of the two union representatives.
US Airways, the sixth-largest airline in the United States, has struggled in recent years even as the industry has enjoyed its most profitable years ever. With maintenance, labor and computer-related difficulties, the carrier has reported three straight quarterly losses. Airline analysts expect it to return to profitability this year.
Since January 1999, its stock has fallen to its current level from $62.25, leaving the company vulnerable to a takeover.
As a hodgepodge of the original airline and a group of companies it acquired in the 1980's, including Allegheny Air Lines and Piedmont Airlines, US Airways suffers from high costs that come with different fleets and complicated work rules.
US Airways also flies relatively short routes in the crowded Eastern corridor, where flights are often late and planes spend more time waiting on runways than they do elsewhere in the country. And in recent years it began to face more competition from Southwest Airlines, the profitable low-cost carrier that has started flying out of Baltimore, Providence, R.I., and other northeastern cities, driving down many fares.
United's executives now face the difficult task of merging US Airways' fleet and its 45,000-person work force with its own at the same time that is in the midst of increasingly contentious labor talks with its pilots' and machinists' unions. In 1995, United became the nation's largest company in which the employees owned a majority stake after the pilots and machinists agreed to concessions in exchange for stock. That agreement expires this year, and US Airways employees are not expected to receive shares as part of the merger
Wall Street analysts said they expected both investors and regulators to approve it. Other deals could then follow, the analysts said.
"The moral to the story is that the dance commences," Kevin Murphy, an analyst at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, said. "This is the beginning of consolidation in the United States and around the world. It won't stop here."
The biggest American airlines have already paired up in alliances over the last three years, agreeing to combine their frequent-flier programs and, in the case of Continental and Northwest, sell seats on each others' flights. Northwest owns a stake in Continental as part of their agreement, but the two continue to operate separately.
The rationale behind the agreements is similar to United's interest in US Airways: the carriers want to be able to feed passengers from anywhere on to their more lucrative, long-haul flights.
The merger would effectively end the frequent-flier partnership between US Airways and American Airlines because United and American, the world's two largest airlines by revenue, would have little incentive to be partners. It also calls into question United's and Delta's frequent-flier alliance, which United signed largely to gain access to Delta's many passengers on the East Coast. If the US Airways acquisition becomes final, United and Delta will become much more direct rivals.
The deal will also complicate United's long effort to improve its credit to "investment grade" and then be able to decrease the cost it pays to borrow money. One of the two largest credit rating agencies, Standard & Poor's, still ranks United just below investment grade. Now, by acquiring US Airways, United is taking on $7.3 billion of the carrier's debt and buying an airline with a credit rating that has dropped significantly since 1990.
"Among the large airlines, they're the weakest other than T.W.A.," said Philip Baggaley, an analyst at Standard & Poor's.
American and Delta, the two biggest airlines after United, both have a stronger credit rating already, Mr. Baggaley said.
A representative of the companies offered news of the merger yesterday to The New York Times, The Washington Post and The Wall Street Journal, on the condition that reporters not post it on the Internet until after midnight or speak to outsiders about the pending deal.
Early yesterday evening, The Financial Times of London reported the merger on its Web site, citing sources in Chicago, where United has its headquarters. That story quickly led to television and news service reports.

HEADLINE: Hecklers, and Guides Too, Confuse Tour Bus Riders

BYLINE: By NEIL MacFARQUHAR 

 BODY:
The hecklers stepped up to the curb along Eighth Avenue yesterday as a distinctive red double-decker bus from New York Apple Tours rolled past.
"Killers! Killers!" yelled a neatly dressed man in a black T-shirt and black leather jacket, standing on the corner of 58th Street. 
 "You know this finger?" bellowed back the tour guide in his distinctive yellow sweatshirt, making an obscene gesture with his right hand from atop the bus.
Minutes earlier, at 47th Street, about two blocks from where a similar Apple Tours bus driven by a man without the proper license had struck and killed a man on Monday, another pedestrian also accosted the bus.
"They killed a neighbor!" he yelled. "Ask to see his driver's license. It should be posted. Make sure he has a license!"
"Get a job!" an Apple Tours employee retorted.
The dozen or so tourists on board looked somewhat bewildered, unsure why their bus was attracting such ire. Things on the bus were also a little confusing. First a guide said the bus was headed downtown, to Battery Park and the Statue of Liberty ferry. Then a new guide got on, and after the bus was moving announced it was going uptown, through Harlem. Then it went downtown.
The tours, which depart every 20 minutes, offer a singular -- not to say skewed -- view of the city to riders who spend a minimum of $26 per tour and are pressed to spend $40 for the two-day version the minute they step forward.
The guide's presentation was heavy on things like celebrity residents, expensive stores and famous corporate headquarters, along with a light smattering of history.
At Grand Army Plaza, for example, the tour guide pointed out that the statue depicting General Sherman was covered in 22-karat gold. Those who did not know that it was Gen. William Tecumseh Sherman, the Union general, were out of luck. Riders did learn, though, that the singer Janet Jackson has an apartment on the same street and that the Indian restaurant Nirvana atop one building has really good views of Central Park.
At Rockefeller Center, the guide said all the flags around the skating rink represented the members of the United Nations. They are, in fact, the flags of the 50 states.
The guide even worked in opinions about politics. He said New York's sharp drop in crime had more to do with things like panhandlers getting jobs in the strong economy than with anything Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani had done. The exception was the mayor's relationship with the police, he said, adding, "If you watched the news, you would hear about many cases of police brutality."
It took about two hours for the bus to wend its way from Times Square to Battery Park, by which time the heavy exposure to exhaust made for red eyes and a burning throat. The tourists swiveled their heads from side to side but rarely spoke.
Some said they really liked the tours, becauseit was convenient to jump on and off all day. Riders can spend 30 minutes at Rockefeller Center, for example, and then hop on the next bus that comes along for the Empire State Building or the World Trade Center, among other stops.
"You can cover a lot of ground in a short amount of time," said Frank Glasson, a musician from San Diego visiting with his wife, Robyn. It was hit and miss with the guides, though. The Glassons said they had one who stayed silent for long periods and spoke in impenetrable English.

HEADLINE: THE CHINA TRADE WRANGLE;
Four Voices From the Debate in the House on the Trade Bill

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 23

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from the House debate today on the trade bill that would grant permanent normal trading relations with Beijing, as transcribed by The New York Times.
 
NANCY PELOSI, DEMOCRAT OF CALIFORNIA -- We have been told over the last decade that human rights in China would improve if we had unconditional trade benefits for China. Not so. More people are imprisoned for their beliefs in China today than at any time since the Cultural Revolution. 
 We were told that unconditional trade benefits for China would stop China's proliferation of weapons of mass destruction to rogue states. Again, not so. Not only does China continue to proliferate chemical, biological and nuclear technology and the delivery systems for them to rogue states, they have added Libya as one of their customers as recently as this March 2000.
But even if we could ignore the serious repression and the dangerous proliferation of weapons of mass destruction, there is serious reason to reject this proposal on the basis of trade alone. China has never honored any of its trade agreements with the United States, including its agreements for market access over the last 20 years -- over and over again -- agreements on stopping the violation of intellectual property and the piracy continues and stopping prison labor exports from coming into the United States. Indeed, the International Trade Commission said that in their own analysis projecting the China deal will result in the loss of 872,000 American jobs over the next decade.
 
JIM KOLBE, REPUBLICAN OF ARIZONA -- I believe as important as the issues about trade and about human rights and economic advantages are, this issue is not really about China. It's about America. . . . International trade has connected our world's economies as never before, has made our people more dependent upon each other. This interconnectedness gives every nation a giant incentive to keep the peace. It's worked in the past. Just look at how far we've come. And it will work in the future, if the United States continues to lead.
America cannot maintain its leadership role by refusing to trade with the world's largest economy. P.N.T.R. is in our economic self-interest. There can be no doubt about that. But it is also vital for peace and freedom throughout the world. If we choose to abdicate our leadership, consequences are dire. Will America continue to show, through the power of its example, that representative government and freed trade lead to stability, peace and prosperity?
 
FRANK R. WOLF, REPUBLICAN OF VIRGINIA -- I'm a free-trader. I voted for Nafta. I was one of the 30 Republicans that voted to bomb Kosovo. So I'm kind of tired of the argument with regard to isolationist. What about the eight Catholic bishops? And now we know from the C.I.A. briefing there are more. What about the 50 evangelical pastors that are in jail? What about the over 400 Buddhist monks and nuns that have been persecuted and are suffering in that dirty jail in Lhasa? . . .What about the missiles directed against the United States? . . . If this Congress, a Republican Congress, votes to give M.F.N., we will be on the wrong side of the American people and we will be on the wrong side of history.
 
SANDER M. LEVIN, DEMOCRAT OF MICHIGAN -- China's integration into the world trading system inevitably presents both opportunities and challenges. . . . But I want to focus right now on the challenges, because there are challenges as well as opportunities. One of them is the issue of compliance. There is weak rule of law today in China. How are we going to make sure that China complies with its agreements? Mr. Doug Bereuter Republican of Nebraska and I have put together legislation to address this challenge, as well as others. And there are some meaningful compliance provisions in our proposal. One relates to the U.S.T.R. review, an annual review within our own ranks. . . . The second one relates to the potential surges in products from China. . . . The third relates to human rights, including international core labor standards in the rule of law. First of all, in the legislation that Mr. Bereuter and I have proposed and will be before us tomorrow, what we do is to set up a task force, and a meaningful one, to pull together the agencies of the U.S. government to work with Customs to make sure that our law on forced imprisoned labor products from China, that that law is implemented. And then the commission that we have proposed, high-level, at the executive Congressional level, full time, fully staffed, patterned after the Helsinki Commission . . .
Rejecting P.N.T.R. now that it's been combined with the proposals in our legislation would likely be a catalyst not for change, but for chaos in the relationships between the U.S. and China.
